text: Mr Gericke, I would like to thank Mr Gericke for his That was not part of the agenda item 'Approval of the Minutes of the previous sitting'. We will nevertheless put your contribution on the record. The minutes of the meeting of 26 November have been approved.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the EU-Turkey Summit (2015/3004 (RSP)."

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you first of all for inviting the Presidency of the Council to take part in this debate on cooperation with Turkey and in particular on the outcome of the summit which took place on Sunday.  The Presidency welcomes the results of this summit, which was organised at the initiative of the President of the European Council and which you have attended throughout its duration, Mr President. The Commission's first Vice-President, Mr Timmermans, who negotiated the action plan with the Turkish authorities, should also be thanked and congratulated for his commitment.  This summit meeting was fully timely, because it was able to address issues of vital to the security of the Union. Indeed, our relations with Turkey, particularly in the current context, are of considerable importance, both on the issues of migration and on the wider framework of our relations. We share many common interests with Turkey and our cooperation is indispensable in the face of the three major crises affecting us and affecting Turkey. First, the war in Syria and the absolute need to find a political solution to this particularly deadly and destabilizing conflict. Secondly, the problem of refugees, which is directly linked to this conflict, and finally terrorism, which has struck in Paris, but which has also struck in Turkey and elsewhere and which must be fought relentlessly. The summit brought concrete results to the point of confirmation of the need for increased cooperation and regular dialogue. The revitalization of our relations, the liberalisation of the visa regime, readmission rules, and humanitarian and financial aid for the 2 million refugees in Syria are precisely concrete results. It must also be said that everything we have concluded with Turkey must nevertheless encourage us to continue what we are doing within the European Union. All measures concerning better surveillance of our borders, better control of our external borders, relocation policies, the various other approaches to borders must of course be pursued, so we must implement everything that has been decided and everything that still needs to be decided must be decided quickly.  You understand, Mr President, that it is not now up to the Presidency to present in detail the outcome of the summit. It will be more appropriate for the Vice-President, first vice-president of the Commission, to give you his assessment of this meeting.  However, as the summit's final declaration notes, all elements approved on Sunday will have to progress in parallel and be carefully evaluated. This also applies to the accession process for which all the conditions applicable to all candidates are obviously also applicable to Turkey.  And the Council will take special care to ensure that the measures adopted last Sunday are implemented in their entirety and in solidarity. And of course Parliament will be fully informed of the follow-up of these decisions.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, President Jean-Claude Juncker has asked me to debrief you on his behalf since I was also at the summit. By the way, President Schulz, you yourself were at the summit. You intervened and you were there for the whole duration of the summit, so Parliament was very well represented and was an integral part of our decision-making. I hope President Schulz will share Jean-Claude Juncker’s view and my view that this summit was fruitful and opened a new chapter in the EU’s partnership with Turkey. Since April, the EU has held four meetings at Heads of State and Government level to discuss the migration crisis. At each of these meetings we said it was necessary to engage with Turkey – and this is what we did on Sunday. It is clear that we need to cooperate to secure our borders, jointly to bring order into migratory flows, and to stem irregular migration. But the focus of the summit went far beyond the current refugee crisis. Turkey is a strategic partner for Europe in many areas: trade, the economy, foreign policy, energy and customs. At the summit, we reached agreement on how to move forward in all key areas of our cooperation. We agreed on the need for a structured, frequent and more dynamic high-level dialogue. We decided to have summits twice a year to discuss mutual relations and international issues. We hope that the meeting created a new partnership both on refugee-related matters and beyond. To name one example, the recent and atrocious attacks in Paris and Ankara – including a bomb again last night – showed how Europe and Turkey are confronted by the same security threats, and they reinforced our resolve to step up counter-terrorism cooperation, which should be a strong focus of this dialogue. This new chapter of our relationship, and now our partnership, will not lead to a situation in which we forget the remaining divergences and differences we may have with Turkey – on human rights and freedom of the press. All of these will be matters to which we will come back again and again. We need to work with Turkey in order to narrow the gap between our positions. The proof of the pudding is in the eating. The Commission is now working to ensure that implementation is swift, effective and immediate. The Commission will prepare a report on the state of play for the 15 December European Council. To go more specifically into what was agreed: firstly, re-energising the EU-Turkey relationship must also mean putting new energy into the ongoing accession negotiations. The summit declaration jointly welcomes the decision to hold the intergovernmental conference on 14 December for the opening of Chapter 17 on economic and monetary union. In a letter sent by President Juncker to Prime Minister Davutoğlu, the Commission reiterated its commitment to complete the preparatory work for the opening, in the first quarter of 2016, of Chapters 15, on energy; 23, on judiciary and fundamental rights; 24, on justice, freedom and security; 26, on education and culture; and 31, on foreign, security and defence policy. Secondly, Turkey has committed to accelerating the fulfilment of the visa liberalisation benchmarks, and we welcome that. The Commission will assist Turkey in this endeavour, and strive to achieve visa liberalisation for Turkish citizens in the Schengen area by October 2016, provided, of course, that all requirements have been met by then. We want to accelerate the process but we do not want to change the requirements. They will remain firm and they need to be applied in full. By the way, Turkey did not ask us to relax the requirements. Progress needs to be made on the management of borders, asylum and migration, quality of travel documents and respect for minorities’ rights. Moreover, the visa liberalisation process can only go hand in hand with substantial progress on the EU-Turkey readmission agreement, notably on the obligation to take back third-country nationals. The date for full implementation of the readmission agreement has been considerably brought forward, to June 2016, from the initially proposed date of October 2017. Thirdly, we agreed on addressing the refugee crisis together. We agreed to activate the joint action plan that was agreed ad referenda on 15 October and welcomed by Heads of State and Government of the EU’s 28 Member States at the European Council held the same day. This is a joint action plan to step up cooperation on migration management in a coordinated effort to tackle the refugee crisis. It identifies a series of actions for both the European Union and the Republic of Turkey. The aim is twofold: this is about confronting common challenges in a concerted manner and supplementing Turkey’s efforts in managing the large number of people in need of international protection in the country. On Sunday, Turkey committed to implementing immediately the elements agreed on in the action plan, notably immediate action to stem the flow of irregular migrants to the EU and to improve the socio-economic situation of Syrians under temporary protection in Turkey. Both sides reaffirmed their shared commitment to step up the fight against smugglers. The EU has committed to providing immediate and ongoing humanitarian assistance in Turkey, including through its overall financial support. The Commission has put forward its decision: the Turkey Refugee Facility was adopted last week. On Sunday there was consensus among leaders that the EU is committed to providing an initial EUR 3 billion of additional resources. The need for, and nature of, this funding will be reviewed in the light of the developing situation. The details will be worked out with the EU Member States by the next European Council. However, let me be crystal clear about the destination for these funds: this is not money for Turkey – it is money to provide help to refugees in Turkey. This is money to provide for medical care for Syrians, for schooling, and for better living conditions for Syrian refugees in Turkey. I hope this House will not question the importance of burden-sharing, not only within the EU but also with all our neighbours. We have put in place several instruments for that: the Syrian Trust Fund, the African Trust Fund and the Turkey Refugee Facility. Let me finish on the question of resettlement. I have repeatedly stressed, including before you, that you take a lot of human misery out of the equation if you have resettlement. You take the criminal networks out of the equation – with all the risks that people take to come to Europe – and you introduce fair burden sharing by the international community. And, by the way, you can identify precisely who you invite to come to Europe. Resettlement is part of the overall partnership with Turkey set out on Sunday. It is explicitly referred to under Point 6 of the summit declaration. The next steps on resettlement were discussed on the margins of the summit. The Commission will prepare a framework for such a voluntary scheme by 15 December. I want to repeat what President Juncker has said: this will be an open and voluntary process. Those Member States willing to join this common undertaking will tell us – yes or no – whether they would like to be part of this endeavour, which the Commission deems very necessary.

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It is good that the summit took place, it was a positive sign. It is good that he has achieved a result. I would like to thank the Commission – Frans Timmermans, you – for the work that is involved in achieving results. But let us also be honest: the summit took place mainly because we have a major refugee issue on the doorstep via the Balkan route, which we must resolve together.  Let us also be honest: the problems are so great because a Member State of the European Union, namely Greece, does not implement the Schengen standards at its external Schengen border. If we were to use all the police and border guards that we are now using to re-establish border security within Europe – between Germany and France, between Bavaria and Austria, between Sweden and Denmark – if we were all using them all to secure the 190-kilometre-long Greek-Turkish border together, then Europe would be better served than what we are unfortunately experiencing in the European Union at the moment. That is why we must be honest that we also have to carry out our tasks internally, namely to secure our borders properly. The points that have been offered to Turkey are far-reaching and there will also be a number of questions in my group. For example, the full liberalisation of visas will lead to debates. We already have the problems of overstayers with other countries – people who enter without a visa and then no longer comply with their obligation to leave. In any case, it will be necessary for us in Europe to think about an entry-exit system, in order to at least document who remains in Europe as an overstayer and who does not.  In our view, the issue of negotiating chapters is an opportunity to hold talks. We support this, but it is clear to us that all the talks are open to results, because we believe in a privileged partnership with Turkey.  Finally, on the EUR 3 billion, the EU is delivering, the Commission is proposing that Parliament is prepared to put the EUR 500 million on the table. And I hope that the Member States will finally fulfil their obligations. When we talk about money, I would like to point out that other countries in the region are also doing a great deal. We are talking a lot now about Turkey, but also Lebanon, Jordan, many in this region are doing enormous work, and I hope that a wave of refugees does not have to arise before the Member States and before we Europeans build up so much partnership with these states that we also provide enormous support to these countries. Last but not least, I would like to make it clear that we support the Commission's approach of finding pragmatic solutions now, on the one hand, but also addressing the critical points in relation to Turkey on the other. In the progress report, this was done by the Commission: the issues of freedom of the press, rights and respect for human rights in Turkey were also clearly addressed by us Europeans in relation to Turkey. Thank you for that clarity. Ladies and gentlemen, it was good that this summit took place. We will now move forward step by step in implementation and we want to resolve the outstanding issues constructively in the coming weeks.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), "blue card" question. Mr President, I note that you are very willing to accuse Greece of 'allegedly' not complying with its obligations. Have you thought about the responsibilities that your own country has, not only in creating this problem, but also in dealing with it? Have you thought that you, who are supposed to be able to deal with the situation, have just faced the first reaction of the people you have closed your borders? Have you considered the responsibilities you have in supporting Turkey, when you are not asking Turkey, which is promoting illegal immigrants in Greece in waves, to keep them there, when you are not asking for checkpoints to be set up there, so that migrants are checked there and do not come to Greece and the rest of Europe?

name: Manfred Weber (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Unlike my colleague, I am not speaking primarily as a national Member, but as the leader of a group. On my group's part, I can claim that we are trying to strike a balance between solidarity and state action in the protection of external borders. I would like to point out that another country in the EU even has state territory on African land, namely Spain, which has been able to secure the corresponding European external border in Ceuta for years. Technical measures are also necessary for this. It is true in the debate that without technical measures it will not be possible to secure Europe's external borders. What Spain is doing in Ceuta should also be achieved by Greece in Turkey.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the agreement with Turkey is a chance for everyone, but it is certainly not a blank cheque. We Socialists and Democrats have not changed our position, Turkey's future will be in the European Union for us, so it is good that negotiations are resumed and that we are beginning to discuss visa liberalisation seriously.  Turkey needs Europe, because the link with the European Union is the levee, for Turkey, to avoid authoritarian temptations and a wear and tear of democracy, and we too need Turkey because Ankara is a force for stability and without the cooperation of our Turkish friends it will not be possible to manage the refugee crisis.  We therefore support the efforts made by the Commission and appreciate the valuable work done in particular by Vice-President Timmermans, but reaching out to Turkey does not mean giving Turkey a blank cheque, let alone underestimating the drift we are unfortunately witnessing. I want to say this very sincerely, I am a little concerned – indeed, very concerned – about the squeeze on the freedom of fundamental freedoms that we seem to be witnessing in Turkey. Attacks on minorities, primarily kurdish minorities, are not acceptable. And the concentration of power in the hands of one individual also hurts democracy. We will also ensure that the funding provided, as Timmermans rightly said, actually goes to refugees. Maximum support, therefore, the Commission, but this agreement has not turned into a kind of forced and forced marriage, the expiry of which is already defined.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), "blue card" question. – Mr Pittella, you have described Turkey as a 'pole of stability', and you know that, even before the ink of the agreement dried up at the European Council, where all the countries unanimously decided to support the refugee crisis, Turkey and, within these countries, Both Greece and Cyprus, Turkey itself, leaving the European Council, sent its planes back into the airspace of both Cyprus and Greece. , with hundreds and thousands of such violations a year, when at the same time Turkey complains that its own airspace has been 'allegedly' violated, while the Russian plane fighting terrorism has been wrongly shot down. You are talking about a 'pole of stability', and I would like to know your position on this, if for Turkey, which essentially respects nothing in the European Union, it would be fair, both European and ethically correct, to open any chapter when Turkey does not recognise a Member State of the European Union and violates every principle of law in Cyprus, and tell me what the rest of us would do. , ladies and gentlemen, even if a colleague, whose country was not recognised by Turkey, would proceed to consent to the opening of funds ... (The President interrupts the speaker).

name: Gianni Pittella (S&D)
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I was talking about Turkey's usefulness for stability because, as we all know, a substantial part of the refugee crisis cannot be resolved only with Turkey's cooperation, we must be realistic. Secondly, we want to correct Turkey's shortcomings – which I admit are there and there are many of them. So we must increase the level of confrontation, opening the chapters does not mean giving Turkey a winning game, it does mean putting Turkey with its back to the wall, that is to say, checking whether we can really move forward in terms of human rights, the solution of the Cyprus question, which is also essential to us.  I think that when we want to solve the problems, it is useful to discuss and discuss and discuss with our interlocutors, that is the meaning of our initiative.

name: Syed Kamall
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, in this crisis we are lurching from one day to the next, grasping at straws, not really getting to grips with the fundamental issues. Yes, it is good to have a summit with Turkey to discuss cooperation, and we welcome that, but there is a big difference between cooperating with Turkey and asking them to clear up our mess.  We feel under a humanitarian and moral obligation to help refugees from Syria who settle in neighbouring countries, and whatever we do will cost money, but we also need to be clear about the signal that we are going to send to those who want to come to the EU, whether they are coming as refugees or coming for economic reasons. So instead, the leader of a large Member State sends a signal that the EU is open to everyone, whether or not they are refugees, and then, when other EU countries struggle and erect borders between each other, EU leaders ask Turkey to play host instead on top of the millions that they already host.  This is unlikely to offer a long-term solution to the crisis and it will do nothing to stem the flows from the Balkan States. Yes, Turkey is a major important NATO ally of ours, but as Turkey’s ally, let us be more honest with them. Let us not pretend that EU membership is on the horizon. There are far too many people in the EU who will never accept Turkey for reasons including: pure prejudice against Turks and their faith; concerns over human rights; concerns over freedom of movement; concerns over the number of votes that they would have in Council and in Parliament; and concerns over EU borders being extended to Iraq, Iran and Syria.  So let us be clear to the Turks about what that relationship is, but let us also be clear to our voters what EU countries get in return for signing a visa-free agreement, and what we get in return for the EUR 3 billion that Turkey is demanding. And let us finally get to grips with some of the basics: a thorough registration process; a proper returns and readmissions agreement with countries in exchange for our aid; and effective external border controls. Let us work together to build long-term solutions, not offer short-term promises that will never be fulfilled. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL)
text: Blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, you spoke of Turkey as an ally of the European Union, as a NATO member. I would like to ask what value the daily slaughter that the Erdogan Government is carrying out against the Kurdish people, if this is being assessed by this European Parliament. There has been talk earlier of not giving Turkey a blank cheque, and I believe that we should perhaps trouble the fact that money is being given to outsource the borders of the European Union to a government that is guilty on a daily basis of massacring a people.

name: Syed Kamall (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I want to continue where Mr Kamal ended. Cooperation with Turkey – yes; outsourcing our problems – no. And let us be honest: the impression that we have is the opposite. A visa-free regime, EUR 3 billion, and speeding up the accession negotiations in return for some Turkish cooperation in helping to manage the refugee crisis. I have to tell you, Mr President, that it is shameful that nothing was said about human rights in Turkey, freedom of the press in Turkey, or the state of democracy in Turkey in the written conclusions. That is the failure of this summit, in my opinion. Let us be honest, the situation in Turkey is becoming worse and worse. I think there is no other country worldwide where there are more journalists in prison than in Turkey at the moment. I have nothing against the search for better cooperation with Turkey to manage the refugee crisis, but at least have the honesty and the courage to talk about the problems in Turkey. Do not just say ‘OK, we shall not talk about them anymore in the conclusions’. It was only at the end, in the press conference, that Mr Tusk said three or four words about it, not in the written conclusions.  That brings me to the key point. Not outsourcing our problems, but solving our problems means that we have to fix our external borders, our European border and coastguard. What I see is that we are not capable of doing so. Greece, especially, is saying they cannot participate, because Greece is the only country for the moment blocking a decision in the Council that has to be taken in a few weeks in December. It is blocking it because it is a question of sovereignty. It is not allowed for foreigners to come to help us to protect our borders. Well maybe we could invite Mr Tsipras a second time to this Parliament, not to talk about the economy, and not to talk about this problem, but to talk about his lack of will for European solutions to the problems that we are facing at the moment.  I was not shocked when, this morning, I read that some countries want to push Greece out of Schengen. Well, the external border of Greece is not a Greek border: it is a European border. It is not a German border, a Belgian border, or a French border, and that is the key. That is what you have to achieve now, with or without Mr Tsipras. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr Cipras is your friend. "He bragged about it. "Not mine. However, I wanted to ask you one thing, do you realise that Greece has been exposed to the mafia of illegal people smuggling for many months, that there has been an incredible increase in people smuggling from Turkey, and we are doing nothing. The previous summit with Turkey did not address this problem at all, the previous talks on Turkey did not concern the fight against illegal immigration at all. This is a problem, not that individual countries are defending themselves against it.

name: Guy Verhofstadt (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Very briefly, it is precisely to tackle human trafficking, to tackle these criminal gangs and to help the Greek Government that we want this European border guard and coastguard. The fundamental problem that we have created is to start with Schengen and not to have a common border system. That cannot work. If you have a common area with free mobility of people and travel, then you also need to have a common border guard and coastguard. The best way to tackle these criminal gangs is to start with a European instrument.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, first of all, I would like to say something to Mr Verhofstadt: Belgium has no problems at all and has nevertheless become a centre for trafficking criminals. Greece has countless problems, which also stem from decisions of the European Union, and I think it needs more support than a complaint to the European Parliament. I understand, first of all, that the main issue of the agreement with Turkey was the management of refugee flows by that country. However, the European Union has an obligation to underline how the suffering of the peoples of the region began when the United States and Member States of the European Union decided how to teach and export democracy. When we were talking about an upcoming 'Arab winter', some people, including in this Chamber, cultivated the illusion of the 'Arab Spring'. The Commission must closely monitor the management of billions towards Turkey. There are thousands of refugees living in model facilities, but there are many thousands more living under truly miserable conditions. Today, in fact, there is a complaint that Turkey, a few 24 hours after the agreement, has arrested 1,200 refugees and is trying to return them where? back to Syria! The Commission must react immediately. The agreement avoids a word about the lame democracy in Turkey, while referring to the opening of funds. Cyprus is ready - I say this for the sake of knowledge - to assist in this direction if Turkey shows that it is also ready to support a solution in Cyprus, which will create conditions for genuine Cypriot independence, and this is achieved if it is determined by the solution that the future is in the hands of the Cypriots alone, based on the rules of the European Union and the security provided by our presence within the Union. The Cypriots of the Federal State have no need for a foreign guarantee to comply with the rules of the solution. I stress this, because if we are close to a solution, after many decades, the opportunity must not be missed because Turkey believes that it should hold the role of guarantor or supervisor of the operation of a Member State.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. My group has always worked to ensure that the European Union negotiates systematically and consistently with Turkey. We have never had any doubt that the European Union needs Turkey and that it is the other way round. I have to tell you that I found it a sad experience in the debate on the future of Turkey and the European Union that it was only when tens of thousands of refugees from Turkey had migrated to the centre of the European Union that the leaders of the European Union remembered that Turkey was really needed. There have been much better times with Turkey to re-engage in visa liberalisation and negotiations. We think it is good that something is being blocked, but we think that so far the leaders of the European institutions and also the Council are not signalling enough awareness of the difficulty of achieving what we want to achieve with Turkey today. We have heard a great deal about what is to be achieved for the refugees, that better accommodation, prospects for children and prospects for employment should be created. Tell me how you really want to guarantee this to the Turkish Government today. I am very suspicious of that so far. In fact, I see that the new possible agreement in Turkey is rather interpreted as being oriented towards foreclosure, that one is even prepared to prevent refugees from leaving, and even to go so far as to detain them. If that is the case, it will indeed be a new step by the European Union – away from its own values and also away from international law. The first news of this kind came from Turkey in the last few days. Ladies and gentlemen! I believe that we need to talk about human rights much more aggressively with Turkey. In fact, the tightening up in Turkey must not be treated under 'remote running'. The assassination of the lawyer Tahir Eli just before the start of the summit, the arrest of the journalist Can Dündar, whom many of us know personally, were real provocations before this summit. I want the European Union to actively seek a better relationship with Turkey, but I do not believe that Turkey can be a good, reliable partner for refugee matters or also for Syria if we simply ignore the internal development in Turkey. The democrats in Turkey would, I think, just be shocked by something like this. Ladies and gentlemen, I have here a list, a kind of memory support: the journalists who have been put under pressure. I am now giving the list to the Council and the Commission and I hope that you will ensure that this list is made in the near future .... (The President interrupted the speaker) (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Listening to your speech, I note that you are interested in closer cooperation but you still have great reservations about the Turkish Government. Thank goodness – I am glad you do. I was wondering whether, in your mind, this closer cooperation will eventually lead to Turkish membership of the EU and, if so, whether you feel the same as me that, whenever I have been to Turkey, almost everyone I speak to says that they want to move to the EU, and that this would lead to a migration situation posing an even greater problem than we have ever faced before. Do you agree that it would be a dangerous folly at the moment even to consider Turkey’s membership of the EU any time in our lifetime?

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I am in favour of the European Union behaving in a faithful manner and of complying with what it has promised Turkey. And that means conducting serious and systematic negotiations. It is good that this is now being tackled again!  When and how we talk about membership of the European Union is highly controversial even in Turkey. But the negotiations, which are wanted by all sides, must also be done by the European Union, which it promised back in 2004.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I have seen quite a lot of policy failures in my long years here: the introduction of a currency that has impoverished the Mediterranean; I have seen the idealised Schengen area lead to the free movement of Kalashnikovs; and every single week and month we see the attempt to create a single state of Europe, which of course the European peoples do not want. But the EU’s common asylum policy is the lowest ebb for policy yet. Chancellor Merkel took the cork out of a champagne bottle and said anyone could come, and now you are trying to put the cork back in and realising it is not possible. So you have turned to somebody else to sort out your own problem. So let’s talk Turkey. They have taken your weakness, and they have now decided they are going to blackmail you. Not only do they want EUR 3 billion from you this year, they are going to want EUR 3 billion from you every single year. And in return they have given absolutely no guarantees whatsoever that they will stop people from coming, or indeed take people back. And they have managed to persuade you, whatever the Commissioner says, into offering them, by October next year, visa-free access for 75 million people, whose average GDP income is half that of the poorest EU Member State. I guess what you are doing is this: you are saying the way we will stop illegal immigration is to make it all legal immigration, and if that does not take the biscuit, now you are going to fast-track Turkey to be an EU Member State. So let us just think about that. A country, 97% of whose land mass is in Asia, apparently you want to join Europe. It is a country that appears to be keener on bombing the Kurds than it is on taking on ISIS. It is a country that has turned a complete blind eye to ISIS fighters travelling through its territory. It is a country where, according to the Pew institute in a poll last week, 8% of those 75 million actively encourage and support the aims of ISIS. It is a country directly and closely linked with buying ISIS oil, and we will finish up bordering Syria, Iraq and Iran. It is mad. It is the most dangerous decision the European Union has yet taken. I am sure the British Prime Minister will be delighted. He has campaigned for this since 2005. To me, without any of the other debates, if there was one single reason why Britain should in this referendum vote to leave the European Union, it is the folly of political integration with Turkey. It is not only stupid: it is damned dangerous. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: A question raised by raising a blue card. – Mr Farage, you have very strongly outlined the downsides that you see in our relationship with Turkey. Can you call me another country that could contribute more effectively to what we are now fighting, namely to bring the refugee crisis under control? And the second question, did you talk just as strongly about this at your home when your country was involved in destroying the countries from which refugees are now fleeing to Europe?

name: Nigel Farage (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Believe you me, I was no supporter of Tony Blair’s endless series of wars, and if I was in a different parliament and not this one, I would vote against the bombing campaign that Mr Cameron wishes to join the Americans and French in, because it has been poorly, badly thought through, with no long-term strategy whatsoever. Look, if you want to deal with a problem that you have caused yourself in life rather than relying on somebody else to do it for you, perhaps it is better to recognise and realise you have made a mistake. And the only solution open to the European Union is to follow the example of the Australians who, from 2008 onwards, had a lot of boats heading towards their country – a lot of boats sinking, a lot of people drowning, many of the similar symptoms and problems – and the Australians said: ‘If you wish to become a refugee or a migrant to Australia, you will not succeed in doing so if you come via this route’. And the boats stopped coming. The EU needs to have the moral courage to stand up and say that, but frankly they have not got the guts.

name: Marcel de Graaff
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – The European elite has taken a knee for the Sultan of Ankara. Turkey will receive EUR 3 billion. 75 million Turks will be allowed to march through Europe visa-free by the end of 2016, and Turkey's accession to the EU is only a matter of time.  Erdoğan wants a new Ottoman empire and the EU will let that happen. Cyprus was only a first step and earlier Erdoğan said: minarets are our bayonets, domes our helmets, mosques our barracks and believers our soldiers. He has said that democracy is not an end, but merely a means, that he is a servant of the sjari'a and that there is no moderate Islam. How clear do you want it?  We must protect Western culture, democracy and freedom, not allow us to be blackmailed, never let us depend on a dictator. Close the internal borders, which is the answer to the flow of migrants and to the Turkish invasion. That is why, Mr President, we must ensure once and for all that Turkey will never, ever, become a member of the EU, in 100 000 years.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, after returning what mr Weber and Mr Verhofstadt have heard in this Chamber about Greece, the European Union, together with these two gentlemen and the rest, is really showing its true face. We want to give money and start the preparatory work for the opening of a number of chapters on the accession route, in a country that cooperates with ISIS, in a country that shoots down a warplane fighting jihadists, under the pretext of violating - listen, listen - 17 seconds of its national airspace, while no one apologizes for its violations against Greece. It deliberately promotes illegal terrorists and drugs in Europe. He enriches him, using the smugglers and slave traders of souls, at the expense of syrian refugees, drowning them at sea, in order to seize, with Germany's blessings, through the supposed search and rescue, Greece's national sovereignty in the Aegean. This policy is not serious, unless we deliberately want to break up the Member States of the Union, alter their social cohesion and start a new disastrous war... (The President interrupts the speaker).

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Madam President, I am pleased to see, in the document adopted on Sunday, that Europe and Turkey are rediscovering the common future and the need to work. I regret that this was only discovered after the crisis so terrible that we have experienced in recent months. I also regret that this meeting was held after the second round of elections held in Turkey; but better late than never, and I welcome the agreement reached.  As for the money to manage the situation of migrants, I believe that we must give this money quickly and not create problems in the creation of this fund. On the other hand, Turkey must show in a very concrete way the commitments it has made. Secondly, with regard to the accession process, I am pleased to learn that the opening of Chapter 17 is going to take place - I think it is a positive step, it was a mistake to postpone so many new chapters - and I believe that then more chapters will have to be opened if there is real progress on the issue of Northern Cyprus: I think it is an important condition. Finally, I do not see why our Greek colleagues are so unhappy that they are being criticised, because Greece's responsibility in the recent crisis is enormous, and I think that in the coming weeks Greece will have to show solidarity with our efforts.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which It was a good result on Sunday, and I would like to thank you once again, Vice-President Timmermans, because you have put a lot of effort and also a great deal of empathy into this work, otherwise such an outcome would not have come out. Now I admit that it is not the very best time for such an agreement, after what we have seen in recent months on television and in the news. Nevertheless, it is right, and it is also right, to open Chapter 17, but I would very much ask you – not only in Turkey or with Turkey – to open Chapters 23 and 24 as soon as possible, because when we talk about freedom and justice, we have the points that are most necessary to be discussed. My final point is that I very much hope that you will not be let down again by the Member States, because we all know that 500 million is not yet three billion. And I think it is a good opportunity, especially for those who do not want to take in refugees, to show that they are still in solidarity.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (
text: GUE/NGL). – Mr Weber and Mr Verhofstadt, stop, at last, insulting, distorting and attacking Greece and the Greek people in order to serve political purposes. My country is taking a heavy burden on refugees, because it is at European borders and because several European countries refuse to take their fair share. My country says 'yes' to European cooperation to guard Europe's external borders and to defend the Schengen Treaty, without violating the rules of national sovereignty, as each Member State says, and Mr Verhofstadt, who was also a former Prime Minister of Belgium, let us explain how Belgium, which has no borders with such countries, has become a centre of action for terrorists. If you want results, put the brakes on the smuggling mafia from Turkey to Greece, organise the direct transfer of refugees from Turkey to all European countries, proportionally, create a land-based European corridor. The common framework between the European Union and Turkey, I shall finish, Madam President, is a positive step, but it is not a wish list and strong control mechanisms must be set up. Turkey will only get the 3 billion if it fully implements all its commitments... (The President interrupts the speaker). (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: Blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, just to say to my colleague that he rightly spoke about Europe's control over Turkey and another concept that I have not heard in this House: reciprocity. I would like to remind you, I saw for myself what Turkey is doing in Cyprus with the devastation of the Orthodox churches. We must also talk about this, as well as the various problems that are there in relations between Europe and Turkey.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" answer. – I agree with the remark, it wasn't a question. What I want to point out, once again, is that Europe, if it wants to guard European borders and the terms of the Schengen Treaty, must give additional technical assistance and organisational assistance and money, and to Greece, which is putting a heavy burden on refugees, with humanity and solidarity, because that is where History and Geography put us. We are not fortunate enough to be either the Netherlands or Luxembourg.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr First Vice-President of the European Commission, I would like to express our thanks to you from the outset for the way you have negotiated in such a difficult context. Our group has repeatedly asked the Commission and the Council for aid for both Turkey and Lebanon and Jordan in order to cope with the influx of refugees. Let us be realistic: these countries face far greater difficulties than the European Union is experiencing. This agreement is good, even if it comes too late or quite late: both in the management of the refugee crisis and in our anti-terrorist strategy, both in the fight against Daesh and in the attempt to stabilise Syria, we need Turkey. We can't spare a partner like that. Without hesitation, I tell you that the process of further enlargement with Turkey must be advanced and new chapters must be opened, apart from Chapter 17, I believe that Chapters 23 and 24 are essential to guarantee fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her What is going on here is truly a great political smear comedy. In this burlesque political theatre, one person is particularly negative, namely Mr Weber from the EPP, who is not here at the time and who wants to blame the whole problem on the Greeks. One can only remind him that the main person responsible for the whole disaster was the German Chancellor Merkel, with the help – unfortunately I have to say this as an Austrian – of the Austrian Chancellor Faymann, who initiated this mass movement in the first place. It is unfair to blame others after this disaster. On the one hand. Secondly, to make a shabby deal with the Turks here, in addition to pre-accession aid to the European Union, which already amounts to one billion, has totalled five billion, and now to fill another three billion a year here in Istanbul, is certainly something that is indisputable. This Turkey can certainly never become a member of a European Community!

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, every other single MEP: if they miss their time, they miss their … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: –  Sir, I was in the chamber, but not on my seat.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Congressman, I'm sorry. Don't shout or stand up. I told you what the source of the problem was. I went over the list, so I called the congressman in the wrong order. You have no right to shout like that, I apologized for it. You probably didn't pay attention to him, and Mr. Brok will follow in the congressman's second place, Congressman Vilimsky. I mean, it's right that I just gave him the floor. Although this was not a clumsy comment, and I would not have any reason to explain this to you, but in order not to shout next time and not to do so, that is why I thought it was important.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you very much! One sentence to my Austrian predecessor: by arguing that more refugees should come to Austria, because only with the help of Turkey can the flow of refugees be limited. He is therefore in favour of more refugees to Austria. I wanted to say the following main points: I would like to thank the Commission and the Council for the summit. Because there is a chance to get order in the process, to reduce the numbers. If Turkey has taken in 2.5 million refugees for four years, and Lebanon, with a population of 4 million, 1.4 million refugees, then we have a responsibility to help these countries – because of the refugees and also because of these countries. We have to play our part in this. And if this has the consequence that fewer refugees come in here and that we can provide decent care for these refugees in accordance with the Geneva Convention, that seems to me to be the right way forward. And if, at the same time, we have the opportunity to establish a structure for the control of external borders, to regulate the question of registration sensibly, to carry out on this basis an understandable form of quotaisation in the Member States, which is manageable and controllable, then this seems to me to be a way of removing this pressure. Let me say one last sentence: all this will only apply if we succeed in ending the war there. And ending the war is only possible with Turkey. And opening chapters with Turkey on human rights and the rule of law, I find exciting, because then Turkey really has to show what has happened. I would also like to say that Turkey will not become a member if, in a series of 72 unanimous decisions in the Council that would be necessary for membership, the sixth and seventh decisions are now taken, irrespective of the decision of the parliaments. But i find it exciting to talk about human rights in Turkey. And if that is also linked to having fewer refugees, that seems to me to be a good deal. (The speaker agreed to answer two questions under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. Thank you very much, Madam President, for the opportunity. I am also very happy to ask Mr Brok personally, as he is one of the most experienced foreign policymakers in the European Parliament. I believe that Mr Brok has also seen countless cases where, because of the failures of either party, an agreement did not go as it should have. If, as it happens, the EU does not provide these three billion euros as it promises, and the Turks may say that they will continue to let refugees go – what control or prevention guarantees do you see for this? Thank you very much!

name: Elmar Brok (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – Don't pay money? Then we broke the deal. Moreover, these funds are not paid into a Turkish state budget, but are paid on a project-by-project basis to deal with the refugee crisis there – project by project, step by step, not in one step, if I have understood correctly, Mr Timmermans. And that is why this danger does not exist, but Turkey has an interest in this deal, Turkey has every interest in honouring this deal, otherwise no chapter will be opened and nothing will be done. Incidentally, I would say that we will not be in a position to end the war. For it is only possible to end the war – by stopping oil supplies, by stopping financial traffic in favour of ISIS – if Turkey is in this boat, among others. That is why I think this is a good agreement.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we should talk about a European winter in the future: after the events in Paris, this other dramatic decision to open Europe's doors to Turkey, just when there are signs to the contrary. The accession negotiations had been interrupted for a very clear reason, because Turkey was rightly regarded as an Islamic country and therefore with major problems. It is no longer Islamic, Erdoğan's Turkey, which arrived in Germany in 2008 and declares that assimilation is genocide against humanity, now it is no longer mentioned. We give him the opening of visas, even in the LIBE Committee the attention of Europeans was drawn, he said: but do you know what you are doing? The visas of 75 million very muslim Turks, we have sold off Europe's values, human rights and freedom of the press, we have become deaf to the appeals of journalists and newspaper directors imprisoned on Europe's doorstep. We want to remember these values or we plan to sell them off in the face of the refugee problem. Shame on Europe! Shame, shame, shame!  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Borghezio, the Turkish geostrategic space is part of the Euro-Atlantic space – part of south-eastern Europe somehow – and everything going on in Turkey seems to influence European security and defence to a great extent. Do you not think that we need Turkey for Europe’s security? – because, just like Italy, Turkey is a Mediterranean state, and the security of Europe is greatly influenced by Turkey. We have to cooperate with Turkey.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF)
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, recent events and Turkey's very serious provocation against Russia, with very serious risks to peace and balance in Europe and the world, seem to be the best answer to your question.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, first internally we must do our homework – together we protect the external borders of the European Union as a shared responsibility of all Member States, the fight against trafficking in human beings, a common intelligence agency, common migration rules. Secondly, in foreign policy terms, the question before us is what is better with or without Turkey, we will deal better with this global challenge. Of course, the answer is not only with Turkey and with Lebanon and with Jordan and with African countries we need to work more closely, but we need to say clearly and be honest – the negotiations with Turkey are different from the previous accession negotiations. The negotiations are open and no decision has been taken on Turkey's full membership of the European Union. Such membership is currently impossible. For us, of course, it is important to negotiate with Turkey, to have in the southeast a predictable partner, a neighbor that complies with European legislation, respects its commitments, a neighbor who accepts our legislation. Through the negotiations, we can also support Turkish civil society and Turkish democracy. For all this, the opening and closing of the negotiating chapters should be used. However, we need to keep a close eye on whether our outstretched hand will improve the human rights situation and media freedom. Before we all do everything that is up to us, the millions of people along the Syrian border with Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan stay there and not go to European borders. Every euro invested in this is many times more euras saved from the maintenance of these people if they were in the European Union. We must control, of course, the funds we give for this, together with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. (The Speaker agrees to answer a question asked by raising a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I would like to ask you one point. Namely: while I understand the intensive police cooperation of European countries within Europol and the establishment of Europol, I completely do not understand why a Member of the European People's Party is preaching the idea of setting up a joint intelligence agency. This is not based on the European Treaties. How do you imagine, under the current Treaty provisions, the establishment of an institution that violates the core of national sovereignty?

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – Of course we need to cooperate more in Europe – and a common intelligence service and general command.  You know very well, and you may not know that unfortunately this cooperation of our special services is not going as it should be. Only a few countries exchange information, and for me, addressing global challenges goes through our common efforts, including a common European army, an idea since the 1950s for a common defence community in the European Union, of course not duplicating TOY and our commitments under the Euro-Atlantic Agreement.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is important that there is a deal with Turkey that will make the influx of refugees to Europe manageable. For too long we did not pay enough attention to the efforts made by the Turkish population by hosting 2.02 million refugees, and with this summit it was recognised that only in partnership can this refugee crisis be handled. However, an essential part of the EU-Turkey agreement is missing, which is due to internal divisions among EU Member States: the fact of resettlement. No agreement has been reached on this yet, and I was at least pleased to hear First Vice-President Timmermans also mention this – that there are plans – and let us hope that Member States will commit to this in the next summit. I welcome the reinvigorating of the accession talks. It is a pity that this crisis was needed to convince Member States that a more intensive dialogue between the EU and Turkey is very much in the interests of both. We do, however, have serious concerns about internal developments in Turkey, already mentioned here by colleagues. In order to make this new momentum last, it must be clear to both sides that the accession process is merit-based, with respect for the rule of law and fundamental freedom at its core.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). Madam President, I do not think there is anyone who does not recognise that the refugee crisis is a big problem and that cooperation with Turkey is needed. Cooperation with Turkey is required, but not supported by the European Union and given continuity by privileges in order to do the obvious. Turkey also needs to fulfil its obligations towards refugees. There is no one who questions the suspicious and insidious role played by Turkey, even in creating the refugee crisis. And, really, I wonder: so far Turkey has actually done what it has done for the refugee crisis? What is her role in the region? I still did not understand whether Turkey is really fighting ISIS and terrorism when it is actually fighting the Kurds and shooting down the Russian plane fighting terrorism, even when it is violating the airspace of Member States of the European Union without reacting to the Same European Union! Do we expect Turkey to fulfil obligations towards the European Union when it does not comply with the agreements, not only with Member States of the European Union, but also under the Ankara Protocol, of which the European Union and Turkey are parties? We want to believe that Turkey will try to solve problems. Unfortunately, to date it has been causing problems and all it is doing is asking, without giving anything to the European Union.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D). – While the problem, Mr Timmermans, is the problem of the flow of refugees, we have come here to discuss the opening of funds for Turkey. And I'm talking slowly so I can get all your attention. These funds, for which you propose opening to Erdoğan, are funds that are frozen because Turkey, among other things, violates the principles and values of the European Union and violates, illegally owning a third of the Republic of Cyprus which is a member of the European Union. So, I wonder, would you ever consent to the opening of funds if Turkey illegally held a third of your country's European territory? And, not just about principles and values, are we giving a gift to Erdoğan at a time when he refuses to implement his commitments so far? These are the essential questions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the leadership of the European Union is proving to be inferior to the circumstances, as it constantly succumbs to Turkey's blackmail. A Turkey that is attacking DAES and smuggling oil with the jihadists. A Turkey that organises the slave trade for the transfer of thousands of refugees from Syria to the Aegean islands at a profit of more than twelve billion euros. A Turkey that continues to violate Greece's airspace. Finally, gentlemen of the European Union, you have the wolf guarding the sheep, and not only: you are also giving Ankara three billion euros. Mr Weber, Greece has been inundated with thousands of refugees because Mrs Merkel has invited them to come to Germany. Mr Weber, Greece is a sovereign country and does not accept co-management of its external borders. Mr Weber, make a decision, Greece's borders are Greek and will continue to be protected by The Greeks and not German troops, as you dream, because this has expired historically and irrevocably for seventy years.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Madam President, let's put our hand on our hearts and tell ourselves the truth. This is an emergency treaty. The emergency agreement, primarily because of us, because of the situation in the European Union, because of all that the migrant crisis has brought to the European Union. But I think, regardless of all this, we need to talk, negotiate, negotiate and talk. Of course, we cannot help but see and believe that the Commission sees everything that is happening right now in Turkey, when we talk about human rights, about media freedom. And that's why I'm saying this is an emergency treaty, of course. Out of necessity when it comes to helping refugees and primarily refugees from war-affected areas. The opening of negotiations and Chapters 17 should be accompanied by Chapters 23 and 24.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL). – Ladies and gentlemen, I hear many people applauding the support package to Turkey. It is hypocritical to welcome measures that create camps for millions of unhappy people, just so that we do not assume our historical responsibilities. The European Union of 28 states and 500 million citizens refuses to welcome three million refugees whom some of them have created and shifts responsibility for its deadlocked policy to the host countries. The solidarity you are evangelise is proving to be a farce, because the famous "relationship" of 160,000 refugees has only been applied to 159 people. You are creating a generation of prisoners, because you know that this situation will not be temporary. But are you thinking about what such a gable will cause in Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan? Let me tell you: it will be the matrix of the cultivation of extreme and fanatical ideologies that will simply solve the current problems. Especially when many claim that jihadists are among the stream of refugees. This myopic policy of the European Union will only cause problems and instability in the region.

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, let us be clear: this is a deal in which Turkey is supposed to stop refugees in return for the European Union turning a blind eye on human rights – and this is bad for the refugees who will be detained and pushed back into Syria. But it is also bad for people in Turkey. Those people were really looking to and hoping for EU accession, for EU values, for the Kurds and for journalists – journalists like Can Dündar, who was arrested a couple of days ago in Turkey. So I would like to ask you, Commissioner, as Vice-President of the Commission with responsibility for fundamental rights: what do fundamental rights mean to you in this agreement?

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, the panic that has taken over the European Union, combined with its inability to deal with the problem of the huge influx of illegal immigrants into it, has forced it to deify Turkey and give it everything, wanting controversial aid in return. But we forget that Turkey is the country that is solely responsible for all this influx of illegal immigrants coming to Greece and Europe, we forget that Turkey is blackmailing us in order to achieve its national interests and, I wonder: - What guarantees are we asking Turkey not to deceive us again? - What guarantees do we ask Turkey to be 'okay', let me say, in its obligations towards the European Union? - Do we have the courage to force Turkey to bann the action of illegal traffickers? - Do we have the courage to force Turkey to stop exploiting these unfortunate people to earn some billions? If we don't have that courage we can't do anything at all... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, when I hear Mr De Graaff and some of his colleagues refer to the beauty of European civilisation, the way they do it I am reminded of what Ghandi said when he was asked what he thought about European civilisation. His answer was: ‘it would be a good idea’. Let us not lose track of the reasons for people coming to Europe. They are not coming to Europe because Mrs Merkel invited them, they are coming to Europe because they want their children not to be victims of barrel bombs thrown from Assad’s planes. (Applause) They want to come to Europe because they do not want to be slaughtered by Daesh or al-Nusra in other parts of Syria. They want to come to Europe because after years of an atrocious war, they have nowhere else to go if they want their children to have an education, if they want to have healthcare, if they want a future that every single one of you wants for yourself and your children as well. We are talking about human beings. We are not talking about fortune-seekers invited by Mrs Merkel. Mrs Merkel took responsibility to offer international protection when it was necessary. We would have less trouble in Europe if every single leader of Europe had done the same when it was necessary at the time. (Applause) Now let me insist on some of the push factors, because it is important for the agreement we have reached with Turkey. As I said before, why are some people leaving from Turkey or through Turkey to Europe? Talk to them, try it! These are nice people, educated people; these are people who can tell you a story. They will tell you: ‘I have left because after two years I am finished, all my savings are gone and I am not allowed to work in Turkey’. So what did we do? We agreed with the Turks that they would allow Syrians to start working in Turkey very soon. That is part of what we have discussed. They say: ‘I am leaving because there is no education for my children’. This is exactly what we are going to do: we are going to use the EUR 3 billion to make sure that there are more facilities for education for children where they are now in Turkey. They say: ‘we are leaving because our living conditions are horrible and we do not have access to medical care’. These EUR 3 billion will be used to improve living conditions and to improve medical care. It is not just the right thing to do, it is the smart thing to do, because keeping people there and offering them help there is much cheaper for the European taxpayer and is much cheaper in moral terms, because it takes the smugglers out of the equation. It takes the danger out of the equation for people having to cross the Mediterranean in very difficult conditions. So when we have these agreements on these projects, it is to take away some of the push factors. This, I think, is a smart approach. Visa liberalisation. Why are we on this trajectory with the Turks? Because if we aligned our visa policies, it would be easier for the Turks to act at their external borders when people come from Pakistan, Bangladesh or other countries who do not have the right to international protection and should then be stopped at the borders. Visa liberalisation also means that we can create the right conditions for Turkey to have the right kind of passports: biometric passports. It would make it much easier for us to control our borders. These are positive measures for the European Union. Do not portray everything as though we are on our knees for Turkey and giving things away. Then about the chapters. I really do not understand some here, like Ms Keller, who just now said: ‘we do not want to talk, we have given up on human rights, we accept everything’. Benchmarking Chapter 23 and 24 is the best possible way of engaging Turkey in a debate on human rights. Opening Chapters 23 and 24 is the best possible way of forcing the Turks to account for what they are doing and to try and help them reform the system so that they move away from the mistakes they make today. So do you really think that we will improve the situation in Turkey by turning our backs on the Turks and saying: ‘oh, let it go’? I do not think so. I think this engaging with them will yield results. And yes, of course, we are engaging with them because we need to stem the flow of those coming to Europe who do not have the right to international protection. Of course we are doing that – but it is in our interest to do so, it is in the interests of the refugees to do so and it is in the interest of Turkey to do so. There is no shame in coming to an agreement based on mutual interest.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over.  Next item on the agenda: Commission statement — Decision adopted on the circular economy package Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – The EU-Turkey agreement is a continuation of the flawed European policy to tackle the migrant problem. This agreement is a capitulation to Europe and to European leaders who, by signing it, have acknowledged that they cannot defend their borders on their own. The €3 billion to be made available to Turkey must be invested in refugee camps, where basic needs such as water, food and medical supplies are lacking. Whether this will happen depends entirely on Turkey itself. Why does the EU not require Turkey to open its labour market to refugees and not let their children into schools? Because if this happens and the living conditions of refugees improve, they will not risk their lives fleeing to the EU. It is abundantly clear that this is not in the interest of Turkey, which will continue to cooperate in migrant trafficking to the EU and will continue to support Islamic State.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – If we ask which of the US allies – from France to Israel, from the UK to the Gulf dictatorships – will have fulfilled, over the past few years, the central role in the destabilisation and aggression operation on Syria and its people, Turkey certainly takes a top place. From the outset, Turkey – a member of NATO – has actively ingested itself in the situation in Syria, in a clear disregard for international law. Turkey was used to serve as a base and support the various armed groups – which make up thousands of mercenaries – who have been assigned the achievement of the objective of destroying the Syrian state, plundering its resources and the heritage of its people. A gigantic plunder that, feeding all kinds of trafficking and having in Turkey a receiver, is one of the sources of financing of terrorists supported and armed by imperialism, which now claims to want to fight them. These are aspects that have been heated up in this debate and which the main political groups have understandably sought to avoid. An accomplice silence. The conclusions of the EU-Turkey summit are in line with the EU's foreign and migration policies, which the summit sought to operationalise: reactionary, inhuman, unacceptable.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. – The deal reached between EU Member States and Turkey in a bid to weaken the refugee inflow starkly contrasts in both speed and magnitude with the decision making on the management of the refugee crisis inside the EU. While Member States are dragging their feet on honouring funding pledges to manage the refugee crisis, EUR 3 billion has been promised to Turkey in return for its help on sheltering refugees.  I acknowledge the need for engaging with Turkey to bring peace and stability to our neighbourhood, but we cannot undermine our enlargement policy by trading off commitments on accession negotiations and visa liberalisation against Turkey’s willingness to carry a bigger burden on migration. Especially not if this means remaining silent on the violation of human rights and freedom of speech in the country, and on the way in which the Turkish government appears to be instrumentalising conflicts in the region to settle matters with the Kurds. There is a thin line between engaging with a country in order to encourage it to do the right thing, and simply buying its cooperation while closing one’s eyes to injustice.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: writing - Turkey promised at Sunday's EU summit in Brussels that it would prevent predominantly Syrian emigrants from entering Europe. Turkey will detain illegal economic migrants, place them in detention centres paid for with EU money and gradually return them to their homes. What is important is where the EU wants to take the eur 3 billion it will provide to build infrastructure and provide food and medical assistance for 2.5 million migrants, so that they stay in Turkey and do not move towards Europe. Only €500 million is earmarked for this in the EU budget. The remaining 2.5 billion must be found by the Member States in their budgets. Some European politicians are considering paying these costs from funds designed to develop employment and growth in EU countries, while others have indicated that they may punish countries that have rejected all of Brussels' proposals to redistribute refugees to date. Both proposals are dangerous. They bring not only a slowdown in the development of underdeveloped regions, but also an increase in tensions within the Community. It will be important for the EU to come to solutions in this sensitive area, not by coercion, but by mutual agreement.

name: David McAllister (PPE)
text: Writing. The European Council summit with Turkey was another building block on the way to tackling the refugee crisis at European and international level. As the most important transit country for refugees and migrants, Turkey is the European Union's most important strategic partner in this crisis. The strategic partnership will be further developed through the EU-Turkey Action Plan. The living situation of the more than 2 million refugees in Turkey needs to be improved in concrete terms so that fewer people take the dangerous flight to Europe. That is why the EUR 3 billion of the European Union for aid to refugees in Turkey is a sensible measure. This money does not go to the Turkish Government's account, but is used exclusively to finance refugee projects. Among other things, they are intended to improve the educational opportunities of the approximately 900 000 children who have to be educated in Turkey. My special thanks go to the Commission. It has negotiated in a very short space of time the concise EU-Turkey Action Plan, which paves the way for further progress in tackling the migration crisis.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Refugees do not come to Europe because they have been invited by Germany or Chancellor Merkel, as politicians who call themselves European often claim. Refugees come because they do not want their children to fall victim to daily bombings. Refugees come to Europe not to take away our jobs or to respect our culture, but to make sure their loved ones are not slaughtered by the Islamic State. They come to Europe so that their children can study, if patients can go to the doctor, they want exactly what we want for our children. We are talking about people, not profiteers, whom Germany has invited to Europe.  At sunday's EU summit, the EU and Turkey reached an agreement to use €3 billion to improve the living conditions of refugees. We provide them with education, adequate health care and humane conditions in Turkey. This is not only morally correct, but also the key to solving the refugee crisis.  Unfortunately, today the Hungarian Prime Minister is one of the biggest obstacles to the management of the refugee crisis and the development of a common EU refugee policy. By rejecting the quota system, it threatens the security of Europeans and hungarians, a Europe without borders. We must put an end to the age of selfish special-way policies, and instead we need European solutions and the establishment of a common European border guard.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The EU-Turkey Summit was appropriate in the light of developments both on refugees and terrorism, as well as in the Syrian civil war and their impact on both the EU and Turkey. Turkey is key to all these issues and a solution cannot be found without cooperation between the EU and Turkey. It is good that a joint statement and a migration action plan were agreed at the summit, but it is important that this action plan and the plans that have been put in place are also implemented. The EU must find the means for the Turkish Fund. In order for the flow of refugees to be reduced, the situation in refugee camps needs to be improved, and this can be done by the EU, in particular by making a financial contribution. It is very important to continue accession talks with Turkey with the EU, but enlargement must be kept separate from the context of the refugee crisis. One can't depend on the other. It is necessary to move forward with the opening of chapters and to work towards visa liberalisation in such a way that all conditions are met.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (
text: PPE), in writing. – At the recent EU-Turkey refugee summit, many favourable decisions have been taken on Turkey, although Turkey has so far not proved to be a reliable EU partner on a number of issues. In particular, it does not respect the Migrant Readmission Agreements, which it has signed with the EU and Greece, and it has proven to tolerate the uncontrolled action of criminal human trafficking networks on its territory, with hundreds of thousands of migrants being channelled into Europe via Turkey. At the same time, it continues to create conditions of tension and questioning of international law with continuous violations of the sovereign rights of Greece and Cyprus - EU Member States - while not recognising the Republic of Cyprus. Why is the EU refusing to press Turkey institutionally to set up refugee reception centres on its coast, as part of more commitments by Turkey to manage migration and prevent the loss of life at sea? Let us not forget that the already increased funding that Turkey receives from the EU for this purpose is going to amount to EUR 3 billion. Why do we have to provide Turkey with consideration to do the obvious?

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the Commission statement - Decision adopted on the circular economy package (2015/2927(RSP)).

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, this morning in the Commission we adopted an important package on the circular economy. It is the result of very intensive teamwork and it really is a pleasure to present this package to you today, together with Vice-President Katainen and Commissioner Vella. This is a really innovative way of working in the Commission. We have worked together with more than half of the Commissioners for a year to bring everything together because here, if we want to make this transformation, we need all areas of our activities. And so this novel way of working is something that is also the way forward: the way the Commission should be working in the future. In the week that COP21 in Paris has started, this is, I think, a very timely proposal. Action on the circular economy ties in closely with our energy and climate policies. More and more evidence shows the wider benefits of the circular economy, including in lowering carbon dioxide emissions. There are many good reasons for moving away from our linear economic model, which is extremely resource-intensive.
