In a world where the population rises every day, with huge demands placed on land, water, food, feed, raw materials and energy, we cannot rely further on a ‘take, make, use and throw away’ approach. The circular economy, as an agenda for change, is not only an environmental necessity, it is the only model that makes sense in the long term for our European economy. It makes economic sense to use natural resources in a smarter way. Europe cannot compete on wage costs, although sometimes we try – and we lose. And Europe is not graced with the same natural resources as other parts of the world: they are finite in Europe, and when they are available, they are very expensive. The future is in providing products that are used and reused and do not deplete the earth’s natural resources. It will also allow us to continue as a market leader for green technologies. So the question is not whether we want to set Europe on a circular path of growth. It is rather how we, at our level, help our businesses, citizens and Member States to get where they want to be, where they need to be, and to get there more quickly and in better shape. With the package we are proposing today, we want to give a concrete push to the circular economy and accelerate the transition. What we are presenting is an ambitious and comprehensive EU framework that Europe needs to take action and make real progress towards the circular economy. It is an all-encompassing approach of smart regulation, market- based instruments, innovation and incentives. It is a clear signal to economic operators that we are simplifying the EU single market in this area to create new business opportunities and to boost the market for secondary raw materials. We want to be more ambitious than in the past by going beyond waste, with measures covering the full life-cycle of products, from the design of a product and production processes – and of better-informed consumption choices – to modern waste management. We want to back this up with our financial instruments and funds. Our action plan and revised waste proposals adopted today are mutually supportive measures that will contribute to making real progress on the ground. While Jyrki will shortly go into more detail on the wide range of actions we propose, let me say a word about our waste management proposals. Continuously advancing on waste management remains a priority. With targets, and through incentives and support for recycling and reuse, we want to ensure that resources stay within the circle and are available for future use. Waste is not managed as well as it could be. From the total waste production in the EU, only a limited share, 36%, was effectively recycled. The largest share, 37%, was simply sent for disposal, whether in landfills or on the land. Losing this material means that significant growth and competitiveness potential is not being exploited. To fundamentally improve waste management practices we need EU waste legislation. The legislative package we have adopted today will provide a very clear and stable policy framework allowing public and private actors across the EU to develop long-term investment strategies focusing on prevention, reuse and recycling, and avoiding overcapacity in incineration. Is it ambitious? Well, let me say that this is most likely the world’s most ambitious legislation and probably contains the strictest recycling and land-filling targets on earth. Our proposal will also reduce the administrative burden for SMEs and public administrations by improving definitions and simplifying reporting requirements. While reflecting a high level of ambition, our proposals also take due account of the different realities and recycling performance levels across the EU. Differences today are huge, but our objective is to achieve gradual convergence to best-practice levels. Efforts to close today’s implementation gaps will be supported by the EU Cohesion Policy, with EUR 5.5 billion already available in the run-up to 2020. Food waste is a particular priority area where we want rapid change. It is economically, socially and, quite simply, morally unacceptable that so much edible food is wasted every year in Europe. In September we adopted the UN Sustainability Development Goals, including a target to halve food waste by 2030 at the retail and consumer level, and to reduce food losses along production and supply chains. The EU and its Member States are committed to delivering on this target. With that aim, we will develop a reliable method to quantify and understand food waste in order to act on it efficiently. We will also work hand-in-hand with Member States and stakeholders on a dedicated platform to support the achievement of our goal. If I may, I would now like to give the floor to Vice-President Katainen.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, it is a very big honour to be here to discuss with you the very significant package the Commission has proposed. This is part of the European Investment Package. The circular economy is a phenomenon in the global market economy which one can compare to globalisation, which we have witnessed over the last two decades. So it is not just a side-effect or a secondary element of the market economy; instead it is a global mega-trend and will be even more so in the years to come. The package which we have proposed is more ambitious than the previous legislative package on waste. Now we are completing the circle. Now we can really talk about the Circular Economy Package. This package is a competitive package and it is also a single market package. How ambitious it is can be measured partially also by the speed with which the co-legislators are dealing with the proposals that the Commissioner is bringing forward. This is about empowering consumers and encouraging businesses to move from an inefficient and unsustainable linear economy to a circular market economy. The package is the beginning of the story. It will not transform the European economy from the current linear model in one go, overnight, to a circular economy. But at least, at the moment, with this package we can create a good start and a good basis and a good structure to further develop circular economy initiatives. The action plan will complement the two initial legislative proposals concerning waste. In the action plan there are proposals ranging from product design to creating an internal market to secondary raw materials, and further support for the industrial symbiosis by recognising the value of by-products. A key objective here is to work on further deepening the EU single market, which is also the most important part of the investment plan for the EU. This matters because there are barriers that make it difficult for businesses to optimise the resources used. That is why creating a market for secondary raw materials and ensuring a reliable quality standard is crucial. It is fundamentally about broadening our internal market. The ecodesign framework is a tool to strengthen development where products are easier to repair, dismantle and recycle. We will broaden the scope of ecodesign from energy efficiency to resource efficiency. Ecodesign is an important tool, which will empower consumers and create a level playing field for businesses. We are also announcing a specific strategy on plastics – an important and complex issue. Today only 25% of plastic waste is recycled, whereas half goes to landfills, with economic and environmental consequences. Large quantities of those plastics end up in the oceans, creating marine litter. We will develop work to address all these issues based on the latest evidence. In addition to this, there will also be a revised regulation on fertilisers in order to recognise organic and waste-based fertilisers and to support bio-nutrition. Also, there will be a legislative proposal on minimum standards for reused water for irrigation. Public authorities, starting with the Commission, will be encouraged to step up their uptake of circular economic criteria in public procurement. This has great potential for the circular economy, as public procurement makes up nearly 20% of EU GDP. We will therefore emphasise circular economy aspects in new or revised criteria for creating public procurement, and the Commission will lead by example. Finally, the Commission strongly supports innovation to make the circular economy happen. We need to rethink our ways of producing and consuming. We need to create new technologies and business models, which will shape our future. In the Horizon 2020 work programmes for 2016 and 2017, we are putting EUR 650 million on the table for innovative demonstration projects. Added to this, there are EUR 5.5 billion in structural funds for circular economy purposes. In addition to this, EFSI can finance projects which are either joint ventures between the private and public sectors or private investors. So by quickly implementing the proposals now, we can achieve both economic and environmental – but also societal – gains by transforming our linear economy to a circular market economy. Let us give consumers an opportunity to lead the transformation by their choices, and let us strengthen competitiveness and create incentives to businesses to change their business models.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I must thank the Vice-Presidents for keeping a commitment on behalf of the Commission, for bringing us this proposal that Parliament strongly wanted and defended last year. This is a proposal that Vice-President Timmermans described as more ambitious and certainly more ambitious inso far as it forms part of a circular economy package and if we wanted to evaluate it solely on the basis of waste targets, we would probably evaluate it differently. But I believe that it is more ambitious, not least because it gives us the opportunity with different positions, for different states with different conditions, to achieve the objectives, and therefore to have a proposal that is well balanced with the current situation. Perhaps we wanted to hear a little more about food waste, we have heard about it and we may have expected something more, but surely the path will be useful in improving the proposal and in achieving a more balanced package that is what this Parliament wanted.

name: Simona Bonafè
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-Presidents, Commissioner Vella, you have spoken, you said that you would present the new circular economy proposal by the end of the year, and today we are here to discuss it; you also said that you would put forward a proposal that closed the circle, as opposed to the retreat, which focused only on the delivery of waste. Today we have before us an action plan which, with precise actions and deadlines, identifies from the immediately beginning of the eco-design of a product, the steps necessary to accelerate the transition of our economic system from linear to circular, with a holistic vision fundamental to us Socialists and Democrats.  This seems to me to be a good starting point and, on the other hand, we can no longer afford to allow 600 million tonnes of waste, which could be reused as raw materials and resources, to be thrown away in Europe every year. We would, however, make a mistake in considering the circular economy only as an environmental policy or, worse still, a matter of waste, it is much more than that! I cannot fail to note that the fact that several Directorates-General have cooperated in this proposal, in itself, underlines that the circular economy is a mainstreaming policy among all sectors of the Commission and we will be watching closely to ensure that this happens with the appropriate funding.  There is, however, one point on which you have not kept your promise to the full: lowering the recycling of municipal waste to 65%, I say this without hesitation, is a mistake. There is also a lack of concrete targets for prevention, the first link in the waste cycle chain, starting precisely from the food waste that was already mentioned Let us be clear, we are not passionate about targets, the problem is not one percentage point more or less, the problem, dear Commissioners, is that with an ambitious roadmap like the one you have presented, to be credible , must be supported by the setting of measurable targets to be achieved that are equally ambitious and because, if we really want to turn towards a circular economy, it is also with truly ambitious targets that we can promote a system that reduces waste and focuses on efficiency, durability and recycling, and reuse of products. On this point, as I say right now, the Group of the Party of European Socialists and Democrats is not prepared to lower the bar of expectations.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Trash is cash. The expression comes from you, Mr. Timmermans. That was well liked. Making better and more sustainable use of resources is essential. We have been delayed for a year and a half and I will of course study the proposal in detail, but I have already had some questions and criticisms, specifically around waste legislation.  1. You yourself said that the major differences between Member States in implementing existing legislation and achieving the 2020 targets are a huge challenge. For example, while in Flanders we recycle 65% of our household waste, some Member States still dispose of 80% of it. A full implementation of the existing waste legislation is therefore a necessary first step. But what efforts will the Commission make? 2. I understand the need for customization, but I do not think that lowering the ambition level from 70% to 65% on recycling targets for household waste and to provide a reprieve to a whole host of Member States is not such a good choice. Alternative solutions to get everyone on board are possible, e.g. through twinning projects, the formulation of interim objectives. 3. Tailor-made solutions are needed not only for Member States that are struggling, but also for forerunners such as my own region. How does the Commission intend to encourage this in practice and ensure that innovation is given every opportunity? Finally, a ban on the landfill of recyclable material should form the basis of a circular economy. It is unclear to me how hard the Commission is making this.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, it is one year since the political blunder of withdrawing the Waste Package, and now we know where we stand. We have, first of all, a new legislative waste proposal which is slightly weaker than the one we had before, and I assume that the Commission expects Parliament to increase the level of ambition and to pick up the fight with the Council. I would tell the Commission that I am willing to do so. Secondly, we have an action plan, but I am afraid it is an action plan in which the actions are to be limited to within the Berlaymont Building. It is a sort of weaker, copy-paste version of the roadmap to resource-efficient Europe that we had in 2011, so we have had not a two-year delay but a four-year delay. I really expected, after the very strong language from the Commissioners, an acceleration in the transition towards a circular economy. I am afraid that is not happening with this action plan, so I urge the Commission to step up its pace and really accelerate.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, Mr Timmermans, Mr Katainen, your proposal departs from that of Parliament. I believe that there is a lack of ambition and concreteness in measures and implementation, and that curbs its potential to drive systemic change, and we really need it to create a circular economy that, among other things, virtually eliminates waste. With regard to the financial framework linked to waste management, the Commission does make it very clear that any investment in this area must meet the recycling objectives. For example, it confirms that there will be no investment in incinerators that is not absolutely justified, i.e. only in exceptional cases.  I ask for more ambition in prevention and reuse, selective collection of bio-waste and recycling targets. It is perfectly possible and beneficial in all aspects to move faster and faster, and cities and territories such as Ljubljana, Gipuzkoa or Contarina have already demonstrated this.

name: Davor Škrlec
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Club. – Madam President, Dear Mr. Timmermans, you have fulfilled your promise a year ago that at the end of 2015 we will receive a circular economy package. And we got a rounded package, but we can't agree that we got a more ambitious package. We lost a year. Our economy has lost its inertia to encourage the European economy at European level to embrace the circular economy as a way into the future.  The new proposal contains new elements, which is commendable, because we really rounded off the economy. However, binding resource efficiency targets have been lacking. The link to the European Semester in resource efficiency indicators has been lost. Waste reduction targets have been lacking, targets for reducing marine pollution and excessive food waste have been lacking. Mind you, he wrote it all down and voted it in his report, in July this year, the European Parliament. But that information is clearly lost somewhere in the corridors of the European Commission.  We did not receive concrete measures but only minor amendments to the waste management directives, and everything else is a list, I would dare say, a wish list or a list of other action plans without concrete measures. There is too much on a voluntary basis, and my question to you, Mr. Timmermans: what guarantees does the Commission give us that the package will be implemented, and today we are witnessing that there are problems in implementing and implementing existing legislation? What market, you mention, will be a guarantee of implementation when it doesn't really exist today?  The proposal to address the conversion of waste into energy within the Energy Union rings alarm bells. Our economy is looking for sustainable innovation, it needs smart design, not burning. Burning, Mr. Timmermans, takes us back to the Stone Age instead of being leaders in new technologies and global leaders. You've done some good things. You have provided some Member States with one free period if they cannot meet their objectives. However, how will you allow these countries that when the time comes and they say that they cannot meet these goals, they can really meet those goals and can meet the measures that, as I said, are in action plans that do not contain concrete measures.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no reference to the elimination of incentives for fossil fuels; no reference to the elimination of incentives for incineration and landfilling; no reuse target, a target on municipal waste recycling that goes from 70% to 65% in 2030, a target on recycling to packaging that goes from 80 to 75% and a target on food waste that goes from 30% to no obligation. Since I have been here, the word I have heard the most is ambition, but it is also, for me, the word that has lost the most meaning, as far as I am concerned, so the Members who are accomplices, who have espoused this word, compared to this proposal, are, for me, complicit in a weakened proposal.

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: Madam President, Vice-Presidents, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to congratulate the Commission for presenting the proposal today – that is the crucial point. Is it an ambitious proposal? It is definitely different, and we need to analyse that carefully. I agree with all those who say that we expected a little more on the subject of food waste, and we will certainly be making amendments to this. It is necessary for many reasons that we are now working swiftly on this proposal. For the current occasion, I would like to draw particular attention to the climate protection argument. When waste ends up in landfill, methane is produced, and methane is a much stronger greenhouse gas than CO2. That is why we need to do something. In my country, Germany, the largest single amount of an industry ever - 20% - comes from the recycling industry. This is certainly a model that we should take a closer look at. So we will be looking at the details carefully, but we must get to work and stop just having fundamental debates now!

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: Madam President, I wrote it in my report on COP 21, this COP 21, the Paris summit, is not only aimed at combating climate change, but also at changing the economic paradigm. However, by developing the circular economy, we are allowing this change in economic paradigm and allowing - and I think it is interesting to see this proposal for a directive, which is going in the right direction - first of all from the savings of raw materials. It should be remembered that EUR 630 billion of the European Union's trade deficit can be attributed to dependence on imported materials. We also have job creation: the circular economy is two million new jobs. And then it's environmental protection; CO2 emissions would decrease by 48% in 2030 and 83% in 2050 compared to 2012 levels. These are proposals for the development of the circular economy that are indeed going in the right direction and are in line with our objective discussed right now in Paris on the occasion of COP 21.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her What strikes me as a former environmental manager of the WWF in Germany and as a former industrial president in dealing with this dossier is that we very often deal here with ideological arguments rather than scientific arguments.  We see it, for example, in the possibility of reusing PVC, which some people in this Parliament believe should be burned. Ladies and gentlemen, this is, of course, contrary to the idea of a circular economy. McKinsey has found that an economically organised circular economy can save 1.8 trillion euros by 2030!  Incidentally, as i am now coming my ceterum censeo, I believe that the single currency must be abolished because it leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioners, let us have a look at the current facts. The current facts are: the waste package has been stuck in the Council, the EU has been split, we have Member States with a pretty bad record on waste management, we have falsification of data, we have differing data, we do not have definitions, etc. This is the real situation and, against that background, I think you have come up with a concept. That is what I would like to underline and what I appreciate. Of course, we can discuss figures – a 65% or a 70% target, etc. – but I think that we need to be ambitious in terms of putting the concept into practice. That is why I think that the cold shower you have received from some of my colleagues may not be entirely justified. I would make two remarks. One is that, in terms of definitions and the latest statistics, this will not be easy. But, apart from the economic incentives, let us look at what we could do in terms of tax, fiscal and other incentives. This is much broader. I am sorry, I have to finish, but I am sure we will have more time in the future, and I have a few ideas for the future.

name: Karl-Heinz Florenz (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, Mr Vella, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work I am not really dissatisfied today. I was very dissatisfied when the Commission withdrew the report. You have kept your word, the date is there. And I believe that it has now come to the attention of the citizens and also of politics that resource policy is an important factor. I hear that percentages and targets play a major role here at the moment. I would like to tell you that do not fall into this trap, because first we have to define criteria and methods for how we get to the objectives. There are certain objectives in Germany and perhaps in Italy, but in reality they are very different in the end. That is why it is right that we are very intensive in our approach to the terms – for example: what is recycling? to deal with. I would think of the chapter "Action Plan" a little more strongly, because that's where the music is in it. Mr Vice-President, you still have to work very hard and deliver quickly so that there is an overall package. That is what matters!

name: Massimo Paolucci (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the circular economy package and communication is a step forward. We like the system approach that goes beyond the wrong logic of sectoral interventions, waste management, food waste, eco-design, reorganisation of production cycles, sustainable buildings, green procurement, are major interconnected issues. The approach is right, on the substance not everything satisfies us, not everything is fine. Ambitious objectives must be reflected in legislative acts and certain and stringent deadlines. Time is not an independent variable. We need more courage and determination, the exact opposite of what the Council has done on the Volkswagen case. More ambitious targets for waste, binding deadlines on targets, a stronger step forward on efficiency indicators, the gap on marine pollution must be closed, the commitment to comply with the UN decision to halve food waste by 2030 is a good one, but we need clear deadlines and legislative commitments.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Commission has today adopted an ambitious circular economy package with ambitious recycling targets of 65%. This is a reality compared to the previous project. Secondly, this objective cannot be achieved without cooperation with local authorities, but also with society. It requires full acceptance of our proposals. Thirdly, the Commission has been criticised for the fact that the new targets will create fewer jobs, but this must also be a viable project, because if it is too ambitious, then households and our families will pay for it. Fourthly, this objective cannot be achieved without recycling toxic substances. The target and the level of recycling of plastics, among others, have been mentioned here, but a large part of them are still in landfills. Something needs to be done about it. Fifthly, some countries should have more time to adapt to this objective. Consideration should be given to raising the current recycling rate to 25% as a criterion for countries that are allocated an additional 5 years to implement this project.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Madam Vice-President, Commissioner, in recent times the successive global conflicts and crises have not been such as to generate hope and confidence in the future. And this is all the more reason to underline the importance of the high-level political consensus that is beginning to draw in Paris. A political consensus not only to mitigate global warming, but to change behaviors and models of economic and social management. The Message from Paris is very similar to the message of this circular economy package. We need to put people and the planet at the heart of the sustainable development process. And this package responds to the challenges of efficient use of resources throughout its cycle of transformation and use, and will help solve key issues such as growth, quality job creation, reducing inequalities, preserving the oceans, or protecting biodiversity. We have reasons for hope and optimism. We cannot let bureaucracy and implementation failures be once again the black beasts of such an important strategy. If citizens, businesses and institutions take this path as their way we will come to a good port.

name: Antonio Tajani (PPE). –
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, representatives of the Commission, in order to ensure sustainable growth in the Union, we must use the resources at our disposal more intelligently. The circular economy is a necessity for Europe: we must reduce CO2 emissions, we must also be more efficient in terms of the supply of raw materials. The circular economy is therefore a great opportunity, it will help our companies to be more competitive in the world, it will open up new markets for us, it will also offer growth in traditional sectors such as steel, aluminium and it will also boost the green economy.  I welcome the package presented by the Commission which aims to strengthen our global competitiveness by stimulating sustainable economic growth and the creation of new jobs. I therefore hope that this package will be a further step in the Eu ropean Union's reindustralisation strategy, approved by the Commission, which aims to achieve the target of 20% of gross domestic product from manufacturing before 2020. Indeed, our commitment to combating climate change cannot ignore the central role that industry in Europe has, and must continue to play.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. Thank you very much for the opportunity, Madam President. Mr Representative mentioned two important things: our relationship with green industries and the use of European money in this area. There are times when the circular economy can do more harm than good. I'll give you an example: processing used tires. It often goes with European support and causes pollution that is difficult to bear. How would you think to prevent them?

name: Antonio Tajani (PPE)
text: Answer to a blue card question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that we must find the right compromise, the one that I always tried to achieve when I was Commissioner, between environmental policy and industrial policy. A marriage of interest can perhaps be arranged between industrial policy and environmental policy, which will certainly be a success. The third industrial revolution can only be a green industrial revolution, of course we have to find, sector by sector, including that of tyres, the right compromises to favour industry and not to harm the environment.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I welcome Mr. Vice President and I fully agree with him that we cannot compete with the level of wages, but with quality and innovative use of natural resources, surely yes. A circular economy means benefiting more from the resources at our disposal. It means recognizing the values in the resources we've thrown away so far.  This package proposed by the European Commission is an important step forward and a clear message from Europe, a message from all of us to put the quality and reusable resources we have at the forefront. The goal of zero waste is important to achieve, but when the formation of waste cannot be prevented then burning this remaining part is a much better solution than disposal.  Finally, €600 billion that we can save annually by preventing waste generation, ecode art design and reusing waste, and how we need it for new investments and job creation.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, by 2015, the Commission, by presenting its new proposal on the circular economy, is honouring its commitments to Parliament, as in its resolution of last July. However, the package is a little less ambitious and with some forgetfulness. Recycling and preparation targets for the reuse of at least 70% of municipal solid waste were expected to increase, while the Commission's proposal stands at 65%. We pointed out the importance of achieving a binding and gradual reduction in all types of landfilling until the complete ban was reached, and here too the Commission maintains a 10% cure. The Economic and Consumer Habits of the European Union are based on an environmentally unsustainable model. We are fortunate enough to live in one of the most prosperous regions in the world, and that is why we have a moral obligation to develop tailor-made products and processes to implement a circular economy that also allows us to exploit our potential for innovation, generating jobs and growth. Together with my colleagues, I will therefore endeavour to improve the Commission's proposal in order to deliver to european citizens a more ambitious package on the circular economy, capable of achieving the objectives of the Seventh Environment Action Programme.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, European society consumes renewable resources 50% faster than it can replace them, while the European Union imports six times more materials and natural resources than it exports. For this reason, a circular economy must be created, with the rule of reuse and recycling. In the face of the linear consumption system, the package of measures of the circular economy is necessary. Moreover, the circular economy will also have to provide economic benefits, and it will do so if we implement it by 2030, when spending will be reduced by EUR 600 billion per year. The total benefits will reach EUR 1.8 trillion, create 2 million jobs and increase the European Union's competitiveness on the world market. Finally, in order to achieve the 2030 targets, emphasis should be placed on innovation, research and science in order to promote the circular economy model.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, a determined commitment in Europe to the circular economy is, together with equality, one of our main competitive advantages in a Union which depends, like no other region in the world, on imports of raw materials.  The principle of treating waste as resources is one of the keys to the future. Supporting research and working on technologies and processes that allow us to reuse at least 70% of waste is key to developing new forms of production, nearly two million jobs and a sustainable, intelligent and innovative source of growth. That is why I share the principle of setting binding recycling targets, eliminating landfills, energy-rated only the non-reusable, driving innovation in this sector and turning this principle into a hallmark of 'Made in Europe'. I also propose a common European fiscal policy that supports the circular economy and trade rules that protect sustainable production from non-sustainable productions. But it must also incorporate the key to reuse into the intelligence of tax systems.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, thank you very much for the opportunity to speak on this. The circular economy has to be about more than legislation and about more than just talking about the circular economy. The circular economy has to be about the way you live your life. You have got to live it, and if you want this to happen, one of the first things you do if you want to make something happen is you lead by example. Now we have got to ask ourselves in here: ‘are we leading by example?’ Are we following the three Rs: recycling, reducing, etc.? Well, we are not. You look at the fact that the water the MEPs drink in here is out of plastic bottles: whatever happened to a water font? We look at the coffee machines: we have cartridges there that are virtually impossible to recycle. Whatever happened to a jar of coffee and a spoon, or is it not good enough for you? We travel up and down to Strasbourg – have you ever heard of ‘reduce’? A good way to reduce it would be to cut out that complete and utter codology. I go to committee meetings – and remember we are asking people to follow us – reams of paperwork! Have you ever heard of e-mail? Lead by example, otherwise forget it!

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for the proposal. Commissioner, you may wonder why you are getting such critical remarks. Well first of all, this is about the credibility of the Commission. When, with a lot of clarity, you promised to be more ambitious, then we expected more ambition. My first question: We now have an action plan. We already have a communication, we have a strategy, we have a roadmap – we have a lot on the circular economy. What makes this action plan different from all the other communications that we have had before? That we would like to see clarified. Secondly, on the legislative package, why did it need to be withdrawn one-and-a-half years ago? Because the only thing you have added is an action plan that could have been added now. Why did you need to withdraw the other plan? And if we then go into the contents of it, we see weaker targets, we see fewer targets in the legislative proposal, and one clear question is: where is the target for increasing our resource efficiency, the over-arching target that has been deleted? That is a very, very bad issue.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – The economy is the right decision and I support the Commission's transfer of the proposal within the promised deadline. It has to become a new model, not just a pile of papers, a bunch of goals. As has already been said here today, it must become a way of life, and in the implementation of this circular economy, we must also focus very much on man, because the individual decides how much he or she will put on the plate, whether the food is discarded or not, the individual decides what he does with the waste. It is very necessary to focus on young people, who can also be great promoters of this way of the economy, but also those who will transfer this behaviour to European homes. I look forward to being able to speak out about the objectives in this process, in so far as we feel that we are under-ambitious, corrected, and above all, we need to live this circular economy in the future.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Madam President, dear Commissioner Vella, one of the objectives of implementing and strengthening the circular economy is to reduce waste flowing into the seas. The impact of plastic waste at sea is extremely serious, holistic and perennial and is identified by several international bodies and is one of the G7 priorities. Plastics and, mainly, microplastics are a problem for the physical, chemical and molecular contamination of the food chains of marine organisms. Plastics contain persistent organic pollutants contaminating the animals that ingest them and causing hormonal problems that cause changes in growth and reproduction rates. Acting as hormonal disruptors, have been responsible for failures in the reproduction of marine mammals, fish and birds to give only three examples. One of the solutions to minimize this problem is to provide the instruments associated with the circular economy, thus ensuring at least not the solution but the urgent mitigation of the problem. The circular economy is unavoidable, not enough, but it can be a breakthrough.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish to thank the honourable Members very much for their comments and advice. Let me start by saying that Commissioner Vella will be present in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on 21 December. That committee will have the opportunity to look at the package in a very in-depth manner.  First, what is different with this package compared to the previous one, which was withdrawn by the Commission? First of all, the previous legislative proposal on waste was partially based on humble aspirations. For instance, if you look at the landfill target, it was not legally binding. I do hope that there is no political group – even the Greens – who would put their political weight behind changing our proposal to the one we withdrew, because it would be weaker than the current proposal.  This proposal is now legally binding, whereas the former was not – it was aspirational; it was a kind of hope that somebody would do something. Now it is legally binding. Also, it is not 25%: it is 10% by 2030. Furthermore, what is different is that we are not only talking about how to deal with the waste, but about how to reduce the amount of waste. That is important and it is one of the reasons why we wanted to withdraw the package, make it more realistic and make it more ambitious, and also to look at how we could reduce the amount of waste and create incentives to use so-called waste, which provides valuable raw materials for industry if dealt with properly.  I very much liked Mr Tajani’s use of the word ‘reindustrialisation’. This is very important, because if we manage to get our incentives right – and Mr Telička mentioned economic incentives also – it really encourages the private sector, entrepreneurs, innovators and also industry, to transform the current business model into a more circular business model.  Also, if you compare the circular recycling target and look at the landfill target, they are one entity. By 2030, recycling levels should be up to 65%. This is legally binding. We also have a review clause which means that by 2025 we have to look at whether we should raise the target above 65%. Also, when we change the landfill target to be more ambitious, it will strengthen achievement of the recycling target.  How many jobs will this create? Well, nobody really knows. Our assessment is that just looking at the landfill target and recycling target, one could imagine some 170 000 new direct jobs. But I would not stare at those figures, because nobody really knows how business will change in the meantime. If you look, for instance, at the Eco-design Directive or eco—design practices and energy labelling practices – without any widening of the scope which we are about to propose – just current practices, our assessment is that, by 2020, the amount of energy we will have saved is approximately the same as the annual primary energy consumption of Italy. So basically it will save money and increase the purchasing power of the average consumer in Europe by a little under EUR 500 per year. Nobody can really assess what kind of impact this will have on job creation. Even if we add our proposal to widen the scope of eco-design, nobody knows exactly what its impact will be, but it is positive anyway; it is significant.  I want to thank Members for this discussion and have one last point on food waste because it was clearly mentioned. Member States are committed to sustainable development goals, and this is mentioned very clearly in the waste legislative package, so Member States must take measures to reduce food waste at each stage of the food supply chain, monitor food waste levels and report back, recording the progress made. The Commission will also elaborate a common methodology to measure food waste. In addition to this, we will clarify legislation relating to waste food and feed in order to facilitate redistribution of safe, edible food to people in need, where it is safe to do so. We will also look at what we could do in order to guide Member States in food donations. This is a big issue. This is a big part of the European investment package, and there is plenty of room for a pragmatic approach with moderate result-minded thinking. Let us try to find new tools in order to empower consumers and businesses to change the business model.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Spanish Socialists believe that the paradigm shift from a linear economy to a circular economy is a pressing necessity. That is why, at a time when COP21 is being held, we support the need to promote new business and consumption models that promote sustainable growth in the economy. We will monitor the fulfilment of the established binding targets covering the entire product lifecycle, from design to purchase and management of resources, by counting H2020-funded projects with EUR 650 million and the more than 5.5 billion earmarked for this purpose by the Structural Funds. During the parliamentary process now under way, we reiterated our greatest ambition to reduce urban waste by 70%, not 65% as proposed by the EC, as well as the need to set binding targets for food waste.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – The ongoing debate on the transition to a circular economy model is as crucial as ever. As concerns about environmental conditions are a constant topical issue and as the impasse in the European and global economy continues, the need to improve the way states and businesses develop and to take any action that can protect the environment becomes apparent. Clear environmental protection objectives, through the reduction of pollutant emissions, better waste management and product recycling, confirm how important the prospect of transition to the circular economy is. However, this model is inextricably linked to radical changes in the structure of both our economy and our society as it requires acceptance of a different production model, which will directly affect small and medium-sized enterprises and workers, possibly leading to job losses. In order to allow such a transition, careful and balanced moves are needed at both a legal and practical level. The productive sector will need a respectable transition period in order to overcome the current perception of the economy, which includes outdated and environmentally damaging structures.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome the revised proposal on waste policy and the circular economy. I support the approach of a circular economy in which resources are used more sustainably. There is an urgent need to look at the entire life cycle of a product in terms of resource efficiency, consumer protection and climate protection, with economic interests also taking their place. Whether the Commission's package will be sufficient to maximise the added value and use of all raw materials, products and waste, promote energy savings and reduce greenhouse gas emissions will be demonstrated in the discussions that are now under way.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. – Around 100 million tonnes of food are wasted every year in the European Union, an invaluable loss that takes place throughout the food supply chain and has a major economic, environmental and social impact on the entire European economy every day. The road map presented by the European Commission on Wednesday 2 December aims to facilitate the transition of the European economy from linear to circular and has among its objectives the definition of smarter and more environmentally sustainable European standards on waste disposal and the fight against waste, including that of food, facilitating the redistribution of safe and edible ones to those who need it. I believe that the full transition to this new circular economy model, a global and long-term strategic objective, can only be achieved through the immediate definition of legislative initiatives with concrete prevention targets and clear and measurable objectives, which are even more ambitious than those that have been provided for so far in the Commission's package of proposals. Only in this way will the European Union be able to respond to the ecological and food challenges of the new millennium, while respecting the principle of safeguarding precious goods and resources, the waste of which cannot be tolerated.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission's proposal on the circular economy is both ambitious in its objectives and realistic in its implementation. Producing and consuming without worrying about the availability of our resources in the future or the waste that accumulates is part of another time. Coupled with a strategy of re-industrialisation, the circular economy can be a model whose vocation is to enshrine Europe in sustainability. It also offers opportunities for growth and green jobs, and weapons against volatile commodity and energy prices.  I particularly welcome the announcements in favour of the water policy, which is already a major environmental, economic and geopolitical issue on a global scale. The principle of wastewater reuse is a key concept to be promoted in Europe, in order to meet the dual challenge of water supply in sufficient quantity and quality.  Our companies are developing state-of-the-art technologies; let us give them the means to disseminate them, by defining clear and common rules at EU level.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Construction materials in the technological process change their original structure. There is a decrease in the exergy of these material systems, accompanied by an increase in their entropy. For this reason, the restoration of their output requires additional energy input, which would inevitably result in an increase in CO2 emissions. This is the case with steel produced by repeated smelting of scrap, in which impurities increase, especially copper, which reduces their plasticity and increases fragility. This happens with repeatedly worked thermoplastics, the polymer chains of which are shortened, accompanied by a decrease in strength. This is the case with composite plastics, with electronic and composite scrap, which practically create waste unsuitable for further processing. The history of technology provides numerous examples of technologies once used, accompanied by significant waste, forming large, currently exploited heaps. Such technological niches are already excluded. To conclude: the circular economy, or waste-free economy, is not a simple recycling, but a creative search for other applications for secondary raw materials, from their production use through the recovery of the energy contained therein to the permanent and useful deposition of residues, e.g. in the form of backing materials.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Today, following the European Commission's proposal, which was withdrawn a year ago, the long-awaited European Action Plan on the promotion of the circular economy has finally been published. Without a detailed analysis of the proposal published only a few hours earlier, on the basis of the preliminary information, I certainly welcome the committee's new approach. The realisation of a circular economy is not just a waste management issue. The essence of a circular economy is sustainability, based primarily on smart use of raw materials, proper product design and precise definition of the tasks of economic operators.  In agreement with the teachings of Pope Francis I, I believe that without a break from our current "discarding" consumer habits, our planet will be unable to survive. The transition to a circular economy will allow us to put behind us the wasteful habits of production and consumption, while creating new business models and job opportunities in Europe.  At the same time, it is important that we take into account the different economic conditions and starting positions of the Member States in our work. The new targets should be feasible, helping to change sustainability approaches rather than increasing infringements. I am pleased that solving the problem of food waste is also part of the European Commission's action plan. European citizens waste around 90 million tonnes of food every year. One of the most important tasks for me in the negotiations on the package of proposals will therefore be to reduce food waste.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE)
text: Written. – The Commission's new draft circular economy seems to have already been thrown into the ring. I very much wonder why the Commission is not proposing binding targets for reducing food waste, but is leaving this in the hands of the Member States in the proposal for a waste directive.  The Commission's proposal does not solve the problems of unsustainable resource use. If we really want to change our production and consumption in line with circular economy thinking, we are facing a major change. Different indicators and indicators are necessary. The mere statement that food waste is halved has a guiding effect on the behaviour of very few people.  A smiling face on the cafeteria wall is concrete. That is not just a reference to the UN declarations. I hope that in the near future we will have lengthy and in-depth discussions about when to hang that smiley face on the wall.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - The proposed circular economy package is going in the right direction, but I expected an even more ambitious proposal from the European Commission. This must become an integral part of the European economy, practically a new concept of economics, but also a way of managing resources that until recently we were throwing away or destroying completely unnecessarily.  It should be emphasized that this new concept must also receive its own special financial support because it is necessary to finance innovative technologies that serve an efficient circular economy. Special attention should be paid to throwing away huge amounts of food, which is the social and moral obligation of all participants in these decisions.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – The Circular Economy Package presented today, which has been announced as more ambitious than before, is deeply disappointing. The Juncker European Commission, for trumped-up reasons, delayed the deadline for presenting the Package, made us all believe that it was all for the right reasons, and then came up with a watered-down proposal with no specifics, which, coincidentally, was completely weakened. Vice President Timmermans has betrayed our trust! As itre committee report on the Circular Economy report, I find it impossible to adopt this proposal. Europe needs a comprehensive economy with legally binding elements, a reimagining of production and other economic processes that hinders waste and minimises and reinvested waste. This is precisely the message reflected in the European Parliament's report voted on in July. The Member States of the European Union can only remain competitive with a sustainable resource policy. The weakness of the current proposal is not only disappointing, but it is outrageous that we have wasted a whole year waiting for it. Last year, we adopted the Commission's explanation in the hope that the new package would indeed close the circle and make the entire economic cycle more sustainable, but let us be honest: without legislative proposals for the production cycle (e.g. the objective of resource efficiency or the integration of resource use indicators into the European Semester), the new package is unacceptable and unsuitable for meeting the targets set.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The new circular economy package is absolutely to be welcomed. We consume so much that – if every human being were an average European – we would need 2.6 earths to generate enough raw materials for a global European lifestyle. More efficient use of resources along the entire value chain is therefore necessary: we need to get by with fewer resources, recycle more resources, and make products more durable and recyclable. There is an urgent need for urgent action, especially for raw materials that are no longer renewable, such as oil or rare earths, packaging materials or products with planned obsolescence that are difficult to recyclable or recyclable. To do this without having to give up on anything seems like squaring the circle. But the approach of producing the same products with fewer resources, making them easier, and saving all non-essential resources in production is a viable solution. There is less waste and from the beginning there is a reduction in resources. Moreover, if resource productivity were to increase by 30%, gross domestic product would increase by one percent and two million new jobs would be created at the same time. Although there is no specific objective in terms of resource efficiency in this package, it is an important step in the right direction.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Commission has today adopted a package of legislative proposals on the circular economy. The circular economy has a direct impact not only on the environment, but also on jobs, industry, energy, research, etc. Key actions in this package must aim to transform the EU economy into a sustainable and competitive economy. Thus, beyond the mandatory product design requirements, we must encourage research and innovation, as well as continuous labour training. I also point out that price is often a barrier to the implementation of the principles of the circular economy. As long as a product (electronic, electro-housekeeping or other) costs less when it is new than if it is repaired, the consumer's choice is obvious. Last but not least, ensuring sustainable access to raw materials is essential for the competitiveness and growth of the EU economy and for the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. Main raw materials, including renewable materials and secondary raw materials, must play an important role in production processes in the circular economy. That is why we need to improve the availability of secondary raw material data and support EU-wide research on the flow of raw materials.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Circular Economy (CE) package is a forward-looking step, an excellent example of the policies we need to adopt in order to tackle challenges like climate change, job creation, economic and social development. It is key to the new business model in Europe, which should focus on innovations and efficiency, smart regulation and competitiveness. Through the circular economy, we can achieve EUR 600 billion for EU businesses, create 580 000 jobs and reduce EU carbon emissions by 450 million tonnes per year. For the circular economy to work and deliver on these ambitious goals, we need to ensure that small and big companies alike are supported in the establishment of a more resource-efficient industry. I thus urge the Commission to establish the necessary regulations and incentives in order to ensure that SMEs are well integrated into the CE. In this regard, the planned establishment of a European Resource Efficiency Excellence Centre, the reinforcement of the resource efficiency element of the Enterprise Europe Network and the work stream of clusters are welcome developments we need to build on. Another important step would be making small enterprises aware of the funding possibilities for resource efficiency improvements, such as the financial instruments under COSME and the Natural Capital Financing Facility (NCFF).

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. - Today we heard from the European Commission the frameworks and how to deliver on the circular economy programme, which can help launch European economies, which will be less dependent on imports of raw materials.  This project aims to ensure economic gains, environmental gains, but also social gains. This is a significant step by which Europe is moving from a linear to a circular economy, which is more sustainable. As such, it should be supported and pursued as far as possible and achieved as soon as possible.  You will agree that we want better waste management – what ended up in landfills we want to use usefully. Food waste should be suppressed because it is immoral to throw away food when so many people are starving. Therefore, we need changes in the value chain, from product design to new business and market models, from new ways of turning waste into a resource to new ways of consumer behaviour. This implies complete system changes and innovation, not only in technologies but also in organisation, society, funding methods and policies. Administrative burdens for family farms and SMEs should be reduced in doing so.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Spanish Socialists believe that the paradigm shift from a linear economy to a circular economy is a pressing necessity. That is why, at a time when COP21 is being held, we support the need to promote new business and consumption models that promote sustainable growth in the economy. We will monitor the fulfilment of the established binding targets covering the entire product lifecycle, from design to purchase and management of resources, by counting H2020-funded projects with EUR 650 million and the more than 5.5 billion earmarked for this purpose by the Structural Funds. During the parliamentary process now under way, we reiterated our greatest ambition to reduce urban waste by 70%, not 65% as proposed by the EC, as well as the need to set binding targets for food waste.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – The question of the durability of products, their repairability, but also, for example, the environmental impact of the constant exchange of consumer goods has recently come to the fore front of consumer policy issues in the EU, and I therefore consider it important to respond to issues such as the obsolescence of products or spare parts. I welcome the fact that one of the stated objectives of the Action Plan presented by the Commission today is to promote the repairability, longer life and recyclability of products. I also support the idea of independent testing to help detect potential cases of planned obsolescence of products. Consumer organisations have often recently pointed to an increased trend in the use of components that go wrong after a short period of use, which are expensive or impossible to replace, forcing consumers to buy new goods unnecessarily. The present plan is the first requested by the European Parliament and therefore a welcome step, but we also need concrete legislative proposals. On waste, the Commission has already done so today. I believe that proposals concerning the production phase of consumer goods will soon follow and will primarily be aimed at the end consumer.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. – There are lots of compelling benefits of a circular economy. Most of them are environmental, such as the improvement of our living environment, the protection of scarce natural resources or the reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. There are strong economic benefits as well, like the sustainable availability of raw materials, job creation within a more labour intensive production model and the decoupling of economic growth from the use of resources.  Nevertheless, the real driver behind the need for a new economic and consumption model is that we do not have a choice; we are already witnessing the irreversible ecological damage we are doing to our land and marine environment. I am happy that the Commission stuck to its promise to present its new circular economy strategy before the end of the year and I am looking forward to exploring it in detail. I do hope that through this strategy we can ensure the long-term economic predictability that is needed to enable the technological development and investment in a new, circular economy.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. – The proposals on circular economy that the Commission put forward today are a total disgrace. There are some crucial elements that were lacking in the Barroso Commission's original proposal, such as the target of using resources 30% more efficiently compared to 2014 and monitoring this through the European Semester. The targets for recycling waste are also weaker both in terms of content and timing, while the Commission's impact assessment itself clearly shows that the stronger the targets are, the higher the economic benefit for each Member State becomes.  In addition, the binding targets for reducing marine waste and reducing food waste have also disappeared. The previous Commission originally proposed a non-binding target to reduce food waste by 30% by 2020. The European Parliament demanded an obligation to waste 30% less food by 2025. Now Timmermans has "a general obligation to combat food waste", with no timetable or binding targets? Quid ambition with such vague terms? Unfortunately, as long as the concept of circular economy does not contribute to an effective and absolute reduction in the consumption of raw materials, this new proposal will not put us on the path of sustainable development.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – The European Commission has presented a new proposal for a package of measures on the circular economy and resource use. I welcome the fact that the Commission has finally taken a step towards a much-needed transition to a circular economy, but I believe that the new proposal falls short of the ambitions previously set. Although the newer package adds new elements, it does not contain key measures of the previously withdrawn proposal. I can give as an example the provisions on resource efficiency at EU level. The previous proposal set a target of 30% increase in resource efficiency by 2030, while the revised package does not contain this. The consequences of including such a measure could result in the creation of 2 million new jobs and a 1% increase in GDP. Likewise, the new circular economy package does not bring about indicators of resource consumption in the European Semester. More ambitious proposals would bring about a number of much-needed changes from an environmental, economic and social point of view. For this reason, I believe that a newer package of proposals, which does not contain effective and binding measures to reduce the use of resources and does not include indicators of resource consumption in the context of the European Semester, will unfortunately not contribute to sustainable development to the extent that it should and would like.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – The accumulation of unprocessed waste places an enormous burden on the environment, endangers the health of people living near landfill sites and also entails great spending on safety measures and future remediation of such sites. We should solve problems when they arise, not sideline them for the future. Nature knows no borders and all mankind must be involved in protecting it. Advanced economies such as the Member States of the European Union and the United States have already done a great deal in the past to combat climate change, even at the cost of reducing their industrial production. Further measures are necessary, but they cannot result in a reduction in economic growth or a threat to existing jobs. It is now the turn of countries such as Russia, China and India to follow us in our quest for a better environment across the Earth.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We are consuming more and more, producing more and more while planetary resources are dwindling by the day: this must stop so as not to seriously handicap the lives of our children and grandchildren. To avoid this waste of food, products, energy, or materials, the European Parliament has already demanded ambitious and binding European legislation. More efficient waste management and product sustainability must once again become European priorities.  Reuse, repair or transform: these are the 3 key words of the circular economy, it is also without which our society has no future. The circular economy must become a real European priority. Preserving natural resources, consuming sustainable and improving people's quality of life rather than behaving like carefree children by plundering the planet is the challenge facing Europe and the world. These changes must be systemic because we can only survive by profoundly changing our regulations, economies, model of society and education.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – Using our resources in an efficient way is an important priority for all of us. Like my colleagues in the EES Political Group, I welcome today's presentation by the European Commission. We cannot waste the resources that our future generations will have to use today. We have to be effective. We have to work by leaving as few leads as possible. However, it is not irrelevant what purpose we will use the resources at our disposal. We must spend them in an efficient way, and their consumption must be linked to economic growth, employment and, of course, to environmental protection. At the same time, we have to be careful. We need ambitious but realistic goals. If we set ourselves an unrealistic goal today, we've done nothing. Let us be consistent and take advantage of the potential that the circular economy certainly brings.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The new circular economy package must go far beyond the idea of simply improving our waste management. It must go further and deal head-on with the fundamental problem, answering the question: why do we generate so much waste? The expected increase in the recycling rate of municipalities, which should reach 70%, and other waste measures are all welcome, but we cannot miss another opportunity to raise the focus on the need for a real change in our consumption pattern and the management of our resources. And if we really want to limit our consumption, then we have to start measuring the resources we use. We need to develop indicators of the ecological footprint of materials, water, land and greenhouse gases. Unfortunately, this doesn't seem to start in the best way. So far, the European Commission does not seem to hear these calls and, without changing paradigms, this package will be more dust for the eyes of citizens.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. – First of all, I would like to welcome the proposal put forward by the European Commission, as I consider it crucial to move forward with the circular economy model. This linear economic model of "take, do, discard" is based on having large amounts of energy and other cheap and easily accessible resources, but it is already reaching the limit of its physical capacity. The circular economy is an attractive and viable alternative that we must encourage from the private sector. The circular economy is restorative and regenerative, and through this circular model we can get products, components and resources in general to maintain their usefulness and value at all times. This model would lead to a continuous cycle of positive development that preserves and improves natural capital, optimizes the use of resources and minimizes system risks by managing a finite amount of stocks and renewable flows.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on the report of Roberta Metsola and Ska Keller, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Petitions, on the Special Report of the European Ombudsman in the OI/5/2012/BEH-MHZ frontex (2014/2215 (INI)) (A8-0343/2015).

name: Roberta Metsola
text: Mr. Rapporteur, i.e. – Nixtieq nibda billi nirringrazzja flower-kollega tiegħi Ska Keller u x-shadow rapporteurs kollha l-oħra għall-kollaborazzjoni tajba li kellna metaġejna biex nidsdiskutu dan ir-rapport flimkien dwar, kif għadek kid għidt int, ir-rapport spe大jali tal-Ombudsman Ewropew rigward FRONTEX. Fuq livell ta' Kumitat aħna ksibna qbil wiesa' fuq il-fatt li FRONTEX tista' tassigura li tissalvagwardja d-drittijiet fundamentali anke billi twaqqaf mekkaniżmu għall-ilmenti individwali. Ilbieraħ sirna nafu wkoll li l-Gumsjoni stess ser tinkludi dan il-mekkaniżmu fir-reviżjoni tar-Regolament dwar FRONTEX li għandu joħroġ fil-ġranet li ġejjin. B'mod spe大ifiku, dan ir-rapport jinkludi referenzi ikeari li jappoġjaw il-ħidma ta' FRONTEX sabiex iwettqu r-rakkomandazzjonijiet tal-istess Ombudsman Ewropew. Fost oħrajn, l-Aġenzija daħħlet fis-seħħħ sistema ta' rappurtar tal-in-adient. Inħoloq forum consulting spe大ifikament dwar id-drittijiet fondamentali. Ġie mwaqqaf ukoll uffi大大ju għal drittijiet fundamentali fiħdan l-Aġenzija li però huwa xorta indipendenti mill-istruttura ta' FRONTEX. Dan ir-rapport ma jaffettwa bl-ebda mod il-prinikeipju tas-slippersjarjetà u l-kompetenzi distinti tal-Unjoni Ewropea u dawk tal-Istati Membri tagħha f'dawn l-oqsma. Dan ir-rapport jagħmel ukoll referenzi speħifi大i għall-fatt li FRONTEX m'għandha l-ebda kompetenza biex tibda miżuri dixxiplinarji kontra persuni oħra minbarra l-uffijaħliga tagha stess. Hemm referenzi oħra dwar il-fatt li r-Regolament dwar il-FRONTEX jagmilħha ħara li t-teħid ta' azzjoni dixxiplinarja jaqa' taħt il-kompetenza esklussiva tal-Istat Membru ta' orġini. Madankollu, aħna tal-fehma li t-twaqqif ta' mekkaniżmu għall-ilmenti individwali ser jipprovdi mezz għall-persuni sabiex jeżer大itaw id-dritt taghomħ għal rimedju aktar effettiv. B'hekk ikun żgurat li FRONTEX u l-istituzzjonijiet u l-korpi Ewropej ikunu iżjed konxji dwar ksur possibbli tad-drittijiet fundamentali. U dan għalina kien importanti ħafna. Dan ir-rapport jenfasizza wkoll il-bżonn ta' salvagwardji legali sabiex jiġi żgurat li l-ilemnti konkreti u ta' ikeerta sustanza biss jiġu ammessi. Aħna qed insejħu wkoll sabiex il-Kummissjoni Ewropea u l-Istati Membri fi ħdana jallokaw riżorsi addizzjonali għal FRONTEX sabiex l-uffi大ju gaħd-drittijiet fundamentali jkun jista' jittratta proprju dawn l-ilmenti. U għalhekk, Sinjura President, jiena ninsab ħerqana li bħalma ksibna qbil fuq livell ta' Kumitat b'maġġoranza daqshekk kbira, issa wkoll inkunu nistgħu niksbu l-istess tip ta' qbil fuq il-livell ta' pnarja. Naħseb li għandna quddiemna rapport bilan大jat u ninsab ħerqana li nistgħu niksbu l-appoġġ tagħkom.

name: Ska Keller
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation, and a very special thanks also to my co-rapporteur, Roberta Metsola, with whom it was a great pleasure to work. And thanks, too, to the Ombudswoman who drew up the original report on which we now have this report. Altogether I think we are submitting a very good report to this plenary for you to vote on. It is a report that will protect the human rights of refugees and migrants at our external borders better, but it is also a report that will enable Frontex to have a clearer picture about where human rights violation might occur and how to solve this problem. It is a win-win situation. What we are proposing is to establish a complaints mechanism that refugees and migrants can use, through which they can address their complaints to Frontex if they feel that they have been mistreated in a Frontex operation – whether involving Frontex employees or guest officers of Member States. All these groups are recognisable by their Frontex armband, and therefore we think that we cannot expect refugees to try to research which Member State a specific guest officer might have been from. Rather, it is really important that they can address their complaints to Frontex and that we task Frontex, as we proposed to do, with making sure that those complaints actually arrive at the right place and are followed up, so that the Member States do not eventually need to follow up on those complaints. Of course, this will need sufficient resources in Frontex to handle the task because it is quite a new and significant task that we want to place in the trustworthy hands of the fundamental rights officer of Frontex. I am very hopeful that Frontex will now act swiftly in response to this request, without waiting until the next Frontex mandate review has been adopted, because that will take some time. I am glad too that the Frontex Consultative Forum sees implementation of the complaint mechanism as a core priority for its work next year. The Consultative Forum, by the way, is a body that the European Parliament helped to create in the last review of the Frontex mandate, so our work here in the Parliament is indeed essential to the functioning of our external borders agency. I believe that, with this complaint mechanism, we can take a further step towards ensuring even more human rights at our external borders. Frontex has, in the past, received more and more tasks, and it may receive even more in the future. So it is only right and fair that Frontex also has to do more on human rights. I hope this House can support our report, which we have been working on for several months now, with really great collaboration among the shadow rapporteurs and the co-rapporteur and with both the Committee on Petitions and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. I also hope that the Commissioner can give us a date when the complaint mechanism can be included in the next Frontex mandate review that he proposes, because I think it is very important that human rights safeguards keep pace with the enlargement of any task Frontex may have.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, first of all thank you for having considered this special report of the European Ombudsman on Frontex and for your follow-up on this very same report. I am aware of the main concern expressed in favour of an individual complaint mechanism in Frontex, and I took good note of the joint report recommending the inclusion of such provisions. The Commission will take the suggestions made in the report into account in its proposal for the future European border guard, which it will present later this month. We agree that the fundamental rights officer could be given a crucial role in handling complaints covering all personnel directly involved in Frontex operations.  The nature and the scope of such a mechanism will certainly be a subject for discussion in both Parliament and the Council. It is my intention to provide for a mechanism whereby the fundamental rights officer, as suggested by the co-rapporteurs, could receive complaints in a structural manner and whereby the appropriate workflows would be established for onward referral to the Member States concerned, and information subsequently obtained about the outcome of the investigation. On the one hand, this should be an administrative mechanism which would allow Frontex to maintain a degree of transparency and accountability, rendering its actions more credible towards the outside and also providing it with the means to deal with these issues internally. But at the same time this is also a fundamental rights tool, because we cannot forget that we are talking about people and ensuring that they are treated in a dignified way. That is why I believe that such a mechanism could be helpful for the credibility of European external borders support operations.  At a time when common external border management and shared responsibility are even more important in rendering the European Union’s migration and asylum policy more effective, we must also make sure that we are not a ‘fortress Europe’. More security goes hand in hand with a stronger and efficient protection mechanism of the fundamental rights of people. This exchange is extremely timely and I welcome the cross-party support for your report. Be assured that we are working to turn your proposals into concrete suggestions in the future legislation. I would like in particular to express my thanks to the two co-rapporteurs, Roberta Metsola and Ska Keller, for their excellent work and their help in our endeavours.

name: Kinga Gál
