text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I wish to congratulate the co-rapporteurs for their excellent work, and let me commend the work that Frontex is doing, with its highly qualified staff, in particular the support it provides to Member States at the EU’s external borders in coordinating the mass influx of migrants during the current immigration crisis. The work done by Frontex should not be underestimated. We should highlight the proactive approach to safeguarding human rights and the measures taken by Frontex with regard to the complaints mechanism. However, we have to acknowledge that the disciplinary measures against national law-enforcement officers participating in Frontex operations remain exclusively under Member State competence and that Frontex has no competence in initiating disciplinary measures against other persons, apart from its personnel, since it has only a coordination function. I wish to reiterate that Frontex is one of our best agencies, and the people who work for Frontex are of the highest integrity. Therefore, the Member States and the Commission should provide the necessary additional resources that it needs to function.

name: Miriam Dalli
text: f'isem il-grupp S&D. – Nibda billi nirringrazzja flower-korapporteurs u lix-shadow rapporteurs għall-mod kif ħdimna fuq dan ir-rapport. Fi大-大irkostanzi li qegħdin ngħixu fihom illum il-ġurnata l-Unjoni Ewropeja iva trid issaħħaħ il-ħidma tagħha biex tassigura l-fruntieri esterni tagħha. Imma biex verament l-Unjoni Ewropeja tibqa' Unjoni ta' valuri komuni, drittijiet umani u rispett rei大proku rridu nirrikonoxxu li kwalunkwe miżura ta' sigurtà trid tkun kumplimentata b'salvagwardji għad-drittijiet fundamentali tal-bniedem. I大-大avetta biex nilħqu dan il-bilan大 hija sempliikei. Irridu nirrikonoxxu li attitudni ta' qisu xejn m'hu xejn i taħdimx u ma taħdimx lanqas il-mentalità ta' stat militari. Mentalitajiet bħal dawn mhux biss inaqqsu l-valuri bażi大i tal-Unjoni Ewropeja imma jeqirdu dak kollu li ħdimna għalih. Ibbażat fuq dawn il-ħsibijiet, huwa ta' sodisfazzjoni għalijja li rnexxielna nassiguraw mekkaniżmu li ja大大erta li allegazzjonijiet ta' ksur tad-drittijiet tal-bnie demikunu investigati b'mod mill-aktar trasparenti u b'kontabilità, filwaqt li inkludejna salvagwardji li joffru opportunità lil min iressaq ilment ġustifikat biex jagħmel dan mingħajr biżgħa ta' xejn. Il-messaġ li rridu nwasslu huwa 大ar: id-drittijiet tal-bniedem huma sagrosanti u mhux negozzjabbli u s-sigurtà trid tkun ukoll fuq nett tal-aendaġ tagħna. Rubber ssarju Avramopolous, huwa ta' sodisfazzjon nisimgħak tgħid li se tinkludi dan l-aspett fil-European Border Guard Package li għandu jkun implimentat għaliex huwa d-dmir tagħhna li l-prinip大ji li nemmnu fihom nipproteġuhom.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – The migration crisis affecting Europe is a major challenge for Frontex. Its responsible action is demonstrated by its commitment to combating trafficking in human beings. Yet people smuggling, linked to the smuggling of drugs, weapons and, unfortunately, terrorism, is part of the phenomenon that we are currently facing.  We need to strengthen the External Borders of the European Union, to implement the return programme. This requires the strengthening of Frontex. I wanted to thank all the agency staff doing a great job.

name: Angelika Mlinar
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would also like to thank the co-rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs for their very constructive cooperation and for a very good result. This report is very timely, since the Commission will soon present a proposal to amend the Frontex Regulation. Parliament has delivered a balanced and workable proposal that will, hopefully, duly be considered. As pointed out by the European Ombudsman, the legal vacuum that surrounds the deployment of third—country officers during joint return operations, and the lack of accountability in cases of human rights violations involving third-country officers, can be dangerous. The mechanism proposed in the report could be a valid instrument to prevent the side effects of the current Frontex structure. Once again, I would like to underline that fundamental rights are not optional. It is during difficult times, rather than fair weather days, that we cannot take them for granted and we have to fight for them.  The influx of refugees cannot be a reason for the EU institutions to accept and tolerate violations of fundamental rights against vulnerable people. We cannot turn a blind eye – now more than ever.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to make it clear that the Frontex Agency is designed for the armour of borders. The Frontex agency is an instrument of the insolidarian Europe, of the Europe of walls and fences, of The Europe complicit that the Mediterranean has become a great mass grave. Therefore, the Frontex agency's own activity is itself a violation of human rights. Frontex is synonymous with mass deportations, breach of fundamental rights at borders, racist raids and military operations in the Mediterranean to prevent the arrival of migrants. Because of this border control, thousands of people have no choice but to put their lives in the hands of the Mafias in order to reach Europe. "Frontex staff watched from the deck of their boat as Turkish, Greek and NGO volunteers saved lives," said a volunteer a few weeks ago who was involved in the rescue of a three hundred-hundred-person vessel heading to Lesbos. Frontex and respect for fundamental rights are a contradiction, and this is not resolved by a mechanism for filing complaints. To guarantee fundamental rights at borders, Frontex must be dismantled, border defence ended and the walls of this fortress Europe knocked down.

name: Bodil Valero
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for In theory, we have the same basic values in europe, but in practice we do not always share our view of what human rights actually mean and, in particular, with regard to women's and children's rights. For me, it is very important that all the officials who first meet the refugees who come to us have a good view of what human rights actually mean. I mean both Frontex officials and those who come and are visiting officials.  What is very important in this context is that you also get a good education for everyone who works with Frontex. However, it is not only good training that we need, but we must also ensure that officials who do not actually do not do so do not have a renewed mandate or that those countries that regularly send officials who may not meet the human rights requirements are not given a renewed task of sending people.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank the two co-rapporteurs, Mrs Metsola and Mrs Keller, for their excellent work and also all the other shadow rapporteurs. It is an extremely important report, which comes at an extremely important and necessary time, it is necessary because the provision of a mechanism that guarantees the possibility of making individual complaints to third parties such as NGOs, law firms, is something that can no longer be postponed and therefore it would have been preferable in our opinion that the dealing of complaints had been managed by a body with greater guarantees of independence; we had provided for a panel of independent experts, so as to ensure greater objectivity, greater third-party ness, but nevertheless we hope that the mechanism proposed in the report will still be able to guarantee the objectivity and impartiality necessary in the handling of the appeal. The hope is that the Commission will follow up these recommendations in order to ensure information, transparency and clear procedures to protect fundamental rights in the context of Frontex's operations.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, three of the Islamist terrorists who killed 130 people in Paris arrived in France through Greece by infiltrating the migrants. This tragedy should have prompted the European Union to tighten its immigration policy. On the contrary, it chose to persist in the error. This report illustrates this: it aims to facilitate migrants' appeals against Frontex agents by citing alleged violations of fundamental rights. The maneuver is obvious, it is a question of further reducing the possibility of deportation; Appeals will take time. NGOs will explain to migrants that they have to be deposited to gain a few more months of stay and at the end of the day, no one will be deported. Already at present, the Union is barely able to keep out one in three irregular migrants: this willfulness is unacceptable. It is the protection of the security and identity of Europeans that should be our priority, not the opening of our borders.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). – Frontex, one of the European Union's flagship repressive mechanisms, is being reinforced with rapid intervention forces "RABIT" to treat tortured refugees and migrants as invaders. According to numerous complaints, Frontex is responsible for inhumane treatment, obstruction in the rescue of lives that are trying to save themselves from the fire of wars lit in their countries by the European Union and its allies, the United States and NATO. The report's proposals to set up a mechanism by which the complained Frontex itself will 'allegedly' monitor the complaints made against it are a source of concern. Frontex's invocation of border guard, in particular Greek, land and sea, in agreement with the Syrian-ANEL government, poses serious risks to the country's sovereign rights, linked to the bargaining and competition of the Greek bourgeoisie with the Turkish, for geopolitical influence in the region. We call for the abolition of European Union repression mechanisms such as Frontex and the Schengen Agreement, and we call for human reception and accommodation centres, as well as the immediate transfer of refugees and migrants to their countries of destination ...  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the co-applicants, my colleague Metsola and Mrs Keller, for agreeing to carry out this report and accepting the complaint made at the time by the European Ombudsman, in which he called for a mechanism to deal with possible violations of fundamental rights. Europe is the benchmark on fundamental rights, and this takes a step further in this commitment of the European Union to respect for the rights of all these groups.  Borders are of all Europeans and their control is a responsibility of the European Union as a whole. Frontex has as its main mission the integrated management of these external borders of the Union, but also cooperation with all national authorities in the management of these borders. There is no doubt that being able to accept these individual claims, dismissing those that do not take place, will strengthen this mechanism, offering special protection to vulnerable groups such as immigrants, women, children, the disabled and LGTBI groups.

name: Edouard Martin (S&D).
text: Madam President, I also join in the congratulations of the two co-reporters and the shadow rapporteurs. More justice and fairness. If we were to sum up the Frontex resolution in two words, they would be: justice and fairness. The coincidence of the calendar meant that we finalized this resolution a few days before the deadly attacks in Paris. So, of course, all eyes are on refugees and of course, many stigmatize them a little more. Europe, despite the dramatic difficulties of the moment, will continue to be a welcoming place for those fleeing barbarism. All the more reason to revisit the role of Frontex: because the situation is dramatic and the climate is nauseating, it is essential that fundamental rights are actually respected.  This inalienable principle is enshrined in the resolution. Frontex will have an obligation to set up an independent internal complaints mechanism. The agency will no longer be able to be a judge and a party and will no longer be able to play the nebula's excuse. And in dealing with complaints, special attention will be paid to pregnant women and unaccompanied minors. In order for them to exercise these rights, refugees will receive information in the ten most spoken languages. Finally, in addition to enhanced cooperation with third countries, Frontex will need to work better with agencies such as the Fundamental Rights Agency and the European Asylum Support Office. The latter, which is present in all Member States, is not sufficiently used; in this time of crisis, it can be an indispensable tool.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the refugee crisis is a great challenge for all European nations. In fact, our values have already been compromised by the clumsy actions of the national authorities of some countries. We should not sacrifice our values in the name of security and public order, because they are actually both based on respect for human dignity and fundamental rights. The problem addressed in the special report by the European Ombudsman is a shame for Europe. It is intolerable that there is no efficient individual complaints mechanism to deal with the human rights violations during Frontex operations. People who are entering Europe in search of protection must not be maltreated without an efficient way to demand justice. The refugee crisis is proof of Europe’s ability to protect its values and to respect fundamental rights. Let us not forget: Europe starts at the European borders.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I am in favour of human rights, but there is a risk that human rights will be used dishonestly. That is what I am concerned about when I read this report. I fear that this will only lead to even more opportunities for illegal migrants to remain in Europe by complaining and appealing.  A proposal designed to give illegal or economic migrants and bloodthirsty war criminals additional opportunities to sabotage the law and prevent them from being deported back to their home countries. Everyone who comes to the EU has the right to seek asylum, but with this proposal you go further than is necessary. Let Frontex do its job and don't put the hook for them.

name: Michał Marusik (ENF).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! Frontex is an institution on the front. In Poland, the name is even very similar: the front is the border that distinguishes our territory from the territory with us competing, very often hostile territory. If we soldiers on the front line, instead of fighting, have to stand trial, then competition and enemies will not only defeat us, but they will still ridicule us. We would just be pathetic. Frontex works badly, ineptly and its functioning should not be deteriorated yet. This should be improved as far as possible, and it is probably best to replace frontex with an institution that will fulfil this role quickly, efficiently and effectively. Frontex is supposed to defend us, not paralyze and not weaken us, and not ridicule us from the whole world. We really need to start defending our own territory. That is what this Frontex is called for.

name: József Nagy (PPE).
text: – First of all, I would also like to thank the co-rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteur colleagues for their work. It is very positive that Parliament is responding to the Ombudsman's concerns, because it is really important that there is a complaints mechanism in relation to frontex procedures that actually works. But this must be set with a very high sensitivity, so that the underdimensed Frontex is not bullied with administrative burdens and conditions are not laid down for abuse. It would therefore be wrong to involve third parties unjustifiably in the complaints mechanism. However, we need to develop a simple and sensible way of representing unaccompanied minors and disabled people.  Frontex is expected to have key responsibilities in external border protection and in the implementation of the Recovery Directive in the coming months and years. We therefore need to develop adequate financial and human resources for the complaints mechanism.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the excellent work of the rapporteurs, which is certainly not simple, has succeeded in creating a very balanced text, where there is, on the one hand, the introduction of human rights and the possibility of individual complaints, and, on the other, of avoiding abuses precisely and it was certainly not easy at the beginning when we started working on the text. In addition, I would also like to mention the commitment made by the Italian delegation, particularly with regard to the introduction of vulnerable persons and pregnant women and children, and a fair means has also been created, a fair compromise, with regard to anonymous complaints which, on the one hand, cannot be made and, on the other hand, the possibility is also given by a third party. , on people with good faith, to be able to make complaints as well.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this report is not a report on the nature of Frontex or its justification as an agency in the constellation of the area of freedom, justice and security, but on what this Parliament can do to strengthen Frontex's commitment to the latest reform of its Rules of Procedure.  A commitment to fundamental rights and therefore to make Frontex agents specialized, identify as such by emblems and also have a specific commitment to particularly vulnerable groups, especially in terms of gender and discrimination based on sexual orientation.  However, above all, allowing Frontex's Executive Director to exclude agents who do not strictly comply with protocols and the Regulation linking the agency to the observance of the fundamental rights enshrined in a Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union which does not discriminate between Europeans and non-Europeans in order to affirm the European Union's commitment to fundamental rights.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear President, the security challenges in Europe were not greater than the time of the defence war in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, and here we analyze our security needs and the activities of the security agency on the basis of the 2012 initiative and the report submitted in 2013 when this current threat did not even exist.  Of course the legislative and administrative procedure should be respected, but I believe that citizens expect from us security measures based on what will be in two years, not on what has been in past years. In addition to the conclusions of the Valletta meeting, this report also focuses on the human rights of migrants instead of the safety of our citizens. Today, when our external borders are under enormous pressure, it is somewhat absurd to suggest an increase in frontex employees for processing received lawsuits about human rights violations of migrants if these human resources could be used much better to protect the safety of our citizens who finance all this.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I can't help feeling that in all the discussions we have when we talk about Frontex, when we talk about the Dublin system, we kind of show that we weren't ready for everything that happened to us. Even in this case, when we talk about Frontex, which I support, which needs to be strengthened, which we will need significantly in the coming years, because this crisis with migrants will last for a number of years and will not end tomorrow or the day after tomorrow, but I do not know what kind of time frame it will even determine.  And we need Frontex, but Frontex which will really simultaneously be both agency and people who will be trained and understand human rights problems and protect those rights that immigrants and people who want to come to Europe have. In this context, I support this report by our rapporteurs.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). – The European Ombudsman's proposal to set up a personal complaints office would be correct if we took all the parameters into account. When we legislate as a Parliament, we must take into account fundamental rights and specificities, sexual, religious, etc., with regard to immigrants. But we must not ignore reality: Frontex is a service which, on the basis of its composition and service capabilities, is unable to cope with migration flows. Here, entire Member States are building fences and restoring cross-border controls to contain the waves of migrants. Imagine that if of the 2 million migrants expected, even 10,000 complained, true or false, the system would collapse. Instead of dealing with the recording and provision of assistance, which is Frontex's main task, we will fall into a series of investigations, legal details and language difficulties. Illegal immigrants, in particular, will hinder the work of the authorities, require their entry into the Schengen area and make it difficult for them to repatriate. The problems will only be solved if we shield the structures. They need recruitment of qualified staff, better training, adequate materials.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the establishment of an individual complaints mechanism as proposed by the European Ombudsman is, of course, necessary. Nonetheless, I believe that this report is absolutely not the basis for questioning the competences of the Frontex Agency.  The proposed provisions applicable to the Frontex fundamental rights policy must adhere to reasonable procedure so as not to block the execution of Frontex duties. The mechanism must provide legal safeguards which balance the need to protect fundamental rights with the possible misuse of the right to complain. That is the reason why I believe that, in general, anonymous complaints should not be considered admissible. Finally, let us have in mind that our voice here can contribute greatly to the soon—to—be—published European Commission proposals for the revision of the Frontex Regulation.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Thank you very much for the opportunity, Madam President. Indeed, I believe that the majority of Parliament believes that special attention should be paid to how Frontex, i.e. the staff of the border protection bodies, the European border protection bodies, are treated and how human rights are respected. However, these recent experiences and recommendations might also be worth recommending to some Member States, because not a few member state authorities – I can mention one specifically: the Hungarian authorities – are, to put it mildly, very insan in their treatment of refugees. They are fed as animals, they are punched and slaughtered, immediate expulsion is the consequence of the entry of each refugee into Hungary, and these often have tragic consequences. So when Hungary country criminalises and, unfortunately, criminalises refugees when they are being punched and punched by the Hungarian authorities, I do not think that it deserves further attention. Thank you very much!

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like, once again, to express my thanks for your fruitful contribution to this debate. The Commission has paid – and will continue to pay – great attention to your special report about the need for an individual complaint mechanism in Frontex. As I have said, your work on this matter could not have come at a more timely moment. As you know, I will soon be tabling the promised proposal for the future European border guards. I will obviously take into account the suggestions made in the report.

name: Roberta Metsola
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, in my introduction I failed to thank both Frontex and the European Ombudsman. If it were not for the European Ombudsman, we would not be here today discussing a recommendation to ultimately make such an important agency for our Union better. For those colleagues who are questioning the timeliness of this, I want to thank you, Commissioner, for accepting and listening to us, and we look forward very much to the upcoming review of the Frontex regulation. This is why we chose – and we also thank the colleagues in this room – to accept an accelerated procedure for the adoption of this report today.  There is a legal mandate for Frontex to make sure that fundamental rights are observed in all its activities, and what this report seeks to do is to properly institute the possibility for a person submitting a complaint to make sure that the complaint is actually received. What happens today is that external complaints are not transmitted properly to Member States, with the result that you can have vulnerable persons whose fundamental rights may have been breached during a Frontex operation. What this report says is that such complaints should be admissible. This report also says that this should not prejudice Frontex’s operations and its prerogatives to save lives. Of course, this should not in any way jeopardise Frontex’s aim of ensuring the secure and effective management of our border controls. This report, in my opinion, is perfectly in sync with what Parliament feels this important agency should be doing. We now leave it up to Frontex – as my colleague Ska Keller said – and we hope such a mechanism is instituted as soon as possible, because it will make such an important agency operate more efficiently and better in line with its mandate.

name: Ska Keller
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you for your contributions! I would also like to thank you very much, Commissioner, for taking up Parliament's request and for including a complaint mechanism now in the next Frontex mandate. Thank you for that. I believe that the complaints mechanism is a really important step towards better protection of human rights at the external borders. Of course, this does not solve all the problems we have with human rights that we have at the external borders – that is quite clear. However, I believe that this will bring us a little more justice at the external borders, so that refugees and migrants do not feel vulnerable to border guards, but also to Frontex, so that the Frontex agency can better verify where human rights violations actually happen, why they happen and how we can better prevent them in the future.  I think that we have put forward a proposal here that is also feasible, that is feasible for refugees – even if refugees are concerned or if they are afraid – and which is also feasible for Frontex, even when it comes to posted officials from the Member States. For this too, I believe that we have found a very good, a workable and feasible, effective way of ensuring that Frontex can nevertheless deal with these requests, these complaints, pass them on, and see that the refugees, migrants and migrants also receive an answer. But it is, of course, quite clear that we are within the scope of Frontex's competences. I really believe that we have worked well together – thanks again to the shadow rapporteurs and my co-rapporteur – and that we have put forward a really good compromise that is really feasible. And I very much hope that we will see the first results in the future.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Since the migrant flows from North Africa and the Middle East have reached unprecedented levels, I view the Ombudsman’s recommendations to set up a complaints mechanism within Frontex as a very positive step in order to protect the human rights of those entering the EU. It is necessary to overcome the agency’s accountability and transparency problems with the external agencies’ border control practices, and to ensure that the staff working for or with Frontex fully comply with the EU’s Charter of Fundamental rights.  This can be achieved only if Frontex sets up a monitoring mechanism to deal with complaints of breaches of human rights internally. Since Frontex would be dealing with breaches of human rights mainly related to non-Frontex staff (national guards), it would help to keep the impartiality of the complaint mechanism, make the national border guards accountable and not immune to impunity, and overcome the existing accountability gap.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. – (2008) I congratulate Mrs Metsola and Ska Keller on their excellent work following the Ombudsman's timely initiative. Since its inception, Frontex has been developing and gaining an increasingly essential role in the control of external borders. Today it is even more clear that we need a Frontex that is up to the challenges we face: able to support member states with the greatest migratory pressure and to play a leading role in return operations. We want to ensure that in the future we will be prepared for crises like this, as we have been asking so many times in this Parliament. The evolution of the Agency, however, was being - and well! - accompanied by increased scrutiny and transparency from Frontex, especially while respecting fundamental rights. It is the other side of the coin of an extension of powers. Only in dictatorships are police forces not subject to controls on respect for citizens' rights. That is why the mechanism we are debating today, and - I hope - we will approve, is even more acuity: it would already be a step in the right direction, but it is necessary in the face of the future role of this Agency. I therefore hope that the European Commission's proposal will already reflect this position of the European Parliament.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. – The European Ombudsman's report clearly and unequivocally shows that Frontex must respect and respect human rights. At the same time, Frontex and the EU must respect the national sovereignty of the Member States of the Union and in particular their exclusive and sovereign right to guard their borders. Because this, Commissioner, a moment ago in the debate on Turkey was attempted to be challenged in this Chamber. My country, Greece, can't stand other refugees and illegal immigrants. The Aegean islands have been flooded by the thousands of poor refugees in Syria. And the European Union, instead of solving the problem in the impoverished Greece, distributing refugees to all EU Member States on the basis of the GDP, population and extent of each country, as I have repeatedly stressed, is proceeding to finance Turkey with EUR 3 billion on the refugee issue, leaving Greece to deal with refugee flows with crumbs. Hot spots should therefore be created immediately in Turkey, and development aid should be given to African countries to stop illegal immigration from there and, finally, efforts to resolve the Syrian crisis peacefully should be intensified.

name: Julia Pitera (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – An independent agency within the European Union – Frontex – was established by the Council of the EU Regulation of 26 October 2004. Over the course of several years of its operation, it has been a frequent subject of criticism from the European Parliament. Mainly because of the insufficient transparency of their actions, in particular as regards human rights violations, i.e. the return of refugees without verifying their right to asylum. The Ombudsman decided to include in his last report a specific request for the creation of a mechanism for the submission and handling of individual complaints. This would be of great importance to Frontex, especially as this need is the result of an increasing number of humanitarian and legal challenges at the EU's external borders. It would thus become the first instance body responsible for dealing with these complaints and would contribute to increased transparency and respect for fundamental rights in the context of Frontex's working arrangements. However, I would like to stress that this mechanism should be based on accessibility, independence, effectiveness and transparency criteria and on an information campaign that includes many aspects, including language. Thanks to such a campaign and a well-structured procedure for the control and admissibility of complaints, assistance to complainants will be more visible and respect for human rights more respected at our external borders.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. – The concern of the originator of this report for respect for human rights with regard to economic migrants and asylum seekers is to be admired. But turning Frontex into an institution to deal with alleged violations of immigrant rights is unacceptable. The aim of the establishment of Frontex is to defend and protect the EU's borders and, during this period, to prevent, by specific means, the entry of people who could trigger attacks such as the one in Paris. It is welcome to recommend the creation of a mechanism for refugees to report possible human rights violations, but it has no reason to set up within Frontex, which is an operational institution and must be a body whose purpose is the safety of the EU and its citizens. By giving Frontex and another, mostly bureaucratic, mission, the Commission will only diminish its ability to cope effectively with the mission entrusted to the establishment, and i therefore i think it would be a mistake at this time when the EU's borders are to be weakened. I therefore believe that measures must be taken to strengthen and increase Frontex's responsiveness to ensure the security of the EU's borders and not invent bureaucratic obstacles.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. – This mechanism, which Frontex should put in place, is undoubtedly important and necessary given the increased number of people coming to the EU. However, it must be ensured that it operates effectively and only deal with relevant complaints. Therefore, I am unequivocally in order to prevent applications from being submitted anonymously in order to prevent abuse of this system. In any case, the identity of the persons who lodged the complaint must be protected and their data treated very carefully.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. – I support the report and congratulate my colleague Roberta Metsola on her good work. I support the establishment of a complaint mechanism. Such a mechanism must, after all, be any similar organisation. The fact is, however, that refugees, migrants and asylum seekers will be able to put a great deal of strain on the new rights and, above all, to increase the agency's operations. This will certainly happen if the right to an anonymous complaint is enforced. However, I would like to stress that we are living in a time when we have to worry even more about establishing the most effective service that will actually protect the external borders of the European Union, which is why it was ultimately established. In practice, Frontex all too much looks like a paper tiger. It has no executive powers; a group of visiting officials working with the authorities of a Member State. Today, when external borders have fallen and European security is under threat, we need a strong and effective Frontex to be able to carry out its mission, and which, of course, also respects the HPP.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on Karima Delli's report, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on sustainable urban mobility (2014/2242(INI)) (A8-0319/2015).

name: Karima Delli
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow 80% of Europeans will live in cities: that is why mobility should be a right for all. For those people who travel to work or to look for them, for these people - and these young people especially - who are going to study, for those people who go to the dentist or the doctor, and for those who go to the cinema or the stadium to have fun: basically, mobility is our daily life.  However, much remains to be done to ensure that mobility benefits everyone, as it is still far from being chosen; most of the time, it is suffered, because of traffic jams, because of the loss of time, because of air pollution. The cause is the excessive use of the individual car, which works with traditional fuels. Cities were built for cars: let's return the cities to the inhabitants, because there is a climate emergency - we are in the middle of COP 21. Urban transportation alone accounts for 25% of greenhouse gas emissions. It is up to us to reverse this trend if we want the European Union to meet its emissions targets by 2030. There is also a health emergency: in 2015, breathing kills. 400,000 premature deaths per year are due to fine particulate matter emitted by diesel engines. Is it necessary, when we have pollution peaks, that we sequester pregnant women, children, the elderly so that they keep lungs intact? There is no longer time to wait: pollution is the disease of the 21st century, as the United Nations acknowledges. There is also an urgency with regard to our independence. The energy consumption needed for our transport makes us too dependent on oil dictatorships, now in the spotlight. There is also an urgent need for the lives of road users. 38% of road traffic deaths occur in urban areas. How can we reduce the number of deaths in the city if we do not reduce the use of cars? And finally, there is a social emergency: 25 million European households are the new mobility insecure, because they have little or no access to public transport, or because these transport are too expensive. So, another mobility is not only possible, but it is above all indispensable. If we want to rethink the way we move, we must take into account the social, environmental, economic and democratic impacts of transport. We must take into account current and future generations. To achieve this, the European Union must set ambitious targets. In the midst of COP 21, let's put energy efficiency at the heart of our urban mobility policies. This will, like it or not, be through the exit of diesel, by the disappearance of our urban centres from traditional petrol cars by 2050. This will also involve the development of clean transport: tram, cable car, bicycle, car sharing, which generate jobs. This will involve the modal deferral of the road to the river, the road to the railway, but also through intermodality through the combination of walking, cycling and public transport.  There are very, very many obstacles. The lobbies of all kinds are there; we are talking in particular about this famous automobile lobby, the proponents of the status quo, who, as we know, will do everything to ensure that these proposals do not come to life. But let's not forget our responsibility. Ambitious legislation is needed if this Commission - your Commission, Commissioner - is really to be the last chance, as Mr Juncker says and reminds us. The Europeans are waiting for us at the turn and are counting on us to move forward. So I say: let us not disappoint them, urban mobility must absolutely be a priority.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the report Members are adopting today is the result of very intensive and fruitful work. It is comprehensive, inspiring and – I am happy to say – to a large extent in line with the Commission’s thinking. I would like to thank the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteur and everyone who worked on the report. There were more than 500 amendments, which demonstrates how much thought and energy went into it. The report showed that cities are of an ever—growing importance for all of us, quite simply because more and more of us are living in the city – 80% of Europeans live in urban areas. So it is logical that we have to tackle some serious challenges in urban areas: congestion, demographic change, road safety, access to mobility and air pollution, including CO2. The report reflects these challenges and proposes solutions that can be manifested. I will not go through all of them, but will mention only three that I find particularly important at this point. First, sustainability and urban mobility plans. These have proven to be a very useful instrument and show that voluntary instruments can work very well. This is encouraging for our efforts to support cities through the exchange of best practices and guidance. So, I would ask Members, when back in their constituencies, to support the Commission in promoting these. An intelligent transport system is the second area. Members may be aware that the Commission is running a platform for Cooperative Intelligent Transportation Systems (C—ITS). The aim is to deploy C—ITS as soon as possible, EU—wide, in a coordinated manner. Cities would greatly benefit from this. More generally, the report recognises the incredible potential that digitalisation offers for individual mobility and city logistics. We fully agree on this point. Digitalisation of transport is therefore a personal priority for me as well.  The third area is investment and innovation. Both are key enablers for jobs and growth. Let us reflect together on how we can support cities in attracting more investment and how this investment can support innovation and how innovation can support sustainability. The report confirms that innovation in urban mobility offers huge opportunities. Just take clean transport and the multiple benefits that decarbonisaton of transport offers. Let us stop associating decarbonisation with cost and start thinking of it in terms of investment. With urbanisation as a global mega-trend, I am convinced that it will really pay off and will contribute to the Commission’s agenda for growth and new jobs. Let me also mention EFSI at this point, which is an appropriate mechanism to address its needs.  Urban mobility is such a rich topic that I would need to mention many more issues to be complete – road safety, the sharing economy, active mobility, EFSI, SAVE and the cohesion funds, multimodality and many more. But now it is time for the debate. I am really looking forward to hearing Members’ concrete comments and I will be very happy to respond to their proposals at the end of the debate.

name: Henna Virkkunen
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, cities really should invest in smooth transport. It is important not only for the economy, for the environment, but also for people in general, for urban transport to be smooth and as efficient as possible. It saves both money and people's time.  All modes of transport will continue to be needed in cities. We need cars, rail transport, walking, cycling, water transport. There are different possibilities across Europe. That is why it is important for the EPP Group that cities themselves are able to choose the best solutions that are most effective and the best in their own region.  It was good to hear about the Commission's priorities, they are very much in the right direction. Digitalisation in particular gives us a lot of opportunities for smart transport solutions, new consumer-friendly services like Carsharing, Uber. These opportunities are worth taking advantage of. Similarly, new technologies will enable more environmentally friendly transport.

name: Lucy Anderson
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, it is important that the European Union consider the great variety of all of our towns, cities and rural areas when discussing policy and legislation. This is an excellent and collaborative report that fully takes account of both the common and particular transport issues faced by people across the EU living in different urban communities. I am very pleased also that our report focuses constructively on innovation in the area of freight. As our rapporteur said, urban areas account for around a quarter of European carbon emissions from transport and so, Commissioner, we urgently need genuinely sustainable mobility for goods and for our economies. I would like your comments on that point. On road safety, it is especially welcome that the report calls strongly for advanced traffic and speed management measures, including enforcement. As elected representatives, we must recognise and act on the fact that a large majority of Europeans think that road safety in cities is a serious problem. Many, many cyclists and pedestrians are killed or seriously injured in our cities in Europe every year. What, Commissioner, are you going to do about that?  Towns and cities are also often unequal places with extreme divisions between rich and poor. As acknowledged by this report, good public transport has important social and economic benefits, as well as environmental ones, helping people gain access to jobs and get out of poverty. Socialists and Democrats are delighted that many of our long-term priorities that I have just highlighted are in this text, and I urge all MEPs to vote for the amendment. There is only one amendment to this report. We all agree that fossil fuel subsidies should be phased out, so please vote for that amendment.

name: Evžen Tošenovský
text: on the ecr group. – Commissioner, as former Mayor of Ostrava and Governor of the Moravian-Silesian Region, I have many years of personal experience with mobility issues in urban areas. In these positions, I have been in frequent contact with colleagues from all over Europe, so I know that every region, every city has specific conditions and different needs due to its history. And we must respect them as well as strictly respect the principle of subsidiarity. I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for taking into account part of our comments. Nevertheless, a number of problematic provisions remain on the table. I have question marks, for example, on sustainable urban mobility plans, and I do not agree with the attempt to ban diesel engines first and then all vehicles for traditional fuels. We should certainly support urban mobility projects, but I am against the earmarking of EU funds or the proceeds from motorway charging. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, I understand that you agree that we need what the rapporteur and those who have worked on the report have said here, we need sustainability, urban mobility and, in the end, you have said that you still have a problem with the fact that the use of diesel would be prohibited by amendments, to put it concretely. The Commissioner spoke here about the decarbonisation of transport – let us see it as an investment. What do you think: can you look at the decarbonisation of transport as an investment and how?

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I certainly agree that sustainable urban traffic is needed, mobility is very important. But a one-time effort to ban a certain type doesn't mean we're going to solve traffic. Decarbonization can go in different directions, it can be quality, scientific research. We don't know what's going to happen in two or three years in the automotive market. I am very humble and very much worship scientific progress as such.

name: Matthijs van Miltenburg
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Every city in Europe is different. Urban mobility therefore requires a local approach. However, Europe must give direction, direction when it comes to meeting climate and environmental targets, to promote flow and road safety, and to allow cities to learn from each other in Europe. Let us focus on intelligent transport systems, mutually communicating cars, clean electric transport, high-quality public transport.  But it can be even smarter, it can be even cheaper. Europe must go on its bikes. Many Europeans travel very small distances in their city. Look at my homeland, the Netherlands, where we prefer to take the bike than the car in the city. That's better for health, it's better for the wallet, and that's better for the quality of life in the cities. So, in Europe, let us focus on raising awareness as a stepping stone to more sustainable urban mobility.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, urban transport accounts for a quarter of co2 emissions from transport and up to 70% of other transport emissions. Listening to these figures, oxygen runs out and weak.  Although the Volkswagen case that boiled over during the autumn is a pity, it has at least opened our eyes. I am saddened, however, that in all the groups in this House there was no genuine willingness to set unambiguous objectives. Subsidiarity is an important principle, but too often you hide behind it when you need active action instead of sharing pain. The aim is to sanctify motoring, which is the largest producer of urban transport emissions and the cause of accidents, noise and congestion, on the altar of European urban life, where urban comfort, population and issues relating to the health and safe living conditions of residents are sacrificed.  Hopefully, the Commission will be prepared to take a bolder step forward towards the Member States.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In your explanatory statement for this resolution, you write: '... Member States to shift traffic from road to water and rail." However, there is no full concept here. Most cities in Europe can be reached by water. Heavy goods traffic could be handled to a large extent by these waterways. I am also experiencing the opposite in the case of rail. Thousands of long-distance buses have been in existence for over two years. In many cases, all or most passenger traffic is shifted from rail to road, which puts an additional burden on driver safety, the environment and additional traffic congestion. Therefore, this concept, which is otherwise quite good, should be further developed.

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE).
text: It is now an open secret that the creation of this report was not easy. The rapporteur is from the Greens and the Greens have very explicit ideas on urban development and urban mobility. The main point of discussion was constantly subsidiarity. What is Europe going to say to the cities? What is Europe leaving to the cities? In drawing up this report, subsidiarity will still be a major point of discussion. Nevertheless, Mr President, we must innovate and we must make cities cleaner. You won't be able to do that without classic cars, especially in the suburbs. But at least we have an initiative report with a result. Good luck!

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: Madam President, urban mobility is one of the major challenges of the 21st century because it is at the crossroads of the three pillars of sustainable development: ecology, the economy and social. To work for sustainable urban mobility means making a concrete contribution to the fight against air pollution and global warming. With transport accounting for 25% of CO2 emissions, increasing urbanization and hundreds of thousands of people dying each year from air pollution, we have a political responsibility to make sustainable mobility one of the key issues facing European policies. I therefore call on all colleagues to support Amendment No 1, which raises the fundamental issue of diesel and calls for initiatives to move towards clean fuels and get out of diesel-friendly subsidies. Working for sustainable urban mobility also means combating social exclusion and ensuring territorial cohesion. This is a fundamental aspect of mobility issues and I regret that, during the debate in committee, the right blocked amendments aimed at strengthening the social dimension of the report.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The life of city dwellers undoubtedly has, in addition to decisive advantages, also disadvantages. Communication problems are undoubtedly one of them. Traffic jams, the high number of fatalities, the lack of sufficient parking spaces or inadequate infrastructure for pedestrians and cyclists are the ills of everyday life for many Eu citizens. It is difficult to imagine a situation when these problems disappear completely, but we can permanently reduce their nuisance. An extensive public transport network taking into account the wide use of trams and other rail vehicles is a solution that is uncho doubtful. However, other road users, including pedestrians and cyclists, should not be forgotten, who should be better protected in urban space. However, despite the unappealed proposals contained in this report, I cannot accept such a one-dimensional treatment of motor vehicle users – a friendly urban space must also take into account these people and these vehicles.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Of course, urban mobility is an issue for EU funding programmes, exchange of experience, best practice – but is it a legislative issue for us? Rather not, that is why this report is already trying to examine the general limit values for car exhaust fumes. This must be discussed, but certainly not in this report! And then there are the bicycles: of course, we have subscribed to responsibility in Brussels for well-being issues. The Luxembourg Transport Council can think of nothing better than to convene a bicycle summit with 28 transport ministers. Do we have no other problems in Europe? Ladies and gentlemen, our shadow rapporteur has tried a great deal, has also steered some things in a sensible direction, but what remains are bicycle quotas, car-free Sundays, the ban on internal combustion engines. I am also in favour of improved urban mobility and I will also vote in favour of the report in this regard. But instead of car-free Sundays, we should take better care of urban problem areas, and instead of cycling quotas, I recommend that European attention be paid to refugee quotas, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you very much!

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D). –
text: Commissioner, tomorrow you will preside in Paris at COP 21, a key event, which aims to highlight the impact that the decarbonisation of the transport sector can have on economic recovery at European level. The European Parliament has been your best partner in these efforts, starting with the White Paper on transport and ending with a vote on tonight's report on sustainable urban mobility. Colleagues, in my six years as General Counsel of Bucharest, I understand that there is only one solution for our cities to prosper following the fourth industrial revolution: improving the environment, the quality of life and health of citizens by ensuring safe, rapid and sustainable urban mobility. As a European legislator, I have come to support these efforts by proposing measures related to efficient transport management, increasing the performance of logistics services, promoting public transport and, last but not least, informing citizens about alternative means of transport.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I do believe that inclusive urban mobility policies need to be promoted by encouraging the use of public transport and also less polluting transport. In fact, I believe that new forms of mobility supported by collaborative economy models should also be driven.  However, there is an issue i would like to leave and i could not pass up that is not to agree with the impositions that are made for the creation of bicycle paths and the imposition of the use of bicycles. I also cannot agree with the elimination of cars in cities when many of these cities do not yet have alternative solutions. We need a balanced urban policy, not discriminating any type of transport, no mode of transport and, above all, respecting the principle of subsidiarity because I believe and believe that the implementation of mobility policies are the exclusive competence of municipalities and we cannot apply a measure to all ...  (The President takes the floor from the speaker.)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the climate, health and social emergency we are experiencing requires the clearest analysis: the European Union is the protagonist at COP21 in Paris on remedies to environmental disaster, but political commitment is threatened by the systematic manipulation of legislation by European producers. Following the Volkswagen scandal, I would like to be denied by the Commission that applying a compliance factor of 2.1 does not significantly weaken the Euro 6 emission standard and does not undermine the reliability and effectiveness of compliance tests, allowing the production of vehicles that emit more than twice the amount of ozone oxide set by Euro 6. If that were the case, it would be a very negative symptom of the car industry's ability to delay the establishment of a regulatory framework adapted to the ambitions of global necessity for quality of life, health and climate protection. I therefore agree with the report's priority focus on sustainable urban mobility on climate protection energy saving, on the need to restore space and infrastructure to citizens.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, as COP 21 is taking place – and I am very pleased that I will be one of those representing Parliament there next week – the discussions we are having today are very relevant. Firstly, we had a very good discussion on the Circular Economy, and now we are discussing sustainable urban mobility. Obviously, with 80% of people living in urban areas, this is a vital topic. In fairness, many citizens are now becoming more and more aware of the need to decarbonise as much as possible. In urban areas especially, we can do an awful lot.  I would like to compliment particular groups in my own country, like the Tidy Towns Committees, which have done a tremendous amount in terms of cleaning up the town, ensuring walkways, cycle lanes, etc. However, some of that is outside their control and we have to do an awful lot, particularly in the area of transport. We need bypasses in towns to keep traffic that does not necessarily have to go through the town out of the town and to give the town back to its citizens, in particular, so that they can have a good quality of life.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, sustainable urban mobility projects are directly linked to the promotion of sustainable urban transport. Given that 80% of Europeans will soon be living in cities and considering that more than 30% of serious road injuries take place in urban areas, accessibility to work and services for all and safety in citizens' mobility should first be ensured. In addition, the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of means of transport should be improved and the attractiveness of the urban environment in general should be increased. At the same time, the European Union should support every local authority and increase funding for urban mobility in order to improve it. Given that 40% of carbon dioxide emissions are due to traffic problems in large cities, binding targets should be set to reduce the pollutants caused.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would, of course, first of all like to thank the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs for the work done. I believe that the key to addressing the long-term problems of European cities with transport exhalations and congestion is the promotion of public transport and the need for better organisation, especially when it comes to connecting suburban areas with urban centres. Good access to public transport is a prerequisite for greater use. The further development of new transport technologies and telematic applications that offer opportunities to find optimal routes will undoubtedly have a major impact on the smoothness of mobility in cities. Another serious problem is the protection of vulnerable road users. For them, however, there must first and foremost be a secure infrastructure with adequate scope for their movement, so that our appeal to the use of sustainable mobility methods is credible.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am proud to have participated in the organization of the first Car-Free Day in Croatia 15 years ago. We wanted to raise awareness of the necessity of reducing cars in the centres of cities and increase the use of public transport.  Despite the efforts made across the European Union, it is evident that the urban transport sector is still the only sector where greenhouse gas emissions are rising. The population in cities is also growing, and in 15 years it is expected unfortunately that 4 out of 5 inhabitants of the European Union will live in cities.  Such statistics are devastating for sustainable space management, but also for quality of life. As the use of passenger cars still prevails in urban transport, there is an unbearable crowd, high noise levels and frequent traffic accidents.  This is why changes in urban mobility are necessary. A shift towards more efficient, energy-efficient, renewable-based public transport needs to be made and based on low-carbon technology. Public transport must be accessible to all citizens.

name: Ulrike Müller (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I welcome the report on sustainable urban mobility. It identifies the main challenges on the way to the digital age as a mobility structure has grown. Firstly, it is extremely important to take due account of regionally different needs and not to take the top-down approach here, but to support those responsible in the regions in developing concepts.  The platform for exchanging best examples can be a great help. We should also offer short-term solutions at European level on what standards for data provision can look like, so that providers and users of infrastructure and mobility services have access to the necessary information while ensuring credible data protection. I hope that this report will be used as an opportunity to create a higher priority for electromobility and that electric buses will be used in public transport.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: – It is very important that cities introduce sustainable urban development, digitisation, investment and innovation in urban transport as soon as possible. Sustainable mobility in the city means, for me, prudent use and combination of different forms of transport: cars, public transport, bicycles and walking, as each of them has both advantages and disadvantages. Good practices, for example in Denmark or the Netherlands, show that sustainable mobility is not a utopia. There is, of course, a need for a shift in our minds so that we do not associate the use of public transport or bicycles with effort. Science provides us with tools to change people's behavior. Behavioural economics examines and explains why consumers make the right choices. It is high time that we made better use of these lessons to develop more effective policies, including in promoting sustainable urban mobility.

name: Michael Cramer (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. The car murders our cities! "Those who sow roads will reap traffic!" – that was what the then very young mayor of Munich, the Social Democrat Hans-Jochen Vogel, said 43 years ago, in 1972. Even if all cars were electric tomorrow and all energy comes from renewable energy, the killing of cities would continue. In Germany, 100 hectares will disappear every day under concrete and asphalt. The German government also wants to reduce this to 30 hectares. On 8 October, the 28 transport ministers of the European Union unanimously adopted the Bicycle Roadmap – the German Transport Minister also raised his hand. This report states that more than half of freight traffic in European cities can be shifted to cargo bikes. Imagine: in Munich, in Paris, in Berlin, in London, half of the lorry traffic would disappear – that would be a nice vision, Commissioner! What can you do to incentivise the cargo bikes to get the width they need?

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – In view of the Commission's assessment that urban areas are responsible for 23% of CO2 emissions from transport and that, without taking appropriate measures, this situation will only be made worse by increasing urbanisation, I think we can all agree that urban mobility developments are one of the most important areas of action and can be part of our fight to reduce climate change.  It is therefore important to develop all our modes of transport from the perspective of sustainable development, taking into account the social, economic and environmental impacts of transport.  I believe that it is for the Commission and the Member States to promote a more efficient sharing of best and innovative practices for sustainable urban mobility and the establishment of public procurement systems in which environmental performance requirements are more important than they are now.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish to thank Members for all their comments and for the questions they raised. Allow me to comment a little bit more and give you more information about our next steps.  We are all becoming more and more aware of the multidimensional challenges that urban mobility presents. With the 2011 Transport White Paper, the Commission set the objective of a competitive and resource-efficient urban mobility. The urban mobility package of 2013 addressed in greater detail how to achieve these objectives, but this report gives new impetus to the implementation of that package.  With Parliament’s support, the Commission will concentrate efforts in the area where EU action can bring added value but with full respect for the subsidiarity principle. In particular, we are planning to: pursue a more holistic approach to smart, sustainable and resilient cities; further support cities, industry and R&I by promoting a marketplace for trading solutions; offer cities and innovative projects promoters support for real—life testing under Horizon 2020; help cities to use different EU funding opportunities, and to combine public and private investment, for instance from the European Fund for Strategic Investment; and run platforms – as one of you also mentioned – for exchange of practices, since at EU level this can have a much bigger impact than many think.  Let me now directly respond to some of your questions and comments.  As regards freight, by all means, you have full support for that from me. The 2011 White Paper already talked about nearly—zero—emissions city logistics by 2030, so green urban logistics are in our programme and in our minds.  The second question was on road safety, which is a very important element, especially for the most vulnerable in traffic. A lot of work has been done, but we are pushing Member States on a daily basis to do even more. We especially work very closely with the countries that statistics have shown to be the worst, with the direct involvement of all stakeholders in the country to bring fatalities figures close to zero in the future. By the way, bikes, as Mr Cramer and some other colleagues have mentioned, are one of the important elements of the green freight solutions in cities so yes, this topic will not go away and we will continue to address it and look for options on how to support it even further.  There were a couple of questions and comments regarding diesel. Clearly we need to improve the overall system that allows cars to be placed on the market – the type-approval system. We need more European oversight, effective control mechanisms and better quality and greater independence of vehicle testing. We need to move – and I fully support this – from lab testing to real driving emission tests for CO2 as soon as possible. At the same time, I do count on the electrification of transport being delivered, as we expect, in the near future. As regards awareness raising, the Commission for example has been promoting multimodality with the ‘Do the right mix’ campaign as part of European Mobility Week and has focused attention on walking and cycling in combination with an increased use of public and collective transport as a good way forward for all of us. Allow me also quickly to go back to the comment regarding cycling. Please, let us not underestimate the economic benefits that this brings, not only in health, but also the positive effects on congestion and CO2 and, of course, the positive effect on the transport industry. I welcome the Council’s declaration, and we will work within our mandate to support it.  Finally, allow me also just to say a couple more words regarding the overall subject. Long-term engagement at all levels of governance is key to making European cities smart, well-connected and green, and the Commission is ready to support the emergence of new ideas within our mandate. They are the stakeholders that can drive prosperity and offer quality jobs.  Within my portfolio, 2016 is the year for decarbonisation and I am sure that we will address urban mobility very comprehensively as part of that initiative. I am counting on Members’ support and am really looking forward to making our planet look even better than it does today.

name: Karima Delli
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to correct some of the comments made by my EPP colleagues. I would like to tell them that, in the report, it is not written: ban on the car. It says: ban on cars in city centres, especially from these cars to conventional fuel, as written in the white paper carried by Mr van de Camp. So let's not try to tell us what is not written in our report, let us restore the truth.  First of all, the solutions in this report are real. Let's set ambitious targets in terms of cycling in the city by 2025. Let's duplicate the mesh of public transport by 2030. Yes, let's create a European cycling day, let's generalize the car-free day. Let us encourage all Member States and cities to have sustainable urban mobility plans. Let's move towards the ambitious speed limit to limit deaths on our streets and make the car compatible with bikes and pedestrians. Let's relaunch freight as part of a European plan. Let us really invest in urban mobility a significant part of the Eurovignette, an important part of the Juncker plan but also of European funds. Finally, let us include in our mobility projects new practices including intelligent transport, I am talking about car sharing, carpooling.  All this will not be effective without a review of air quality legislation. For too long, Member States, including my own, have been prosecuted before the Court for failing to respect the limitations. The victims are the Europeans and the Europeans. They are the same people who are victims of diesel emissions fraud. So I say this, Commissioner, all this needs to be urgently reviewed in order to be more effective in the service of the health of citizens but also of the state of our planet.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The fight for a sustainable economy has always been one of our delegation's top priorities, and transport is undoubtedly one of the areas in which this battle must be pursued. The use of private cars with traditional fuels must slowly be replaced for the benefit of common public but also private and environmentally friendly means of transport. At the moment, with COP21 under way, it is important to stress the absolute need to stop the race for climate change, and the report voted on today goes in exactly this direction.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. – The report rightly points out that the development of innovative sustainable, environmentally friendly urban logistics strategies, including private and public bodies, is of the utmost importance for solving congestion and environmental problems in cities. It is rightly pointed out that logistics must be based on sustainable modes of transport, which calls for better optimisation of the supply chain in urban areas based on new, cost-effective types of operation, technology and business model. The Commission is therefore called upon to develop policies to encourage the freight sector to improve its fleet ecologically. An important report, which is rightly supported.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – More than 70% of the European Union's population lives in cities, which account for around 85% of EU GDP. By 2050, the population share of 70% is expected to rise above 80%. According to Eurobarometer surveys, EU citizens are seriously concerned about problems arising from the increase in urban transport, such as traffic disruptions, deterioration of air quality and more frequent accidents.  The European Structural and Investment Funds, and in particular the European Regional Development Fund, can provide an effective response to these problems, which can make a decisive contribution to the sustainable development of urban transport, which is of great importance for improving the urban environment and the quality of life of urban citizens.  One of the thematic objectives of cohesion policy 2014-2020 is to support sustainable transport and infrastructure. An important element of this is efficient, affordable and safe public transport, the promotion and extension of which also involves the creation of jobs. EU cohesion policy, the European Structural and Investment Funds, can provide effective responses to the challenges of sustainable urban development and smart transport. I think it is important that we take the opportunities offered by cohesion policy in the area of urban mobility.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – In order to ensure sustainable urban mobility, account must be taken of both goods and passenger traffic. As public transport and freight transport are still particularly ineffiably in many Member States, quality investment in this sector is inevitable to achieve sustainable mobility. I am thinking, in particular, of the development of integrated urban public transport and of the increasing uptrading of environmentally friendly forms of transport. However, in addition to improving infrastructure, we must not forget for a moment the issue of emissions.  As is well known, compared to 1990, industry and agriculture have managed to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions, but in the transport sector this figure has increased by 30% in the last 25 years. Urban transport is responsible for a quarter of total emissions, most of which comes from road transport. In this area, it is essential to make progress as soon as possible, which must be achieved both by redirecting as much of today's road users as possible to more environmentally friendly rail transport and, on the other hand, by providing as much space as possible for technologies based on non-internal combustion engines in the propulsion of urban road transport vehicles.  In order to achieve these objectives, it is essential, on the one hand, to further develop urban rail transport and, on the other hand, to support the widest possible use of electric and other non-greenhouse gas drive systems in urban road transport.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I support this initiative for the introduction of a Sustainable Urban Mobility plan, financed by the EU budget, to protect the well-being and the safety of EU citizens and of the environment. The report outlines that currently 38% of road deaths occur in urban areas where traffic congestion costs are estimated at EUR 80 billion. Consequently, car emissions have also increased by 30% since 1990. It is therefore crucial to reverse this trend by redirecting urban mobility towards sustainable modes of transport.  The report also stresses the importance of synergies between the Commission and the Member States to employ EU funding sources alongside the smart and sustainable mobility policies and projects, as well as the maximisation of these resources to achieve economic and social benefits. The report ultimately outlines the fact that existing initiatives such as road charging (Eurovignette), and new approaches to urban transport such as car sharing, are imperative in the intermodal mobility chain, alongside cycling, walking and public transport. I emphasise the need for cooperative networks at both European and national levels, as well as an in-depth consideration of the aforementioned prospective solutions – with the ultimate objective of making mobility in urban areas more sustainable.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Ladies and gentlemen, the definition of plans for long-term sustainable urban mobility is important in achieving the objectives that the European Union has set itself in terms of CO2 emissions, noise pollution, air pollution and accident reduction. It should also be remembered that it is estimated that almost 82% of EU citizens will live in urbanised areas by 2050. It is also in this capacity that the development of sustainable urban mobility plans should and should be one of the guiding principles for project financing within Europe. I encourage Member States to review their strategies in this area. Thank you.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing – Urban mobility, its problems and solutions affect every state. Anyone who lives or works in a smaller or larger city knows how hard it is to get from one point to another point of interest. That is why, as shadow rapporteur in the REGI Committee, I have tabled amendments that have also been approved in order to place emphasis on an integrated transport system based on cooperation between modes of transport in urban mobility. Furthermore, I stressed the importance of cross-border urban interconnecting in the urban planning process, as this stimulates regional development. In sustainable urban mobility, the quality of human life must be the focus, with a direct focus on the release of places from excessive congestion by vehicles, or the planning of parking lots, in order to allow free movement of pedestrians and the attractiveness of urban centres. We must also not forget that cycling plays an important role in modern planning for sustainable urban mobility and is part of the solution in preventing congestion, while separate routes for cyclists and pedestrians should be a matter of course when building and reconstructing roads.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – Nowadays, a large concentration of inhabitants lives precisely in urban areas, and estimates that by 2050 82% of EUROPEAN Union citizens will live in cities. As the urban population is projected to grow significantly, urban centres will continue to face societal challenges relating to quality of life and sustainable development, with serious urban planning required.
