By increasing the city's population, it increases urban mobility, and it still means car use. 96% of transport's energy needs in the EU depend on oil and its derivatives, which corresponds to a third of total energy consumption.  I believe that spatial planning is the most important stage for creating smooth, safe and persistent transport networks that have a real impact on citizens' lives and transport, and I emphasise that safety must always be seen as a key element of sustainable urban planning. It is also necessary to prioritise means of transport with a low CO2 content, including electric vehicles and vehicles using alternative fuels or having intelligent transport systems installed.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Diversification of means of transport and the pursuit of sustainable urban mobility undoubtedly have a positive impact on the climate and on improving air quality, which directly translates into the protection of the health of urban residents. Therefore, measures to seamlessly combine transport solutions such as collective transport, shared transport, the use of bicycles and rental companies are much needed. Especially since they not only reduce air pollution, but also support very important physical activity every day. However, it is important not to overdo it and that our actions resulting from good intentions do not have the opposite effect, do not make it difficult for residents to live in the city, especially those groups that carry out, for example, economic activities on the basis of a particular mode of transport. It is also worth remembering that the use of European civil satellite navigation programmes Galileo and EGNOS, which provide information on traffic and mobility, for example, can be extremely helpful in assessing the needs and impacts of the measures implemented.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item is voting time. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes). Mrs Corazza Bildt, have you raised a point of order? You're welcome!

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as you know, more than a month has passed since the disclosure in this House of Ms Le Pen’s voting fraud. I think that many colleagues here – and myself – would like to know the status of the inquiry that you are leading, in particular regarding Mr Marcel de Graaff, who is the co-chair of Europe of Nations and Freedom, and Mr Nicolas Bay, who is the Secretary—General of the Front National.  I would also like to ask you whether you also intend to convene Ms Le Pen for a hearing, as she is co-chair of the group of Europe of Nations and Freedom.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mrs Corazza Bildt! I have carried out an investigation into this erroneous and incorrect vote, firstly in the case of Mr de Graaff. I have listened to Mr de Graaff. Mr de Graaff acknowledged that his vote was incorrect. I now have to decide – and I have not yet done so – what sanction I will impose. I will impose one. Mr de Graaff has told me that he recognises that this was wrong and that he will accept the sanction. I have also listened to Mr Bay. Mr Bay has denied the accusation made by several colleagues that he voted for Ms Le Pen in Ms Le Pen's absence. He said that was not true, that he did not. I then asked the colleagues concerned who had written to me that they saw that Mr Bay voted in place of Mrs Le Pen for a discussion. The conversation has taken place – you are also a member of my colleagues – and you have been listened to by me. All the Members in question have assured me – in a protocol to be signed, which is also signed by colleagues – that they will stick to seeing that Mr Bay voted. Once I have completed this investigation, I will talk to Mr Bay again and then make a decision on how to deal with it. Because here we are in a situation where four or five colleagues say' 'that was the case, we saw it', and a colleague says' 'No, I did not do that'. The investigation into Mrs Le Pen is such that I have been informed that Mrs Le Pen was in the Chamber during the vote, which Mr Bay is accused of. This will mean that I will have to agree with Mrs Le Pen on this point, at least in terms of whether she knew that her colleague was voting for her or whether she did not know. Whether or not the now Secretary-General of the National Front is a matter of no question in this context. But we will have to find out. When I have completed the investigation, I will make you informed.

name: Michael Cramer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I had already asked at the time because there were very close results in this vote, in which there was either a difference in votes or a tie. I wanted to ask whether you have checked which votes have been so close and how you will behave when you find that a narrow majority or a narrow minority was only achieved by fraud.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Cramer, I would like to thank Mr Cramer for his We have followed up your advice. There is no close vote in any of the incriminated cases. So where Mr de Graaff or Mr Bay voted for Mrs Le Pen, the results of the vote were such that this wrong vote could not have changed the result. In this case, we would indeed be faced with a serious situation. That is quite clear.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, I am an old Member of Parliament whose prostate is increasing as energy decreases. On that day, the votes lasted two and a half hours. Can you please tell me what provisions the regulation allows for my political presence to be ensured in spite of the requirements of physiology or do I have to meet my natural needs by staying in my seat? Finally, I conclude by pointing out that, on 10 October 1987, in the French National Assembly, I witnessed the fact that our former colleague, Mrs Trautmann, a Socialist Member of Parliament, voted for more than 160 members of her group, together with only one of her colleagues, by turning the keys fraudulently, contrary to the rules of the National Assembly, the French Constitution and the organic law that governed the delegations of Members.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Gollnisch, I would like to thank Mr Gollnisch for his excellent report. The ageing process is certainly a serious process for all of us; it affects all organs from head to toe. In this respect, it is, of course, really worth considering any discussion of how we can help you. I will discuss this again with the political groups.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The voting list includes two votes, one on the establishment and one on the designation. Is that wrong?

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Bütikofer, I would like to thank Mr Bütikofer for his excellent work The vote was correct. The second is a nomination that follows the vote. In this respect, we have acted correctly.

name: Karima Delli
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, the amendment you are about to vote on is really important because, despite the revelations about the Volkswagen scandal, there are still public subsidies for fossil fuels. I am thinking in particular of diesel, which has a tax advantage over traditional gasoline.  If we want to reduce the use of cars to traditional fuel in our cities, we must act. We therefore collectively propose, through this amendment, to call on Member States to put an end to public subsidies for fossil fuels.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, sorry, but that was a political speech. That was not a point of order. Surely it is up to our whips’ meetings to decide. That was a political point. That was not a point of order.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr President, mr President, I would like to thank the commissioner for Mrs Delli is the rapporteur who is entitled to ask for the floor. Strictly in accordance with the Rules of Procedure, I must give her the floor, but not, of course, for a political statement. In this respect, Mrs Delli, you have skilfully used the Rules of Procedure for a political statement. That concludes the vote.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the statements by the Council and the Commission on 'Implementation and legacy of the European Year of Development' (2015/2994(RSP)).

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, members of Parliament, just a few days before the official closing ceremony of the European Year for Development on 9 December in Luxembourg, I am particularly pleased to have this exchange with you on this example of excellent collaboration with the European institutions, involving Member States, civil society, the private sector and all those involved in development issues. From the outset, the Council and the Member States of the European Union have been very directly involved in the European Year for Development. Firstly, in the context of the preparatory work for the adoption of the decision of the European Parliament and the Council, which enabled the launch of the European Year for Development, on the basis of a Commission proposal. As of January 1, 2015, we were ready to celebrate and live this year under the motto "Our world, our dignity, our future".  Together, we have put in place an exceptional programme of activities to highlight the results achieved by the European Union, acting with the Member States, as a global player and the world's leading provider of official development assistance. Key events were held, such as the inaugural session in Riga or the debate in Brussels on the post-2015 development agenda, particularly with young people, in the presence of UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon. A large number of Member States have also organised an official inauguration of the European Year for Development in their countries, in the presence of the highest authorities, demonstrating their commitment to development cooperation and attracting the spotlight of the national media. But, above all, Member States have played a key role in implementing the European Year for Development by bringing activities closer to European citizens. We have worked hand in hand with regional and local authorities, civil society, education, culture and research actors, all those partners who, in one way or another, share a sense of responsibility and solidarity. We have, of course, also associated the private sector, because its role is paramount and development is a responsibility for all of us. We have focused on social media and digital media, which have reached one of the priority target groups, youth. Young people are at the heart of the new 2030 Sustainable Development Goals. Many young people are actively engaged, but it was essential to continue to support them, to inform them in their approach, and to arouse the interest of those who feel even less concerned. 2015 was an emblematic year rich in international events directly linked to sustainable development: the Milan World Expo, the UN General Assembly, at which the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals were adopted, the Conference on Financing for Development in Addis Ababa, the Climate Change Conference - right now in Paris - , to name but the most important. These are all events that have served as a sounding board for the European Year for Development and have enabled the European Union to carry its message with strength and conviction.  I do not need to repeat here the importance of development. The many debates we have had in this Chamber in recent months, particularly on migration and the refugee crisis, have once again demonstrated this, if necessary. Development is often the key and is, in a way, the flip side of migration.  I had the opportunity to say that when we debated sustainable development specifically a few months ago. The fight against poverty and despair that drives people to leave their country in the worst conditions must remain a high priority. This year has enabled us to raise public awareness of the benefits of development cooperation, not only for beneficiaries, but also for EU citizens, and to increase understanding of the concept of policy coherence in the service of development. Despite the difficult times we are going through, European citizens tell us that they are largely in favour of development cooperation and that they remain in solidarity with our less favoured partners. We must do everything we can to keep this state of mind alive and continue to translate this will for solidarity into concrete actions.  I would like to thank, here, first of all, the European Parliament and, in particular, Mrs McAvan and her Committee on Development for their contribution to the success of this European Year. Next week you will be, Madam, with us, in Luxembourg, to close this year. I would also like to congratulate myself here on the spirit of inter-institutional cooperation which has enabled a joint declaration by Parliament, the Commission and the Council, which represents the legacy of the European Year for Development, to be set in motion in a very tight timetable. This declaration will be symbolically signed in Luxembourg on 9 December to, precisely, perpetuate the spirit of this Year and encourage the European institutions and Member States to continue their efforts to raise awareness among European citizens beyond 31 December 2015.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we are approaching the end of the European Year for Development. This has been a year of partnership, innovation, networking and the sharing of experience. It has seen the European institutions come together with national governments and parliaments, and with civil society and private sector and international organisations, to promote the message that development cooperation is important for all.  The Year’s motto, ‘Our world, our dignity, our future’ has been a constant reminder that development cooperation is not just about people in developing countries. It is also about how we, as Europeans, respond to them. I wish to thank Parliament for its vital role in initiating, supporting and driving the European Year for Development.  This has taken many forms. I can see that the square outside this Chamber is being decorated with European Year For Development posters. I would like to thank, in particular, President Martin Schulz, Mrs Linda McAvan, the Chair of the Committee on Development, and Mr Charles Goerens, member of the Committee, for their strong support. 2015 has been a critical year for development, with the Addis Ababa Action Agenda and the 2030 Agenda on Sustainable Development adopted and, hopefully, an ambitious climate framework forthcoming. At the same time, a significant increase in refugees and migrants worldwide is a stark reminder of how important it is to address the root causes of instability and irregular migration – in other words, to give everyone the potential to live a life of dignity at home, rather than fleeing from hunger, poverty, insecurity or violations of human rights. For me the main success of the European Year for Development was – and is – the partnership with so many development actors in Europe and beyond. I am very happy that Parliament, the Council and the Commission will together acknowledge the legacy of this year by endorsing a joint declaration at the official closing ceremony in Luxembourg.  Let us work together to maintain this spirit of partnership when discussing, promoting and communicating development cooperation beyond 31 December this year. Let us all take the legacy of the European Year for Development forward to become a common framework and a true platform for a continuous and ongoing European development dialogue in the years to come.

name: Davor Ivo Stier
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, we may have expected 2015 to develop in another way at the beginning of this year. Perhaps someone will say that 2015 has actually been more years of mass migration towards Europe than the European Year of Development has been and there is no doubt that migration has dominated our discussions and attention lately, but all this only confirms the importance of an effective development policy. This confirms the need to focus more on the causes of the problem, not just the symptoms. The causes of poverty, war, and then of course mass migration. And the causes can be found precisely in systematic violations of human rights, in endemic corruption in many countries in our neighborhood and in the absence of good rule.  And that is why this year, the European Year of Development, we have sought and managed to change the global framework for development and enter a specific development goal, development goal 16, on peace, on justice, on the fight against corruption, on effective justice, on good governance. This is one great success of the European Union. Here I am, using the opportunity to highlight here the role of Mr. Commissioner. Implementation is now important and in this implementation of the new global Agenda 2030, we need to focus precisely on this development goal 16 as a priority in our action, all in line with the concept of human rights-based development policy. We must also accept fully that there is no development without peace and vice versa, that is, that there is one clear nexus, one clear link between development and security.  Finally, I would also like to congratulate my colleagues from other political groups, in particular the leaders of our Development Committee and also Mr Goerens, who has conceptually designed parliament's work in this European Year of Development.  (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. "Thank you very much for the opportunity, Mr. President. I will not argue with The Representative that much has been different in 2015 than we had planned. But you say there is no development without peace. I think what I've found out this year is that without development, there's no peace. In other language, Europe finally has the opportunity, to say the least, to do foreign policy through development. Don't you agree with that?

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Distinguished colleague, what I said is that there is no peace without development and that there is no development without peace. So I said it really like that. One thing and another go together. I think there's one link between development and security, and that's what most of us on the Development Committee point out. We must now see in the implementation of this new Agenda what measures we need to revise within our development policy to remove those barriers that make it possible to address this link between development and security in a better, more efficient way.

name: Linda McAvan
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I only have one minute tonight in which to speak, so just two quick messages really. The first is about action. We started the year in Riga saying we wanted action, not just warm words. Well we did act, we got agreement in Addis Ababa, and then in Paris, and we hope to get agreement at the COP 21 in Paris next week. We have also agreed a new Agenda Action Plan, but now we have to turn those commitments into real policies on the ground, and that is the second word really – legacy – which both the Commission and the Council spoke about. We have to deliver on the promises. We have spoken, Commissioner Mimica, about renewing the European Consensus on Development and maybe it is time now to bring that idea forward to create a new buy-in, by all the partners, into the next 15 years of development policy.  Finally, I would like to thank the Luxembourg Presidency for its commitment, the Latvian Presidency for its commitment, and you, Commissioner Mimica, for yours, as well as my colleagues, who throughout the year have been extremely supportive in getting the message out.

name: Richard Sulík
text: for the ECR Group – The European Union's development assistance is above all a victory for good marketing. Two thirds of the population of the European Union believe that expenditure on development aid needs to be increased, despite all sorts of failures. The more the European Union's development projects fail, the more the European Union spends on marketing. In the meantime, the European Union is giving more to its promotion than Coca-Cola worldwide. At the same time, however, several Member States are reducing their share of development aid. For example, Finland from 0.82% to 0.6%, France from 0.5% to 0.36%, etc. It is ridiculous, and especially unrealistic, to ask countries that are drowning in debt, such as France, Greece, Portugal, to give 0.7% of their GDP to development aid. That is why it is time to stop dreaming of the European Union as a saviour of the whole world and to make the peace of development aid real. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – I would just like to ask my colleague if he is aware that it is friends from his party in the Finnish Government who were celebrating this deep cut in the development budget by 42%. I wonder if he agrees with his colleagues from Finland that this was the right move, as I did not quite get the point.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the Blue Card – Yes, of course I agree with that. Finland is a country in recession that has to struggle with its problems, which has to do its reforms and, above all, not produce deficits. The European Union is in debt, so either we start to manage properly and then we can play saviours and save other countries, but if we are making debts and more and more debts and the overall debt is rising, let us stop playing heroes and save all the countries around us.

name: Charles Goerens
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, it can be said, after eleven months of large-scale awareness campaigning, that the European Year for Development has been a success. The cooperation that has been established between the actors that are the political leaders, the representatives of NGOs, the territorial representatives, and those of the private sector in particular should be commended. The major challenges that emerged in 2015 highlighted the indispensable contribution of development to solving our problems. In this regard, the refugee crisis is note. The last few weeks show how essential it was to put the principle of respect for dignity at the centre of the 2015 campaign. Some, including the European Commission and a few Member States, have acted in accordance with this principle. Others, although supportive of the idea of the European Year for Development, have tended to promote the principle of indifference. No threshold, no ceiling, no consideration based on the exploitation of difference can impair dignity. The European Year for Development reminds us that the current problems of illegality, poor governance and the threat to internal peace in developing countries are the result of what we have done over the last 15-20 years. These problems are the result of our action, but also of our inaction. What we fail or refuse to do today is sure to affect the situation in the world over the next twenty years. Let us be determined, resolute, uncompromising as soon as our promise is made. This promise will have to be declined not only in terms of principles, but also in terms of the means we intend to mobilize for implementation. There is no question of ending the great awareness campaign of 2015; the motto "Our world, our dignity, our future" is intended to be perpetuated as it is important to preserve it in the path laid out in 2015. Let us therefore act relentlessly in accordance with the objectives, principles and motto of the European Year for Development. The joint declaration by Parliament, the Council and the Commission clearly goes in this direction and it is to be welcomed.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I would not dare to take stock of the European Year of Development, it is still early. It is true that 2015 is being a very important year. Since July we have had a new financing framework for development; since September we have had a new policy agenda set by the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals; and in the coming days, in Paris, I hope that an ambitious plan against climate change will also be adopted.  However, we can't wear medals, because the complicated starts now. We have all the work to do. It will be up to us that the good intentions of this 2015 do not stay on wet paper, but become truly effective actions. That's how we want it.  The new Sustainable Development Agenda for 2030 is universal in nature, which means that we share a responsibility to make it a reality. Part of our work is to effectively ensure the principle of policy coherence for development; that's the only way we're going to achieve our goals. We must stop giving with one hand what we take away with the other, as is the case, for example, with our trade policy, which cannot continue to impoverish the people of the South and undermine the objectives of development policy. Only if in 2030 we have met all the objectives proposed this year, the success of 2015 as the European Year of Development will be a reality, like the year of change.

name: Maria Heubuch
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Putting the issue on the agenda in public was certainly very important. I myself have taken part in many events in Germany, where there has been a lot of discussion about trade, migration, food sovereignty and what is or is not being done. And it is also good to show what we have done here. But we cannot rest on our laurels!  These words must now also be followed by concrete deeds, actions that safeguard human dignity and ensure the future of our children. National governments are in particular in demand here, but so are every citizen. With regard to the refugee debate, this means that the dignity of refugees must also be safeguarded. We must welcome them to our countries and we must be prepared to find solutions to meet this challenge together. And with regard to the SDGs, it says that we also need to start our consumption, our waste, to save energy, to live more climate-friendly, and for that we do not need a budget title. Our world, our dignity, our future – that is, to look beyond our own borders and to act in the real interest of all, and the key word for this is policy coherence.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I cannot have such a positive opinion as I have heard from some of my fellow Members on The European Year of Development because, while it is true that, from a certain point of view, we have used the resources to advertise, to talk about development, it is also true that development has been talked about for other reasons, for the crisis, for the refugee crisis. , because of the increase in migratory flows to Europe, and so some people have begun to ask: perhaps in order to solve such great problems, we need to look at development policies outside Europe? I believe, however, that, from another point of view, we have not been able this year with the facts to show that development is important, because there has been no significant growth in programmes and results. We hope that the discussions that have taken place this year and the commitments made in September will produce positive results in the future, but I do not think this is the time to sum up and talk about results, but simply to hope that something will change, because as Mrs Sánchez rightly said, we live in an institution where the right hand does not know what the left hand is doing. , that is, the left hand is perhaps the strongest, which is trade policy, which is totally contrary to the principles of development and cooperation.

name: Olaf Stuger
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Not only in the last Year of Development, but throughout its existence, the EU is already giving a great deal of money to development aid. But the effect of this is never considered. But what effect can you expect if you give money to dictators of Zimbabwe, Sudan, Sierra Leone and Mozambique? The last transfer of 236 million to Mr Mugabe was celebrated by him with a barbecue at which two elephants ended up. I have to tell you, in small pieces. Mr Museveni bought a private plane for himself and six fighter jets for his personal army from EU money. And Ali Bongo of Gabon has treated himself to a beautiful apartment of over 100 million euros in Paris.  But the most devastating effect, Mr President, is that the dependency relationship between the government and the citizens is being cut. A government needs taxpayers' money to exist and citizens are only willing to pay taxes to a just government. This creates the balance between fair governance and tax ethics. But if a corrupt government receives development money from the outside, it can still govern and survive without the support of its taxpayers, and it does not have to care about the wishes of the people. Development aid therefore encourages corrupt governments. So today we are not closing the Year of Development, but the year of stagnation and corruption.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, a year and a half ago, in April 2014, we were voting right here in Brussels on the regulation that established the European Year for Development, and here we are now in a position to discuss the application of this regulation and what may follow after the European Year for Development. This means that for more than a year we have had the opportunity to raise awareness among European citizens about the 12 priority themes. We have been able to explain how taxpayers' money is spent, how development funds can change the lives of citizens in some of the poorest countries in the world. And – as is the case with Romania – for several new Member States, which do not have a very articulated tradition of development cooperation, this European Year was a very good opportunity to connect citizens to the European Development Agenda. As a permanent rapporteur on policy coherence for development, I welcome the fact that this concept has explicitly been one of the priorities of the European Year. The need for the Union to have a fair and coherent approach to developing countries must be explained, I believe, beyond the narrow circle of initiatives. The European Year for Development is an investment in the future of our development policies, not just a simple communication exercise, because the implementation of the 2030 Agenda requires joint efforts, the involvement of a very large number of actors with diverse capacities. However, without European citizens feeling actors in sustainable development, without a genuine approximation of the 2030 Agenda, we will not be able to move forward.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we closed a year in which there has been a little more coherence, a lot of interinstitutional dialogue and cooperation with the social actors. A year in which Parliament has held consistent positions for international summits. But in December we have more problems than in January; we have more crises, development, humanitarian crises, conflicts that require an even more ambitious response than at the beginning of the year.  We would not be generous with what we have done this year if we did not take advantage of the drive to respond to these challenges with determination and the first of these challenges is to fulfill our commitment to devote 0.7% of our wealth to supporting those who barely reach 0.7% of our well-being. That is the future to which we must dedicate this year's legacy.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am a great supporter of development aid, the duty of Europe that John Paul II once wrote about – solidarity on a global scale. But since I am a big supporter of development aid, I urge you to be sober so that we do not talk about it in terms of an advertising campaign. What we need is not complacency, but a real evaluation of the effects that European measures bring. The answer to the question of whether we agree well on European spending with Member States' spending, and finally the question of whether our resources are well complemented by other major actors in international politics, by the United States and China. This requires a culture of integrity, not a culture of complacency. I also urge you, and this great response to the challenge of today, to the challenge of migration and refugees. I am convinced that development policy needs to change in order to respond effectively to this challenge.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the EU is the biggest aid donor in the world, but how much actually goes towards development? How much money has gone instead towards military spending and wars? Whilst the European Year for Development sought to address the eradication of poverty and hunger, EU countries are indeed contributing to poverty and hunger by fighting wars, either directly or by proxy, across the Middle East and Africa.  Westminster is voting tonight on whether to drop more bombs in Syria. That is neither the answer nor the solution. That will cause more deaths, more refugees and more suffering. Pope Francis said last week that such a war will leave ruins, thousands of children without education, so many innocent victims and lots of money in the pockets of arms dealers. We need development goals which end extreme wealth and which recognise that poverty is not a naturally occurring germ, and that poverty has a cause.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, as the European Year for Development is now drawing to a close, and ambitious negotiation for a climate agreement is still going on, I would like to draw attention to the fact that we need to invest more in adaptation to climate change in the poorest countries of the world, such as the Sahel countries of Africa. These countries are the most vulnerable, and their populations will be totally unprotected as climate change progresses. I believe that many of the market forces are active on the side of mitigation of climate change, but there is much less attention to adaptation. This is a big task for our development efforts. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Olaf Stuger (ENF)
text: "blue card" question. – I would like to ask my colleague - it is, of course, a trick that is often used here, namely to link everything together. We are talking about refugees and we are bringing the climate to that because these people are coming here because the climate is deteriorating. We need to give more development aid, because the climate is deteriorating and we need to give more development aid, because the refugees are coming here, one big mush so that no one understands anymore. But when we talk about climate change: I come from the Netherlands, the country that is most vulnerable because it is almost entirely below sea level. So perhaps this is an opportunity - and I would like to have your answer to that - that the Netherlands will finally get some money back from all the billions it has pumped into this circus.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for your statement. I believe that the Netherlands is in a position to help the really poor countries of the world to adapt to climate change because it also masters certain technology. What is expected of us in the climate change negotiations now is that the rich countries make available the technical innovations that they have developed. Notably, I would say, know—how in controlling floods, but also investment in renewable energy and energy efficiency, are things that the Netherlands can very well transmit to the poorest countries.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, this year, 2015, has been the European Year of Development. I am sure that those people watching this on YouTube, and the three people in the gallery, are well aware of that. Well, actually, let’s get realistic. As I predicted last year, this patting ourselves on the back, and a blatant propaganda campaign, has gone completely ignored by the public at home. The EUR 17 million wasted on this could have, and should have, been used to save lives, and not on advertising how compassionate and how wonderful we are, with taxpayers’ money. There will be no legacy of the European Year of Development.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the From my point of view, the European Year has been a successful year because it has shown the importance of political coherence in terms of development policy. This has become clear in the twelve months of thematic issues that have highlighted this. I have also suggested in the German Bundestag that there is a regular coherence report – there is now a study by the Scientific Service. This year has had positive and negative times. Unfortunately, at the financing conference in Addis Ababa, we did not achieve 0.7% of the gross national income of the Member States and the European Union being spent and promised on development cooperation.  At the same time – and here I disagree with my colleague – we have had a good campaign, which has also shown that, for example, a textile alliance is being stepped up, including through the new Presidency of the Council. At the same time, I would like to make it very clear that this was a prelude to the 2030 SDGs, which we are now going to tackle in the coming years – coherence will be strengthened. I would like to thank the Commissioner and the representatives of the Presidency for the successful work they have done together with Parliament and the Commission. Thank you very much!

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, this European Year for Development has not changed the world, it is true! You wouldn't even expect me to! But it was worth it! It has helped raise public awareness, fostered debate and, above all, boosted projects, partnerships and decisions that go in the right direction, including at major international conferences such as Ababa and New York. But nothing we've done is a guarantee of success. It is in the implementation of the commitments that the future of development policies will be judged. And when we see signs of lack of political will and even a retreat in public development aid, we are more than cause for concern and, above all, for an attitude of vigilance. It is this vigilance that we must also call on today by the European Commission and all those who take place in this European Parliament.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: For the catch-the-eye procedure that follows, I have more than twice as many speeches as I can take into account. I am very sorry that I cannot call everyone. I therefore ask for your understanding. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – With regard to this Year in Europe, we all agree on the importance of development policy, especially in the light of the migration phenomenon of recent months and the ongoing climate conference in Paris. It is in the well-understood interest of European citizens to accelerate economic development and increase living standards in poorer regions of the world. At the same time, I believe that the development of a country is inconceivable in circumstances where hundreds of thousands of people of working age decide to emigrate permanently. It is precisely these countries that have the most negative consequences for these countries, as massive emigration makes development only slower and uncertain. That is why we must do everything we can to stabilise the situation in conflict zones, because the young and well-educated population currently emigrating could represent the hope that the countries of development policy will not once again need our support. Thank you very much!

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, 2015 has been seen as the year of implementation of the European Union's development objectives. Among the main objectives of the European Year of Development are the fight against discrimination and violation of human rights, the consolidation of the rule of law and the building of fair and inclusive institutions. However, the European Union does not seem to be promoting growth as much as it should in its Member States. Thus, for 2015-16, EUR 18.8 billion in commitments is foreseen in order to increase competitiveness in order to have employment and growth. This amount is not sufficient and should be increased, especially for the countries of the European South which have been impoverished by mercelian austerity.  As long as the debt of some Member States of the Union remains at current levels, it is impossible to achieve the objectives of the European Year of Development. Only by writing off the debt of these countries, and in particular by writing off the shameful debt in Greece, will we be able to have growth and it will be possible to hit poverty and boost employment and prosperity.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, exactly everything that is happening in the world, everything that happened in 2015 shows all the meaning of the European Year of Development. All that has been done by the European Union, member states and all those who have good intentions in helping the countries that are the poorest in the world, where immigrants come from, where the crisis comes from, shows the need for solidarity in action to have no alternative.  That is why I strongly support the European Year of Development as I also support all those intentions that go towards preventing future migrants, namely climate migrants, migrants due to the changing climate. I think that's what we're going to have to deal with in the coming years and it's certainly going to be one new, very big challenge for the European Union.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, today we are discussing the development aid that the European Union gave to the so-called Third World in 2015, in which the thematic emphasis for December was supposed to be on the 'link between development and the protection of human rights'. But all this sounded ironic when, just three days ago, the European Council awarded economically and politically the semi-authoritarian Erdoğan regime in Turkey, forgetting systematic human rights violations. The unsolved mass murder of hundreds of peaceful demonstrators in Ankara a few weeks ago, the assassination of the president of diyarbakir's bar, a few days ago, the arrests of journalists for revelations about the harboring of Islamic State criminals by the Erdoğan regime, were all forgotten for serving temporary purposes. The Turkish regime trades in refugee drama and the European Union pursues a policy of appeasement, humiliating its own code of values.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, in the UK development aid is a very controversial issue: it is ring-fenced. So while there are sweeping cuts to defence, education, law and order, and health, foreign aid is ring-fenced. And then the British people, I am sure, will be, as one of our former monarchs would say, ‘not amused’ to find out that not only is our taxpayers’ money from the UK Government being sent out to a rather peculiar bunch of dictators across the world, but then we have taxpayers’ money that has gone to the EU which is then being further sent out, and to compound this insult, we find that we are actually having yet more of our taxpayers’ money spent on telling us what a good thing it is. This is the ultimate bad deal for Britain. It is absolutely appalling.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as well as being an MEP, I am mayor of a small town in northern Italy and seeing the budgets of the European Community and seeing how the money is spent, I really get the ulcer every time. We have to take the Alka-Seltzer all the time, because the anger that comes to me to see how money is thrown away when there are so many realities, both in Italy and in Europe, where we try to be very present on spending, to help citizens, to help businesses, to really help those who need it, it is an insult to be , so to speak, economically correct. And to think that we are giving money, as was said before, to Turkey, for example: EUR 10 billion and now we are giving it more; when we see how Turkey works, it is an insult, just as we give money all over the world and instead forget our people, Europe, Europeans, those who pay the taxes that allow us to have the money, so...  (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, at the beginning of the year we knew that 2015 was going to be a crucial year for mapping out the future of development cooperation at international level. The adoption of the new sustainable development goals provides us with a new context for our work in the next 15 years.  The world is increasingly complex and fast-moving. New crises and new challenges emerged this year, only to remind us how important it is to make development work for migration and migration work for development. Our communication on development issues needs to be up to the mark and inclusive, engaging all partners and the wider public – particularly young men and women – in support of sustainable development beyond this year.  Let us build on the work we have done together in this European Year for Development to make sure that the voice of the vulnerable continues to be heard.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like once again to thank the European Parliament for its contribution to the success of the European Year for Development. It is indeed about to end, but our efforts to eradicate poverty and create a fairer and more peaceful world must continue and even intensify. Above all, they must be translated into concrete action through our development cooperation and the commitments that have been made in this regard. These commitments must be respected. Nearly 1.3 billion people still live in extreme poverty. And while hundreds of millions of people have been out of poverty, it must also be noted that inequalities within countries have often widened in many parts of the world. The survival of our planet is now at stake and many developing countries are particularly affected by the effects of climate change. Everything must be done, now in Paris, to meet this climate challenge, because that is also the whole meaning of sustainable development. Just as there is no peace without development, and has been repeated many times, there is no security in a world where inequalities in development remain so great. This commitment to development must therefore not end with this Year. This work of awareness, explanation and persuasion must be actively pursued.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Year for Development 2015 was a key opportunity to raise awareness on the importance of development policy across Europe. In this year the Millennium Development Goals are to be reviewed and new targets to be set up. This policy is of utmost importance as it can help us address major challenges like terrorism and migration and poverty. Conflicts within countries and the lack of opportunities for people are common root causes of these challenges and they must be addressed without delay. People who are still living in poverty deprived of healthcare, education and living standards, in conflict-affected and fragile states, are the most hit, and development policy is the only way to ensure effective and innovative cooperation. We need the highest level of coordination in order to achieve coherence with all affected policy areas like environment, international trade, human rights, agriculture, and to ensure consistency in development activities.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Year of Development plays a particular role for communication and the active involvement of European citizens and civil society organisations in development aid and political dialogue. According to official figures, around 20 million EU citizens are personally involved in development NGOs, around 130 million people make donations to organisations helping developing countries, 72% of the European population supports the idea of helping countries with low levels of development. This is a good result, also indicating that more and more people understand that development begins in their own country through mutual assistance, fair trade or participation in political processes.  The key to the success of previous thematic 'European years' has been close cooperation between the EU institutions and civil society, both at national and EU level. Multi-level actions play a key role in shaping policy processes and should therefore be an absolute priority and receive sufficient funding. Majority of OFFICIAL DEVELOPMENT ASSISTANCE (60%) member states, which are somewhat supported by the EU budget. Efforts should be made to establish a broad and stakeholder-wide alliance of civil society organisations, which, as in previous years, should play a leading role in the planning and implementation of the European Year of Development.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. 2015 was a key act for the Union's external relations and dedicated it to the issue of global cooperation and development sent a clear message of unity. This House has said time and time again that we need more union in this Europe. And if, on the foreign policy front, the Union too often appears to be divided, it is certainly united in terms of cooperation. The European Union is the world's largest donor and provides more than half of the world's official development aid. It was right to open the spotlight on this, to inform, to involve the citizens. Now, however, we need a proper budget. Of course, the results of international cooperation are not always quantifiable, but we know that unfortunately we still have 1 billion people in extreme poverty in the world today. The 2030 Agenda is ambitious: ending poverty and hunger in the world can no longer be just a dream.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa The end of the European Year for Development has set itself one of the priority objectives of raising eu citizens' awareness of development aid: what is it? What does it serve? How does it have public funds? We wanted the message to reach as many people as possible that development aid serves us all, increases our sense of shared responsibility and teaches us solidarity on a global scale. It culminated in a special summit on sustainable development setting development goals for the world by 2030. I am particularly pleased with the poverty reduction targets and the re-development of the Global Development Partnership, in which we will further strengthen international cooperation in this area. I was also pleased to appreciate my country's initiatives, covering a whole range of cultural events, in particular those aimed at young people, such as photo competitions and the 6th HumanDOC International Documentary Film Festival, which combined the presentation of world-class cinema with global education and the promotion of the idea of helping developing countries. I hope that the legacy of the ERR will be a valuable contribution to the new sustainable development goals, and that its motto 'Our world, our dignity, our future' will be remembered for longer by citizens as a symbol of our collective European shared responsibility and solidarity over the past year.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The EU has called 2015 European Year for Development and once again proved to be a pillar in world development policy. We are the biggest donor of official assistance and development policy is an important area of our foreign policy. The primary objective of EU development cooperation is to reduce and eradicate poverty which has multiple and interlinked economic, political, and security causes. Not only that, our aim is to promote human rights and to spread democracy, good governance and the rule of law. Unfortunately, the ongoing conflicts and humanitarian crises in neighbouring regions proved that development policy cannot achieve these objectives as a stand-alone policy, but must be integrated into a broader approach which combines foreign and security policy, trade and any other external action policy instruments. The EU need a comprehensive and coherent strategy for its development aid in order to meet the United Nations’ post 2015 development goals. Goals which are very, very difficult like goal number 16 – LIVE IN PEACE. It is not only a moral obligation, it is our duty to work for a stable, prosperous and more equitable world.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – It is to be welcomed that the European Development Fund, which provides funds for the development of cooperation with developing countries outside the European Union, is the most important financial contribution among the least developed economies. It is regrettable that some Member States are not fulfilling their commitments in terms of the size of official development aid of 0.7% of gross national product. At the same time, in order to increase the efficiency of the European Development Fund, better and operational coordination of all funds is needed, with the same purpose: to develop cooperation with the least developed countries. It is also necessary to make full use of these funds and to link the funded objectives with the development strategies of the countries concerned.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The establishment of 2015 as the Year for Development was linked to the deadline for achieving the Millennium Development Goals agreed in 2000 worldwide. It is also a period in which the Sustainable Development Goals are to be set, i.e. priorities for the coming years. One of the objectives of the European Year for Development was a campaign aimed at EU citizens to inform how development aid contributes to change in countries that need such assistance. It was also intended as evidence of the European Union's special commitment, as the world's largest donor of development aid, to the fight against poverty, climate change and the protection of the Earth's natural resources.  Not only the EU institutions, but also the Member States have been involved in promoting the Year. Information campaigns, conferences, events and debates were organised across Europe. Thanks to digital and social media, the message also went to young people. It should be remembered that development aid serves to build a safer and more prosperous world. Over the past 10 years, EU funding has helped 14 million children go to school, more than 70 million people have gained access to clean drinking water, and 7.5 million births have been taken away by qualified medical staff, saving the lives of mothers and children. The European Year for Development, in my opinion, has met its objectives and has been a success.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Council on the balanced representation of women and men among the non-executive directors of listed companies by Evelyn Regner, Maria Arena, Tadeusz Zwiefka, Mariya Gabriel and Constance Le Grip on behalf of the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament and the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) (O-000136/2015 - B8-1109/2015) (2015/2967(RSP)).

name: Evelyn Regner
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the In order for men and women to be equally represented on the Supervisory Board, we need binding rules throughout Europe. Little or nothing happens on its own. Only in those countries where there are corresponding binding rules do we see really good progress and a higher proportion of women on supervisory boards. Patience is no longer a category. The European Parliament has done its job. What do we want? In listed companies, the proportion of women will increase to 40% by 2020. And what do we want? By introducing objective procedures. Objective procedures, that is, that the best men and the best women should be selected. That is good for the economy, and it is, of course, fair. That is the point alone. This is actually gentle and an offer to the Member States. And then there is also this passage, which allows countries such as Germany, for example, to make their national efforts – all that they have tried in recent years and are now trying to achieve a higher proportion of women in companies – counted. In other words, there is really an offer for the Member States to be courageous and to adopt this report. This dossier is ready and ready to be negotiated, it is on the table. I would therefore really like to thank the Luxembourg Presidency for showing this energy, and now – I do not want to say one last, but nevertheless – to make an effort to try to take on board the Member States that are now keeping themselves covered. Very soon, on 7 December, is the next Council (Employment), and here we can only ask the Member States to take a good look at the whole dossier. It is damn gentle and accordingly worth saying goodbye. After all, it is good for men, good for women, good for the economy. And perhaps one last word: especially in the context of the refugee tragedy and the fact that gender issues are repeatedly highlighted as European values, it is all the more important to take gender issues, but also corporate governance at European level, very seriously.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like first of all to thank you, Commissioner, but also to thank the Luxembourg Presidency and, in particular, Minister Mutsch for their efforts to unblock the situation with regard to this draft directive. Unfortunately, two years after the European Parliament voted at first reading, I could take almost word for word the speech I gave in plenary on that occasion. Parliament has done its part and it is up to the Member States to roll up their sleeves and put into practice the commitments they have made for gender equality in Europe. Let me first point out the facts, because it seems that there are still some irreducible skeptics about the potential of this directive. On the one hand, the facts have shown that a greater presence of women on boards translates into better governance and economic performance. Again, what are we waiting for to harness women's potential and empower us to achieve economic and social goals? On the other hand, the facts also show that legislative pressure works. Between the publication of the proposed directive and today, we have gone from 15.8% to more than 20% of women on boards of directors. The trend of progress is much stronger since there is European legislative pressure. Companies anticipate the effects of the directive and select competent women. In addition, I would like to stress once again the snowball effect we can expect from this directive: positive effects at different levels of the hierarchy, in particular thanks to the related measures that could be put in place. So, for those who are not convinced, at least be pragmatic. The second general point is that the legal basis chosen, the tool chosen, which is the directive, and the proposals put forward by Parliament already offer Member States a great deal of leeway. In the end, the only thing we have been waiting for, and for two years now, is a commitment from the Member States and coherent measures to achieve real results. In conclusion, three key words: responsibility, flexibility, concrete commitment. And behind each of these words, the Member States.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Regner, Mrs Gabriel, I welcome first of all the opportunity to address Parliament and to inform you of the progress of the work on the Commission's proposal for a directive on improving gender balance on boards of directors. On this issue, Parliament has already adopted - as you have just mentioned - its position at first reading, in which it largely supports the Commission's approach. In October, the Commission published new figures on gender balance on the boards of listed companies. These figures show that, in the European Union as a whole, barely one-fifth of board members are women. Although ridiculously low, this figure indicates some progress. I agree, we would have to be extremely patient so that, in fact, at this process, we can get to equality or balance. So it is indeed necessary to settle this in a different way and to speed it up a bit.  It should not be forgotten that in 2010, when these debates began at EU level, only one in ten of the boards of directors was a woman. So we have to continue to address this problem. There is simply no reason why, in the twenty-first century, boards of directors should be dominated by men. Greater equality in leadership positions is a positive signal to society as a whole.  The balance between women and men in decision-making bodies is of course a question of concrete equality. It is also a symbol, but I would add that diversity is very often - as you said, Mrs Gabriel - positive from the point of view of good corporate governance. Ladies and gentlemen, the Luxembourg Presidency has made this issue one of its top priorities. We have put forward several new drafting proposals to find a compromise within the Council. Within the Council's bodies, the proposal has been extensively discussed and discussed. We have now, after all these discussions, put the issue on the agenda of the EPSCO Council, which will meet next Monday, to take stock and see if, in fact, a qualified majority in favour of the proposal could emerge. I do not want to anticipate the outcome of these discussions in the Council, but I can, unfortunately, already tell you that the recent debates at The Coreper have not been very encouraging. Today I have received very good news, since I have learned that a country, which you know well, Commissioner, has indeed announced that it has changed its position from an unfavourable position to a favourable one. That, I think, is a good signal that is quite positive. So, as you know, this proposal contains binding procedural rules that aim to achieve quantitative objectives. It requires that the selection process for board members be fair and based on merit and transparency. The main difficulties arise from the fact that Member States have different approaches to the subject. Some Member States are at a more advanced stage than others in terms of the level of equality between women and men in this regard. But, on the whole, I would say that there is a consensus in favour of the objective of this proposal. However, while a large number of Member States are in favour of EU-wide legislation, others - and unfortunately, for the time being, they are still a blocking minority - retain a preference for national measures (by the other way forward) or advocate non-binding measures at EU level.  The Presidency has also drawn up, in the context of gender equality, the Council's conclusions, which will also be adopted - on this point, I believe they will succeed - at the EPSCO Council on 7 December. Our work was based on a report by the European Institute for Gender Equality, which provided an update on the current situation in the European Union. In conclusion, we must ensure that our largest companies can benefit from the talent and dynamism of both women and men. Europe has a multitude of untapped talents and above all, today we find that 60% of university graduates in Europe are women. There is therefore no reason why, in the twenty-first century, governments, businesses, banks or other institutions are still mainly led by men. Let me thank the European Parliament for keeping the issue of gender equality on the agenda. I hope that this debate will inspire some at our Council meeting on 7 December.

name: Constance Le Grip
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, we are here this evening quite few - many, I should say, unfortunately, two years after the first reading vote on the Kratsa-Regner report, to debate again the subject of greater participation of women in the decision-making bodies of large European companies listed on the stock exchange and to know exactly where the work in the Council stands. Mr Minister, you have a little, on the model of the Scottish shower, alternated the good and the bad news. We can only conclude from this that we are whole-hearted with you and with Commissioner Jourova for progress, on a path of progress, at the EPSCO Council meeting on 7 December.  Nevertheless, I wanted to point out, as my colleague, Mariya Gabriel, has done, that there is unquestionably, on the part of the European Parliament, in the context of this first reading, an effort of lucidity, of responsibility, a strong commitment which has been made but with great pragmatism and respect for the positions of the Member States, respect for the principle of subsidiarity , respect for a number of principles and wishes that had already been put forward by different Member States.  We have taken responsibility, we have taken a significant number of steps without compromising on the essentials, without res due to our strong commitment to greater participation of women in the decision-making process on boards of directors. There are still a few of us here in Parliament who think that coercion and quotas can work. I come, for example, from a country - France - where a law came into force in 2011, the so-called Copé-Zimmermann law. It definitely worked. It has undoubtedly produced effects: 33% of women on the boards of large French groups. Undoubtedly, the constraint works. But we are respectful of what can be said, of the different legal cultures and approaches of the Member States. We just have to keep this in mind - as has been said by others, but I want to stress this point - that the waste of women's talent, the waste of women's skills, the waste of the fantastic training and education efforts that are being deployed through our education systems, our training systems for women, for young girls... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Anna Hedh
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr On 14 July this year, the current Presidency of the Council, Luxembourg, voted in favour of the Directive on gender balance on the boards of listed companies, thank you for that. But Luxembourg is not alone in this, both the European Parliament and the OECD now see the clear need for a directive. A more equal representation on company boards is supported by both economic and feminist arguments.  The OECD bases its position on the fact that companies statistically benefit from including more women in boardrooms economically. Apart from the economic, it is also high time that the glass ceilings and patriarchal networks that reproduce male boardrooms were undermined. Since companies have had the opportunity to improve without much success, legislation must now be in place.

name: Beatrix von Storch
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Parliament wants to enforce quotas for women with all its might, which is as wrong as water wet! Why, then, are only quotas for supervisory boards – if quotas already – and not also for blast furnace engineers or the fire brigade? And why gender quotas only for women and not for all other genders? For bisexuals and transsexuals and intersex people – I mean, if quotas, then right!  Quotas for private companies are an interference with the freedom to conduct a business. An entrepreneur has the freedom to hire 100 women, 100 men or 100 chimpanzees – it is his free choice! Quotas are nothing more than discrimination on the basis of sex. They discriminate against individuals in favour of a group, and I reject that. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Evelyn Regner
text: Author, question about the procedure of the "blue card". Have you read the report? The report mentions procedures, namely objective procedures, in order to achieve an objective. And it is not in it that it is a quota.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The target is a 40% quota on supervisory boards. That is the beginning. This goal is wrong, and the methods do not improve it. The aim is to discriminate against women because they are recruited as women and nothing else. The objective is wrong, and that is why I reject it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, today, in Europe, six out of ten students or senior graduates are women. However, eight out of ten directors of European companies are men. This is unequal, unfair, costs us money and harms the competitiveness of the Union. And it's easy to solve. Quotas have proven effective in correcting such problems: a political decision is sufficient to facilitate and encourage the incorporation of female talent into the direction of the European economy. There are good reasons to do so. Studies abound – like the one presented right here last month by FIona Jurdant of the OECD – that show that companies with balanced advice are more competitive, have fewer governance problems, more performance in capital, and better economic performance. That's why they work better and build more trust in clients and investors; therefore, incorporating that value into our economy is strategic and innovative; therefore, to bet on public programs and legislation to achieve this, an investment; that is why it is a competitive advantage in which we must be world leaders; and that's why we need transparency and fairness in selecting the people who make up the board of directors. I thank the Luxembourg Presidency and the Commissioner for their will, work and interest and all their efforts to bring this initiative forward. I encourage the countries that block it to review its positions and I hope they understand that as long as these things continue to happen, the great proclamations on equality will be wet paper.

name: Eleonora Forenza
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am very sorry to have heard a fellow Member disadge a problem that is in front of everyone's eyes: it has been calculated that since 5 November women have been working unpaid because of the gender pay gap, that is, the non-existence of the wage differential between women and men that exists in my country, it exists in the European Union. This is not about setting quotas to protect women, it is about making a world where discrimination against women is still very high less discriminatory, as on the boards of directors, but of course not only on the boards of directors. It is therefore a question of understanding together what strategies can be adopted to finally defeat the crystal roof, to create a world in which men and women can be at ease, with the same rights, with the same powers.

name: Terry Reintke
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Mr Schmit, I would like to thank mr Schmit for his excellent work and for the work he has done. In fact, it could be quite simple. We have a common political objective, equality between men and women, fair representation in decision-making positions. We have instruments that have been proven to work, these binding rules that Mrs Regner referred to, and everyone would benefit: men, women, the economy – all in our society. Politics could sometimes be so simple. But some Member States in the European Union still do not seem to have recognised this, and above all the German Federal Government. And that's why: Dear German Federal Government! The Commission has really responded to the demands in all areas. It would not only be wrong to vote in favour of the proposal now, it would simply be absurd. To Mrs Schwesig, as The German Minister for Family Affairs, who supports this proposal: the European Parliament is behind you! Get your way so that the proposal can find a majority in the Council next Monday with the votes of Germany!

name: Diane James
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, my contribution to today’s debate will utilise my experience as a former non-executive director of a UK Stock Exchange-listed company, a venture capital trust, as a board chair, and finally as a charity board trustee. The dimension that this EU policy does not address is that endemic through the business community is the aspect of ‘not what you know, but who you know’. Even the international recruitment sector responsible for people search acknowledges this depressing situation. Thus, whilst we all want to see more women take board or other influential roles in companies, the reality conspires against that outcome.  The issues at stake are not about merit, experience and qualifications: they are about transparency of the recruitment process and the contribution that quality recruitment will and could make. Gender is completely immaterial, and by introducing quotas the fight against discrimination then becomes skewed by discrimination. Forcing companies to adopt 40% gender quotas and penalising them if they do not is hardly responsible or even realistic legislation. If the EU truly wants to redress the situation, then go back to the drawing board, please, and tackle the misogynist establishment which utilises the old boy network across Europe. I cannot support this.

name: Gianluca Buonanno
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I find this debate at the moment to make no sense in relation to a comparison I want to make with regard to women. In several countries, unfortunately here in Europe too, there is a method on women that is even done on girls: it is called infibulation, that is, genital mutilation. These things are done in Muslim countries, then Muslims come to Europe. These things are only done to girls for religious reasons, and you talk about women in public limited companies, women who have to be everywhere, but don't fight against this crap of those pigs doing things like that to girls! Isn't that defending women? You're only interested in boards, you're interested in money, you're interested in seeing women doing fashion shows during S.P.A. and boards. The crap is the infibulation of those Muslims who, like pigs, hurt little girls who are ruined all their lives! This sucks!  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: "blue card" question. – First of all, I would like to tell you that we have all debated here with respect and I would ask you exactly the same. Secondly, I would also ask you to be in all the debates in which we have talked in this House about the equality, discrimination and suffering that many women in the world live in, including girls and women from other worlds, and in which reference has been made to genital mutilation. It is known that you have not been in these debates and I would like to ask... (The President withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Madam President, thank you very well I understand what you have said. But I very much regret having to tell you that it was not a question that was put to the honourable Member.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: Answer to a blue card question. Yes, I would like to point out that I am in 22nd place out of 751 Members as a presence and as a job in the European Parliament, so I do not give lessons to myself, I give them to you. Second, I talk about what's going on in the world, with women, and you talk about the board. But shame on you, you're just arrivals, you just think about power, you don't think about the things that happen in the world, you fill your mouth on women because you're radical communist chics of caviar and champagne. That's you!  (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Buonanno, I would like to thank Mr Buonanno for his work on I would like to tell you that the debate was on the very subject that the Members have been talking about, and you are the only one not.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: " Mr. President, I am sorry that Mr. Buonanno has interrupted this relatively idyllic discussion, but I would be glad that many more men have participated in this discussion because now that we are talking about this ourselves it seems like we are in some kind of conflict of interest and we are fighting for our own interests. However, unfortunately the fact is that in this Parliament, I have to tell you the older I get, the bigger the quota supporter I am. Simply, society will not be just until women are equally represented and there are half and half of us or even more than half of us. Of course, with a level playing field, with the same procedure as has already been said here.  Therefore, great progress has been made since 2010, as Mr. Schmidt said, and thank you for keeping this topic high on the agenda. From 11% we came to a 21% share of women on supervisory boards. I think it's one solid improvement, but still insufficient. You said to be patient. Women are known for being patient, but I think the time has come to finally see this gender equality in some way and in these supervisory boards. I believe we will succeed in this, but of course the Member States are the ones that have to react.  I expect on Monday 7.12. that you will exert, tentatively, influence over member states and that they will accept this directive because it is obvious that where there is legislation, then they behave differently in that Member State. I would therefore ask you, as Parliament has done its job, to continue to do the job in the Council as well.  As for female graduates, of which there are 60% compared to men or 6 in relation to 1000, I think there is a huge discrepancy here and therefore it is definitely clear that in all countries it is not of this scale. I would just like to point out that there are 2.5% in Malta which is very small compared to the European Union average of 21%. I believe we all strive... (the president interrupted the pay phone)

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D).
