text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Luxembourg Presidency for all the good work they have done on this. They have very much put it back on the agenda, which it should never have left. As has been said by many speakers, companies with more women on their boards tend to perform better than those with fewer. I believe that this, in itself, makes the case, but we are nowhere near parity, as we know. As a result of that, we are of course missing out on a whole pool of talent. Although the number of women on boards has been going up since the Commission draft was published, it is still, quite simply, not enough. It has even gone up in the UK, where about 25% of non-executive directors are now women. As we all know, the Conservative Government in the UK is part of the blocking minority. I have specifically mentioned non-executive directors because that is what this report is about. We need to move on and to make sure that there are more women executive directors ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: – Today, it is not a question of whether it is good for more women to be on the supervisory boards of listed companies. Of course, it is good for companies themselves if there is diversity, not only on behalf of women, but also, for example, of persons with disabilities or persons of different nationalities. However, the problem is in the solution. There are companies and countries in Europe that may also be able to accept quotas, as this topic has been alive in them for decades. At the same time, we have countries where the experience of similar solutions is very unfortunate and negative. Therefore, I do not think it is right to support women in a way that actually calls their position in such countries into question. I think that gradual organic change will be more permanent and more in favour of women than quota solutions, however tempting they sound. We have many other tools to support women. Let us work with men, let us work to support infrastructure for families, let us politicians be leaders of change and draw attention to examples of good practice in successful countries and companies. It may be a slower but more certain path.

name: Daniela Aiuto (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as the 5-star Movement, we have always been opposed to the introduction of pink quotas, both in listed companies, civil society and politics. This is because we are calling for effective participation and real affirmation of women to be the fruit of our capacities and competences and should be fostered through the definition of transparent and equal meritocratic criteria for all. We do not want and do not think it right that a managerial and working position should be given to us simply because we are women, because that is true sexism; instead, we believe that we are worth and deserve much more. Against this premise, we can only take note once again of the umpteenth deficit in the decision-making and legislative process, which once again sees, as was the case with the maternity directive, Parliament witnessing helplessly and helplessly the Council's failure to adopt a position. For better or worse, the European institutions must come to a clear decision within a certain time. This is something that will have to be changed and that is no longer tolerable for us.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Schmit, I would like to thank Mr Schmit for his Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her FROM next year, DAX companies will have to have a female quota of 30% and the rate of implementation is not so bad. Currently, one in four supervisory board positions in large German companies is filled by a woman – exactly 26.7%. Across Europe, the rate is 18.6%. Germany has passed a mandatory quota for women by law. An EU quota for women on supervisory boards will be discussed in the Employment Council next week. Specifically, it is a question of implementing a directive which provides for an increase to 40% of women on the boards of large listed companies by 2020. In my view, this draft is problematic because the establishment of a legally binding quota for women is not within the competence of the EU and – at least for some Member States – the principle of subsidiarity is being disregarded. Gender diversity has a positive impact on the business success of large companies. Especially in Germany, it can be observed that companies with a high proportion of women in the committees perform well on the stock exchange. The consumer goods group Henkel is an example of this – the chairman of the supervisory board is a woman. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am afraid that the European Union is dealing with serious security risks these days, but I think it is also right that we are also addressing this long-standing issue of promoting equal rights, equal representation of women. It is today that the Czech Government adopted its resolution, in which it was among the countries that are positive about this directive, expressing its symbolic position on this issue. Our goal is therefore to improve the representation of women in the decision-making bodies of large companies, the Czech Republic will only affect six companies. However, I would like to stress that I do not think that all the means of positive motivation in particular have been exhausted. I do not find it logical that it starts with private companies. I would prefer that organizations ised by the state were motivated in this way. I think that this regulation should therefore not come from the centre, from the European Union, but that the Member States should deal with this situation within their competence. After all, it is in the interest of companies and organisations that there should be more women on boards, as has already been said here.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Mr President, thank you to the Luxembourg Presidency, to Nicolas Schmit and also to Mrs Mutsch for the effort and energy they have devoted to the issue of equality between men and women We have talked about the 21% on average of women's participation on European boards. In this 21%, unfortunately, and it has been said, including Ms. Le Grip, some countries have scores of more than 30% and other countries are at 2.5%. Now, we see that when there are legislative procedures, when there are laws to move towards that equality, well it works. That means discrimination where there is no law. That there is discrimination, that there is inequality, that there is no will to have women on boards. The question I am asking is simply: the Commission has done its job, Parliament has done its own. We want to see a binding approach. I just wanted to know what the arguments were of the Member States who are against it, to be able to talk with them, to be able to dialogue with them, to be able to find solutions. So our goal is to be able to find solutions with these...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I think we all agree that women are woefully under—represented both at management level and at board level across the EU, albeit with differences between Member States and with things improving, which we should acknowledge. However, while I have always believed that the best man for the job is usually a woman, I do not like quotas. I never have. I find them just a little bit demeaning. I do believe in merit. I also believe in subsidiarity and my – and indeed my government’s – objection to this has largely been on the grounds of subsidiarity, and that this is a decision that should be made by Member States. So I was not expecting to see much in the Council position to interest me. So what a surprise to read Article 4 on flexibility. Thank you, Luxembourg – at last someone is listening! Maybe, just maybe we have the beginnings of an agreement here. I wish you the best of luck.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are talking about this directive once again in this House and we are talking about it once again, because many people, institutions and organisations want gender balance on company boards and supervisory boards to become a reality.  At the moment we have a situation where this directive is stuck in the Council, there is a blocking minority, that is Denmark, Germany, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, the Netherlands, the Czech Republic, the United Kingdom, Sweden. I would like to draw the attention of all of us to the fact that there are very diverse countries among this blocking minority, because there are countries, such as Germany, Denmark, the Netherlands, Sweden, which are very intensive in dealing with this issue and have different solutions. Germany has introduced quotas, Sweden is spending a lot of money on its programmes, in any case those countries that want a goal, that is, a different pool than those countries that do not want a directive, but have a very low share of women on boards and do nothing to change this situation.  In my opinion, it is necessary to negotiate and discuss in practice with those countries that do not want to achieve the objective that is in the directive and with those countries that want to achieve this goal. Perhaps these alternative methods of achieving the objective, other than in the directive, could somehow be associated with this directive, and then perhaps we would have achieved the goal, because we really want women to break the glass ceiling, so that women's competences and women's talents are not wasted and that women can take responsibility for the results of their work not only in politics, but also in business.

name: Clare Moody (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to extend my thanks as well to the Luxembourg Presidency for its efforts.  It is astonishing to reflect that here we are in 2015 still having to fight so hard for gender equality. Alongside many of my colleagues here today, I do implore the House to think about how we can make progress on this directive and realise that we do need to take action right now. We were deeply frustrated by the decision to refit the Maternity Directive earlier this year, and we need to have some change made on the issue of gender. This directive is not just about directors, it is about changing the shape of culture within companies. With more women in elevated positions we can exert influence not just in those positions but at all levels throughout the company. Empowering women at the top works towards a more equal future for all.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, women are still the under-advocated gender among the members of the boards of directors of European companies, although we discuss this and similar topics several times a year. I believe that we all agree in this house that management positions in European companies must be equally accessible to women and men. Women must have the same opportunities as men because they are equally able to learn, work hard, perform the most complex tasks and lead other people. That is why I want women to have an equal role in the business world – because they deserve it – through hard work, not someone's compassion. Any woman who earns her place on the company's board of directors by imposing herself on her male colleagues with knowledge and skills seems immensely much for all women. Because of such strong women, we must work to change awareness among the business people of Europe, and punish any form of discrimination properly.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, in the 400 largest Croatian companies, the share of women on boards is 15% and in supervisory boards 21%. We talk a lot about the glass ceiling that women come encounter in the business world, but we have not made any major progress. We agree that we need to give women more access to the business world, especially to the very top of the world.  While quotas may not solve the structural problem of women's under-representation in the business world, they can help foster greater gender equality and open up new opportunities for women that would not be provided without quotas.  No one expects women to be put in positions simply because they are women, but quotas must serve as incentive measures so that able women who have the necessary knowledge and qualifications to manage businesses, and who are denied leadership positions simply because they are women, get the opportunity they deserve.  The business world can't just be a man's world, and it is now. We have to open it to women and we have to be united in that. We have a model, and we have to work on its implementation, but so that we do not impair subsidiarity and so that we do not oblige private entrepreneurs to something that we are not able to implement in the public sector.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Since 2010, the proportion of women on supervisory boards in Europe has been growing very slowly. This is a small crack in the glass ceiling, but also a very small crack! And the Commission has proposed the introduction of a transparent procedure for the appointment of supervisory boards throughout Europe, with the aim of having 40% of the supervisory board posts filled by women by 2020.  Parliament approved this in 2013. We have been waiting for two years for something to be done in the Council. Voluntary agreements are of no use, because we can see that, especially in the countries where we have mandatory regulations, something has changed for the better. That is why I do not understand that my own country, Germany, has a mandatory quota of women on supervisory boards. Something has changed, but it is precisely these countries that are opposed to this – there must be a solution, and I also share what my colleague Maria Arena said, and we need to speak again. Nothing should be taken away! After all, there should be a basis for all European women.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I share my colleagues’ disappointment in regard to my very own country, Malta. The current situation represents clearly that Member States are not ready to walk the talk on gender equality. An electoral promise of having the most feminist government has actually decreased the number of female participants in leadership positions.  While in the European Pact for Gender Equality the Council acknowledged that gender equality policies are vital to economic growth, prosperity and competitiveness, yet this proposal which deals only with a very specific commercial structure and only with non-executive positions still today does not seem to have the backing of Member States. It seems that, even in the Council, Member States are not willing to walk the talk on gender equality.  Member States fail to see the need to reap from their investment in education the aspirations as well as the capabilities of women. No one today can use the excuse that there are no qualified women, nor can they argue that society is against gender equality. Even in Malta more female MEPs were elected to this Parliament than male candidates. This is not a debate on favouring women because they are less capable than men, but about giving equal chances to qualified women as much as to men. Non-binding measures have proved insufficient. We do not want to create bureaucracy for these entities but we do need to ensure that this public and social responsibility is taken seriously.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – According to the World Economic Forum, the world will hopefully experience gender equality in the year 2095. Unfortunately, I have to live to be 135 years old and frankly I don't want to wait that long. Member States such as France and Germany have understood that boards and supervisory boards with more diversity are achieving better results. Unfortunately, my own country, the Netherlands, has not yet understood this, and this deprives the Dutch business community of the talents and visions of top women who are now unable to get past the application threshold for top jobs. The Luxembourg Presidency has indicated that it wants to find a solution to the blockade in the Council, but this is urgently needed. We need a compromise proposal soon, because we do not have to count on this point in the Dutch Presidency.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are talking today on a very serious subject, but also on a sensitive subject. There is no reason why there is no equality between women and men in modern 21st century society these days. This is absolutely particularly important, relevant and ruthless to implement in public institutions and, above all, those that represent and are representative of the community.  However, the problem is not and does not concern the public sector, but the private sector, and I understand that problem. It must be borne in mind that this is an economic activity, that is to say, the freedom to carry on that economic activity. This raises the issue of the inviolability of property rights. This is compounded by the autonomy of states in creating a legal situation in their own countries. This, in turn, is linked to the principle of proportionality within the framework of European Union legislation. That is why I understand the problem of advice and understand that this case takes a long time. I suppose it will continue to take time, because it is about changing culture rather than the law.

name: Maria Noichl (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Today we are talking again about this: do we need a quota, or do we not need it? I would like to make it quite clear that we have had a quota for decades, but we have had a quota for men for decades! It is enough to be a man to get to certain positions. We women are concerned about whether qualification would be good enough. I repeat: we have had a male quota for decades. The male rate in Malta is currently 97.5%, the european average for men is around 80%. However, I would like to make it quite clear once again that it is our right as women and it is not indecent to demand 40%. It is our right, and it is not indecent. If we were to ask for 50, 60, 70%, we could talk about whether it would not be too much. Now we are only demanding what we are entitled to – we have had the quota of men for decades!

name: Der Präsident. –
text: We now come to the catch-the-eye procedure. I can take all my fellow Members into account, since we have only one speech too much. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: – Gender equality, one of the important principles of a modern democratic society, is an approach that allows women and men to participate equally in all areas of public and private life. In addition to gender balance in the area of political engagement that we have been dealing with in recent years, we also need gender balance in the economic field. I welcome the initiative for the Council to speed up the adoption of a common position on the Commission directive of 2012, introducing a target of a minimum, 40% share for representatives of the under-represented sex among non-executive directors on boards. A number of research in this field shows that gender-balanced boards achieve better results with significantly more comprehensive decisions, taking into account the wishes and expectations of both the female and male populations.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, since 2012 a directive has been proposed to ensure that 40% of non-executive directors correspond to the under-represented sex, in order to improve the low representation of women on the boards of publicly traded companies. The legislative pressure appeared to affect gender representation rates, since in October 2015 there was a significant increase in the representation rate of women in publicly traded companies, compared to 2010. Thus, in 2010 it was 11.9% and today reached 21.2%. However, in most European Union countries, rates remain low, with the exception of France, Germany and Finland, where rates exceed 25%. After all, women, especially in times of economic crisis, are directly affected, more than other groups, and this has already been shown. The reduced employment of women is therefore evident in all sectors and not only in listed companies.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, we're on the right track. We're heading in the right direction, but the finish line is still a long way off. When I was younger, I was a little surprised how come we needed quotas. But after 25 years of politics, I am definitely convinced that this is the only correct path if we really want gender equality.  We should ask ourselves what this Parliament would look like if there were no political quotas on various lists, especially when we are talking about smaller, lower units of local or regional self-government. But I will also say this: I am not entirely sure that the approach we just heard about male quotas is something that will contribute to all of us to really talk honestly about gender equality here. This kind of radicalism is not sure that it will contribute much to those of us who want this equality.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: –  Mr President, a 40% share of women as a binding rule across the EU in boardrooms was mentioned by the Commissioner. Any intervention on this scale is a blatant intervention into the free market by the state. Without free markets and free market enterprise you don’t have free people. What we need to be looking at is equality of opportunity, not equality of outcome. That is the most important thing. It is very important that politicians and well-meaning state authorities do not start with this kind of thing, closing down freedoms in order to have laudable goals. Freedom of opportunity is the main and only thing that matters in a real truly free society.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, interference with the free market, I have to think about it a little bit, because I think that God or fate determines what the specific ratio between women and men is in society. The ratio is 51:49 to the detriment of men, and that's the natural ratio. I'm not against number 40- the representation of women on company boards. Natural relationship in society, that's what I said here. Once we deviate in the tens of percent, I think that's really what's unnatural. And I don't know if, in that sense, the free market is the defining one. But I really want us to sweep on our own doorstep. The composition of the Commission falls short of the 40 quota. Show me all the other public sectors where the representation is at least a little bit in line with the natural ratio. I think it would be a good idea to get your ass covered on your doorstep first and then go to those private companies.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr All my life I have worked for women's rights and I have always been in male-dominated contexts, even here in the European Parliament, I can say. However, I do not believe that the Commission's directive on women on boards is the best way forward for real equality. Partly because, as a Liberal, I think that companies should be allowed to decide for themselves how they are to be governed and represented, and partly because we must respect the property rights that have been fundamental in every European democratic state.  And ownership is still fundamental. But above all because I think it is to start at the wrong end. If we want to create a gender balance, we must have a balanced distribution of parental leave, good childcare in all our Member States so that women and men can participate in working life on an equal footing. Today, there are far too many women who give up their careers and become housewives. Europe, Mr President, simply cannot afford to have the world's most well-educated housewives, we must stop doing so and make sure that we work, both women and men.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I said earlier that I can take all those who have signed up. Unfortunately, if people have come forward after that, I cannot take that into account, because we are already close to the time. (End of catch-the-eye process)

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, almost 60 years ago, men, who were not yet very advanced on gender equality, enshrined in the Treaty of Rome the principle of equal pay for men and women. Surprisingly, because at the time, the gender pay gap was huge. Gigantic! Today, it is still clear that almost 60 years after the drafting of the Treaty of Rome, a gap remains between the salaries of men and women. Imagine if this provision had not been included in the Treaty of Rome... I doubt that this would be the case today, even if the current situation is still largely unsatisfactory. I therefore believe that what is being proposed is certainly not a desirable proposal, since what we would have liked is that equality be actually achieved and that there is no debate to promote women. Because then the situation would be simply normal: sometimes there would be 60% men, sometimes 60% women.  The reality, as you well know, is quite different. So now we need an instrument so that, in fact, we do not have to wait another 70 years or even 90 years, as someone said.  I did not plead for patience. I said it would require too much patience. You are asking me what the positions are in the Council? They are not that different from some of the positions I have heard here. Sometimes it is subsidiarity, sometimes it is not to agree that we need a mandatory instrument, sometimes it is free enterprise that will, somewhere, anyway, make the right choice. The various positions in the Council reflect quite well the variety of positions expressed here. I guarantee you that the Luxembourg Presidency will do its best, if not a little more, but the qualified majority is a qualified majority.  Therefore, you have to do everything you can to get it. We will of course work on it, but I cannot give you all the guarantees of the world.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: That concludes the debate. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – Already in 2013, we have adopted our position in the European Parliament on this directive, which could serve as a very good example of ensuring gender equality in other areas. Gender equality in the highest positions of companies is still not guaranteed at European Union level, but the available talent should be exploited while promoting gender balance on the boards of all companies operating in the internal market. Since the Commission's draft was published, the number of women on company boards has increased from 16.6% at the time of publication to 18.6% in 2014. Legislative pressure seems to be an important factor in changing existing structures. It is therefore essential to continue negotiations in the Council on a European directive on quotas for women in companies and to ensure that at least 40% of non-executive directors of companies are of under-represented sex. The Luxembourg Presidency has now explicitly advocated the proposed directive by presenting its agenda at Parliament's Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality on 14 July 2015. I would therefore like to call on the Luxembourg Presidency in the Council to seek to reach a consensus between the Member States as soon as possible. Because it would be a great pity if, after a series of discussions and negotiations, this directive were blocked.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. In order to achieve the quantitative targets for the presence of women at company top management, measures must be taken to achieve them. The paradox – which I would consider ridiculous, if it were not dramatic – is that we do not want to admit that the issue of women, whatever the area in which it is dealt with, is a moral obligation that cannot be postponed and is based on a difficult change of mentality. This delay in applying the 'principle of nature', of gender equality, leads, given the hand, to a reduction in European economic potential, whereas growth in innovation, research, training and skills acquisition is never accompanied by the active participation of women because it is limited by the lack of inclusion of women in decision-making bodies. It does not seem strange, therefore, that studies suggest that a greater presence of women in the labour force would increase GDP by 21% in Italy, 19% in Spain, 9% in France and Germany and 8% in the United Kingdom. In the correlation between the percentage of women on boards and the financial performance of companies, the return on equity is 41% higher than that in which women are absent. This data does not need further comment.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, the proposal for a Directive on women on boards, which was supported at first reading by the European Parliament, is a small legislative step in view of the narrow scope of its impact, but provides an important example of the real implementation of gender equality policy in the European Union. Without this example, we could not have expected that women's participation in leadership positions would be encouraged in both small and medium-sized enterprises.  The topic of women's career development is not only nuance in gender equality policy, but is also part of the economically sound balance of decision-making. I therefore call on the Council, the Member States and the forthcoming Dutch Presidency to make every effort to overcome differences in positions and to demonstrate in practice the importance of a horizontal gender equality policy.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The problem of gender imbalances not only on company boards, but in the labour market in general, has been a concern of the EU institutions for many years. It is necessary to reflect on the actions taken. The Directive on the presence of women on boards is the best example of hard action contrary to the expectations of entrepreneurs and some governments. There is even an obstruction on the part of the Council, which has been unable to take a position for several years. It may be necessary to consider whether a directive imposing certain gender limits on company boards is the best solution.  Increasing the participation of women among directors cannot be an end in itself. It is more important to improve their situation on the labour market, and this requires creating the conditions for reconciling family life with working life. Indeed, even if we force companies to take a certain number of women on boards and lack this support, women with families will choose to do so to a small extent. So it should not be our goal to establish a 40% share of women on boards, but to make the road to this body open to all competent people regardless of gender. This requires greater involvement of men in the upbringing of children and the uptake of mechanisms to facilitate the linking of family and professional life, rather than mandatory quotas and other rigid mechanisms.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. The text of the proposal for a directive on gender rebalancing on the boards of listed European companies, as it stands, is a perfect example of respect for the principle of subsidiarity. It is legislation that proposes a more transparent and fair selection process, without providing for measures such as gender quotas, which have also proved to be – in the countries where they were introduced, including Italy – the most effective and rapid way of actually combating discrimination against women in decision-making places. I understand that the last year and a half has been full of important events which have attracted the attention of all the European institutions, but we can no longer afford to regard gender equity as a second-class priority. , which I do not believe Europe can afford at the moment. Today we have an excellent compromise text, the time for discussions is up and it is time to produce concrete results.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. I hope that the Council will soon reach agreement on this directive, the implementation of which would finally ensure a balanced representation of women on the boards of European listed companies. At a time when European women are still struggling to fully integrate into the economic and social life of the Community, the adoption of this measure would symbolically and actively sanction the equal vocation of the European Union. The European Parliament took up this challenge two years ago by voting by a large majority for the proposal. I therefore expect the Member States which have so far shown reticence to disband their reservations in this area, and I finally agree with the need for them. It is with pride that I stress one fact: the country I represent in the European Community Assembly, Italy, has proved to be a forerunner in this field, through the adoption of a bipartisan law guaranteeing the presence, in the social bodies of listed companies, of at least a fifth of women. I hope that the other European states will follow our example, overcoming their doubts, in the name of the desire to ensure the construction of a totally inclusive Union.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – I support the proposed ‘Women-on-Boards Directive’ not only for economic reasons. It does not make sense for any corporation to utilise in its production only half of the machines it has available. This applies for mechanical as well as for human ‘machines’. Women were excluded from operational and decision-making posts for ideological reasons. These acted as barriers to entry that inhibited the full development of productive potential in societies, firms and governments. Quotas were the tool to overcome this barrier. Once equality of gender opportunity and its effective implementation are ensured, chances for an improvement in productivity are improved. Gender quotas automatically become archive material. They have been effective at operational level. They will be equally so for executive, decision-making positions.  I speak from experience. In the Malta Labour Party, we introduced quotas for women in elections to the general conference and the national executive. Within fifteen years, quotas were no longer needed. Gender parity was being automatically achieved, via the ‘normal’ electoral process for these institutions. There was a clear improvement in their functioning. However we did not introduce quotas in the party bureau, which was a mistake. Dominated by men, its effectiveness remained open to question.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – The pursuit of gender balance is an important objective. However, in my speech, I would just like to draw attention to one more aspect, notably the fact that I firmly believe that this ambition should not only be underlined 'among non-EXECUTIVE DIRECTORS of listed companies' and should never be emphasised one way, focusing solely on one of the mains, because, despite this positive objective, we can generate counterproductive results.  We must also exercise particular caution in this area to ensure that our steps towards guaranteeing equality do not lead to negative processes that neutralise positive targets or, worse, negative processes contrary to what is to be achieved.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – Only half a century ago most women in Europe did not have voting rights, discrimination was at rife, women’s jobs were second-class and the pay gap was huge. Thankfully, women have come a long way, winning the battles for legal, political and economic rights. However, we are far from true gender equality, particularly in the business world where senior management positions are still held by men. The fact is that, in the EU today, women account for just 21.2% of board members of the largest publicly listed companies registered in the EU countries. Although quotas are a controversial topic, I view them as the best available solution to ensure better gender balance on corporate boards of European companies.  Therefore I support the 2012 Commission proposal for a directive setting a minimum objective of 40% of the under-represented sex in non-executive board-member positions in listed companies in Europe by 2020, or 2018 for listed public undertakings. The European Parliament has strongly backed this proposal; unfortunately the Council was less enthusiastic. I would therefore wish to remind Members of the blocking minority, and that we need strong rules to tackle the gender imbalance in company boardrooms and ensure greater gender equality in the corporate world, and also in our society.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the situation in Hungary: follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 10 June 2015 by Claude Moraes on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (O-000140/2015 - B8-1110/2015) (2015/2935(RSP)).

name: Claude Moraes
text: author. –   Mr President, on behalf of the LIBE Committee, allow me to present the oral question to the Commission which we have tabled concerning the situation in Hungary. On 10 June Parliament adopted a resolution in plenary on this situation, where it asked the Commission to assess the situation and to establish an EU mechanism to monitor democracy, the rule of law and human rights annually across the EU. The aim of the resolution is not to single out a single Member State or government but to call on EU institutions, particularly the Commission as the guardian of the EU Treaties, to fulfil an obligation to ensure the application of and compliance with the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU, across the Union.  The EU, as we all know, was founded on values of respect, freedom, democracy, equality and rule of law as well as human rights. With this in mind it is important that Member States and all EU institutions work together to protect these basic European principles.  In paragraph 11 of the resolution the European Parliament urged the Commission to ‘activate the first stage of the EU framework to strengthen the rule of law, and therefore to initiate immediately an in-depth monitoring process concerning the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary, assessing a potential systemic serious breach of the values on which the Union is founded as per Article 2 TEU including the combined impact of a number of measures exacerbating the state of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, and evaluating the emergence of a systemic threat to the rule of law in that Member State that could develop into a clear risk of a serious breach within the meaning of Article 7 TEU’, and asked the Commission to ‘report back on this matter to Parliament and the Council before September 2015’. So I put the following questions to the Commission: Has the Commission carried out this in-depth monitoring process as requested by Parliament? If not, can the Commission explained the reasons for not having initiated such in-depth monitoring? Secondly can the Commission provide the European Parliament with its assessment of the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary today? Third, has the Commission activated the Rule of Law Framework as called for by the European Parliament, and if not, can the Commission provide a reasoned argument for not having done so? I am very much looking forward to the responses of the Commission and the debate of Members on these key questions.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Parliament for the oral question on the situation in Hungary. I know that there is a lot of discussion on whether to trigger Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union or the Rule of Law Framework as regards Hungary. Today I would like to set out for the House what action the Commission is taking to monitor the situation in Hungary, and to ensure that European Union law and fundamental values remain respected there. And it is against that background that I will also explain to you why the Commission does not believe that there are grounds at this stage to trigger Article 7 or the Rule of Law Framework. During our previous debates I have always made it clear that the Commission will be vigilant when concrete measures and actions are taken by the Hungarian authorities. I have also said that the Commission will use all the means at its disposal to ensure that Hungary – as well as any other Member State – complies with its obligations. And you know that the Commission has already done so in the past when it took Hungary, for instance, successfully to Court for the early retirement of judges or violation of the independence of the Data Protection Supervisor.  This is what we have done. Following Parliament’s resolution of 10 June 2015, the Commission has taken a number of actions with respect to the recent developments in Hungary. Let me give you a brief overview. As regards migration, the Hungarian Government formally announced on 15 September 2015 a ‘crisis situation caused by mass immigration’ on the basis of legislation that had entered into force that same day. A preliminary assessment of the Hungarian legislation revealed a number of concerns and questions on substance and implementation relating in particular to the compatibility of this legislation with the EU’s asylum and borders acquis, and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. These issues were addressed by the Commission’s services in a letter sent on 6 October 2015 to the Hungarian authorities.  A detailed reply from the Hungarian authorities was received on 4 November, which clarified a number of questions but did not remove all outstanding concerns. This response is currently under assessment by the Commission.  As regards the debate on the reintroduction of the death penalty, both Commission President Juncker and First Vice-President Timmermans made clear statements on this: Article 2 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights prohibits explicitly and clearly any person from being condemned to death, or executed. In addition, the European Court of Human Rights has ruled that the death penalty is a violation of the European Convention on Human Rights. The abolition of the death penalty is a condition which states are required to meet in order to become members of the Council of Europe or of the European Union. The reintroduction of capital punishment would be contrary to the EU’s fundamental values. A reintroduction of the death penalty by a Member State would therefore lead to the application of Article 7 of the Treaty. The debate launched by Prime Minister Orbán did not materialise and the death penalty has not been introduced.  As regards the situation of civil society in Hungary, the Commission expressed its concerns about the disagreement between Norway and Hungary and about the follow-up to this dispute, which may have a serious impact on a number of NGOs working on the promotion of human rights in Hungary, and negatively affect the functioning of the European Economic Area and Norwegian financial mechanisms.  The Commission’s services sent an administrative letter to the Hungarian authorities underlining this concern. On 7 October this year it was reported that the National Tax Authority had closed its investigation into the NGOs relating to the European Economic Area/Norway grants. The decision to withdraw the tax registration numbers of the NGOs concerned is still pending before a Hungarian court. We have also noticed that a Hungarian court ruled that a police raid on watchdog NGOs in 2014 was illegal. As regards the situation of Roma, the housing situation remains a concern. The Commission’s services started an EU pilot procedure and are assessing the matter in the light of the Directive on Racial Equality, which prohibits discrimination on grounds of ethnic origin in a number of fields, including housing.  On the education of Roma, concerns remain as well, in particular relating to possible segregation and discrimination of Roma children. Also on this matter the Commission’s services started an EU pilot procedure and are following further developments, again in the light of the Directive on Racial Equality.  As regards the transposition and implementation of the Framework Decision on racism and xenophobia in Hungary, a meeting took place on 15 October 2015 between the Commission’s services and the Hungarian authorities to discuss a number of outstanding issues. The meeting was part of a series of bilateral dialogues held during the past year with Member States on this topic prior to the possible launching of infringement procedures.  I can assure you that the Commission will not hesitate to take action to ensure the proper transposition and implementation of the Framework Decision by Hungary, like any other Member State. We underlined this in the European Agenda on Security as well as during the Commission’s Colloquium on Fundamental Rights in October. As regards the situation of the media, the Hungarian Parliament amended on 27 May 2015 its advertising tax law, following an EU Pilot procedure and an in-depth state aid investigation launched by the Commission. As a result, the EU Pilot procedure could be closed, while the state aid investigation continues, as certain state-aid related aspects still remain to be clarified.  The Commission has also taken note of the opinion of the Venice Commission of 22 June 2015 on Media legislation in Hungary and is following the response of the Hungarian authorities to the recommendations contained therein. As regards corruption and misuse of EU funds, the Commission suspended on 14 July 2015 payments for several contracts across eight programmes due to the use of an excessively restrictive selection criterion in public procurement procedures. The Commission had already suspended interim payments to Hungary from the European Regional Development Fund for priorities 1, 2 and 3 of the operational programme ‘Economic Development’. This suspension was lifted by the Commission on 23 September 2015, following corrective action by the Hungarian authorities. OLAF is continuing investigations.  In the context of the European Semester, the Commission noted continued shortcomings as regards corruption and lack of transparency affecting public administration, decision-making and public procurement in Hungary. Following a Commission proposal, country-specific recommendations were adopted by the Council on 14 July 2015, calling for action to address these issues.  The Commission is actively pursuing infringement procedures against Hungary in a range of other areas. Several infringement procedures are rule-of-law related, for instance, concerning the principle of legal certainty, the effectiveness of judicial review, or the powers and independence of administrative authorities. Other infringement procedures are related to economic discrimination, in particular affecting the freedom of establishment, the freedom to provide services or the free movement of capital. In addition, the Commission is actively conducting state aid investigations, inter alia concerning two recent Hungarian measures with steeply progressive rate structures, notably a food-chain inspection fee and a new tax on sales of tobacco products. In these cases the Commission issued injunctions, prohibiting Hungary from applying the progressive rates until the Commission has concluded its assessment. The Commission also opened, last week, in-depth state aid investigations into Hungary’s plans to provide financing for the construction of two new nuclear reactors in the Paks plant. The Commission is also following how the judiciary in Hungary is fulfilling its role of guarantor of the rule of law. In recent months a number of noteworthy judgments have been rendered by the Supreme Court, the Constitutional Court and also by ordinary Hungarian courts.  This overview demonstrates that the Commission is actively monitoring the situation in Hungary and is ready to use all the means at its disposal to ensure that Hungary – as well as any other Member State – complies with the obligations under European Union law and respects the values of the European Union enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. This includes using infringement procedures in case of violations of European Union law as well as the EU Rule of Law Framework where this is necessary. The Commission has at this stage not activated the Rule of Law Framework as regards Hungary. The Rule of Law Framework will be activated where there are clear indications of a systemic threat to the rule of law in a Member State, in particular in situations which cannot be effectively addressed by infringement procedures and if the ‘rule of law safeguards’ which exist at national level no longer seem capable of effectively addressing these threats. These national ‘rule of law safeguards’ refer to all judicial and constitutional mechanisms and safeguards which aim to ensure the protection of democracy and fundamental rights in a Member State.  Considering that concerns about the situation in Hungary are being addressed by a range of infringement procedures and pre-infringement procedures, and that also the Hungarian justice system has a role to play, the Commission takes the view that the conditions to activate the Rule of Law Framework regarding Hungary are at this stage not met.  The Commission will continue to monitor the situation in Hungary closely, including the functioning of the national rule of law safeguards referred to above.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, iwould like to thank the Commissioner for the very comprehensive overview. And also a thank you for the answer that you actually gave us on 5 November, which, unfortunately, did not pass on Parliament's administration to Members within the appropriate timeframe, so that we therefore unfortunately received the answer so late that we made an unjustified reproach to you in the question, namely that you allegedly did not reply to us. You have replied to us, and I would like to express my thanks for that. Secondly, I would like to thank you for being very objective in dealing with the issue. In view of the problems that we have, not only in Hungary, but also in Greece and Poland, for example, in a great variety, but also in Slovakia and the Czech Republic at the moment, in the area of dealing with refugees, in dealing with refugees and the like, I think it is urgently necessary for you to try to address this in a objective, structured way and to continue the work here with care. What I see as problematic on the part of Parliament at the moment – and I have said this to colleagues on several occasions – is that the focus is solely on Hungary, when there are enough other Member States with very similar problems. The judicial system in Greece suffers at least as much as it does in Hungary. It is under a left-wing populist and right-wing populist government, which has been experiencing considerable problems for many years, without us discussing this offensively against Greece here in this Parliament under the threat of Article 7 through Parliament. We also have problems with refugees in Hungary, not just in Hungary. We have the same problems in Greece, including with human rights violations. We also have problems in Poland, partly with arguments that are very strong and which are very intense and speak out against refugees, with everyone signing the Convention on Human Rights and having to know that refugees have the right to find refuge in a Member State of the European Union if they are fleeing war, death, hardship and misery and cannot survive in their own homeland. Then we are obliged to give them a home. There should be no discussion about this, but solidarity among the Member States. I would like to say that I find the structured way of proceeding very positive. Commissioner, I would like to ask you: you wrote in your letter that there are a great deal of – so to speak – control mechanisms, monitoring systems. It would be very interesting for us to know which Member States are being followed in what way, because then, for example, as an MEP, I too could have a better overview of whether the systems are being applied fairly – so to speak, evenly – to all the Member States, or whether the view has become a little too specific. I rather believe that you are proceeding very fairly, but I would simply be interested to know more about it.

name: Péter Niedermüller
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Thank you, Mr. President. The Group of Socialists and Democrats strongly stands by the core values of the European Union. These core values are the binder that holds the Union together.  Since 2010, the Hungarian Government has been agreath of European legislation and values, with no regard for the other Member States, the Commission, nothing and no one. Yet what we are debating tonight is not simply a Hungarian issue, but a European matter. The illiberal, anti-Union, far-right politics based on national selfishness are no longer just a threat to Hungary, they have also hit the ground up in other Member States. The Hungarian Government is deliberately and systematically weakening the European Union with its policies. And his party family, the European People's Party, tolerates this without a word. We know that this debate is about the future of the European Union.  Today, the Hungarian Prime Minister found the immigration crisis to be the product of the people smugglers, the paid rights team and the leaders of the Union, who are doing this refugee crisis. I ask if there is anyone in the Commission, or even in the People's Party, who dares to say with a calm heart that this blatant and toxic politics does not endanger the Union as a whole. I don't think so. Commissioner, you have read a long list, but allow me to say that I have the impression that there is a lack of courage and political courage in the Commission to face the actual situation. I'd appreciate it if it turns out I'm wrong. Thank you!

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The concern for democracy in Europe, for the law, for fundamental European values is glorious. It is the European Parliament's duty to respond to violations in member states. However, country-specific assessments and analyses of the situation should be balanced and fact-based, and must not interfere with the democratically taken sovereign decisions of these countries. That is why the European Commission's balanced position is so welcome.  Hungary has been criticised in the European Parliament for its alleged attempt to reinstate the death penalty, but nothing like this has happened, and the Hungarian Government has denied from the outset that it had such intentions. It is absurd to criticise the Hungarian Government for seeing a link between immigration – mass immigration – and a security threat in the light of what happened in Paris. It is hypocritical to accus Hungarians of closing the border when it comes to solved the problem of protecting the EU's external borders with Turkish hands. Accusations of populism, nationalism or xenophobia, thrown without cause, serve only as a political weapon against uncomfortable governments or political parties. While respecting The German Willkommenskultur, we cannot agree to impose it on all European countries. While respecting the diversity of political views as the essence of democracy, we cannot accept a monopoly of left-liberal views in Europe. It is worth recalling Article 3a of the Treaty of Lisbon: "The Union respects the equality of the Member States vis-60 vis-60, as well as their national identity inextricably linked to their fundamental political and constitutional structures. It shall respect the essential functions of the State, in particular those aimed at ensuring its territorial integrity.'

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, contrary to the previous speaker, I do not think that this is about national culture or being left-wing or right-wing; that is rubbish. This is about the European Union being a community of values. This should be a space where every single European citizen can live in freedom, make choices for his or her life without having to fear the authorities.  The thing is, listening to the Commission – not just now but during all the years in the past – the Commission is taking a fairly narrow legalistic approach, and I understand that it does not have that many instruments to do anything else, but the Commission is only assessing whether there is a strict violation of European Union laws. But let us be fair – and I think the Commissioner would agree with me – if we look at the state of Hungary today, is it a place where people are free, happy citizens? No, because there is a government there that is fuelling xenophobia and homophobia, that is harassing the media, harassing NGOs, harassing the opposition – just yesterday 17 people from the opposition were arrested on charges of defamation – restricting free research, and I could go on and on.  Maybe we do not really have a legal instrument to tackle this but we need a political instrument because, quite frankly, I too, like most of my Hungarian colleagues probably, are tired of talking about Hungary. Soon we will be having similar debates about Poland. I have serious concerns about Poland as well. The Polish Government is saying: ‘Oh, we think Mr Orbán is a perfect example to follow.’ What has the new parliament done? It has fired five judges and immediately appointed new ones. That makes me really concerned about the independence of the judiciary.  So I do think that we need to move beyond monitoring the situation or silent diplomacy. I mean, Mr Timmermans’ silent diplomacy is so silent that I do not even see him here today. I really hope that with all the Groups in this House we are going to elaborate the Democratic Governance Pact, which will serve to monitor and debate the situation in all Member States to ensure that we will have, or we will be, this community of values.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, since May 2010, the human rights situation in Hungary has been deteriorating. This Parliament has had the opportunity to debate it and vote on resolutions calling on the Commission to act. Indeed, Hungary is not the only state concerned, all states are more or less concerned with human rights violations, and it would be good if both should cease their political obsessions. Your answer, Commissioner, was long, but I am not satisfied. Is the commission really the custodian of all the articles of the treaty? What about the role of the European Parliament if our resolution last June seems to pass in losses and profits? Is the Charter of Fundamental Rights really an integral part of the treaties? How can it be repeatedly flouted without a real reaction from you? So yes, the rights of migrants are symbolic. They are being raped in Hungary as elsewhere, especially in France, my country. But I would remind you that in Hungary, the police now have the right to shoot migrants. When I hear you, Commissioner, I am sad. I see once again that the Commission is more efficient in terms of the economy: you have talked about state aid, higher taxes, but what about people's rights? You are waiting for court decisions, but you are telling us yourself that justice is a problem in this country. So it is no longer time to write, it is no longer time to say, it is no longer time to worry, we must act without waiting for the death penalty to be reinstated, as you have just told us.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Commissioner, you say that there are enough reports and that there is enough research. We don't need more mechanisms, and I actually share that opinion with you. There's a lot known, but it's not being acted on. You also say in the examples you give: Viktor Orban has indeed spoken about the death penalty, but the proposals have not materialised. That should be added again, I would say. But isn't that already a huge problem, that this can always be talked about, that the conversation in Europe is getting louder, that everyone is saying as a kind of disclaimer: I don't want to compare the refugees to the terrorists, but ...?  I have thrown away my speech, because I read The Guardian this evening in which Donald Tusk, the President of the European Council, says that every migrant arriving in Europe must be locked up for 18 months, so that we can respect security, so that we can see if that migrant is not actually a terrorist. Mr President, Commissioner, I understand, in the light of these debates in Europe, that you do not have the space to use a mechanism of rule of law. I understand that. But I really do not know what to do in this European Parliament at a time when the President of the European Council is saying that every migrant who comes in must be detained for 18 months. Of course, you will never get the support in the Council for any action towards Hungary or for an activity towards Poland, which is now dismissing its judges, if the President of the Council can find this and it is not contradicted. Commissioner, I really only want one thing: I want us to make tusk's comment here tonight that refugees, migrants should be locked up for 18 months, that we all take them back here.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Hungarian Government has adopted political practices, it has launched reforms, legislative measures, accused of eroding democratic control and of creating an increasingly authoritarian regime. Democratic principles, the rule of law and human rights are under threat. The reality is that no strong action has been taken, especially at European level, to respond to what is seen by many as a threat to the founding values of the European Union. Even two days ago, it was presented by the citizens, it was registered on the European Commission's website, an initiative calling for the application of Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union. We must therefore provide an appropriate response from the European Union, we must have a mechanism for protecting fundamental rights that acts preventively and not wait for the death penalty to be introduced, for example, and then sanction a Member State, otherwise respect for fundamental rights will remain nothing more than a declaration of intent.

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, once again this umpteenth debate on Hungary is taking a lynching of the government of Viktor Orban. It's a strange concept of European solidarity, which you're listening to. For, in essence, what is being blamed on the head of the Hungarian government? To respect the Schengen agreements to the letter? These agreements provided for free movement within the European Union and I will not complain to the countries of the former Soviet Union that they were strong supporters of it. But in return, these same agreements were supposed to guarantee the external borders of the European Union. However, in the face of The obvious failure of Frontex, in the face of the lack of political will to stem the unprecedented influx of illegal immigrants, Mr Orbon is doing what all European leaders should have done, he is protecting his people from the massive and uncontrolled immigration which he has seen the consequences in Western Europe: mass unemployment, communitarianism and, today, terrorism. When we see what has become of Brussels, now under siege, we understand that Viktor Orban wants to preserve Budapest from your madness.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: " Mr. President, thank you for the floor. The situation in Hungary is once again on the European Parliament's agenda. If we ask whether relations between the rule of law and democracy in Hungary should be improved, the answer is yes. I mention two areas, one is increasingly open corruption and the other is the serious inevadence of media relations. But it happens in other countries. Why Hungary the person they want to prosecute would result in the suspension of the right to vote.  The answer is simple: because the Hungarian Government, with the support of a large majority of parliament and the population, has implemented an immigration policy that is different from what the Commission represents here and the majority of Parliament, but is effective. It defended its own sovereign borders and, with it, the Schengen borders. And yes, he thinks the quota system is wrong, because it is not necessary to distribute immigrants, but to prevent immigration.  Should we have a common European migrant policy? Should. But it should be effective. To do that, we would have to face the fact that this influx of organised immigrants is part of a war. And by the way, let me add that just because a country, its population, does not welcome immigrants with signs that say "Refugee welcome" does not make it xenophobe. Thank you!

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I listened carefully to the Commissioner’s speech, which lasted more than 15 minutes, on the long list of violations and the saga of the illiberal democracy of Viktor Orbán. My question is, what is enough for the EPP Group and what is enough, and when is it enough, for the European Commission?  Let me be clear from the outset that we have to distinguish between Orbán’s dangerous behaviour and the Hungarian people. The choice of the present instrument, an oral question, is the result of a very mature and responsible debate within my political group which aims exactly at this: protecting Hungarian citizens and not penalising them for the severe infringements carried out by the Hungarian Prime Minister.  It is high time to understand how Parliament can be both offensive and effective against Viktor Orbán without falling into the trap of his extremist populist rhetoric. The time has come for the Commission to assume its responsibilities as outlined by the Treaties and to unmistakably identify and present the deficiencies and shortcomings in terms of rule of law and democracy registered by Orbán and his government, and to take action now.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, today we are once again discussing the situation in Hungary, as we did about half a year ago. In view of all the other undeniably troubling topics, in my opinion, this debate is completely unnecessary, it is a waste of time, a waste of effort, with a single purpose - to make consecutive pointless criticisms of the government of Viktor Orban. Even less I support the idea of preparing many resolutions on this topic. How will these resolutions be different from the one that was proposed on 10 June? On 10 June, we asked the Commission to monitor the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary. Yes, all Member States must respect their commitments and protect fundamental rights, but yes, we all have the right to express and defend this view, but we should not interfere in the monitoring procedure, as it does not fall within the competence of this legislative house. According to Article 17 of the Treaty on European Union, only the European Commission has the competence to conduct such a study and it is only for it to ascertain whether European law and treatises have been infringed. Dear colleagues, I have been listening to this discussion for some time and I am thinking this: I just heard that Viktor Orban's behaviour was dangerous. No, I don't think so. I think the behaviour of those who do not understand what is happening in Europe is dangerous. The behaviour of those of our colleagues who do not understand that the situation has changed greatly, that we are currently at war and that this war will not end unless we defend our values, our nation states. The rest is a waste of time, the rest largely, dear colleagues, are empty talk and hypocrisy.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, it is with great distress that we have witnessed the constantly worsening state of democracy and rule of law in Hungary over the past years. The freedom of the media has been curtailed through Fidesz-controlled media supervisors who have brought about fear and self-censorship. The court system has been politicised and the freedom of minorities is being trampled on by the Government. This week we saw the arrest of a number of opposition politicians in Hungary, purely for having shared political criticism of Fidesz policies on Facebook. It was notable that, although these posts were shared by many individuals, the actions of the now Fidesz-run judiciary of Hungary targeted its attacks at active members of the political opposition. I am usually a big fan – a supporter even – of the Commission, but I would say to the Commissioner that on Hungary, quite frankly, the Commission is nothing but pathetic in your inaction. You have done absolutely nothing with regard to Parliament’s resolution adopted in June. You only offer words and hot air and not a single concrete political action. You are supposed to be the guardians of the treaties, not the guardians of oppressive governments. What are you waiting for? Does Mr Orbán have to turn into an exact copy of Mr Lukashenko before you wake up and smell the coffee? I find it appalling. Your inaction leaves a lot to be desired by citizens out there. Take action on this and do it now.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Mr Orbán's Government in Hungary is systematically violating human rights. His proposal to implement the death penalty; inhumane treatment of refugees at borders; violence against migrants. And there has not yet been any forceful sanction on this Member State of the European Union. Why? Well, because he's one of yours. Because it's from the European People's Party.  Because he was a few weeks ago at the Congress of the European People's Party in Madrid with Mr Mariano Rajoy, Mrs Merkel and even Berlusconi. And there you applauded your xenophobic speech. They protect him, pat him, because they protect his friends and because, deep down, in reality, many, deep down, share their program.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE).
text: Thank you, Mr. President. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. We have said many times that the debate on the democratic situation in Hungary is not primarily about Hungary, but about Europe. It is about whether this integration dreamed up by the founding fathers is a mere economic cooperation, or a community of values, with commonly agreed moral standards, expectations of the rule of law, the observance of which it forces its members to comply.  The Commission's inertia and delay in relation to the Hungarian Government, which consistently and systemically violates these common values, strengthens those who willingly disrebehavie these values throughout Europe. Those who, like Viktor Orban, regard the EU as nothing more than a sucker milking cow. For whom a common Europe is merely a scapegoa on the back of which they can climb politically. But the sight of helplessness makes this example sticky. Those who delay now will be hit by a storm. Those who do not act now will be weak to act later. It will be too late later, fellow Members.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: –  Mr President, here you go again. All for the rule of law, as long as it is your law. All for freedom, as long as it is the freedom to live within EU constraints. I saw disgraceful disrespect to the leader of a sovereign independent government when Mr Orbán came to Strasbourg. He was treated in an appalling manner and why? Because he dared to consult with his people about immigration, about law and order?  Now he has upset you again by building a fence to keep out immigrants.  Well, you might not like it, but this is the elected government of a sovereign state. They should have the right to make their own laws. Any attempt to change the situation in Hungary would be a sinister EU regime change. The people of Hungary should follow the example of the people of the UK, regain their independence and freedom, and leave the EU.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, on 10 June, our Parliament adopted a pseudo-moralising proposal to denounce the desire for political revival initiated for five years now in Hungary by Mr Orbon.  Since then, the Hungarian government has aggravated its case in the eyes of the political correctness of Brussels. He successfully erected a deterrent barrier at his country's border, he refused the quota system that dilutes and perpetuates the migration invasion, he has made a living by animating a real political resistance in Central Europe, gathered in the Visegred group, together with Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovakia.  Unlike the true candid and false naive people who populate this assembly - and I am not talking about hypocrites - Mr.  Orban did not wait for the tragic events in Paris to take action. His fears were well-founded since we learned only a few hours ago that the alleged mastermind of the Paris attacks, Salah Abdeslam, who had returned from Syria, had transited through Hungary and Austria before the Paris attacks.  The will of Mr Orbon to preserve the security and freedoms of Hungarians is better than your guilty blindness of yesterday and your soft and unabsorbed security policy today.  Thank you to Budapest for giving Europe of the peoples as well as the oligarchy lessons of lucidity and good governance.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Mr President, we will soon be called upon to press the European Commission to impose measures against Hungary because it has been accused of violating fundamental principles of the European Union, the rule of law and democracy. All this, because as an independent and sovereign state, it has taken a decision that some circles of the European Union did not like. The whole affair, method, and procedure, in addition to the purposes it serves, also shows the extent of the hypocrisy that percesses the European Union. The European Parliament is sensitive to some possible violations of the principles of democracy and the rule of law by Hungary and is defiantly indifferent when these violations occur in a way that cannot be disputed in Greece. How many times, both myself and my fellow Golden Dawn MEPs, had we denounced the then Greek government which, unnecessarily and illegally, imprisoned the leader, MPs and members of our party, the country's third political power? When did the European Parliament show sensitivity to the murders of the two young supporters of our party, Giorgos Foudoulis and Manus Kapelonis, and asked with the same warmth to arrest their murderers who have so far been on the loose for two years? When was the European Parliament moved and called for action when the onerous measures of the Memorandum made the Greek people angry? Now you're asking us to consent to collusion against a sovereign state... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, today, six months after we discussed them, many of the considerations put forward, such as the concern and condemnation of the intentions expressed to recover the death penalty or discrimination and persecution of immigration, alongside the walls of shame in Hungary, but also the Member States of the European Union, which are beginning to replicate.  We do not accept, however, that - on the pretext of the humanitarian crisis, authoritarian and undemocratic abuses - in any country there will be democracy and that interference will be formalised. We are against the unacceptable set of proposals which then and now seek to be implemented, in particular the unacceptable proposal to create an authentic ranking of the rule of law democracy and fundamental rights, not least because we do not recognise the European Union or the European Commission the legitimacy to do so, because we know that its concept of democracy differs according to its interests. This would be a tool of the Commission on Member States whose consequences can only result in further intervention and interference.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, what is this? A debate about Hungary? No. It is a debate on the situation in Hungary with Viktor Orbán's government, from the family of the European People's Party, installed in extreme nationalist rhetoric and, moreover, aggressively anti-European – rayane in europhobia – which speaks of the death penalty, builds walls. And so it is a debate that reaches the whole of Europe and affects the whole of Europe in the worst crisis in its history.  It defies the Copenhagen criteria, which are not only demanded when entering the club, but when staying at the club. And they therefore call for European action by this European Parliament and the European Commission. And the European Commission is even unable to implement the rule of law mechanism to assess the lack of democratic quality, respect for the rights of minorities, judicial independence and the right to the court of law in Hungary, as a citizen initiative registered on 30 November which requires the application of Article 7. Commissioner, convince the College of Commissioners, Mrs Jourová, for the Commission to do something to defend the European values put into crisis more seriously than ever with Viktor Orbán's Government in Hungary. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Mr President, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. Do you realise that Article 2(2) of the Charter of Fundamental Rights prohibits the adjudication and execution of the death penalty and does not force governments to block discussion.  And if we are talking about a Charter of Fundamental Rights, it may be worth it for you to remember whether your government respects the rights of parents, which are guaranteed by the Charter of Fundamental Rights, to raise their children according to their own moral beliefs. I saw in Spain how Spanish society was reacting at the time, so I really encourage you: a little more modesty.

name: Presidente. –
text: Blue card, Mr Jurek. The blue card is for asking questions. No, no, it's not a question, it's your consideration, the question didn't ask. Mr López, it is not a question that you have asked. However, Mr López.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
