text: "blue card" response. – Mr President, of course, I have not heard any questions because there has not been any questions. I have heard a mention of an article of the Treaty on European Union which must be read with all others, particularly in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  Tell Viktor Orbán's Government - in case he has not known - that being part of the European Union means being part of a space without a death penalty and, therefore, anyone who introduces that matter into the debate will have to answer to the whole of Europe. A conquest of the civilization of law and freedoms that must be actively preserved by the guardian of the Treaties, which is the Commission. That's why we debated. When a ruler of the European Union dares to talk about the reinstatement of the death penalty as an object of debate, he is disrespecting the contract he acquired when he became part of the European Union.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank Commissioner Jourová for her report, but we are still concerned about the situation in Hungary and the situation in those countries where the measures taken by governments may lead to a clear violation of fundamental rights and values, such as respect for human dignity, democracy and equality, on which the European Union is founded. This is also true of the citizens of those same countries, who, moreover, at the time of accession to Europe, believed in the model of democracy and the defence of the rights that the Union represents. We all expect, therefore, that the European Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, will carry out careful and constant monitoring for the maintenance of the rule of law in all Member States, and we expect the Commission to address the issue of rights in its entirety and not in a fragmented manner, thus exercising its role in the European context in an incisive and effective manner.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: - Dear Hungarian Citizens! Don't believe everything they tell you. It is true that I represent the Netherlands in this Parliament, I say openly that I am very proud to be of Hungarian origin. My message to all Fidesz members is that I am not talking about the situation in Hungary tonight in revenge.  However, as Europeans, we must stand up for European principles. If Orban and his cronies pocket the money of EU taxpayers, it is right that we hold the Fidesz government to account. If schengen is really to be maintained, they need to know that it is also a community of values, not just about interests. The Hungarian Government has long ignored these values and is working against the interests of the Hungarian people. Thank you very much!

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In view of the long list of serious problems, Mrs Jourova, I do not understand the Commission's decision not to activate the first stage of the rule of law mechanism in the case of Hungary. When will we finally turn a sharper eye on the activities of the Orban government? In all seriousness, do we want to continue to act so laxly when this government questions and mocks the common European values? This question has been asked to me time and again, including in my constituency in Berlin. The citizens are asking with deep concern, and they are asking this precisely because they know how much we Germans owe, how much we Berliners owe to Hungarians. And the fact that this concern is evidently also well-received by civil society in many of our Member States is demonstrated by the European citizens' initiative Wake Up Europe, which has just been launched. It calls on the Commission to initiate Article 7 against Hungary, and I think that is a clear sign that we are being asked to act clearly and that we should not look further away. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI)
text: blue-card question. – How would you stop Mr Orbán? By sending in the Red Army?

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. That is really a very nonsensical question. They do not expect me to answer 'yes'. It is quite clear that we have common European values enshrined in the Treaty. The list of problems raised by Mrs Jourova is very long and covers many policy areas. We all have every reason to be concerned about developments in Hungary. The responsibility for this lies with the government. And the government must also face up to criticism from this House and other European institutions, as well as from civil society. We owe this to the joint development of this European House!

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I will comment on the part that concerns, of course, Hungary, although To some extent I agree that some other Member States would also deserve attention. I think my colleague Hohlmeier is right about that. But if we are examining the constitutional reforms that have been implemented in Hungary, even though I am a member of the PPE here in Parliament, I cannot obscure the fact that it is an embarrassment. It is embarrassing because Hungary was the first country to be subject to monitoring by the Council of Europe. It was the first EU member state. I was a member of the Council of Europe at the time, so I know what I am talking about. And it must not be obscured that those constitutional reforms that have been implemented in the last two or three years are, in my view, well behind the edge of acceptability in terms of European rules, european values.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: "Thank you for the opportunity, Mr. President. Listening to this debate, I was a little shocked, because, after all, the subject matter was how the Commission assessed the situation in Hungary, and most of the speakers took up the issue of refugees after all.  Indeed, many, hundreds of thousands of refugees have suffered in recent months because of the various actions of the Hungarian Government, but my biggest concern as a Hungarian MEMBER is that millions of Hungarian people have been suffering for years now.  And I just want to say three things very quickly. Can you imagine an international press group, a rotating group, being thrown out of the Hungarian Parliament at the press conference of the Prime Minister and the NATO Secretary General because they were not specifically invited there? Or is it that contracts from European sources can only be obtained in Hungary if someone is a relative of the Prime Minister, or at least forming a consortium in which he must be a relative of the Prime Minister?  Ladies and gentlemen, I'm sorry. This is no longer about Viktor Orban's world, this is about orwell's world.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the huge refugee wave affecting the European Union has highlighted its inherent contradictions. Its leaders started a dog fight since no one wanted to take responsibility. But closing borders will not reduce the refugee flows that Western policy itself has caused. Because it is the West that has created this explosive situation in Syria, Iraq, Libya and Afghanistan through its interventions. Closing borders channels flows elsewhere. After Hungary, Slovenia, Austria and Germany closed their borders. This has left thousands of refugees in the European South and especially in Greece. According to the decision of 23 September, the leaders decided on a refugee allocation clause based on the country's size, population and GDP. Thus, Greece is hosting 11,000 refugees, not 50,000, which Mr. Tsipras quite wrongly accepted. And yet, nevertheless, "we have heard them from above" with the strong criticism of the 'so-called' Europeans who only care that if the unfortunate refugees of Syria spoil their peace.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, where are our friends from the European People's Party now? There's no one here. They're not interested in Hungary? The situation in Hungary? Or maybe our friends don't have any arguments, so that's why they're not here and they don't want to participate in this discussion?  Madam Commissioner, you have listed so much that I wonder if the country is even a member of the European Union. Would someone who has all these problems you have listed: the issue of the judiciary, freedom of the media, attitude towards the Roma, freedom of movement of capital, state aid - could such a country become a member of the European Union? We really have a serious problem within us. Maybe even Hungary is no longer an isolated case. And I believe that this Commission will really do everything to finally try to sort out everything that is happening in Hungary. Otherwise, article 7 will really need to be activated to the end.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, due to the fact that my speech at the beginning was really quite long and I enumerated all the problems which we are addressing using the instruments we have in hand, I only want now to repeat that we are monitoring closely not only Hungary, but also other Member States.  When we see, based on an objective, thorough assessment, that there is a systematic breach of the Treaty, we will act using Article 7. Up till now we have been using the instruments which we have for the problems which I enumerated in my speech.  This does not mean that I did not follow very closely what you have said and all your arguments, and I can only, on behalf of the Commission, confirm here that Hungary will be at the centre of our attention, as well as other Member States where we see similar problems, because one of the principles which we have to keep to is equal treatment towards Member States. Let me thank you for the discussion.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the next part-session. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF)
text: in writing. I find this debate somewhat superfluous, at least now. It calls for an update of the monitoring of the rule of law, democracy, human rights or the violation of human rights in Hungary following statements made months ago by President Orban, which are questionable, of course, but at this unnecessary historical moment. There is talk of exasperation of the state of democracy and systematic threat to the rule of law. Well, I move the subject over what Orban has done to protect his country: a real defence of borders and, consequently, of his people. Orban was right to launch a public, democratic consultation on immigration, including on migration and terrorism: in the light of what happened only a few weeks ago, he saw us right. Consultations accusing European policies: is it not said that Europe must do more and that some policies are wrong? I evaluate the 12 questions asked in the questionnaire that are absolutely legitimate, relevant and forward-looking. We wash our mouths talking about democracy and involving the people through consultative referendums, but one may well wonder what the Hungarian President has ever done. Such a President would also be needed in Italy! Good President Orban!

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – As a proud Hungarian and European Democrat, I will never support the us introducing any sanctions against Hungary for the functioning of the current government that harm the interests of the Hungarian nation. Viktor Orban is not equal to the Hungarian nation. However, some things cannot be left without retaliation. In Hungary, almost all of the EU funds used from the common funds are used to fatten up the close-to-government clique. And without consequences.  Allow me to quote briefly from the previous Electoral Programme of the People's Party Fidesz in the European Parliament. They say: "One of the weaknesses of the European Union at the moment is its difficulty in aitheses in up to its own values and principles (...) This is mainly due to the fact that the institutions of the Union are afraid to interfere in the internal affairs of a government. At the same time, Fidesz is convinced that the acre of our common values and principles cannot be weighed. It is therefore necessary to give the European Union the means to continually urge its members to represent values and to adhere to the principles; without it, there is no strong Europe (...) It is a contradiction to expect the UNION to get the governments of the Member States to follow the norm, but we are reluctant to give it the authority that might undermine our sovereignty." Fidesz was right, even if it now says the opposite. It's time to do something until it's too late.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on linda McAvan's oral question to the Commission on "Protection of the Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of the Congo" by Linda McAvan, on behalf of the DEVE Committee (O-000108/2015 - B8-1111/2015) (2015/2728(RSP)).

name: Paavo Väyrynen
text: deputising for the author. – Mr President, the oral question was adopted by the Committee on Development on 22 September 2015, together with a winding-up resolution on the protection of the Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). I am very pleased to present it on behalf of the Committee. This debate on the protection of Virunga National Park in the North Kivu province of the DRC comes at a critical time, as just three days ago, on Sunday night, the Ugandan rebels of allied democratic forces attacked a military headquarters of the Congolese army in Eringeti and the city itself in the territory of Beni, close to the northern border of the park. This illustrates the violence and insecurity in the whole region of eastern DRC and particularly in the North Kivu province, where the park is located. On Monday, the Committee on Development organised a joint hearing with the Subcommittee on Security and Defence on the links between development and security. Yesterday, the Committee received the High Representative/Vice-President of the Commission, Mrs Mogherini, who again stressed the link between development and security. I would also like to stress here, in this debate on the protection of the Virunga National Park, the link between development, ecology and security. The resolution that we will vote on in Strasbourg in two weeks’ time stresses the absolute need to protect the Virunga National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It stresses that irreversible damage to the Virunga National Park could occur as the result of exploration and exploitation of oil or other activities. Currently, fishing in Lake Edward generates an estimated USD 30 million per year to the benefit of the local communities which live near the park. This figure is projected to double as a result of sustainable fisheries created by the Virunga Alliance, the park’s clean energy initiative. Mountain gorilla tourism alone could generate USD 38 million per year and create thousands of jobs. I think we should do more to protect local communities, as well as the endangered species in the park, such as the mountain gorillas and okapi.  I recall that oil exploration and exploitation are not compatible with UNESCO World Heritage status.  The message of our resolution is very clear. We call on the Commission and the Member States to further address the root causes of armed conflicts and corruption and to support sustainable development and peace—building strategies in the park and the surrounding region. We also urge the Commission, the Member States, the DRC and any oil company interested in drilling for oil to protect the current boundaries and the neighbouring areas of the Virunga National Park from the exploitation of fossil fuels.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am grateful to the honourable Member for bringing Parliament’s attention to the situation in Virunga National Park. Virunga illustrates the multi—dimensional challenges faced in the Great Lakes region, where peace—building, stabilisation and state-building need to go hand in hand.  Virunga is a unique World Heritage Site. Sadly, it is also a dangerous place to work and a difficult place to protect. A group of courageous and dedicated individuals have sacrificed their safety and sometimes their lives in the cause of conservation. They deserve our respect and appreciation. The EU must remind partners, including the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), of their duties under international agreements, including those which relate to natural resources. At the same time, we recognise the importance of taking into account the needs and the economic aspirations of local populations. This is an important focus within our development assistance to the DRC, designed to incentivise environmental protection and alternatives to illegal activities within parks.  The honourable Member rightly draws attention to an important human rights dimension among the challenges faced by Virunga: serious crimes, including sexual violence and violence against children, stem from conflicts with and between armed groups. Sadly, Virunga is not alone in this respect. Predation by armed groups on the resources of other DRC national parks such as Garamba, the scene of illegal activities by the Lord’s Resistance Army (LRA) and groups from as far afield as Sudan, also needs to be urgently addressed. Supporting human rights defenders and civil society around the park needs to remain a priority for the EU.  Our overall approach to Virunga recognises not only the need to protect the park but also to encourage legitimate development. Virunga produces significant renewable and sustainable products and services, including managed fisheries, hydro-electricity and agriculture, and it ensures food security to millions of people.  One goal of our financial support has been to support priority actions defined by mutual agreement with the Government of DRC. We have used European Development Fund and budget resources to boost an ambitious development programme, the ‘Alliance Virunga’.  Under the 10th European Development Fund, the EU supported Virunga with around EUR 10 million. Under the 11th EDF, EUR 40 million is available, triggering other donors to add their resources and, in particular, substantial private funds from the Buffett Foundation.  This support needs to be seen in the broader context of EU support to DRC national conservation policies and management of forests and biodiversity. The regional programme on management of fragile ecosystems of Central Africa (ECOFAC), also supported by the EU, has funded complementary actions. And the Global Climate Change Alliance was allocated EUR 14 million under the Environment budget line for mitigation actions in the region.  Finally, environment and sustainable agriculture is an area of concentration in the 11th EDF, with EUR 120 million allocated across the Democratic Republic of Congo. The impact on the populations living in the vicinity of protected areas will be a key issue in the programme.  I would like now to turn to the remaining specific issues raised by the honourable Member in her question. The first of these concerns the diplomatic response. In partnership with the Member States and other donors present in the DRC, the EU conveys messages on the protection of the park and other World Heritage Sites. Virunga has been raised in meetings with President Kabila and Prime Minister Matata by high-level EU representatives including Commission Vice-President Sefčovič and Commissioner Mimica as well, of course, as the Head of the EU Delegation to the DRC and other EU Heads of Mission. The EU has participated in joint initiatives, including a joint letter to the Prime Minister, expressing concern about oil exploration in Virunga, which was sent earlier this year.  Recognising the integrity of the park is an essential part of the EU position: Lake Edward is part of the ‘universal value’ that grants Virunga World Heritage status, and oil exploration and exploitation are incompatible with the UNESCO Convention.  The question also mentions how the EU can help the DRC Government address armed conflicts and support sustainable development and peace—building. The EU supports the Addis Ababa Peace Security and Cooperation Framework, the principal international agreement focused on peace and stabilisation in the Great Lakes region. This is the only viable roadmap for long-term peace and security in the region. More specifically, the EU assists the DRC in addressing insecurity in Virunga and the surrounding area, and the EU is active in the justice and security sector reform processes. To give one example, an EU-funded expert has trained the judicial authorities in ballistics examination. This was done in the framework of Investment contributing to Stability and Peace (IcSP) funded projects in support of military justice. Such expertise has been applied in the investigation into the shooting of the Director of Virunga National Park. The EU also supports conflict resolution initiatives through its Instrument contributing to Stability and Peace. Thus, the IcSP has funded two relevant projects: the ‘security and stabilisation of cross-border areas of the Central Albertine Rift’ and ‘Strengthening of government institutions in management of protected areas’.  The honourable Member also drew attention to the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. The UN Guiding Principles are a framework conducive to responsible business, forming part of our Strategy on Corporate Social Responsibility. An EU Staff Working Document sets out the EU’s activities in implementing the guidelines and promoting progress in business and human rights. And, of course, the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises is also a building block of the Strategy on Corporate Social Responsibility.  More broadly, on natural resources, I would also recall the EU engagement on responsible sourcing of tin, tungsten, tantalum and gold originating from conflict-affected and high-risk areas and, in particular, the EU financial support to the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region (ICGLR) initiative on natural resources. Finally, a word on the strategic environmental assessment of oil exploration and exploitation in the Northern Albertine Rift. The EU and other partners encourage the DRC to wait for the results of the Sustainable Environment Assessment (SEA) before any decision on oil exploration or exploitation is made. For the SEA to be a real decision-making tool, it will be essential to ensure the maximum level of professionalism and transparency in the award of the contract for the next phase. That includes sufficient ownership by the Ministry of the Environment in agreeing the Terms of Reference. I have tried to address the different aspects of this question. However, I wish to end on a broader conclusion. Ensuring a viable future for parks and protected areas in the DRC means addressing both the root causes of conflict and the root causes of illegal activity. It also means working on state—building, because in the long term only effective governance by the DRC itself will ensure the protection of the parks and their development for sustainable activities. For this reason, the EU’s ongoing focus on security sector reform, governance, anti-corruption and public financial management in the DRC remains as important as the specific support we have given and will continue to give to Virunga.  Also, of course, I cannot ignore the importance of democracy and accountability to the DRC’s stability. The EU will continue to recall the constitutional obligations and the need for a rapid consensus on the electoral cycle between now and November 2016.

name: Joachim Zeller
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which The Virunga National Park on Lake Edward, in the east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, is the oldest nature reserve in Africa. Famous for its wide variety of rare plants and animal species, but mainly because it has the last larger population of mountain gorillas. About 400 of these imposing animals still live in the mountain forests of the Virunga volcanoes.  The Virunga National Park, a World Heritage Site, is also one of the most endangered natural paradises. In the vicinity of the park and on its territory there is a strongly growing population. Many people who have fled the genocide in Rwanda are still there. But marauding militias and rebel groups are harassing the population, killing and raping people. It is poached and valuable timber is illegally harvested. The greatest threat is experienced by this unique natural paradise, which the government of the DRC once committed itself to protecting, but by the fact that this government of the DRC awards production concessions to international energy companies, because oil deposits are suspected in the area of Lake Edward.  Although Total – and a few days ago, under international pressure, so-called SOCO International, based in London – has returned its mining rights, the DRC maintains its claim to continue to search for and extract oil in the area. But it is not only hunting the animals and the natural resources of the park – in the last 20 years, 140 of the park protectors have already had to pay for the service to preserve the park with their lives. The Park Rangers need our urgent support, financially and materially, as they perform their dangerous service to the preservation of this natural monument for all mankind. However, this also means that no raw materials from illegal mining in this area may be imported into the EU, including products containing materials that originate from illegal mining or have been promoted through forced labour.  And pressure must be exerted on the governments of Congo, and also uganda, to ensure the protection of the World Natural Heritage that they have contractually guaranteed. To this end, they should receive our help in the economic development of their countries. Thank you!

name: Maria Arena
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr. President, Virunga Park, it has been said, has been a Unesco Heritage Site since 1979. This world heritage is now under threat. It is threatened by exploration for the exploitation of oil, gas, but also minerals - wealth that, as we know, in this region, feeds all the lusts, from multinationals to militias and armed groups, as well as at the local level. The security environment is also very tense at the moment in the Democratic Republic of Congo, as you said, Commissioner, on the eve of the elections, and in Virunga Park, it has been said, more than 140 people working there have already been murdered. And so, once again, economic interests, wherever they may be, take precedence over the protection of nature, the environment and even entire lives in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The resolution raises a number of questions: First, how can we encourage the Congolese government to respect these riches? The second is how can we ensure that European multinational companies operating in fragile regions comply with the UN's guidelines on business and human rights?

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – SOCO is a British oil company that wants to drill for oil in Virunga National Park and this shows that there are no adequate European rules to deter a European company from causing enormous damage in a unesco-recognised nature reserve that is a base of operations, including for the local population, and where tourism can still take place. It shows that we are not doing enough.  You can say that, of course, it is mainly because congo is a failed state. That's true. But it is also another illustration of the commodity curse and we could do more about it. You yourself mentioned the legislation on conflict minerals. It's not about oil. It is about minerals, but still, it is ahead in Europe. The European Commission has only put forward a proposal for voluntary certification. That could be a lot harder. I think the solution to this kind of commodity swearing is: real hard legislation.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Wirunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo is one of africa's most famous parks, a Unesco World Heritage Site. Irreparable damage to the park's fauna and flora may occur as a result of oil exploration and extraction, as has already been said here. More than 80% of the park area is covered by hydrocarbon exploration concessions. Concerns are raised that the granting of concessions is in breach of international conventions of which the Democratic Republic of congo is a signatory, as well as Congolese law itself. In addition, the legal system of that country, on the basis of which oil is exploited, is ineffective. Attempts are being made to declassify part or all of the park.  Wirunga Park is also one of the most dangerous places in the world: for more than 20 years there has been an armed conflict between rebel troops and government forces, so effective nature conservation in the area is greatly hampered and workers' lives are at risk. In the last 10 years only, more than 240 guards mentioned by my colleague Zeller have lost their lives in their service. There are systematic human rights violations in the park: guerrillas commit murders, rape the people living in the park, and destroy their settlements.  The European Union should assist the Congolese authorities in the reform of geological law so that this law effectively protects the unique fauna and flora and that investors wishing to operate in the Democratic Republic of congo operate in accordance with national and international standards. The international community should support the country in its efforts to end the conflict in the park and prevent the financing of rebel groups from the oil trade. It is crucial to ensure the safety of the families, the guards of this park, as well as the people living there.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo is considered one of the most important parks in all of Africa, with rich biodiversity, and is also considered a world heritage site by UNESCO as it has thousands of rare wild animals. However, in Virunga Park, the Democratic Republic of Congo, in violation of international conventions, has authorised the exploration and extraction of oil, gas and other minerals, thus putting the protection of the park and, by extension, the protection of the wild animals living there at immediate risk. At the same time, armed conflict and corruption are on the agenda, resulting in a violation of human rights in the region, culminating in the risk of life for the park's guards, one of whom was recently shot. The Commission should therefore take immediate and multiple measures to protect the biodiversity of the park but also to protect endangered animals and, at the same time, should take initiatives to force the Democratic Republic of Congo to comply with international requirements.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, is it possible that our generation will witness a culturecide we saw in Palmyra or an ecocide we may see in Virunga? Before our eyes there are major crimes against the cultural heritage of humanity, the natural heritage proclaimed by UNESCO, and that is why I am sure that all of us here must some way take some responsibility for what is happening.  The United Nations must do something about it. It must be the European Union that encourages the United Nations, even with units that will preserve the cultural and natural heritage of the world in those parts of the world where we have unrest. I think that's the only way we need to go because everything else will mean the destruction of centuries-old cultural and, of course, natural heritage.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, two thirds of the world's known oil reserves are in the Middle East, but dependence on this area is unacceptable from a geostrategic point of view according to the imperial powers. Thus, the main multinational oil companies are clearly involved in the search for new oil exploration on the African continent. In 2010 the Congolese government signed an oil exploration contract in areas covering 85% of the Virunga park area, although Congo law prohibits any exploitation in this park that is considered a World Heritage Site by UNESCO. Thus, this national park is now threatened, in particular by the concessions given to multinationals. With respect for the sovereignty of all the countries involved, and in particular the Democratic Republic of congo, it is our duty to seek to ensure policies for the exploitation of resources at the service of local people and not at the service of the accumulation of profits by multinationals that do not look at ways to reach their ends.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – So, it is one of the largest parks in the world, it is one of the parks with almost the largest bio diversification, and years ago there was a warning about the risk of oil extraction in these areas. And despite numerous warnings and UNESCO guidelines on the operation of multinationals, it has tried, in fact, to achieve dominance over national parks through the capital's influence. Thank God it didn't quite happen, but it certainly left a consequence. Nevertheless, I think that we must also report from this podium that these parks can also be a huge opportunity for so-called sustainable and sustainable development, including for so-called alternative energy sources, which, of course, can also provide new jobs, in this case more than 50,000 jobs, as has been shown in one of the studies. And it is actually our duty to support that.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Madam President, I am not a democrat, but if you are a democrat, you must believe that the sovereign Democratic Republic of Congo has the right to drill for oil and for whatever it wants. The sovereign Republic of Hungary can introduce the death penalty or decide not to. That is democracy. That is sovereignty.  I just wanted to ask how one can be wasting European taxpayers’ money on a discussion about the internal situation in the Republic of Congo. Moreover, I think that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, let us be clear about this: it is good to talk about the situation in the Virunga park, but we have no intention of solving the problem there, because the multinationals that go to exploit the resources that are there – we are talking about oil – are European: Soco is English, Total is French. The companies that are supposed to be involved in the park electrification project, which has been authorised by the Congolese Government, the Democratic Republic of Congo, are Belgian and British, so they are European companies, companies that we should try to put pressure on or at any case a modus operandi that is respectful of a place that is the greatest example of biodiversity, a park of 8,000 square meters. , a park in which there are species to be protected, a park that is a World Heritage Site. However, on the other hand, our priority has always been to protect trade diplomacy, so, in short, it is a little difficult to find a solution when one thing is done with one hand and with the other the opposite is done completely.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I just want to thank you for a useful discussion.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the next part-session. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Virunga National Park is Africa's richest biodiversity park. It has been on the Unesco World Heritage List since 1979 and is home to many emblematic species (gorillas, okapis, elephants, etc.). Oil exploration and exploitation, relayed by a range of illegal activities, can cause irreversible damage to this park. It is threatened by this exploitation, but also by those of the gas and minerals that fuel all the lusts, be it those of multinationals or local armed or terrorist groups.  Currently, more than 140 people have already been murdered in the DRC in Virunga Park. We see once again that economic interests take precedence over the environment, nature, but also human beings as a whole.  Against the principle of interference, I believe that we must cooperate jointly with the DRC, the United Nations and all possible local actors to ensure the safety and preservation of this magnificent park and its species. We must also find a solution to put pressure on European multinationals based in the DRC to respect the principles of human rights or nature in that region.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I believe that this debate shows Europe's hypocrisy towards its former colonies. After decades of political interference and economic exploitation, of absolute indifference or even hostility towards the sovereign development of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, the European Parliament suddenly laments the destruction of a natural heritage such as Virunga's, without considering the origin of this crisis, without wondering what interests the oil multinationals represent or the origin of the guerrillas operating in the region - because if it did , should assess the past and present of economic spolio and political interventionism for which he is guilty. Beyond the solution to this crisis, a full re-evaluation of European policies in this area is needed.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches pursuant to Rule 163 of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in my short speech, I wanted to speak on a subject that concerns the digital single market. I wanted to take advantage of the Commissioner sitting here, where this agenda partly falls within her portfolio in some legal aspects. I have held several meetings with various business groups in the Czech Republic and have been to various conferences and I was pleasantly surprised at how this topic is vividly perceived by Czech entrepreneurs. For the sake of completeness, I supply at least one statistic. In the Czech Republic, 26 small and medium-sized companies sell online goods online, the most in the whole of Europe within SMEs. I therefore wanted to use this short speech to call on the European Commission to speed up the preparation, especially on a legal level, of online sales contracts and the transport of goods across Europe, so that entrepreneurs can streamline their business and profits.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the European ceramics industry employs more than two hundred thousand people in Europe, thirty thousand in Spain and more than half, 17,000, in my region, the Valencian Community. It is a competitive, innovative, exporting and high value-added industry. An industry that suffers, however, from social, environmental dumping, subsidized prices and energy costs higher than its competitors and which must now face global overproduction and the possible granting of market economy status to China. It is obvious that China is not a market economy, and the European Union should not grant it such status in advance if it does not meet the established conditions.  To preserve a competitive and job-generating European ceramics industry, we need renewed and effective trade defence instruments. We need to subject importers to the same demands as European producers and reciprocity in market access. I have just been appointed President of the Forum of the European Parliament on Ceramics and I will work decisively together with my colleagues in this Parliament to ensure that the ceramics industry can remain an example.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – We have just had a debate on Hungary, and this coincides with the information that the media is bringing about a European shell court, which is supposed to deprive Hungary of its rights in the European Union. In fact, the whole issue is even more about Europe than Hungary itself. Because perhaps those who attack Hungary here with such fanaticism, perhaps those who are arranging these European petitions, will make the European Union an unbearable place. Just be sure that we will not convert our freedom for any benefit, no praise, no certificates of political correctness. You may be able to break up this Union. Just really think about whether that's what you're all about; because if so, at least everything is clear.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, the rural areas of the European Union are the great wealth of our continent. We have excellent examples of successful cohesion policy, we have excellent examples where the rural area has really evolved rapidly, but unfortunately we still have many more opposing examples. We have major problems with the application of cohesion policy and the development of the rural area.  What I want to highlight are some examples that I personally worked on which are successful examples, especially in this case I am talking specifically about the development of central Istria. Small towns, such as Motovun, Gračišće, Tinjan, Pičan, Grožnjan, Oprtalj are small areas that, through an integral approach, development of infrastructure, tourism, agriculture and culture, managed to really raise the whole area, the rural part of Istria, and this is a great example of how synergy of all activities can develop a rural area in the Territory of the European Union.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, today we heard an anti-Greek delirium from the head of the European People's Party. Mr Weber's finding that the refugee situation is problematic because Greece is 'supposedly' not applying the Schengen rules, and his recommendation for more border guards at the Greek-Turkish border is out of reality. The truth is that refugee flows do not pass through land, but through maritime borders which are practically impossible to seal. Since Turkish slave traders board the unhappy people on the boats and send them to the Greek islands, the only effective method of halt would be submersion, but that would involve countless victims and would be in stark contrast to the fundamental values of our culture. Instead of blaming Greece unfairly, try to find a peaceful solution to the Syrian problem so that refugees can return home.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – According to the World Health Organisation, as many as 5% of the world's population, or 360 million people, live with various hearing impairments, of which around 80 million are deaf. Due to hearing impairment, deaf and hard-of-hearing persons have great difficulty communicating and integrating into the environment in which they live, study, work or spend their free time, which can lead to different forms of social exclusion. One of the key problems faced by deaf people is the inaccessibility of information and sign language education, which in turn makes it difficult for them to exercise all other rights. This is, of course, also a major problem with access to information in the media, especially in television. This can be achieved by subtling dry content on television, which represents a financially minimal cost, but, on the other hand, it is, of course, a step forward. Finally, I would like to draw attention to the very poor access to certain european Parliament content for deaf people, and it is therefore worth considering the establishment of sign languages as official languages in the European Parliament.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Sicily is an island with such an exceptional history that it is enough to dig a metre everywhere and to find archaeological finds of all kinds. Unfortunately, European funds for the development of tourism in a structural way are used to finance nativity scenes, festivals and country festivals. We found EUR 315 000 spent on the illuminated scale of Caltagirone, EUR 160 000 on the Custonaci nativity scene, to give examples, with money that had to be spent on structurally developing tourism to the region. This system is basically used for local politics, to make rain contributions and to secure a certain consensus in the elections. However, since it is European taxpayers' money and should serve to bring all the reasons to the same level, we must try to change something in the rules between the controller and the controlled person, who are often and willingly the same person, and who cause this type of blackout, which then take away the possibilities of the Sicilian citizens who are also European citizens who pay taxes and are entitled to the same services.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF).
text: – Mr President, yesterday was 1 December. December 1st is one of the most important days for the Romanian nation. It is our national day and symbolizes the formation of the modern Romanian unitary national state. Although we Romanians are a nation that was born and evolved with Europe, our recognition, as a national state, came only at the beginning of the 20th century, when from the great empires were born, through self-determination and recognition of the other Europeans, the states of central and eastern Europe. National Day is a moment of joy, but also a moment that urges you to reflect, to reflect on nations and how they must work together within the European Union - I would also like to urge you. The last danger that challenges the lives of European construction is the immigration crisis. By imposing on each Member State to take over refugee quotas, the European Commission has done nothing but tarnish the sovereignty of those Member States that have different positions in the refugee crisis. As things stand, I ask you the following question, to which I ask you to reflect: when, for some reason, Brussels wishes to decide on behalf of national governments, despite their opposition, is it not an attack on the fiber of the nation, and, by implication, on the foundation of the European Union? Because, after all, the nations of Europe form the basis of the architecture of the European Union. Happy Birthday, Romania!

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – It is so strange that EU values are exactly the opposite of European values. In Europe, there was a rule that those who do not work do not eat – there are allowances in the Union for those who do not work. There was a rule in Europe that the murderer has a hang - there is a rule in the Union that the death penalty is abolished. The consequences are that while European values were in power, we Europeans ruled the world, and today we are coloned by nations that have values higher than EU values. I want to say that those who have lifted the death penalty have blood on their hands – the blood of people murdered by bandits who are not afraid of death. People can be murdered, bandits are not allowed to murder. And we must return to European values. I call on the Union to return to Europe. More besides, I think that the European Union must be destroyed if Europe is to return to its glory.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would also take advantage of Commissioner Jourová's presence here, because, in my opinion, the European Commission's proposal to amend the Directive on the control of possession and acquisition of weapons has certainly not been possible for the Commission. Trying to combat terrorism by restricting the legal possession of weapons by up-to-be citizens is obvious nonsense, even in the light of the Paris tragedy. The Commission has failed to deliver on a number of previous promises, is progressing late and sometimes does not understand the terminology of gun legislation at all. Terrorists did not access weapons legally, firstly from non-EU countries, i.e. Serbia, and in the latter case from EU countries. I would like to stress here that, under Directive 2008/51/EC, the Commission should have issued common guidelines on standards and deactivation techniques in order to ensure that deactivated weapons are indeed irreversibly incapable of firing, and it has not yet done so for me for incomprehensible reasons. It is unacceptable to me that the Commission should compensate for its former passivity by presenting a nonsensical draconian proposal.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Mr President, control-free or check-free travel within the frontiers of the Schengen area is a basic principle and one of the greatest achievements of the European Union, although recent tragic events have indeed put Schengen to the test. However, the question of closing European borders was raised well before the Paris terrorist attacks by many Member States in their inadequate attempts to deal with the flow of refugees. This was not the case in Belgium, yet passengers from Hungary, when arriving at Brussels Charleroi Airport, are treated as third-country citizens. Their travel documents are checked at the official checkpoints, while not all other European citizens have to undergo such monitoring. These are not random but rather systematic checks aimed at people coming from Hungary. While we must do our best in order to provide security for everyone under current circumstances, such discrimination and unjustified violation of the Schengen Agreement is both unacceptable and unreasonable.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the masks fell off a few hours ago in this Chamber. Mr Weber and Mr Verhofstadt have called in the most open way for the restriction of Greece's national sovereignty. They asked for troops from Germany and other European countries to guard the Greek border. It turned out, then, what I had denounced from the very first moment, when Merkel and Juncker, speaking of so-called European borders, insidiously called for the co-management of the Greek borders and, by extension, of the Aegean under the pretext of the huge refugee flows that guide the Turkish slave trade. They question Greece's sovereign and non-negotiable rights to guard its borders. So, since the troika has turned Greece into a protectorate and a debt colony, it now wants to send European troops to Greece, supposedly guarding the Greek border. So let the lenders and the troika know that this is not going to pass. The borders of my country are and will remain Greek.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: –  Mr President, to kick-start struggling economies across the Eurozone, the ECB is currently engaged in what is commonly called quantitative easing: EUR 60 billion created every month to spend on the purchase of sovereign bonds on the secondary market. Meanwhile, the ECB is forcing the Irish Central Bank to engage in what I call quantitative squeezing: the destruction of EUR 31 billion, billions that were created in 2009 and 2010 at the height of the euro crisis to bail out the creditors of two zombie, insolvent, non-systemic Irish banks. Does anyone see the contradiction here? In 2011 our central bank destroyed EUR 3.1 billion. Last year we destroyed EUR 1 billion and already this year we have destroyed EUR 1.5 billion. This destruction of borrowed billions is happening at a time when Ireland is suffering record suicide numbers, record numbers of patients waiting on trolleys in accident and emergency, record numbers of people homeless.  Next month a single resolution fund will be introduced which will ensure that in the case of any new failures, banks rather than the sovereigns will foot the bill. Where were those structures in 2009 and 2010? Why has it taken until now, five years later? Biggest question of all, why is Ireland still being forced to carry the full cost of this fundamental failure by the EU in the design of the euro, and by the ECB itself to pay for those possible bank failures?

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – 25% of all deaths on the roads of the European Union are related to alcohol. According to the World Health Organisation, Lithuania is the third largest in the European Union in terms of per capita alcohol consumption. Alcohol consumption leads to a huge number of deaths and injuries on our roads. It is clear that neither Lithuania nor the European Union has done enough to restrict the availability of alcohol. An excellent example of this is the sale of alcohol at gas stations. I have reasonable doubts as to whether European Union funds are not used for the development of the alcohol industry. I therefore call on the European Commission to carry out a thorough study in this area and to ensure that funds are allocated regularly to inform the population about alcohol-related harm.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, yesterday, 1 December, Romania celebrated its national day, thus marking a moment of great historical significance: 97 years since the Great Union. I do not see a better context and place than the European Parliament to talk about Romania's preparation for the Presidency of the Council in 2019. In the autumn of this year, we launched together with several representatives of civil society in Romania a coalition to prepare the Romanian Presidency of the Council. It is essential that in preparing this important event for our country we involve as many voices of society as possible transparently, in a common and coherent approach that generates a clear set of priorities for 2019, capable of marking the future of Romania and the European Union. The start of Romania's preparation for this moment must become a priority, we must set the objectives of the Romanian Presidency and, at the same time, start a wide-ranging public debate on this subject, which obviously involves as many relevant actors of Romanian society as possible in the preparatory efforts of this extremely important moment for Romania.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I would like to use this European rostrum to talk about almadraba: an art of millennial tuna fishing. An art that creates employment and is strongly linked to the territory, capable of producing, but with absolute care and respect for the species. I ask from here for the support of my companions for the written statement on the almadraba and the claims it collects. In particular, I would like to stress the need to give the almadraba an additional fee to improve scientific observation of tuna, as a recent study by the Committee on Fisheries has pointed out.  I also call on the Commission to implement measures at European level to support almadraba, measures which must necessarily include requiring Member States, such as Spain, to respect environmental criteria in the allocation of quotas for sustainable arts such as this fishing model. This fishing art contains the seed of a new production model, a model of economics at the service of work and the environment. That is why it is important that this Parliament supports the lives of an entire people, the life of an entire region.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the Paris Summit raises the very serious problem of global warming of the planet. Certainly, control of the climate and the artificial elements that alter it is of decisive importance for life on earth. But this problem not only has technical solutions, because it is a political and civil problem. If particularly developed countries continue to pursue unreeded industrial and economic growth, we will also go to collective disaster.  Soon, very soon, we must consider our ideal of development. If the well-being of humanity must be sustainable, we cannot base it on constant growth but on development, global for everyone and sustainable for all, that not only seeks to increase wealth but wants to keep us all in well-being, that is, knowledge, beauty and goodness. Because the important change on the planet is attitudes, values and goals.

name: Paul Brannen (S&D).
text: –  Mr President, as Members of this Parliament know, the British Conservative Government has called a referendum on our continued membership of the European Union. In a recent article in the Financial Times Stuart Rose, the former head of Marks and Spencer, called on British business not to stay silent in the EU referendum debate. Alas, this seems to be exactly what many are doing.  So I would like to take this opportunity to say to the business community: don’t wait for permission from David Cameron before you discuss and make your views clear. Speak out now on our membership of the European Union. But not just the business sector. We also need to call on the voluntary sector to speak out. Don’t become the silent sector, instead discuss and speak out. And to the churches: don’t hide behind the offer to facilitate the debate on our EU membership. Take a view, speak out, defend the peace created between European nations that once fought each other.  In the context of our membership of the European Union, silence is not golden. Silence in a democracy is an abdication of responsibility. Don’t abdicate; engage, speak out.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the launch of another cycle of the European Semester shows that the European Union remains blind to reality. A reality marked by low public and private investment, unemployment and the growth of social inequalities. What are these rules in which most countries remain outside the absurd limits of the Stability Pact and the Fiscal Treaty, which have been set in the name of a clear strategy aimed at imposing a neoliberal economic model designed to suit the interests of large economic and financial groups? How can we have a Central Bank pouring billions of euros directly into the coffers of the financial system, while preventing governments from promoting the necessary public investment, or socially addressing the economic crisis in which the European Union has been snare for almost a decade? Continuing to bet on the same hypocritical recipe represents the continuation of a path that must be fought by the struggle of workers for the good of Europe and those who live there.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D).
text: –  Mr President, there are many reasons why public transport is important. One of them is that 64% of job seekers do not have access to a car or cannot drive. So there, in a nutshell, is your link between public transport and the economy. And yet public expenditure on the economy in the West Midlands is GBP 256 per head, whereas in London it is GBP 2 604 per head. Now I do not think that is very fair, and I do not think my constituents think it is very fair either.  We do get some support from the European Union for this public expenditure in the West Midlands, but very little, partly because the Conservative Government of the UK is ideologically opposed to match-funding that funding. So now that we are going to have regional government at last in the United Kingdom, I appeal to the European Union: fund us directly, don’t let the UK Government take our money.

name: Presidente. –
text: The one-minute speeches pursuant to Rule 163 of the Rules of Procedure end here.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst UKIP recognises that there is a need for bodies like the OECD and G20 to revise the tax treatment of multi-national companies, we have seen from the plenary resolution of 25 November 2015 that the European Parliament and the TAXE Committee are more interested in harmonising taxes, eliminating tax competition and extending the powers of the EU into tax matters which are properly the exclusive competence of sovereign nations.  These are not matters for the EU, and the TAXE Committee has shown itself to be powerless to require attendance of witnesses or disclosure of documents – without which its investigations can only ever be inconclusive.  For these reasons UKIP voted against.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This vote expands the work of the Special Commission on Tax Agreements and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects, whose investigative work on the LuxLeaks scandal lacked depth because of the numerous absences of multinationals and governments convened at parliamentary headquarters, as well as the unwillingness to subdue those responsible for the European institutions (and , in particular, the Commission and the Eurogroup) to a scrutiny of their responsibilities. While the reconstitution of the committee does not in itself guarantee a better outcome, it gives us the tools and time to demand responsibility for tax avoidance in Europe, so I voted in favour.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of setting up the TAXE II committee. According to the new mandate TAXE II should either produce a resolution or another report. I have called for a report to be produced as a report is more effective and carries more authority as opposed to a resolution.  As it stands, it has been agreed that a report will be issued but only if the TAXE II makes new discoveries. I have a number of reservations as to whether the Committee will discover anything of substance, as the lack of political will to date has been very disappointing. However, I will continue to monitor this situation closely.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The question here is whether to decide on a further extension of the TAXE commission or rather to establish a TAXE 2 commission with a new mandate. Its mission will be to complete the review of documents that the Commission and the States did not initially provide in connection with the LuxLeaks scandal. Although it is not a commission of inquiry as we would like, it will have significant leeway to continue its investigation. The work of this committee will lead to a final report presented by two co-reporters.  Together with my colleagues from the National Front, we are in favour of the establishment of this new TAXE committee, in order to denounce the tax evasion of certain large groups. That is why I voted for this report.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to set up a special committee on tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect and harmful corporate tax regimes and practices at EU and international level. The Committee's task will be to examine the practice of applying EU State aid and taxation rules in relation to advance tax rulings taken by Member States and other measures of a similar nature or effect if such practice proves to be an action by a Member State or the Commission.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has approved the new mandate of the SPECIAL committee TAXE.  I am pleased that all the political groups have agreed on the proposal made by the group. They are thus giving the SPECIAL commission TAXE a strong mandate for the next six months. A mandate that will allow: - to resume investigations into unfair tax practices between certain Member States and multinationals. In recent months, several European tax havens, including Belgium and Luxembourg, and large companies have tried everything to cover up the agreements negotiated between them.  The new mandate will increase the pressure to obtain all the information;   - to ensure that the ambitious measures recommended in last week's TAXE report will be taken into account by Member States;  - to open a new construction site. MEPs will tackle VAT fraud in the European Union.  I insist that all 28 Member States of the European Union should be equally aware of the fight against tax evasion and evasion. It is a quick way to free up enormous financial resources, which can be allocated to education, health care, infrastructure...

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this Resolution extending the functioning of the TAXE Special Commission for the investigation of tax rulings between multinational companies and the Luxembourg States and the Netherlands in particular. Given that under the previous mandate there was a lot of information to be clarified, and that new information has appeared that personally involves Jean-Claude Juncker and Jeroen Dijsselbloem, we believe that this extension was necessary, and we are pleased that the mandate is practically identical to the previous one.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of the Special Commission on Tax Agreements and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects to continue working after last week's TAXE Commission vote in Strasbourg.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal for a decision extends the mandate of the TAXE Committee by six months from 2 December 2015, in order to examine the practical application - whether this practice is a matter of a Member State or the Commission - of EU law on state aid and in the tax field, particularly with regard to tax rulings and other similar measures by their nature or effect by Member States , and on harmful corporate tax regimes and practices at European and international level.  In fact, this text allows the appointment of a new commission with a new mandate, in order to complete the work of reviewing documents that had not been provided by the Commission and the States. It is still not a commission of inquiry, but the new rules are broad enough to allow for further investigations, as has been requested by several political groups.  Another final report will be produced at the end of the six months, so I voted for it in the meantime.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I wanted to support the reappointment of the members of the TAXE Commission, both for the good work they have done and to ensure an immediate and effective continuation of what has been done so far.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision by which the European Parliament proposes the establishment of a special committee on tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect and harmful corporate tax regimes and practices at EU and international level. The task of this Committee shall be to examine the practice of applying the European Union State aid and taxation rules in relation to advance decisions taken by Member States on tax and other measures of a similar nature or effect where such practice appears to constitute an action by a Member State or the Commission. The new special committee will have 45 members (as will the TAXE Special Committee). The European Parliament considers that the new special committee would maintain the structure of the TAXE Special Committee. The mandate for the new Special Committee shall be conferred for a period of 6 months from 2 December 2015.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I was very pleased to support the establishment of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings, which will examine the practice of implementing EU State aid and tax legislation and examine harmful corporate taxation systems and practices at European and international level. I am in a pro-tax way to pay taxes where revenue and profits are also generated. The Luxleaks affair has exposed the very unfair practices of individual countries, and it is right that the EU is actively dealing with this problem, as it is practically legal tax evasion. I am not opposed to countries having different tax systems and rates, so they are still competing with each other, which is useful. However, it is unfair to have an undertaking operate in one country and pay tax where it is most at its advantage. I therefore really hope for better information sharing between countries, the elimination of such 'by-pass's' and a quick better solution.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution aims to extend the TAXE Committee in order to complete the work of reviewing documents that had not been provided by the Commission and the Member States.  We can commend the work of this committee, which makes recommendations to the European institutions to limit the tax optimization practices that multinationals engage in with the cooperation of national authorities in some Member States.  That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. I am voting in favour of setting up a special committee on taxation, continuing the positive experience of the TAXE Committee. As communicated by the Conference of Presidents, it is the intention of all the political groups in Parliament to continue the experience of the TAXE Special Committee.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Parliament's decision on the constitution, powers, numerical composition and term of office of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other similar measures by nature or effect.  The committee, which will consist of 45 members and will have a six-month mandate and will supervise both the Member States and the multinationals. It has been shown that the harmful practices of certain tax and national administrations allow multinationals to transfer profits in order to avoid taxation in the territories where they were generated. I therefore consider the establishment of this committee to be very important, and I hope that it will succeed in ensure that competition between governments in attracting foreign direct investment or in maintaining economic activities within the country takes place in full compliance with EU legislation.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of setting up the TAXE II committee. According to the new mandate TAXE II should either produce a resolution or another report. I have called for a report to be produced as a report is more effective and carries more authority as opposed to a resolution.  As it stands, it has been agreed that a report will be issued but only if the TAXE II makes new discoveries. I have a number of reservations as to whether the Committee will discover anything of substance, as the lack of political will to date has been very disappointing. However, I will continue to monitor this situation closely.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst UKIP recognises that there is a need for bodies like the OECD and G20 to revise the tax treatment of multi-national companies, we have seen from the plenary resolution of 25 November 2015 that the European Parliament and the TAXE Committee are more interested in harmonising taxes, eliminating tax competition and extending the powers of the EU into tax matters which are properly the exclusive competence of sovereign nations.  These are not matters for the EU, and the TAXE Committee has shown itself to be powerless to require attendance of witnesses or disclosure of documents – without which its investigations can only ever be inconclusive.  For these reasons UKIP voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this decision so that the new committee can analyse, examine and assess any harmful corporate tax regimes as well as whether the Member States and the EU institutions follow our taxation law and apply the state aid. The committee should also continue to work on any issues unresolved by the previous committee, whilst always respecting the concept of subsidiarity.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Not finding any particular problems I voted in favour of the establishment of a new TAXE commission that in the next six months will have to complete the outstanding issues.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. – That the Conference of Presidents of the European Parliament managed to agree on setting up a new mandate for the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures Similar in Nature or Effect (TAXE) is a victory in itself. Moreover, the Committee will not only continue its work as planned, but it will also operate on a stronger mandate. The Socialists and Democrats Group was very much concerned with, and engaged in, securing an extension that, at a minimum, preserved the current committee’s role. Thanks to the new TAXE Committee mandate, we will be able to monitor the Commission and the Member States as to the implementation of the measures laid out in the report that reflects the first six months of the Committee’s work. We must continue to battle tax fraud and tax avoidance. Big multinationals are getting away with avoiding to pay far too much of their fair share, for far too long.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the continuation of the work of the European Parliament's Special Committee on Tax Decisions which will continue within the framework of a new six-month mandate. The Special Committee will examine the work of the European Commission in the fields of State aid and taxation, Member States' compliance with tax legislation, and will work on the ongoing work of international organisations, including the OECD and the G20.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The vote to extend the mandate of the special committee on tax rulings is a continuation of what we voted on in parliament's previous plenary session in Strasbourg. It was then found that one of the main flaws of the report was the fact that the current mandate was not requested to be extended. As today's vote extends the committee's mandate without attempting to change its structure or composition, I consider this to be a positive step and that is why I have decided to vote in favour, expecting to have tangible results in the near future on harmful corporate tax regimes at both European and international level.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the decision to set up a special committee on tax rulings and other similar measures in nature and effect. The special committee will be responsible for analysing all existing aid schemes in the Member States, will consist of 45 members, will have the structure of the TAXE Special Committee and a mandate of 6 months from 2 December 2015. Finally, the Special Committee is called upon to present a report or resolution to present a summary of the work carried out.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision submitted pursuant to Article 197 of the Tax Regulation because, in view of the committee's decision to examine the practices and in view of the resolution of the end of November 2015 on early decisions in tax matters, I believe that each Member State, under EU law, must voluntarily communicate to the other Member States advance information on decisions. The aim must be to ensure the greatest possible transparency and communication between all Member States; In my opinion, this is a fundamental prerogative that must be the basis for keeping to the concept of "union" that is so close to our hearts in the European Union. I also agree with the decision to confirm the status quo, because what we wanted was an extension of the existing Special Commission and we achieved our objective.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst UKIP recognises that there is a need for bodies like the OECD and G20 to revise the tax treatment of multinational companies, we have seen from the plenary resolution of 25 November 2015 that Parliament and the TAXE Committee are more interested in harmonising taxes, eliminating tax competition and extending the powers of the EU into tax matters which are properly the exclusive competence of sovereign nations.  These are not matters for the EU, and the TAXE Committee has shown itself to be powerless to require attendance of witnesses or disclosure of documents – without which its investigations can only ever be inconclusive.  For these reasons UKIP voted against.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the establishment of a special commission for tax rulings and other similar measures by nature or effect, which will have the task of examining practices in the application of EU rules on State aid and taxation. This committee will also have the task of monitoring the harmful practices and tax regimes of companies at European and international level. I therefore think it would be useful to draw up a report setting out a summary of the activities carried out.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Special Committee on tax rulings can play an important role in fostering tax transparency and the fight against tax fraud, but the committee’s mandate should respect the principle of subsidiarity, so different measures like the corporate tax base must remain an issue of national competence since they reflect the different challenges of the economies of Member States. These challenges include their domestic market size, geographical realities or resources. I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of extending a new, broader mandate for the special Committee in the European Parliament which investigates tax avoidance across Europe. Greater tax transparency is greatly supported particularly when it comes to how people’s money is being spent. However, I must reiterate that I am against CCTB which would destroy the economies of smaller Member States on the periphery of Europe.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to adopt the mandate of the new special commission on tax rulings and similar measures by their nature or effect (TAXE II), which is created for six months. Following the "Lux Leaks" scandal at the end of 2014, the European Parliament set up a temporary special committee dedicated to the tax system in February 2015 (TAXE committee). The purpose of this report is to extend the mandate of the commission in order to complete work that was not finalized during the first period. Considering that the work of this committee has accelerated reflections on the fight against tax evasion, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the wake of the Luxleaks scandal, the European Parliament has set up a special committee to investigate corporate tax evasion and evasion in the European Union.  A serious and comprehensive overview of the methods used by multinationals has been drawn up and several recommendations to combat these practices contrary to the principle of equality before tax advanced.  For this issue concerns not only Luxembourg, but many other European countries which have granted, at the card, extraordinary tax advantages to a particular entity, or even to states, leading to unwelcome distortions of tax competition. One answer is possible: tax harmonisation within the euro area.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing.
