I supported the extension of this special committee which, despite its limited investigative capacity, which I had supported the creation of a commission of inquiry with greater powers, did an excellent job of elucidating the harmful practices of tax rulings, which allow certain states and large multinationals to agree in order to circumvent European taxation.  The aggressive tax planning practices involved have a very serious impact on the Union's public finances and obstruct its ability to have substantial budgetary resources to take concrete action. The political cost at the population level is also very high. To make Europe believe, it must be shown in an impeccable light.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Special Committee on Tax Rulings in the European Parliament already had. The mandates of the special committees are 6 months, this one was even extended until the end of November 2015. Now they want to make a new one with the same name and features, and even from the first one there were no clear results. I stress that this is an area of work for the Member States and tax policy cannot and should not be decided at European Union level. I do not understand why there is a need for another such special committee, given that there is a working group on these issues and it is under the leadership of my colleagues on the Committee on Economic Affairs. However, if such a committee is set up, although my vote is against it, I am not against its instant composition.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I remain convinced that this special committee does not carry out the work for which it was set up.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. As we said when voting on the TAXE committee's report in plenary, we have always said that the free movement of capital would lead to increased tax erosion and avoidance and facilitate the transfer of profits, which would harm the public coffers. This report sinned by not making public the advance tax rulings that were taken, by not quantifying the size of those decisions, their impact on the tax revenues of the different Member States and for being soft on those responsible for those decisions. Luxleaks and tax commission investigations showed that while governments imposed draconian "austerity" programs on workers and the people, they designed tax rulings and laws that allowed multinationals to minimise their tax rate and encouraged them to transfer profits. But it is evidence that much has yet to be investigated and investigated. Many have been the blockages raised to the action of this committee, starting with some of those targeted in the scandal, notably the current President of the European Commission. Despite the well-known limitations, the committee's activity was required for these reasons. The largest groups in this Parliament (EPP and S&D) have done everything they can to stop it. Only public pressure has prevented them from blocking this extension, which our group has proposed.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. – I am voting in favour of this report, since it is, in principle, a positive step to set up a committee to monitor decisions on taxation and State aid, but at the same time I also have strong reservations as to whether this committee will achieve tangible results.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This mandate will make it possible to repeat investigations on unfair tax practices entered into between some Member States and multinationals. In recent months, several European tax havens, including Belgium and Luxembourg, and large corporations have tried to hide the agreements negotiated between them. The new mandate will increase the pressure to get all the information needed. Moreover, it will ensure that ambitious measures recommended in the TAXE report adopted last week will be well taken into account by Member States. It will be possible to tackle VAT fraud within the European Union. All 28 Member States of the European Union have to fight together against fraud and tax evasion. This is a quick way to generate enormous financial resources that will be allocated to education, health care, infrastructure, etc.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the proposal, it was decided to set up a special committee to deal, on the one hand, with tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect, examining the practice of applying EU law on State aid and taxation in relation to tax rulings taken by Member States and other measures similar in nature or effect, where this practice appears to be applied by a Member State or the Commission , on the other hand, addresses harmful corporate tax systems and practices at European and international level, and which is a special committee: The committee set up builds and completes it entirely on the work carried out by the TAXE Special Committee, in particular addressing the unresolved issues highlighted in the abovementioned resolution of 25 November 2015, access to documents relating to its work, including the minutes of meetings of the Code of Conduct Group, and to international, European and national institutions and for a. , with a view to developing the necessary contacts and organising joint hearings with the parliaments and governments of the Member States and third countries, as well as representatives of the scientific, business and civil society community, including the social partners, in close cooperation with the Standing Committees.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of the Special Commission to examine practices in the implementation of EU legislation on state taxation and aid and on harmful business tax practices and regimes at European or international level. We must move towards greater homogenisation of the taxation of EU Member States to reduce tax competition and bad business practices.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of renewing the mandate of the Special Parliamentary Committee on Tax Rulings and other similar measures by nature or effect, strongly supported by the S&D Group, because I believe it is of fundamental importance to continue the work done so far by this committee, on the basis of a much more robust mandate. I welcomed the extension of the mandate of the Special Committee (TAXE 2), as I agree with the new tasks assigned to it, which include the possibility of examining the European Commission's work on State aid and taxation, member states' compliance with tax regulations and aggressive tax planning by companies.   The TAXE 2 Committee will be called upon to carry out important monitoring work on the implementation by Member States and the European institutions of the recommendations contained in the final report of the TAXE 1 Committee and will also have to follow up the recommendations of international institutions, such as the OECD and the G20. After the EP's careful diagnosis and equally comprehensive prescription, the time has come for the European Commission and the Member States to introduce effective legislation against any dubious tax practices.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the establishment of a special committee on tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect, its powers, numerical strength and mandate time, as I believe it is important for Europe to address the issue of tax justice and transparency across all borders. It is not acceptable for citizens, families and small and medium-sized enterprises to fill the tax coffers, while large corporations are sunbathing in the no man's tax haven.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Together with my colleagues in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I have once again advocated effective and fair tax systems. The establishment of a special committee ensures that existing tax rules continue to be respected. However, the real problem is not the tax models of individual states. The lack of cooperation between member states is the reason for the emergence of ever-new tax loopholes.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour  of this special committee as it is important the EP continues its work on taxation files and keeps up the pressure on the Council to make sure loopholes in European taxation legislation are closed.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution, extending the functioning of the TAXE Special Commission for the investigation of tax rulings between multinational companies and the States of Luxembourg and the Netherlands in particular. Given that under the previous mandate there was a lot of information to be clarified, and that new information has appeared that personally involves Jean-Claude Juncker and Jeroen Dijsselbloem, we believe that this extension was necessary, and we are pleased that the mandate is practically identical to the previous one.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on setting up a special committee on tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect, its powers, numerical strength and term of office, because I believe that it is important to fully build on and complete the work carried out by the TAXE Special Committee, in particular to address unresolved issues highlighted in its resolution of 25 November 2015 and to make the necessary contacts and hold hearings with international, European and national institutions, the national parliaments and governments of the Member States and third countries, as well as representatives of the academic community, business and civil society, including the social partners, in close cooperation with the standing committees.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as it is important to fully build on and complete the work carried out by the TAXE Special Committee in particular to address the unresolved issues highlighted. It is also vital to allow access to relevant documents for its work, including the minutes of meetings of the Code of Conduct Group. In addition to this, it will allow the necessary hearings with international, European and national institutions as well as the other parties involved or affected to take place which is vital going forward for Member States.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst UKIP recognises that there is a need for bodies like the OECD and G20 to revise the tax treatment of multinational companies, we have seen from the plenary resolution of 25 November 2015 that Parliament and the TAXE Committee are more interested in harmonising taxes, eliminating tax competition and extending the powers of the EU into tax matters which are properly the exclusive competence of sovereign nations.  These are not matters for the EU, and the TAXE Committee has shown itself to be powerless to require attendance of witnesses or disclosure of documents – without which its investigations can only ever be inconclusive. For these reasons UKIP voted against.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision establishing a Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or impact, its powers, composition and term of office, thus enabling an analysis of the European Commission's practices on continuous scrutiny of aid systems existing in the Member States, consultation on the functioning and development of the internal market, and an examination of all those measures relating to taxation , and other measures similar in nature or effect.  I consider it positive that this committee will complement and continue the work of taxe, and I also support the proposal to monitor the work of international institutions and how the EU institutions and Member States implement the recommendations set out in Parliament's Resolution of 25 November 2015.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Whilst my UKIP colleagues and I recognise that there is a need for bodies like the OECD and G20 to revise the tax treatment of multinational companies, we have seen from the plenary resolution of 25 November 2015 that Parliament and the TAXE Committee are more interested in harmonising taxes, eliminating tax competition and extending the powers of the EU into tax matters which are properly the exclusive competence of sovereign nations. These are not matters for the EU, and the TAXE Committee has shown itself to be powerless to require attendance of witnesses or disclosure of documents – without which its investigations can only ever be inconclusive. For these reasons my fellow UKIP MEPs and I voted against.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the establishment, for six months, of the new special committee on tax rulings (TAXE II), to monitor the implementation of the recommendations made by the European Parliament on tax rulings. As Parliament has spoken and put forward proposals on the tax rescript practices of Member States and businesses, the effective implementation of these recommendations is important and must be monitored and supported in real time by the European Parliament. The establishment of this special committee was supported by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The extension of this mandate will make it possible to continue the work already done by the Special Committee on Tax Rulings. The aim of the Special Committee is to limit tax fraud and tax evasion within the EU as much as possible. I therefore agree with this proposal.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it entrusts a TAXE 2 committee for six months to extend the work of the TAXE 1 committee. This extension is indeed useful for examining certain documents provided late by the Brussels Commission.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Special Committee on Taxation has completed the first stage of its work. I rate the results of this work positively, although we are aware that the time was too short to achieve the intended effect. The problem is articulated, but there are still no clear recommendations for new solutions. We need to be aware that the problem is not easy. We are often dealing with transnational corporations on the one hand and strong budgetary interests of states. The extension of the work of committees in the same composition will allow the continuation of work on a continuous basis and in accordance with the will of almost all political groups. My group and the Polish delegation in the Group of socialists and democrats certainly wish to do so.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 N-VA supports the continuation of the work of the Special Committee taxe. For N-VA, it is vital that a broad trust can be present in the research results of this particular committee. Some questioned the results of the first phase of research. We call on Parliament to focus on the relevant issues which have unfortunately been under-highlighted so far. In concrete terms, we want to give the European Parliament every opportunity to further examine whether tax rulings are being misused as illegal state aid. This Commission should examine what measures are needed to combat such unfair State aid and to ensure adequate transparency in tax rulings. This theme is far too important to play political games with.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This vote expands the work of the Special Commission on Tax Agreements and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects, whose investigative work on the LuxLeaks scandal lacked depth because of the numerous absences of multinationals and governments convened at parliamentary headquarters, as well as the unwillingness to subdue those responsible for the European institutions (and , in particular, the Commission and the Eurogroup) to a scrutiny of their responsibilities. While the reconstitution of the committee does not in itself guarantee a better outcome, it gives us the tools and time to demand responsibility for tax avoidance in Europe, so I voted in favour.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. I supported the proposal of the Conference of Presidents to re-create a Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect, TAXE 2, for a term of 6 months. The SPECIAL TAXE 2 Committee will continue and complete the work of the TAXE 1 Special Committee and will continue to monitor the practices applied by Member States regarding EU state aid and taxation rules and corporate tax practices. With this decision, the European Parliament once again sends a message that there are no exceptions between Member States when it comes to taxes, but also how important fair competition and fair tax policy is.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the proposal for a decision on the establishment, responsibilities, composition and duration of the mandate of the Special Committee on tax rulings, and other measures of an equivalent nature and effect, and because I consider it necessary to operate this committee with a view to combating tax evasion and avoidance.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 I support the decision to establish a Special Commission on Tax Agreements and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects, which will allow us to examine practices in the application of EU law on State aid and taxation. We must ensure maximum rigour in the compliance by the Community institutions, the Member States and all the persons or entities involved with the legislation, and that is why the creation of this body is so important.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposal will allow the Special Committee to deepen its work. There is a reasonable hope that this decision would curb tax evasion within the EU. I therefore support this proposal.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Luxleaks case, on the current tax rulings in Luxembourg, was revealed in November 2014. A special committee in charge of the case was set up by Parliament in February 2015. It was renewed to continue its work in July 2015. When we presented his report last November, we saw that there was still a lot of uncertainty about the responsibility of the Luxembourg authorities and multinationals in this matter. Although this 'special' committee has limited powers, I am voting for the establishment of a new special commission on tax rulings which will retain the structure of the special committee TAXE.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the extension of the TAXE Committee, the appointment of new members and the definition of a new mandate, with the aim of completing the work of reviewing documents that had not been provided by the Member States and the Commission. There is still no commission of inquiry, but the drafting is broad enough to allow further investigations to be carried out. I therefore logically voted in favour of this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The main priorities of tax policy at EU level are: removing tax obstacles to cross-border economic activity, combating harmful tax competition, promoting greater cooperation between tax administrations with regard to controlling and combating fraud. I voted in favour of the decision to set up a Special Committee on Early Tax Rulings and Other Measures of a Similar Nature or Effect (TAXE 2) in order to examine the application by a Member State or the Commission of State aid law and Union tax law in relation to advance tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect taken by Member States , where such practices constitute an act of a Member State or of the Commission, and on harmful corporate tax practices and regimes at European and international level. Its mission is to monitor and monitor the implementation of the recommendations of the TAXE 1 Report.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of setting up a special committee on tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature as it will increase the level of transparency and combat cross-border tax avoidance.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the establishment of the Special Committee TAXE II, under Rule 197 of Parliament’s Rules of Procedure. The Special Committee has been established for six months to fully build on and complete the work carried out by the TAXE I Special Committee, in particular to address unresolved issues on tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect and to access relevant documents for its work.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 12 February 2015, the European Parliament decided to set up a so-called TAXE Special Committee on tax determinations and other measures similar in nature or impact, its powers, headcount and duration of its mandate. The special committee's report, which expired in the summer of this year, was discussed and adopted by Parliament on 25 November.  In view of the findings contained in the report, the Conference of Presidents recommended that parliament set up a special committee identical to the TAXE Special Committee in its powers, numbers and structure with a view to completeing the work of the TAXE Special Committee and to monitor the implementation of the recommendations contained in the resolution of 25 November. I supported the proposal for a decision.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The SPECIAL committee TAXE, tasked with shedding light on the Luxleaks scandal and formulating proposals to combat aggressive tax optimisation, has not been able to fully complete its work, in particular because of the reluctance of the Commission and some Member States to release the requested documents. We can therefore only support the extension of the six-month term, although it is regrettable that it does not explicitly include the search for personal responsibilities of the leaders of the States in question, in particular Luxembourg (J-C). Juncker) et des Pays-Bas (J. Dijsselbloem).

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which allows the creation of a special committee TAXE II, composed of the same members as those of the TAXE Committee whose mandate has expired. This new commission will continue, for a period of six months, the information work undertaken on tax rulings and other similar measures by their nature or by their effect. The aim is to combat tax evasion, which can result in particular from fictitious transfers of profits.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of setting up a special committee on tax rulings in order to examine the practices followed in the application of EU aid rules and other similar measures by nature or effect taken by Member States. This committee is based in full on the work carried out by the TAXE Special Committee, and on its completion, in particular to access documents relevant to its work, establish the necessary contacts and hold hearings with institutions and in international, European and national for a, with national parliaments and governments of Member States and third countries, as well as with representatives of academia , business and civil society.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the setting up of this special committee that will examine practice regarding tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect issued by Member States since 1 January 1991.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report, as the work also builds on and complements the TAXE Special Committee. In particular, unresolved problems will be addressed and, at the same time, greater transparency in corporate accountability should be provided. In addition, important institutions will be in constant contact and working closely together in the future.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Decision establishes a Commission to examine practices in the application of State aid and tax legislation in the Member States and harmful corporate tax systems and practices at European and international level.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the extension of the activities of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect and the granting of new investigative powers. In order to discuss unresolved problems and prevent harmful practices, it is necessary to examine more in more detail the practices of applying EU State aid and taxation rules in relation to tax rulings taken by Member States and other measures of a similar nature or effect. In addition, it is essential that other institutions, including the President of the Commission, cooperate more closely with the committee and explain their position on past scandals.  In order for the committee to be able to properly fulfil its mandate, its members must have full access to all documents of the Code of Conduct Group, as well as other relevant information.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Whilst UKIP recognises that there is a need for bodies like the OECD and G20 to revise the tax treatment of multinational companies, we have seen from the plenary resolution of 25 November 2015 that Parliament and the TAXE Committee are more interested in harmonising taxes, eliminating tax competition and extending the powers of the EU into tax matters which are properly the exclusive competence of sovereign nations. These are not matters for the EU, and the TAXE Committee has shown itself to be powerless to require attendance of witnesses or disclosure of documents – without which its investigations can only ever be inconclusive. For these reasons UKIP voted against.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the need for a special commission to take early decisions in the field of taxation. I would like to take this opportunity to wish my colleagues a good job and I am confident that their efforts will make to the already excellent work of the TAXE Committee.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the decision for the work of Parliament’s Special Committee on Tax Rulings to be continued under a new mandate for six months. Harmful corporate tax regimes and practices at European and international level could hinder considerably economic growth. Therefore, I voted in favour because I fully support the ‘good governance’ practice in the tax area (i.e. more transparency, exchange of information and fair tax competition).

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The initiative on solving various manipulations of multinational companies' tax reports, all for the purpose of making illicit added profits, came in handy in times of crisis when states face a drop in tax revenues due to reduced economic activity. I welcome the proposal to put an end to large multinational corporations that use loose legislation from individual European Union countries, especially third countries, to make a profit, avoid paying taxes or pay less than required.  The operations of multinational corporations must have a positive effect, both on the local economy and on the economy of the whole country, and consequently on its revenue side of the budget. The introduction of detailed reports on the operations of companies and the tax system is a step forward in ensuring that companies will operate according to the law, but also that the beneficial impact of the local economy will actually be felt.  I support the introduction of a regulatory body that would bring together all national information findings on legislative solutions, company profits and special agreements between national governments and companies. The privacy protection of persons who show illegal activity or to show models of tax evasion must be the focus of institutionalising the fight against tax avoidance.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the strengthening of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures resulting from the long-term work of the European Social Democrats. As part of its new six-month mandate, the Committee will focus on tax evasion across the EU, with particular attention to tax evasion by large multinational corporations. The members of the Committee will have access to new information and will be able to see that the essential requirements of the European Parliament, as defined in the report of the special committee still in operation, are applied responsibly by the Commission.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The european Parliament's new special committee, which is responsible for taxation, will focus its work mainly on dangerous tax practices implemented by companies at European level. The new committee will have the same structure as the previous one. It will consist of 45 members and will have the task, among other things, of examining the European Commission's work on State aid and taxation and member states' compliance with tax rules. It will also ensure that the Member States and the European institutions comply with the recommendations made by the TAXE Parliamentary Committee and will follow up the recommendations of international institutions such as the OECD and the G20 while respecting the competences of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs with regard to taxation issues. In the hope that this new parliamentary committee will be able to work in the interests of European citizens and businesses, helping to make the European tax system more transparent and less burdensome, I voted in favour of its establishment.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Pursuant to this Decision, the European Parliament approved the establishment of the successor to the Special Committee on Early Decisions and Other Measures of a Similar Nature or Effect, giving it a new 6-month term of office starting on 2 December. This new special committee will continue the work carried out by the previous Special Committee on Early Decisions and Other Measures of A Similar Nature or Effect, set up on 12 February 2015, the results of which were presented in the report adopted in plenary on 25 November 2015. In this regard, it shall be responsible, inter alia, to monitor the implementation by the Member States and the European institutions of the recommendations contained in that resolution of 25 November 2015; monitor the work that has been carried out in this area by international institutions, including the OECD and the G20; assess the Commission's actions in investigating State aid and ensuring the correct application of cooperation obligations in the field of taxation; member states to comply with obligations under European tax legislation; and analyse the aggressive planning practices carried out by commercial companies. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst UKIP recognises that there is a need for bodies like the OECD and G20 to revise the tax treatment of multinational companies, we have seen from the Plenary Resolution of 25 November 2015 that Parliament and the TAXE Committee are more interested in harmonising taxes, eliminating tax competition and extending the powers of the EU into tax matters which are properly the exclusive competence of sovereign nations. These are not matters for the EU, and the TAXE Committee has shown itself to be powerless to require attendance of witnesses or disclosure of documents – without which its investigations can only ever be inconclusive. For these reasons UKIP voted against.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I welcome the establishment of a new special commission TAXE II, certainly with similar contours to the committee that preceded it (so the mandate takes up all the main elements of the previous special committee, the same structure and the same number of members, and will be in place for six months as well). The new committee will be responsible for examining Member States' practices and compliance with their obligations, including under the Administrative Cooperation Directive, as well as assessing how the Commission has implemented its obligations to monitor state aid and as guardian of the treaties.  The special committee should complement the work of the previous committee in order to resolve certain outstanding issues (including access to the group's "code of conduct" documents). It will also have to monitor the implementation by member states and relevant European institutions of the recommendations of the TAXE I Committee and the work at OECD and G20 level.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament on the establishment of a Special Committee on Early Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect (TAXE2), because I consider it important to review and control such decisions, harmful corporate tax practices and regimes at European and international level, as well as the examination of existing aid schemes in the Member States and their compliance with Union rules on State aid and other EU tax law. I also endorse the tasks conferred on the TAXE 2 Committee listed in the report and i would stress that this Commission "will be fully based and complete the work carried out by the TAXE 1 Special Committee, in particular in order to address outstanding issues underlined in its resolution of 25/11/2015"- as can be read in the text of the report. I also believe that the numerical composition (45 members), equal to that of the SPECIAL COMMITTEE TAXE 1 and the duration of the respective warrant (six months), which began on 2 December 2015, are also appropriate. For the above reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's proposal for a decision as I believe it would be appropriate to renew the establishment of the Special Committee on Early Decisions on Tax (Tax Rulling) and other similar measures by nature or effect. The committee will consist of 45 members, maintain the structure of the Taxe Special Committee and have a 6-month mandate. One of the main tasks of the committee will be to analyse and evaluate practices in the application of EU state aid rules.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution, extending the functioning of the TAXE Special Commission for the investigation of tax rulings between multinational companies and the States of Luxembourg and the Netherlands in particular. Given that under the previous mandate there was a lot of information to be clarified, and that new information has appeared that personally involves Jean-Claude Juncker and Jeroen Dijsselbloem, we believe that this extension was necessary, and we are pleased that the mandate is practically identical to the previous one.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This vote expands the work of the Special Commission on Tax Agreements and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects, whose investigative work on the LuxLeaks scandal lacked depth because of the numerous absences of multinationals and governments convened at parliamentary headquarters, as well as the unwillingness to subdue those responsible for the European institutions (and , in particular, the Commission and the Eurogroup) to a scrutiny of their responsibilities. While the reconstitution of the committee does not in itself guarantee a better outcome, it gives us the tools and time to demand responsibility for tax avoidance in Europe, so I voted in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mandate for the new TAXE II Committee because there should be nowhere to hide for those governments and companies who have been complicit in tax dodging. Over the last nine months, the Special Committee on Tax has uncovered scandalous details about the nature and extent of tax fiddling in Europe. But that Committee has not had access to everything it needed to make a full assessment. The task is not over. That is why it was so important today to establish the TAXE II Committee: so that it can continue to investigate tax dodging across the EU, make sure MEPs have access to the right documents and have hearings with key individuals, and monitor the Commission’s and Member States’ progress in putting measures into place to stop tax fiddling.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the draft EP decision on the establishment, scope, composition and term of office of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect. The Special Committee will examine how EU state aid and taxation legislation in relation to tax rulings is applied in practice. The new Special Committee shall have the power to analyse and assess the Commission's procedures, which consist in the ongoing examination by the Member State of all aid schemes granted in the Member States, of proposing appropriate measures requiring the gradual development or functioning of the internal market, of the Member States, of checking whether aid granted by the State or through State resources is compatible with the internal market and is not abused. The new committee will have 45 members and its term of office will be 6 months from 2 December 2015.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures similar in nature or effect will examine how tax ruling rules under EU State aid rules apply in all Member States. In my opinion, such a committee has its merits.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this proposal for a decision, as I believe that the establishment of a committee at EU level that will deal with tax-related issues will contribute to efficiency in tax policies and help Member States control tax rulings and measures. The task of this special committee is to continue and complete the work of the TAXE Special Committee, in particular with a view to addressing the outstanding issues raised in the aforementioned Resolution of 25 November 2015 and gaining access to relevant documents for its work.  The role is also to analyse and assess the Commission's practice of carrying out constant monitoring, in accordance with Article 108 of the TFEU, of all aid schemes existing in the Member States, to propose to Member States the appropriate measures necessary for the gradual development or functioning of the internal market, to verify whether the aid granted by a State or state aid is linked to the internal market and not used in a manner that is against the rules.  I also believe that the Commission should clarify and communicate the role of the Committee so that there are no misunderstandings between Member States about the role thereof. I also believe that this Committee will contribute to further linking and opening markets within the European Union.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mandate for the new TAXE II Committee because there should be nowhere to hide for those governments and companies who have been complicit in tax dodging. Over the last nine months, the Special Committee on Tax has uncovered scandalous details about the nature and extent of tax fiddling in Europe. However, that Committee has not had access to everything it needed to make a full assessment. The task is not over. That is why it was so important today to establish the TAXE II Committee: so that it can continue to investigate tax dodging across the EU, make sure MEPs have access to the right documents and have hearings with key individuals, and monitor the Commission’s and Member States’ progress in putting measures into place to stop tax fiddling.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The establishment of a committee to monitor decisions on taxation and State aid is, in principle, a positive step, but at the same time we also have strong doubts as to whether this committee will achieve tangible results.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the establishment of a Special Committee on Tax Exemptions in the European Parliament. In its recently adopted report, the first TAXE Committee excellently summarised the harmful tax avoidance and fraud practices carried out so far by individual Member States and multinationals and made clear and detailed recommendations to the European Commission and the Member States on how to deal effectively with the unacceptable situation. However, this is not the end of the work. Until we fully eliminate harmful tax avoidance procedures and achieve a fundamental change in political morale in this area, close and continuous monitoring will be necessary. Unfortunately, harmful tax practices in some countries have become almost the norm. In addition, new tax avoidance schemes and loopholes are emerging. They should be constantly monitored and raised. This will be where the new special committee will play a major role. I also think it is right that the new committee retains the structure of the first TAXE committee, on which members have been able to work effectively over the past year.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I am pleased that all the political groups have agreed on the proposal made by the group. They are thus giving the SPECIAL Commission TAXE a strong mandate for the next 6 months.  This mandate that will allow three things. Resume investigations into unfair tax practices between some Member States and multinationals.  In recent months, several European tax havens, including Belgium and Luxembourg, and large companies have tried everything to cover up the agreements negotiated between them. The new mandate will increase the pressure to obtain all the information.   Ensure that the ambitious measures recommended in last week's TAXE report will be taken into account by Member States.  Open a new construction site.  MEPs will tackle VAT fraud in the European Union.  Let us insist that all 28 Member States of the European Union be equally aware of the fight against tax evasion and evasion. It is a quick way to free up enormous financial resources that can be allocated to education, health care, infrastructure, etc.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the decision of the Conference of Group Chairs of the European Parliament I approved in plenary the decision to set in place a new special TAXE II Committee, as it is in my opinion necessary to pursue the important work of the European Parliament on this topic.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I object to the extension of the mandate of the TAXE Special Committee, i.e. the establishment of taxe II for a period of six months, proposed by the EPP, S&D and ALDE groups, saying that the same is necessary in order to guarantee the successful apprehension of the mandate of the first TAXE Board. The main arguments went in this direction that the first committee had not yet received all the necessary documentation and information requested from the Commission and the Member States, which would allow it to bring the mandate to an effective and effective end. The primary function of the new committee, accordingly, would be to concentrate on receiving the missing information, and in general to continue implementing the recommendations made by the first committee. I believe that the establishment of the new TAXE II committee is completely unnecessary and pointless because it will not give any added value, but will have only a mere formal function of completing the work of its predecessor, which is efficient enough, if not more efficient, and in any case cheaper for taxpayers, and this can also be solved through the already existing European Parliament forums, such as the ECON Committee Tax Working Group. So I voted no.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the establishment of a Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures of a Similar Nature. Since a large part of the Member States have not cooperated fully with the TAXE Committee in the past, I think it is a good thing that we continue to work. The continued work of the TAXE Committee will build on the pressure on the Council and the Member States. Both I and the EES political group believe that the existing TAXE has done a good job. For the vast majority, the committee has achieved the tasks it has pursued. That is why we do not need a completely new committee that starts work again. The new TAXE Committee should not repeat the work of the first committee, but should build on its work.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution, extending the functioning of the TAXE Special Commission for the investigation of tax rulings between multinational companies and the States of Luxembourg and the Netherlands in particular. Given that under the previous mandate there was a lot of information to be clarified, and that new information has appeared that personally involves Jean-Claude Juncker and Jeroen Dijsselbloem, we believe that this extension was necessary, and we are pleased that the mandate is practically identical to the previous one.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has decided to set up a special committee after the end of the work of the TAXE Committee, which will deal with tax provisions and other measures similar in nature or impact, examining the practice of applying EU law on State aid and taxation. The new body builds entirely on the work carried out by the TAXE Special Committee and tries to close the open questions. It is natural that I voted in favour of setting up the board.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the continuation of the European Parliament's work on the mass tax evasion of large corporations. That is why I believe that extending the mandate of the TAXE Special Commission, of which I am a member, is an institutional necessity.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision on setting up a Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures Similar in Nature or Effect. In this document I supported the decision to set up a special committee (TAXE II) to examine the practice in the application of EU state aid and taxation law in relation to tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect issued by Member States. The TAXE II Special Committee will have 45 members. I agree that the new committee should build on the work done previously, in particular to tackle unresolved issues and that focusing on harmful corporate tax regimes and practices at European and international level is essential for ensuring transparency in this field.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This vote expands the work of the Special Commission on Tax Agreements and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects, whose investigative work on the LuxLeaks scandal lacked depth because of the numerous absences of multinationals and governments convened at parliamentary headquarters, as well as the unwillingness to subdue those responsible for the European institutions (and , in particular, the Commission and the Eurogroup) to a scrutiny of their responsibilities. While the reconstitution of the committee does not in itself guarantee a better outcome, it gives us the tools and time to demand responsibility for tax avoidance in Europe, so I voted in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the creation of the new TAX II Committee so that the European Parliament would be able to continue its work on this issue successfully and to have every opportunity to do so.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This process confirms the nature of the current European integration process, designed to favour large multinational companies. It also confirms the link between the main political families present in Parliament and the interests of these large companies which are and will continue to be the ones that profit the most from the liberalisation of the economy and from the weakening of the capacity of national states to control their economies. Our work in committee is therefore part of building another Europe that is focused on the interests of people and workers.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposal will allow the Special Committee to deepen its work. There is a reasonable hope that this decision would curb tax evasion within the EU. I therefore support this proposal.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the new mandate of the TAXE Committee because, in this way, it will not only be able to continue its work, but also undertake investigations with an even stronger mandate. Parliament has sent out a strong signal. The ball is now in the court of the committee and the Member States to introduce effective rules against illegal tax practices by companies.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I too supported the proposal to continue the work of the European Parliament's Special Committee on Tax Decisions, which examines harmful corporate tax regimes and practices at European and international level.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted for the European Parliament's decision establishing a Special Committee (TAXE 2) for tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or with similar effect, its powers, numerical composition and mandate (2015/3005(RSO)) because I agree that it is necessary to examine the practice of applying EU State aid and tax legislation with regard to tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect implemented by Member States.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as a mere technical formality, which completes the extension of the mandate of the Special Commission on Tax Agreements and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the appointments to the Special Committee on Tax Rulings (TAXE II). However, while of course the composition of the committee is very important, we should not lose sight of the fact that this committee should not just be another elaborate PR stunt.  According to the new mandate TAXE II should either produce a resolution or another report. I have called for a report to be produced as a report is more effective and carries more authority as opposed to a resolution.  As it stands, it has been agreed that a report will be issued but only if the TAXE II Committee makes new discoveries. I have a number of reservations as to whether the Committee will discover anything of substance as the lack of political will to date has been very disappointing. However, I will continue to monitor this situation closely.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal, which reappoints the members of the previous TAXE committee of which our colleague Bernard Monot is a member.  The TAXE Committee has produced serious work, despite the limited resources at its disposal and the attitude of Commission President Juncker, who says that he was not responsible for his administration when he was Luxembourg's minister. Together with the other Members of the National Front, we expect the new TAXE Committee to shed more light on these scandals.  So I voted to reappoint its members.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal of the Conference of Presidents for the appointment of members to the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In the interests of continuity of work already begun since February 2015, the members of the special committee on tax rulings have been reappointed.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this Resolution, by which the members of the TAXE Special Commission are appointed in their new mandate.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This text should allow the TAXE committee to be extended for six months and it simply proposes to renew the 45 members of the previous TAXE 1 committee. So I voted for it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. For the ENF Group, the taxe members of the previous phase are reconfirmed, as recommended by the Conference of Presidents itself, so that we can immediately continue the good work finalised with the own-initiative report voted on in Strasbourg at the last plenary session.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the appointments to the Special Committee on Tax Rulings (TAXE II). While of course the composition of the committee is very important, we should not lose sight of the fact that this committee should not just be another elaborate PR stunt.  According to the new mandate TAXE II should either produce a resolution or another report. I have called for a report to be produced as a report is more effective and carries more authority as opposed to a resolution.  As it stands, it has been agreed that a report will be issued but only if the TAXE II Committee makes new discoveries. I have a number of reservations as to whether the Committee will discover anything of substance as the lack of political will to date has been very disappointing. However, I will continue to monitor this situation closely.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this decision so that the new committee can analyse, examine and assess any harmful corporate tax regimes as well as whether the Member States as well the EU institutions follow our taxation law and apply the state aid. The new committee should also continue to work on any issues unresolved by the previous committee.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the appointment of the members of the new TAXE committee which, in fact, maintains the same composition as the previous one.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We agree with the appointment of members to the special committee on tax rulings.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. I think it is important to give a decisive boost to the appointments to the Special Committee on Early Decisions on TaxAtion. This is a decision of internal organisation, its importance lies in the crucial nature of the matter and its repercussions in terms of administrative transparency.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report appointing 45 members of the new special committee because I believe that they will be able to analyse and evaluate in more detail and precise all existing aid schemes in the Member States. I am also convinced that it will be possible to propose to the Member States the appropriate measures required by the gradual development or functioning of the internal market in checking whether the aid granted by a State, or through state funds, is compatible with the internal market and whether it is not being implemented illegally. Finally, I think it would be appropriate for the structure of the TAXE Special Committee to be maintained in the new special committee, and I would like to take this opportunity to wish the new members every success in their work.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst UKIP recognises that there is a need for bodies like the OECD and G20 to revise the tax treatment of multinational companies, we have seen from the Plenary Resolution of 25 November 2015 that Parliament and the TAXE Committee are more interested in harmonising taxes, eliminating tax competition and extending the powers of the EU into tax matters which are properly the exclusive competence of sovereign nations.  These are not matters for the EU, and the TAXE Committee has shown itself to be powerless to require attendance of witnesses or disclosure of documents – without which its investigations can only ever be inconclusive. For these reasons UKIP voted against.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the appointment of my elected colleagues to the Special Committee on Early Tax Decisions and I firmly believe that they will do an excellent job in the area of tax rulings and that they will help to monitor the harmful practices and tax regimes of all those companies operating at European and international level.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Special Committee on Tax Rulings can play an important role in fostering tax transparency and the fight against tax fraud, but the Committee’s mandate should respect the principle of subsidiarity so that different measures like the corporate tax base must remain an issue of national competence since they reflect the different challenges of the economies of Member States. These challenges include their domestic market size, geographical realities or resources. I voted in favour.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to adopt the composition of the new special commission on tax rulings and similar measures by their nature or effect (TAXE II), which is created for six months and whose mandate has been extended.  It is proposed to my colleague Alain LAMASSOURE to continue his work as chairman of this special committee. I think he has done an outstanding job and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I remain convinced that this special committee does not carry out the work for which it was set up.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The TAXE commission's investigations showed that while governments imposed violent "austerity" programmes on workers and the people, they designed tax rulings and laws that allowed multinationals to evade paying taxes. It's evidence that has remained uninvestigated and investigated. Many have been the blockages raised to the action of this committee, starting with some of those targeted in the scandal, notably the current President of the European Commission. Despite the well-known limitations, the committee's activity was required for these reasons. The largest groups in this Parliament (EPP and S&D) have done everything they can to stop it. Only public pressure has prevented them from blocking this extension, which our group has proposed. It is important now that the members of the new committee take on the need to carry forward the full clarification of all that remains unclear and undetermined. Some people responsible and involved – such as the current President of the European Commission – need to be called back to the committee and not to back all clarifications this time. But we have no illusions. With the composition of this committee, its extension will have been more good to calm public pressure than to go deeper into its research work.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained because I do not believe the EU should have a role in the tax affairs of Member States.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the appointments of members to the special committee on tax rulings because I do not think that the committee, in its specific composition, could fulfil its role.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the appointment of members of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures Similar in Nature or Purpose.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of appointments following the evaluation of the proposed candidates.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of appointing the members of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings, as I am satisfied with the selection made.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. After a thorough examination of all the candidates, I have agreed to the nomination of the proposed members to the Special Committee.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution, by which the members of the TAXE Special Commission are appointed in their new mandate.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the decision on appointments to the Special Committee on Tax Rulings since the Committee will perform on key issues, analysing and assessing all systems of aid existing in Member States, proposing to the Member States appropriate measures required by the progressive development or by the functioning of the internal market, checking whether aid granted by a State or through State resources is compatible with the internal market and not misused, and deciding that the State concerned is to abolish or alter such aid.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution in order to allow the TAXE Committee to continue their work and address any unresolved or outstanding issues.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst UKIP recognises that there is a need for bodies like the OECD and G20 to revise the tax treatment of multinational companies, we have seen from the Plenary Resolution of 25 November 2015 that Parliament and the TAXE Committee are more interested in harmonising taxes, eliminating tax competition and extending the powers of the EU into tax matters which are properly the exclusive competence of sovereign nations.  These are not matters for the EU, and the TAXE Committee has shown itself to be powerless to require attendance of witnesses or disclosure of documents – without which its investigations can only ever be inconclusive. For these reasons UKIP voted against.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for appointments to the Special Committee on Tax Rulings, as this allows the Committee to start its work over a period of six months and within 45 members, and is in accordance with Article 197 TB. Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. I believe that the Committee will play an important role and that the structure of taxe committee should be maintained, while consistency and independence will be essential to achieve the objectives set.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the composition of the new special committee formed to monitor the implementation of the recommendations made by the European Parliament on tax rulings. The composition is identical to that of the previous TAXE committee, its members already knowing the subject and being best able to follow up on the measures they themselves have proposed. The appointments were validated by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this proposal. This is an automatic appointment of the members. This does not require a separate vote.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as a mere technical formality, which completes the extension of the mandate of the Special Commission on Tax Agreements and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Proposal of the Conference of Presidents on the appointment of members of the Special Committee on Tax Decisions and other measures of a similar nature or effect – TAXE 2. Congratulations to all Members who have been re-elected to the Special Committee, especially colleagues from the European People's Party.  Members of the Special Committee must stress that strengthening the single market is one of the Union's priorities, and in order to achieve this, we must have clear positions in the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion and ensure that Member States comply with the minimum requirements of the tax rules laid down.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposal will allow the Special Committee to deepen its work. There is a reasonable hope that this decision would curb tax evasion within the EU. I therefore support this proposal.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The appointment of the members of this committee is proportional to the composition of the parliament: 13 members for the EPP, 12 for the socio-liberals, 4 for the ECR, 4 for the ALDE, 3 for the GUE, 3 for the Greens, 3 for the EFDD, 2 for the ENF and 1 for the non-registered. I vote for the appointed members so that this committee can continue its work as soon as possible.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. In favour of the renewal of the TAXE committee, I vote for the appointment of its members.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal of the Conference of Presidents on the indication of the composition of the Special Committee on tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect. The committee is composed of 45 MEPs.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the appointment of a Special Committee on Tax Rulings as it will increase the level of transparency and combat cross-border tax avoidance.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the appointments to the Special Committee on Tax Rulings established for six months, as its composition should be identical to TAXE I. The TAXE II Special Committee will build on and complete the work carried out by the TAXE I Committee, therefore in my opinion it is only logical that the composition of both Committees is the same.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament approved the proposed appointments without a vote.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The reappointment of the current members of the special committee TAXE is a consensus, it allows to complete the work undertaken last February and to fulfill the new mandate with elected officials who have already followed the work in progress.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which allows the creation of a special committee TAXE II, composed of the same members as those of the TAXE Committee whose mandate has expired. This new commission will continue, for a period of six months, the information work undertaken on tax rulings and other similar measures by their nature or by their effect. The aim is to combat tax evasion, which can result in particular from fictitious transfers of profits.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the appointments to the Special Committee on Tax Rulings.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the establishment of a special body to continue the fight to abolish unfair corporate tax practices. This body will have to work to ensure that all Member States are equal in their tax treatment of national and multinational companies. Since several achieved manipulations have already been identified through agreements (formal and informal), concerning the specific tax policy towards the targeted companies, I am of the opinion that such a body is a necessary tool in ensuring basic competition rules that must be the same for all.  Competition policies must comply with European practice and must not deviate in any segment due to the particular interests of individual groups within governments or corporations. The foundation of the European Union is the common market, and if the quality of action of this foundation can be helped by the establishment of a permanent body that will be in charge of ensuring the implementation of Union regulations and monitoring practices, then I certainly support this initiative. Obviously, this is one additional problem that the European Union needs to address institutionally.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the adoption of the Decision on the establishment of a new Special Committee on Early Decisions and Other Measures of a Similar Nature or Effect, to supplement the work carried out by the previous Special Committee on Early Decisions and Other Measures of A Similar Nature or Effect, set up on 12 February 2015, I voted in favour of this Decision, referring to the list of the 45 members comprising it.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I welcome the establishment of a new special commission TAXE II, certainly with similar contours to the committee that preceded it (so the mandate takes up all the main elements of the previous special committee, the same structure and the same number of members, and will be in place for six months as well). The new committee will be responsible for examining Member States' practices and compliance with their obligations, including under the Administrative Cooperation Directive, as well as assessing how the Commission has implemented its obligations to monitor state aid and as guardian of the treaties.  The special committee should complement the work of the previous committee in order to resolve certain outstanding issues (including access to the group's "code of conduct" documents). It will also have to monitor the implementation by member states and relevant European institutions of the recommendations of the TAXE I Committee and the work at OECD and G20 level.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the appointment of the members proposed by the Conference of Presidents.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal concerning the appointment of the members of the Special Committee on Early Decisions in Tax Matters, as I believe that the members chosen for this matter are competent and willing.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution, by which the members of the TAXE Special Commission are appointed in their new mandate.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as a mere technical formality, which completes the extension of the mandate of the Special Commission on Tax Agreements and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support the appointments of Members to this Special Committee on Tax Decisions, as I believe that those with their expertise in fiscal policy and tax will contribute to the quality of work of the Committee itself. The role of the Committee is to propose to the Member States the appropriate measures necessary for the gradual development or functioning of the internal market, to verify whether the aid granted by a State or state aid is linked to the internal market and not to be used in a rules that are opposite to the rules, which leads to an improvement in the functioning of it.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This committee, with its proposed composition, is not expected to bring the expected results.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the appointment of the members of the special committee on tax rulings and other similar measures by nature or effect, following the advice of the ECON specialists of the S and D political group and in particular my colleague Hugues Bayet, who has contributed greatly to this positive result.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The setting up of, and appointments to, the TAXE II Special Committee are important decisions to continue the work of the EU against tax avoidance on our continent. The new committee and the Members appointed will be tasked with examining the practices of the Member States and whether they are complying with their obligations. It will also assess how the Commission has implemented its obligations on state aid control and in its capacity as guardian of the Treaties. It will also monitor the implementation, by the Member States and the competent European institutions, of the recommendations of the TAXE I Committee and work at OECD and G20 level.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I did not support the appointment of the proposed candidates to the Committee on Tax Rulings, as I consider that the extension of the work of this Committee will not significantly contribute to the discovery of new information concerning allegations that some Member States benefit from special tax advantages to international corporations, which is why it was originally established. In the course of its work, the Committee studied tax rulings in the Member States and held hearings with experts, as well as various meetings with NGO representatives and public servants involved in the creation of taxation rules, during which committee members concluded that modern competition in the field of corporate taxation was harmful. According to their findings, such competition not only resulted in the loss of public revenues, but also led to unfair provisions under which tax amnesty, tax rulings and other tax exemption and benefit systems were reserved for large corporations while small and medium-sized enterprises and citizens were subject to an increase in state revenues.  These results show that the interim committee has fulfilled its task and I believe that the powers of the already established authorities dealing with this issue should now be restored. Since I am against the creation of a new TAXE II committee for six months, I also voted against appointing members to the same committee.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the appointments to the Special Committee on Tax Rulings. In view of the work of the original TAXE Committee, I believe that it is important for all those appointed to this committee to be aware that existing work needs to be upgraded, not repeated.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution, by which the members of the TAXE Special Commission are appointed in their new mandate.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As I have already made clear in the context of the setting up of the Special Committee, the European Parliament has decided to set up a special committee after the end of the work of the TAXE Committee, which will deal with tax provisions and other measures similar in nature or impact, examining the practice of applying EU law on State aid and taxation. The new body builds entirely on the work carried out by the TAXE Special Committee and tries to close the open questions. I also supported the related technical proposals.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the appointments of the Special Commission on Tax Agreements and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects, of which I will be a party.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour and thereby supported the appointments to the Special Committee on Tax Rulings because I agree with the importance of the role of this special committee and I support the tasks that have been assigned to it. It will have several powers, such as: to analyse and examine practice regarding tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect; proposing to Member States appropriate measures required by the progressive development or by the functioning of the internal market, checking whether aid granted by a State or through State resources is compatible with the internal market and not misused, deciding that the State concerned is to abolish or alter such aid within a certain period of time, and referring the matter to the Court of Justice of the European Union if the State concerned does not comply; to analyse and examine compliance by Member States regarding the obligation to cooperate and provide all necessary documents; and to analyse and examine compliance concerning mutual assistance by the competent authorities of the Member States in the field of direct taxation and taxation of insurance premiums.  I believe that the granting of such powers to the Special Committee will guarantee heightened transparency in this field.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as a mere technical formality, which completes the extension of the mandate of the Special Commission on Tax Agreements and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the appointments to the Special Committee on Tax Rulings because they are a necessary decision to combat tax evasion and tax fraud at European level.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This process confirms the nature of the current European integration process, designed to favour large multinational companies. It also confirms the link between the main political families present in Parliament and the interests of these large companies which are and will continue to be the ones that profit the most from the liberalisation of the economy and from the weakening of the capacity of national states to control their economies. Our work in committee is therefore part of building another Europe that is focused on the interests of people and workers.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposal will allow the Special Committee to deepen its work. There is a reasonable hope that this decision would curb tax evasion within the EU. I therefore support this proposal.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the EU acting in its own capacity to enter into international agreements that could be agreed on a bilateral or multilateral basis between nation states.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Principality of Liechtenstein signed an agreement in October 2015 on the automatic exchange of financial information to combat tax evasion and fraud. It is important to remember that, unfortunately, the Principality of Liechtenstein, in addition to countries such as Switzerland and Monaco, is one of the states most sensitive to the issue of tax evasion and avoidance, put in place by European and non-European citizens. While it is true, however, that the agreement certainly represents a step forward in the control policies implemented for compliance with financial and fiscal obligations at international level, it is also true that it could be further improved. That is why I have chosen to abstain from voting, because I believe that the text as formulated is not capable of achieving the necessary level of control and cooperation, by virtue of a series of regulatory gaps that can be easily circumvented.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite containing positive measures to control transactions with Liechtenstein, we consider the total ban on tax havens necessary. It is already problematic that it is only now that the EU develops such tax partnership agreements with Liechtenstein, especially at the specific point of savings yields, from which the Union's main fortunes benefit. We consider fiscal cooperation between two economically interconnected countries absolutely essential. However, in the case of tax havens, such as Liechtenstein, tougher measures are required that directly prohibit the fortunes of EU nationals from using their advantageous tax systems. Since this report has no reference to this prohibition, I have not been able to vote in favour of it.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report.
