The intention of the report is positive in the sense that it is seeking to ensure that interests on savings income is paid, however, there has been no real effort to deal with this very important matter authentically or with any real will.  The shadow to the report was unable to make any improvements to the text as Parliament was only heard after the ratification of the agreement. Moreover and very importantly, the agreement falls short of the Mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation report, which was approved in October in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON).

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union has acted on the end of bank secrecy by the Council's decision of 20 March 2014. From now on, automatic exchanges of information are being made between Member States. Austria and Luxembourg were reluctant and demanded that Switzerland and Liechtenstein take similar measures because of their proximity to the EU countries, which in fact created unfair competition.  As was the case with Switzerland during the third plenary session in October, the European Parliament was called upon to give its opinion on the protocol for amending the agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein. This agreement provides for certain provisions that will limit the ability of taxpayers to evade their reporting obligations to tax authorities. Tax transparency and an end to bank secrecy is necessary to limit capital flight. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement between the European Union and Liechtenstein. It is a great preventive measure to stop the evasive spread of tax fraud and tax evasion. Exchange of information relating to income in such forms as interests and dividends will help to better administrate tax matters in cross-border related situations, avoid tax evasion and help to reduce the administrative burden by avoiding unnecessary investigations.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to approve an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial accounts on tax matters with Liechtenstein. In October 2015, the EU and Liechtenstein signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information in order to improve international cooperation and tax compliance. This contributes significantly to the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion. From 2017, the EU and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information about their residents' financial accounts, thus responding to cases where the taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets for which taxes have not been paid. I agree that tax authorities in the Member States and Liechtenstein should correctly and clearly identify the relevant taxpayers, administer and enforce their tax legislation in cross-border cases, assess the possibility of tax evasion and avoid unnecessary further investigations.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have approved the new agreement between the European Community and Liechtenstein on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. The measures taken in this text relate to the exchange of information according to the OECD Convention and to greater data protection.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this report on the transposition of the Savings Interest Directive into a bilateral agreement with Liechtenstein. While the Agreement is a step forward in the fight against tax evasion and evasion, it is clearly insufficient in terms of transparency and legal obligations. It establishes excessive discretion in disclosing information, and makes the exchange of information conditional on the agreement between the competent authorities. In addition, the European Parliament has only been consulted after ratification of the Agreement.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which refers to the Agreement signed by the EU and Liechtenstein on 28 October 2015 on the automatic exchange of financial account information with a view to improving tax cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. I support the rapporteur, who welcomes the Agreement, which represents an important step in the current fight against tax evasion and tax evasion.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report relates to the Council's proposal for a decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol for Amendment to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein providing for measures equivalent to those provided for in the Council's Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. The amendment protocol aims to implement the single global standard for the automatic exchange of financial account information between EU Member States and Liechtenstein. This standard was published by the OECD Council in July 2014. This agreement is the counterpart of the EU-Switzerland agreement signed last month, which marks the end of banking secrecy in Liechtenstein, through the adoption of the OECD standard. In return, it must allow Luxembourg and Austria to abandon bank secrecy at EU level.  So I voted for this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is shareable and unbleased. By amending the agreement between the EU and the Principality of Liechtenstein, exchanges of account and bank transaction information will be automatic, ensuring greater transparency and enabling more effective action to combat tax fraud. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this measure.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. On 28 October 2015, the EU and Liechtenstein signed an Agreement on the Automatic Exchange of Bank Account Information, an important step in efforts to pursue tax evasion and tax evasion, which updates the 2004 Agreement, which ensured that Liechtenstein complied with measures equivalent to those of the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. According to the Agreement, from 2017, the EU and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on the bank accounts of their respective residents. The aim is to deal with situations in which the taxpayer intends to hide capital on which he has not paid taxes. It will be ensured that Liechtenstein applies measures equivalent to the new legal framework to which the EU has been provided in this area and, in particular, to those of the Administrative Cooperation Directive. I note as key issues that the tax administrations of Member States and Liechtenstein will be able to correctly and unequivocally identify the taxpayers concerned, administer and enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations, assess the likelihood of tax evasion and increase the effectiveness in prosecuting these crimes. That is why I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report on the Agreement between the European Union (EU) and Liechtenstein on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. On 28 October 2015, the EU and Liechtenstein signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information in order to improve international cooperation and compliance with tax. This agreement is an important step in the ongoing fight against tax fraud and tax evasion and corrects the 2004 agreement, which ensured that Liechtenstein applied measures equivalent to those of the EU Savings Tax Directive. Under this agreement, from 2017, the EU and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents. The aim is to respond to cases where a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets for which no taxes have been paid. The agreement aims to ensure that Liechtenstein applies stricter measures that are equivalent to an EU directive adjusted in March 2014 and that it complies with the provisions on the automatic exchange of financial account information, which are promoted in the implementation of the 2014 OECD global standards. The EU-Liechtenstein Agreement should enter into force on 1 January 2016.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The AGREEMENT between the EU and Liechtenstein on the automatic exchange of financial account information is the logical consequence of the latest disclosures, when a huge amount of money, including illegally obtained, is hidden in the accounts of smaller countries, and in this way individuals also seek to avoid taxation in their home country. By exchanging information, at least in the case of Liechtenstein, this will no longer be possible, and therefore my support for the agreement will also be possible.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The exchange of information is one of the main principles that must be strengthened on the European continent in the field of taxation. At the end of October 2015, the EU and Liechtenstein signed an agreement on this subject that ensures greater control over compliance with tax rules and obligations, strengthens mutual commitment to combating tax fraud and evasion and follows liechtenstein's commitment to equip itself with internal instruments equivalent to those of the Union (EU Directive on the taxation of savings income). I support this report, which further strengthens cooperation between the EU and Liechtenstein.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. In order to convince the Austrian and Luxembourg authorities to ratify the agreement on the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts, which was announced in March 2014, the European Union has worked to negotiate with Liechtenstein the end of bank secrecy, which created unfair tax competition in Europe.   The agreement, which will take effect from 2017, provides for EU Member States and Liechtenstein to automatically exchange data on income, account balances and capital gains from the sale of financial assets. These measures will greatly limit the ability of Europeans to evade taxation from their country of origin and allow Member States to recover the tax revenue due to them.  We are in favour of this cooperation, which will limit tax evasion in Europe. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. Parliament's agreement with Liechtenstein will make it more difficult for EU citizens to hide capital from their national tax authorities; From 2018, the European Union and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of each other's residents.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein laying down measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. In order to strengthen the fight against tax fraud and evasion, it is absolutely necessary to promote the automatic exchange of information as a future European and international standard of transparency in tax matters. This tool, in addition to being essential to counteract the eversive phenomena, guarantees maximum transparency and collaboration between the administrations involved. The agreement is intended to ensure that Liechtenstein's application of measures in line with the Legal Framework of the European Union applies enhanced measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU legal framework, as well as compliance with the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the EU acting in its own capacity to enter into international agreements that could be agreed on a bilateral or multilateral basis between nation states.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because our 2014 agreements with Liechtenstein needed to be upgraded in line with the latest world developments so that we can continue our effective cooperation in the field of taxation. These will continue to help us combat tax evasion and fraud.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the agreement between the European Union and Liechtenstein on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes signed on 28 October 2015, an automatic exchange of information on the financial accounts of their residents will be carried out from 2016, in order to increase efforts to combat fraud, avoidance and tax evasion. Although this agreement certainly contains improvements compared with the current situation, I believe that a more complete and in-depth agreement could and should have been seeking, since this still has several regulatory gaps that can be easily circumvented. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Concerns the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein providing for measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. In view of the report by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, we support the report positively.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the conclusion of an amending protocol to the Agreement between the Council - in the name of the European Union - and the Principality of Liechtenstein was discussed today. This report, which provides for measures to tax - in the form of interest - savings income, is of particular importance in the light of the excessively harsh austerity policies pursued in recent years, particularly in countries such as Greece which have faced the economic crisis and been forced to take very harsh measures at the expense of weak social groups. Such a proposal to record and tax sources of savings interest income should be accepted as a whole. As in the recent case of an agreement with Switzerland, this agreement is also in the right direction and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. The agreement signed on 28 October 2015 between the European Union and Liechtenstein on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes from 2017 represents an important step forward in ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion. The possibility of identifying taxpayers and applying cross-border tax discipline uniformly will act as a deterrent to the practice of concealment of capital, whether these consist of income or activities subject to tax evasion. The agreement is intended to ensure that Liechtenstein applies enhanced measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU legal framework, as updated in December 2014. The additional provisions aim to ensure that the information exchanged relates not only to income such as interest and dividends, but also to account balances and proceeds from sales of financial assets. The rapporteur considers the agreement to be fully positive and calls for the date of entry into force of the agreement to be respected.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the agreement signed between the European Union and Liechtenstein on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes has improved cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. Furthermore, in my opinion, the agreement represents an important step forward in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion and improves the 2004 agreement guaranteeing liechtenstein's application of measures equivalent to those contained in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. Finally, I would like to stress that the agreement is intended to ensure that Liechtenstein applies enhanced measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU legal framework and respects the automatic exchange of information concerning financial accounts.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the adoption of Council Directive 2003/48/EC, the Savings Directive, and in order to preserve the level playing field of economic operators, the EU signed agreements with Liechtenstein providing for measures equivalent to those laid down in the Directive. The Commission adopted on 17 June 2011 a recommendation for a mandate to initiate negotiations with Liechtenstein in order to upgrade the EU’s agreements with those countries in line with international developments and to ensure that those countries continue to apply measures equivalent to those in the EU. On 14 May 2013, the Council reached an agreement on the negotiating mandate.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the EU acting in its own capacity to enter into international agreements that could be agreed on a bilateral or multilateral basis between nation states.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the agreement with Liechtenstein. Money knows no borders, so we need uniformly strict rules to allow tax administrations and Member States to apply tax laws in cross-border situations and to identify taxpayers correctly and unambiguously.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the EU acting in its own capacity to enter into international agreements that could be agreed on a bilateral or multilateral basis between nation states

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to combat tax fraud and evasion, it is essential to improve cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. I therefore vote in favour of this ad hoc report to ensure that Liechtenstein applies enhanced measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU legal framework and respects the automatic exchange of financial account information promoted by the 2014 OECD Global Standards. This agreement will reduce the risk that taxpayers will be able to conceal income capital or carry out tax evasion activities. I also believe it is essential that the agreement is concluded in time to allow it to enter into force on 1 January 2016, so as to meet the agreed deadline.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the adoption of the Savings Directive, and in order to preserve the level playing field of economic operators, the EU signed agreements with Liechtenstein providing for measures equivalent to those laid down in the Directive. The Commission adopted a recommendation for a mandate to initiate negotiations with Liechtenstein in order to upgrade the EU’s agreements in line with international developments and to ensure that these countries continue to apply measures equivalent to those in the EU. This report approves the conclusion of the agreement, thus I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report focuses on the agreement signed between The European Union and Liechtenstein on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The agreement represents an important step in ongoing efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion and upgrades the 2004 agreement that ensured that Liechtenstein applied measures equivalent to those in an EU directive on the taxation of savings income. While I reiterate my personal and Malta’s position against any attempts at tax harmonisation I am fully committed to clamp down on any potential tax fraud. International co-operation is a key to such a fight and therefore I fully support this new agreement and voted in favour of this report in Parliament.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this amending protocol, which brings the EU and Liechtenstein’s automatic exchange of financial account information into line with OECD global standards. Enhancing data protection is vitally important in maintaining public confidence in authorities’ use of their information. This agreement, as well as the similar agreement with Switzerland and upcoming agreements with San Marino, Andorra and Monaco, will help in ensuring we have the highest standards of data protection around financial information exchange, as well as in meeting our international obligations under the OECD.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to strengthen measures to combat tax evasion and evasion between the European Union and Liechtenstein. In particular, it aims to make it more difficult for EU citizens to hide capital from their national tax authorities. Under the agreement, the EU and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information about the financial accounts of residents of each country from 2018. These will include income, interest, dividends, balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. Considering that tax evasion and evasion penalize citizens by undermining state resources and creating a sense of injustice, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information signed between the European Union and Liechtenstein provides for the strengthening of cross-border tax cooperation. The measures included in this agreement are essential to strengthen the fight against tax evasion and evasion in Europe. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerned the Council's proposal for a decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol for Amendment to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein providing for measures equivalent to those provided for in the Council's Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. Thus, by applying this agreement to Liechtenstein, distortion of competition is avoided. It is appropriate that within the European Economic Area the rules should be respected by all parties to the agreement. Attached to financial transparency, I voted for this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the EU-Liechtenstein agreement on 'taxation of savings in the form of interest payments'. The establishment of secure and endaque measures for economic operators equivalent to those in the Taxation Directive is a positive development. We still suffer too often from financial crimes, taking advantage of differences in security levels and safeguards. Through technical alignment, we can tackle financial crime in a more effective and transparent way. Updating the Amending Protocol is a welcome change creating global OECD standards that are compatible with EU standards. Data protection is now more important than ever, especially in light of recent political developments.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report as Liechtenstein is a well-known tax haven and, consequently, the exchange of tax information serves international tax cooperation and compliance.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Principality of Liechtenstein have signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of information from financial accounts to improve tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. This is important progress in the efforts being made to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. Under the Agreement, the EU and the Principality of Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of residents of the other Party from 2017. I agree and express my full support for the agreement.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it is in the direction of better financial transparency.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2003/48/EC is limited to the taxation of savings income in the form of interest on claims, excluding issues relating to the taxation of pensions and insurance benefits. The agreement signed this year on the automatic exchange of financial account information, which aims to improve international tax cooperation, represents a step in the right direction in ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. The report, however, falls short of what is necessary and sins for several shortcomings, such as: a) The lack of efforts to achieve absolute transparency and full disclosure of information between the parties and the presence of legal constraints in the agreement; (b) the existence of an exemption from disclosure of information, which is too broad and ambiguous conditionality; (c) conditions for the exchange of information on the basis of the prior approval of the competent authorities. Furthermore, as had already happened with the agreement between the EU and Switzerland, the European Parliament was only heard after the ratification of the agreement, and it is impossible, in practical terms, to introduce any improvement. Hence our abstention.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained because I do not have an opinion on this.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the EU-Lichtenstein agreement on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments, since Liechtenstein is a well-known tax haven and, consequently, the exchange of tax information serves international tax cooperation and compliance with the relevant provisions.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the EU-Liechtenstein agreement on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments because it represents an important step in ongoing efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion and upgrades the 2004 agreement that ensured that Liechtenstein applied measures equivalent to those in an EU directive on the taxation of savings income. Being in line with the need for more transparency on tax issues in the EU and in its relations with third countries, I consider it important that tax administrations in the Member States and in Liechtenstein will be able to: identify correctly and unequivocally the taxpayers concerned, administer and enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations, assess the likelihood of tax evasion being perpetrated and avoid unnecessary further investigations.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 28 October 2015, the European Union and Liechtenstein signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. I believe that the agreement represents an important step in efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion.  Under the agreement, an automatic exchange of information between the EU and Liechtenstein on the financial accounts of each other's residents will be established from 2017 onwards. The aim is to address situations where taxable persons seek to conceal capital conbodied in the sense of income or property for which the tax has not yet been paid. A key element of the agreement is also to ensure that the information exchanged relates not only to revenues such as interest and dividends, but also to account balances and income from the sale of financial instruments. In this sense, I welcome the role of being able to define the taxable persons concerned precisely and unequivocally and to be able to apply and implement their tax legislation in cross-border cases and to assess the likelihood of committing tax fraud.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this agreement as an important step in the current fight against tax evasion and evasion. Thanks to the agreement, the EU and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their respective residents from 2017.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the EU-Liechtenstein agreement on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts, as I welcome all measures across Europe to prevent tax and financial evasion and to ensure tax justice for the benefit of our citizens and families.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Automatic data exchange is another step towards closing existing tax loopholes. Tax fraud and tax evasion are problems that need to be tackled consistently.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this report on the transposition of the Savings Interest Directive into a bilateral agreement with Liechtenstein. While the Agreement is a step forward in the fight against tax evasion and evasion, it is clearly insufficient in terms of transparency and legal obligations. It establishes excessive discretion in disclosing information, and makes the exchange of information conditional on the agreement between the competent authorities. In addition, the European Parliament has only been consulted after ratification of the Agreement.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I voted in favour of the signing of an agreement between the EU and the Kingdom of Liechtenstein in order to guarantee equal rules for economic operators, based on those already contained in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on tax savings. I voted in favour of this agreement because, due to the revisions made to the rules on global and European reporting standards, administrative cooperation and, in particular, the exchange of financial information between tax authorities in the European Union have been disrupted. As a Member of the European Parliament, I consider it extremely important that consistent rules on the exchange of information throughout the EU, especially when they guarantee tax transparency, are at the centre of the fight against tax fraud, and regulate and improve the cooperation of the tax authorities of the Member States.  The citizens of my country are already fed up with leaky laws, broken procedures, the use of tax loopholes by those in power and monopolies. Citizens Polish want to live in a safe, properly governed country, and this is also facilitated by the introduction of transparency of financial rules at EU level. That is why, as a member of Polish, I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report on the EU-Liechtenstein agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. The European Union and Liechtenstein signed an agreement on 28 October 2015 on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. It is a very important step in ongoing efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion and upgrades the 2004 agreement that ensured that Liechtenstein applied measures equivalent to those in an EU directive on the taxation of savings income. Under the agreement, the EU and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of each other’s residents, starting in 2017. The aim is to address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which aims to assist in improving international tax cooperation and compliance. I agree that this report is an important step in ongoing efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion. Through this report tax administrators in Member States and in Liechtenstein will be able to identify correctly and unequivocally the taxpayers concerned, administer and enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations and assess the likelihood of tax evasion being perpetrated.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the EU acting in its own capacity to enter into international agreements that could be agreed on a bilateral or multilateral basis between nation states.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU and Liechtenstein signed an agreement in order to secure a level playing field for economic operators on the basis of the measures equivalent to those laid down in the Savings Tax Directive (2003/48/EC) in 2004. The importance of automatic exchange of information as a means to combat cross-border tax fraud by ensuring tax transparency and cooperation between tax administrations has also been recognised at OECD level. This amending protocol seeks to implement the OECD Global Standards on automatic exchange of financial account information between the EU and Lichtenstein. I voted in favour of it. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished, because it leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the EU acting in its own capacity to enter into international agreements that could be agreed on a bilateral or multilateral basis between nation states

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, because the agreement represents an important step in the on-going efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion.  The EU and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of each other’s residents, starting in 2017 for information collected in 2016. The aim is to address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income or assets for which tax has not been paid.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein on measures equivalent to those set out in the Council Directive on the taxation of savings interest income, as this improves international tax cooperation and coherence. From 2017, this will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of EU and Liechtenstein residents. In addition, Liechtenstein will apply strengthened measures in this area that are in line with the legal framework of the European Union, and I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. In March 2014, the automatic exchange of information at EU level sealed the fate of banking secrecy within the European Union. This was not done without the reluctance of Austria and Luxembourg. One of the conditions for the abandonment of banking secrecy by these countries was the acceptance by Switzerland and Liechtenstein of similar measures, so as not to create unfair competition. The Loones report on the Memorandum of Understanding provides for an automatic exchange of information on the financial accounts of their respective residents between the EU and Liechtenstein from 2017.  Liechtenstein will apply automatic trade measures, equivalent to those in the EU Directive 2003/48. In addition, the agreement provides for a limitation on the opportunities for taxpayers to evade their reporting obligations by transferring their assets or investing in financial products outside the scope of the agreement. The information that will have to be exchanged relates not only to income, but also to account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. It is important not to leave a country with financial opacity at the doorstep of the Union, except to see a capital flight continue. I voted for it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – My fellow colleagues and I opposes the EU acting in its own capacity to enter into international agreements that could be agreed on a bilateral or multilateral basis between nation states.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Sander Loones' report on the EU-Lichtenstein agreement on the automatic exchange of information. This text supports the conclusion of an agreement with the Lichtenstein which will strengthen the fight against tax evasion and bank secrecy by introducing an automatic exchange of information on the financial accounts of European citizens with an account in Lichtenstein. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this report. This report concerns the agreement between the EU and the Principality of Liechtenstein on future arrangements in the field of taxation of savings income. The implementation of the agreement will lead to greater transparency and all Member States will be able to tackle tax evasion more effectively.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the agreement between the European Union and Liechtenstein on the automatic exchange of financial account information. The report underlines that the aim is to address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid. I support this report and I welcome the agreement as it aims at improving international tax cooperation and compliance and represents an important step in ongoing efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The agreement signed on 28 October 2015 between the European Union and Liechtenstein aims to strengthen the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes. The primary objective is linked to liechtenstein's application of enhanced measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU legal framework. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the report, believing that this is a great step forward in fiscal matters and that it is fully in line with the overall standards promoted by the OECD in this area.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it marks the end of bank secrecy in Liechtenstein, through the adoption of an automatic information exchange system with the European Union.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite containing positive measures to control transactions with Liechtenstein, we consider the total ban on tax havens necessary. It is already problematic that it is only now that the EU develops such tax partnership agreements with Liechtenstein, especially at the specific point of savings yields, from which the Union's main fortunes benefit. We consider fiscal cooperation between two economically interconnected countries absolutely essential. However, in the case of tax havens, such as Liechtenstein, tougher measures are required that directly prohibit the fortunes of EU nationals from using their advantageous tax systems. Since this report has no reference to this prohibition, I have not been able to vote in favour of it.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. The Agreement between the European Union and Liechtenstein on the exchange of financial account data was signed on 28 October 2015 with the aim of improving international tax cooperation. I supported Representative Sander Loones' report because the Agreement represents a step forward in combating tax fraud and tax evasion. It also complements the 2004 agreement that ensures the same application of the rules on the taxation of savings income as in the European Union. From 2017, the EU and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on residents' financial accounts. The ultimate goal is to address situations where the taxpayer seeks to hide capital, income or assets for which taxes have not been paid.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I support an agreement that will allow for a flexible exchange of financial account information between the Union and Liechtenstein. The agreement will help to detect tax fraud and evasion, which are being prepared by EU countries by hundreds of millions of euros.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstain from voting in the report on the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein providing for measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments, because it is not complete and documented, and because additional actions and measures are needed to combat tax evasion and avoidance of multinational companies and natural persons who find refuge in tax havens such as Liechtenstein.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report. This agreement is part of the end of bank secrecy through the automatic exchange of information within the countries of the European Union. Austria and Luxembourg only agreed to abandon this banking secrecy if Switzerland and Liechtenstein agreed to similar measures, so as not to create unfair competition. With this agreement, Liechtenstein agrees to apply measures equivalent to those provided in the European texts, and thus follows Switzerland's example.   Tax transparency and the end of bank secrecy are objectives that we support.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I supported Parliament's report on the EU-Liechtenstein Agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. All measures taken to improve tax cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level are well received. In this way we will be able to advance the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion, dealing with situations in which a taxpayer tries to hide a wealth representing income or assets on which no taxes have been paid.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This agreement represents an important step in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report aims to approve the tax agreement reached between the European Union and Liechtenstein in October 2015. This agreement will increase tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations through the introduction of an automatic exchange of financial account information.  Thus, this new agreement would participate, somewhat, in the fight against tax fraud and evasion, but in view of the tax practices tolerated within the European Union (massive tax evasion in Luxembourg revealed by the Luxleaks case), one can legitimately doubt its effectiveness. Especially since the text excludes issues related to the taxation of pensions and insurance benefits, while life insurance is the first investment medium. Finally, it is possible to depart from this agreement via the "information disclosure exemption", which applies under too broad and ill-defined conditions. I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The end of bank secrecy through the automatic exchange of information at EU level has had to overcome the reluctance of Austria and Luxembourg. One of the conditions for the abandonment of banking secrecy by these countries was the acceptance by Switzerland and Liechtenstein of similar measures, so as not to create unfair competition. Liechtenstein will therefore apply measures equivalent to those provided in the European texts (Directive 2006/48 review). It will thus accept the automatic exchange of financial account information, as set out in OECD global standards in 2014.  Tax transparency and the end of bank secrecy are all objectives, in particular in order to preserve Member States' tax revenues. I therefore vote in favour on this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein on the exchange of information on financial accounts. The aim is to prevent situations where a taxpayer tries to hide capital corresponding to income or assets for which no tax has been paid. The fight against fraud and tax evasion should be listed as one of the European Union's priorities.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Following on from the Commission’s recommendations I chose to support this report as it consents to the conclusion of the Council’s agreement on behalf of the EU with the Principality of Liechtenstein.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The fight against fraud is intensifying at the European level. It is essential that in the face of this global phenomenon, we can put an end together to these illegal and fraudulent practices which are undermining the tax base of our Member States. I am pleased that the European Parliament has approved this agreement, which will put an end to the banking secrecy of European citizens in Liechtenstein. The European Union and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on the bank accounts of their respective citizens by 2018. Given the importance of the dossier, it was by an overwhelming majority (461 in for, 49 against and 30 abstentions) that the European Parliament sent a strong message to end tax evasion.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Liechtenstein agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. The agreement aims at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. Under the agreement, the EU and Liechtenstein will be obliged to automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of each other’s residents, starting in 2017. This agreement represents an important step in ongoing efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion which will help to address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 28 October 2015, the European Union and Liechtenstein signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The Agreement has been submitted to the Council for approval by the Commission, which is obliged to consult parliament before taking a decision under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. In its report, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs recommends that Parliament approve the conclusion of the agreement. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The end of bank secrecy in Europe requires that border countries also accept the same transparency rules, so as not to create tax havens at the EU's doorstep, which would unfairly compete against Member States' institutions and public finances. The agreement signed with Switzerland last month is here resumed with Liechtenstein. There is therefore every reason to vote in favour on its principle.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Principality of Liechtenstein signed an agreement on 28 October 2015 on the automatic exchange of financial account information with the aim of improving tax cooperation and the application of international tax obligations. This Agreement provides that the European Union and the Principality of Liechtenstein shall automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of residents of the other Party from 2017. This Agreement is intended to prevent cases where a taxpayer tries to hide capital corresponding to income or assets for which no tax has been paid. By advocating greater cooperation, transparency and sharing of tax information, with the aim of reducing fraud and evasion, this report and the adoption of the Agreement deserve my vote in favour.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which approves the conclusion of the Protocol for Amendment to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein providing for measures equivalent to those provided in the Council's Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. The aim is to combat tax evasion by allowing the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the conclusion of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein laying down measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. Signed on 28 October, it represents an important step forward for the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, as promoted by the OECD's global standards of 2014. We therefore believe that it can contribute to the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion at international level and improve the 2004 agreement guaranteeing liechtenstein's application of measures equivalent to those contained in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. Starting from 2017, in fact, an automatic exchange of information on the financial accounts of the respective residents will be carried out in order to cope with situations in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion. The additional provisions also aim to ensure that the information exchanged relates not only to income such as interest and dividends, but also to account balances and income from sales of financial assets.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the agreement between the European Union and Liechtenstein on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, aimed at improving cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. It represents an important step forward in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion and improves the 2004 agreement which ensured that Liechtenstein applied measures equivalent to those contained in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. With this agreement, tax administrations, both in the Member States and liechtenstein, will be able to correctly and unequivocally identify the taxpayers concerned, ensuring that their tax legislation is applied in cross-border situations.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report, because I believe that the harmonisation of legislation between non-EU Member States with an organic trade relationship with the European Union can greatly facilitate the effectiveness of taxation within the EU. In this case, I consider it of the utmost importance that the exchange of information be started as soon as possible, thereby reducing the budgetary losses resulting from tax fraud and evasion. However, it is not inconsiderable that the exchange of mutual information will also avoid the conduct of a number of unnecessary investigations in the future.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ On 28 October 2015 the European Union and Liechtenstein signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. I voted for this report that aims at ensuring that Liechtenstein applies strengthened measures that are equivalent to the EU legal framework and that it complies with the automatic exchange of financial account information promoted by the 2014 OECD Global Standards.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the EP's agreement to conclude an agreement with Liechtenstein on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest income as an important signal in the context of the intensification of the EU's efforts to increase tax assistance. At the same time, the agreement will serve as a legal basis for the implementation of oecd global standards on the automatic exchange of tax information between the EU and Liechtenstein. I see the benefits of the agreement, inter alia, in allowing the correct and unambiguous identifying of the taxable person concerned, to enforce, where necessary, the tax laws of Liechtenstein and the EU Member States in cross-border situations, to assess the likelihood of tax evasion and to avoid unnecessary lengthy investigations.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this agreement as it represents an important step in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. The agreement is intended to ensure that Liechtenstein applies stricter rules. In addition, tax administrations in the Member States should be able to correctly identify the tax obligations in question.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report proposes to approve the amendment of the eu-Lichtenstein agreement on income taxation, in order to bring it into line with the measures set out in directive 2003/48/EC on tax cooperation between Member States. The establishment of an automatic exchange of banking information is thus planned, according to the terms of the directive, with the aim of combating massive tax evasion to the principality of Liechtenstein. The fight against tax evasion and evasion is necessary, but the measures in this directive are not sufficiently effective. Among other weaknesses, there is an exemption from disclosure applied under unclear and ambiguous conditions. I abstain to denounce the lack of firmness.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The agreement is an important step forward in the ongoing work to combat tax fraud and tax evasion.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report submitted. This agreement between the EU and Liechtenstein on automatic exchange of financial accounts on tax matters is a major step forward in the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion more effectively. It is essential to ensure that Liechtenstein applies measures equivalent to EU instruments. It should be noted that automatic exchange of information is a particularly important tool that helps to ensure full tax transparency and cooperation between tax administrations on a global scale. A coherent, coherent and comprehensive approach to the automatic exchange of financial account information in the internal market should therefore be applied throughout the European Union. In addition, automatic exchange of information needs to be promoted in order to become a European and international standard for the exchange of information in the field of transparency and taxation.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP opposes the EU acting in its own capacity to enter into international agreements that could be agreed on a bilateral or multilateral basis between nation states.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is always necessary to stress the importance of the fight against tax evasion and any measures taken in favour of this end deserve full attention and full support. In this case, the existing agreement between the EU and Lichtenstein on this subject needs to be adapted to current European legislation for a more effective exchange of information between the parties. I would like to contribute by expressing my positive support for this.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I am in favour of the agreement between the EU and Liechtenstein concerning the exchange of information on the bank accounts of each other’s residents, because I believe it will allow a more transparent and open flow of information regarding tax fraud. Tax evasion siphons away money that could be invested in productive resources needed to diversify the economy and address social and environmental problems.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein on measures equivalent to those set out in the Council Directive on the Taxation of Interest on Savings, on behalf of the European Union, aims, inter alia, to improve international tax cooperation and coherence which I certainly support.  I support the agreement signed by the European Union and Liechtenstein on 28 October this year on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts, as it represents an important step in combating tax fraud and tax evasion. The Amending Protocol seeks to implement the OECD global standard between Member States and Liechtenstein, which is a good thing because it contributes to transparency and aims to ensure that Liechtenstein applies strengthened measures equivalent to the EU legal framework. Taking into account the proposal for a Council decision, the draft Protocol on Amendment and the recommendation of the committee responsible, I voted for this report and I am in favour of approving the conclusion of the Amending Protocol.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support Representative Loones' report on the proposal to amend the Agreement between the European Union and the Principality of Liechtenstein on the taxation of savings interest income so that the measures are equivalent to those set out in Council Directive 2003/48/EC. This amendment will develop an automated system through which members of the European Union and Liechtenstein will exchange information about the bank accounts of their citizens. This will take a major step in the fight against tax fraud, which is one of the European Union's pressing economic problems.  It is estimated that up to a trillion dollars are lost annually due to tax avoidance in the EU. This amendment, starting in 2017, could reduce this figure.  Also, precisely because of the automation of the system, the costs of researching each individual case of fraud will be avoided. In addition to the financial aspect, and in view of the Advice of the European Commission, the principle of data exchange described in this report was created in accordance with the OECD's global standard for automatic exchange of financial account information.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support this agreement that is critical to increasing tax cooperation and compliance across borders so that tax evaders cannot hide.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and Liechtenstein, in order to ensure compliance with international tax obligations, have signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of information relating to the financial accounts of their residents. This agreement, which will enter into force on 1 January 2016, aims to address the situation in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion. I voted in favour of approving this agreement because it represents a further step towards combating tax fraud and evasion at European level.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament approves the conclusion of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein, adapting it, this time, to the enhanced measures equivalent to the EU Directive, updated in March 2014. Under the amendments, the Protocol provides that, in the context of exchanges of information on the financial accounts of residents of the other Party, the exchange of information will be facilitated, not only with regard to income, such as interest and dividends, but also with regard to account balances and the proceeds of the sale of financial assets. Whereas the Agreement makes it possible to prevent situations in which a taxpayer attempts to hide capital corresponding to income or assets for which no tax has been paid, and whereas the prevention of tax evasion limits the negative consequences for economic development and, therefore, the negative impact on the achievement of solidarity and prosperity contemplated in the letter of the Treaties , I voted in favour of this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP opposes the EU acting in its own capacity to enter into international agreements that could be agreed on a bilateral or multilateral basis between nation states.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution on the agreement between the European Union and Liechtenstein on the establishment of an automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts. The agreement, which dates back to last October, is now due to enter into force on 1 January 2016. It will allow the automatic exchange of information about the bank accounts of residents of each country from 2017.  I would like to welcome here a significant step towards ending the bank secrecy of European taxpayers. It will be more difficult to hide money, for which citizens are taxed, from the country's bank accounts. The tax administrations of the Member States should be equipped with the necessary means of action. From now on, they will be able to identify the taxpayers concerned, manage and enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations or assess the likelihood of tax evasion involved.  Tax evasion cannot be tolerated, and that is why I welcome this agreement. I would also like to remind you that we endorsed a similar agreement between the European Union and Switzerland on 27 October.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. On 28 October 2015, the EU and Liechtenstein signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of bank account information, an important step in efforts to pursue tax evasion and tax evasion. It updates the 2004 Agreement, which ensured that Liechtenstein complied with measures equivalent to those of the EU Directive on the taxation of savings yields. Under the Agreement, from 2017 the EU and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information about the bank accounts of their respective residents. The aim is to deal with situations in which the taxpayer intends to hide capital on which he has not paid taxes. It will be ensured that Liechtenstein applies measures equivalent to the new legal framework to which the EU has been provided in this area and, in particular, to those of the Administrative Cooperation Directive. I note as key issues that the tax administrations of the Member States and Liechtenstein will be able to correctly and unequivocally identify the taxpayers concerned, administer and enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations, assess the likelihood of tax evasion and increase the effectiveness in prosecuting these crimes. That is why I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Union and Liechtenstein signed an agreement on 28 October 2015 on the automatic exchange of financial account information to increase tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. This agreement, which I voted on, marks an important step in the current efforts to combat tax evasion and evasion: from 2017, the EU and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their respective residents.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In October 2015, the EU and Liechtenstein agreed to automatically exchange information on financial accounts to improve tax cooperation and enable compliance with international tax obligations. The main objective of this agreement is to combat tax fraud and tax evasion, while also updating the 2004 agreement which allowed it to implement measures similar to those provided for in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. One of the improvements implemented concerns the possibility of automatic exchange of information on the financial accounts of residents of the other party from 2017, thus contributing to prevent potential situations of taxpayers to hide financial capital corresponding to income or assets on which no tax has been paid. In addition, the standards laid down for the global scale (established in 2014 by the OECD) are also expected to be followed with regard to the requirement for automatic exchange of information on financial accounts. With these measures strengthening the equivalents of the EU Directive updated in March 2014 we will have a fairer and more transparent system, so I supported this report by voting in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. Last October, I supported the report on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. In particular, it was important to conclude bilateral agreements with third countries as soon as possible in order to give full effect to this provision.  Therefore, I voted in favour of this report which endorses the agreement reached by the Council with Liechtenstein to continue to apply measures equivalent to those of the European Union.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein laying down measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments as I consider it necessary to combat crimes of fraud and tax evasion at both European and international level. Through the conclusion of the agreement signed on 28 October 2015, the European Union and the Principality of Liechtenstein, starting from the year 2017, undertake to exchange financial information for the tax purposes of their residents.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this report on the transposition of the Savings Interest Directive into a bilateral agreement with Liechtenstein. While the Agreement is a step forward in the fight against tax evasion and evasion, it is clearly insufficient in terms of transparency and legal obligations. It establishes excessive discretion in disclosing information, and makes the exchange of information conditional on the agreement between the competent authorities. In addition, the European Parliament has only been consulted after ratification of the Agreement.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite containing positive measures to control transactions with Liechtenstein, we consider the total ban on tax havens necessary. It is already problematic that it is only now that the EU develops such tax partnership agreements with Liechtenstein, especially at the specific point of savings yields, from which the Union's main fortunes benefit. We consider fiscal cooperation between two economically interconnected countries absolutely essential. However, in the case of tax havens, such as Liechtenstein, tougher measures are required that directly prohibit the fortunes of EU nationals from using their advantageous tax systems. Since this report has no reference to this prohibition, I have not been able to vote in favour of it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 28 October 2015, the European Union and Liechtenstein signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes with the aim of ensuring a better level playing field for economic operators. I have decided to support the conclusion of the agreement with the Principality because I believe that it represents an important step forward in the ongoing efforts to combat fraud and tax evasion. From 2017, therefore, Member States and Liechtenstein will begin this automatic exchange of financial information between their administrations. A similar agreement has been made with Switzerland and, as in that case, the aim is to prevent or find situations in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of illegal income or assets.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement: it is in line with the call and need for more transparency regarding tax issues in the Member States of the European Union and improves this dimension with our relations with third countries – those states not members of the EU.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ when voting on the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of an amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein dealing with measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments on behalf of the European Union, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution. The protocol at question extends the scope of the savings taxation agreement, which aims to reduce tax fraud and tax evasion, to the exchange of information relating not only to income such as interest and dividends, but also to the state of accounts and proceeds from the sale of financial assets.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on the EU-Liechtenstein agreement on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. On 28 October this year, the European Union and Liechtenstein signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information aimed at improving international cooperation and tax compliance. Under this agreement, the EU and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on their people's financial accounts from 2017. The aim is to address situations where the taxpayer tries to hide capital in the form of income or property for which no tax has been paid. The agreement is an important step in reducing tax fraud and tax evasion. On this basis, tax administrations in the Member States and Liechtenstein will be able to correctly and unambiguously identify the taxpayers concerned, implement and enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations and examine the likelihood of tax evasion.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. On 28 October 2015, the EU and Liechtenstein signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. The purpose of this agreement is to improve international cooperation in the field of tax and compliance. It is an upgrade of the 2004 agreement, which has already made it possible for Liechtenstein to implement measures equivalent to those laid down in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. Under the new agreement, from 2017, the EU and Liechtenstein will have an automatic exchange of information on residents' financial accounts. This will help the tax authorities in the Member States and Liechtenstein correctly and unambiguously identify the relevant taxpayers and manage and enforce national tax legislation in cross-border situations. The tax authorities will also have the possibility to assess the likelihood of tax evasion and thus be able to ensure that further investigations are carried out, if necessary and justified. Since the agreement has many advantages and, among other things, it prevents situations where the taxpayer tries to conceal capital in the form of income or property for which it has not paid tax and generally wants to prevent various forms of tax fraud, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 Unification of rules brings greater transparency and efficiency of international cooperation in the framework of tax compliance control. The same rules will make it easier to exchange information and check compliance in this area.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this proposal for a decision of the Council of the European Union, as I believe that a further agreement between the European Union and the Principality of Liechtenstein in this area will make it easier to locate and monitor natural and legal persons trying to evade tax levies. I believe that punishing offenders in the future will discourage potential perpetrators of these same offences. I also believe that we must adopt this draft as soon as possible so that it can be put into practice by 1.1.2016.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. After the adoption of Council Directive 2003/48/EC, the Austerity Directive, in order to maintain a level playing field for economic operators, the EU signed agreements with Switzerland, Andorra, Liechtenstein, Monaco and San Marino. The importance of automatic information sharing as a means to combat cross-border tax fraud has also recently been recognised internationally. The G20 entrusted the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) with the task of developing a single global standard for the automatic exchange of financial account information. The OECD Council published a global standard in July 2014. Given that the scope of Directive 2014/107/EU is broader than the scope of Directive 2003/48/EC, it provides that, in the event of overlapping, the scope is prioritised by Directive 2014/107/EU. On 18 March 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal to repeal Directive 2003/48/EC.  I support this proposal as this amendment ensures a coherent and comprehensive approach to the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts in the internal market at Union level and implements a global standard between EU Member States and Liechtenstein.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Directive 2003/48/EC is limited to the taxation of savings income in the form of interest arising from claims, with the exception of matters relating to the taxation of pensions and insurance benefits. At regional level, the Directive applies to interest paid by a paying agent, for example, a financial institution, a bank or an investment fund that pays interest or ensures that it is paid to beneficialholders established on EU territory. Parliament's report has to do with the information exchange agreement on the above issue with Liechtenstein, leaving large windows for large incomeees and large corporations. Also, as was the case in the agreement between the EU and Switzerland, the European Parliament was only asked to ratify the agreement. In this sense, Parliament could not give a real opinion on the agreement. As acpels, however, we respected the decisions taken by democratically elected governments, so, although we disagree on the substance of the issues, we have decided to abstain.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Liechtenstein is a well-known tax haven and therefore the exchange of tax information serves international tax cooperation and compliance with the relevant provisions.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report, which updates the 2004 agreement between Liechtenstein and the EU to ensure that the Principality applies measures equivalent to the EU Directive on the taxation of savings interest income. The EU-Liechtenstein Convention on the Automatic Exchange of Financial Account Information in October 2015 is of paramount importance as it enables more effective action to be taken against tax fraud and evasion. It is important for the EU to enter into similar agreements with third European countries and to update them if necessary, as this is the only way to effectively combat tax evaders who seek to hide their otherwise taxable income and wealth from European tax authorities. Liechtenstein should be welcomed as an EU partner in international tax cooperation.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Council's proposed decision amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein is another step to increase the effectiveness of measures taken against tax avoidance. This issue is particularly important when these activities are taken by natural and legal persons established in the Union with the help of financial institutions established in third countries.  The European Parliament's report highlights the benefits of the decision to automatically exchange financial information from 2017. It offers an opportunity to improve international tax cooperation and compliance. It is important that this agreement takes effect as soon as possible and that the European Union and Liechtenstein do not delay its adoption.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The tax systems of the EU Member States are the basis from which the Union's budgetary projection starts. Without coherent tax systems at national level, pooling European financial resources would become impossible. That is why the Member States and the European institutions must prevent and combat the phenomenon of tax evasion and tax fraud, which can take place through so-called 'tax havens'. With a view to achieving this, the European Union has launched concerted action to conclude agreements with European states where the level of taxation is very low and which can serve as a 'shelter' for fraudsters in the Member States. Such an agreement was concluded with the State of Liechtenstein on 28 October 2015 and involves the exchange of information on residents' accounts from 2017 onwards in order to avoid hiding income or assets for which the due taxes have not been paid. In particular, measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments are envisaged, in accordance with European rules on administrative cooperation and OECD standards in the field. I believe that this agreement should be supported.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for it. The European Union and Liechtenstein signed an agreement on 28 October 2015 on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at increasing tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. This agreement marks an important step in the current efforts to combat tax evasion and evasion and reinforces the 2004 agreement which ensured that Liechtenstein applied measures equivalent to those provided in the EU directive on the taxation of savings income.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Liechtenstein agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. The agreement represents an important step in the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion. Under the agreement, the EU and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of each other’s residents, starting in 2017. The objective is to address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The extension of the 2004 agreement with Liechtenstein aims to ensure compliance of Liechtenstein's measures with the Legal Framework of the European Union, through the automatic exchange of information on the financial accounts of its citizens entering into force in 2017.
