In my view, this extension is an important step in the effort to combat tax fraud and tax evasion, as it will allow for increased transparency and the enforcement of tax laws in other countries. In addition, I find it extremely useful that this exchange will assess the possibility of tax evasion and avoid unnecessary investigations.  I believe that aligning this agreement with the current global standards of the European Union and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development will contribute to a more effective fight against cross-border tax fraud, and therefore I voted to extend this agreement.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the agreement between the EU and Liechtenstein on the automatic exchange of financial account information. I think it is important that the countries with which the EU cooperates economically and financially gradually adopt the same standards in these areas. Mainly because many companies as well as individuals declare their profits in so-called tax havens because of favourable tax conditions.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this report on the transposition of the Savings Interest Directive into a bilateral agreement with Liechtenstein. While the Agreement is a step forward in the fight against tax evasion and evasion, it is clearly insufficient in terms of transparency and legal obligations. It establishes excessive discretion in disclosing information, and makes the exchange of information conditional on the agreement between the competent authorities. In addition, the European Parliament has only been consulted after ratification of the Agreement.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The end of bank secrecy through the automatic exchange of information at EU level, enacted in March 2014, had to overcome the reluctance of Austria and Luxembourg. One of the conditions for the abandonment of banking secrecy by these countries was the acceptance by Switzerland and Liechtenstein of similar measures, so as not to create unfair competition. The Memorandum of Understanding provides that the European Union and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their respective residents from 2017.  Liechtenstein will apply measures equivalent to those provided in the European texts (Directive 2003/48 review). It will thus respect the automatic exchange of financial account information, as set out in OECD global standards in 2014. In addition, the agreement provides for certain provisions to limit the ability of taxpayers to evade their reporting obligations to tax authorities by transferring their assets or investing in financial products outside the scope of the agreement.   Tax transparency and an end to bank secrecy is a goal supported by all, in particular in order to preserve the tax revenues of states. So I'm voting for this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 28 October 2015, the European Union and Liechtenstein signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The agreement represents an important step in efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion and updates the 2004 agreement to ensure that Liechtenstein applies measures equivalent to the EU Directive on the taxation of savings interest income. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report. The signature of this agreement between the European Union and Liechtenstein is a step towards more cooperation on exchange of information between the EU and Liechtenstein on financial accounts of residents, but we also call upon both parties to increase cooperation in order to fight corporate tax evasion and avoidance, which remains a major concern.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I support this agreement between the EU and Liechtenstein, which ensures the automatic exchange of information on the bank accounts of each other’s residents, starting in 2018. The information to be exchanged includes not only income, such as interest and dividends, but also account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. I believe this is necessary to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion by ensuring that Liechtenstein applies stricter measures, equivalent to those in place within the EU since March 2014.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. On 17 June 2011, the European Commission approved a recommendation for the Council to open negotiations with Liechtenstein with the aim of updating European agreements in line with Council Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. Following the conclusion of an agreement within the Council's negotiating mandate, the European Parliament proceeds to approve the text in accordance with the simplified procedure. Taking into account the nature of that agreement, I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of it.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I have serious reservations about the fact that the agreement between the EU and Liechtenstein on the automatic exchange of information on the taxation of savings income is a credible and sufficient response to the problem of the flight of the capital of large evaders. Although I recognise that a step has indeed been taken in the fight against evasion, I believe that there are still many critical issues, linked to the narrow scope – since the agreement concerns only the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments by their residents – and above all the presence of regulatory gaps, legal loopholes and excessive discretion with regard to disclosure obligations , which evidently keep various channels open to cheer the legislation and give the green light to Chinese boxes and relocations to other tax havens. I must also point out that, over and above the considerations of substance, Parliament has once again been relegated to a completely symbolic and marginal role, since the agreement which was the subject of Parliament's opinion had in any case already been ratified more than a month earlier. For these reasons, I abstained on the report approving the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite containing positive measures to control transactions with Liechtenstein, we consider the total ban on tax havens necessary. It is already problematic that it is only now that the EU develops such tax partnership agreements with Liechtenstein, especially at the specific point of savings yields, from which the Union's main fortunes benefit. We consider fiscal cooperation between two economically interconnected countries absolutely essential. However, in the case of tax havens, such as Liechtenstein, tougher measures are required that directly prohibit the fortunes of EU nationals from using their advantageous tax systems. Since this report has no reference to this prohibition, I have not been able to vote in favour of it.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and Liechtenstein on the automatic exchange of financial account data. This agreement is an important step in the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion. From 2017, the European Union and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange data on the bank accounts of each other's inhabitants.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement could represent important progress in the efforts being made to combat tax fraud and tax evasion and updates the 2004 agreement which ensured that the Principality of Liechtenstein would apply measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. In this way, the EU and the Principality of Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of residents of the other Party from 2017. The aim is to prevent situations where a taxpayer tries to hide capital corresponding to income or assets for which no tax has been paid. Unfortunately, history shows that it is not because of a lack of agreements or regulations that tax evasion and evasion continue to exist. It is important to monitor compliance with this agreement, avoiding the use of the usual trapdoors of these agreements which often serve only to elude public opinion.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This agreement represents an important step in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I expressed my positive opinion on the agreement between the European Union and Liechtenstein because this text is in line with the demands of the Group of the Party of European Socialists and Democrats for greater transparency on tax issues in the EU and in relations with third countries. Thanks to this agreement, information relating to residents' bank accounts will be automatically exchanged to resolve capital situations hidden from the competent authorities.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of EU, of the Amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Lichtenstein providing for measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments.  The report is designed to improve international tax cooperation and compliance. It represents a very important step in the ongoing efforts to eliminate tax frauds and tax evasion. According to that report, the EU and Lichtenstein will be able to automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of each other’s residents. This is going to lead to addressing those situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid.  Due to the above, I believe that this is a very useful tool in combating the tax frauds, therefore I fully support the report.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the Agreement between the EU and Liechtenstein on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. This agreement is an important step in the current efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion and updates the 2004 agreement ensuring that Liechtenstein applies measures equivalent to those of the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. This agreement will enter into force on 1 January 2016.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU-Lichtenstein agreement on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments, under which from 2017 onwards the EU and Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on each of the financial accounts of the other's tax residents. The aim is to deal with situations in which the taxpayer seeks to hide funds representing income or assets for which no taxes have been paid.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion of the Protocol on the establishment of measures equivalent to those provided for in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments is more than welcome. Improving tax cooperation and compliance with tax obligations is essential. They are the cornerstone of the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion. This Agreement only equates the measures applicable in the EU and Liechtenstein in this area. Thanks to this agreement, from 2017 Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information about its residents' financial accounts with the EU. It's the best way to avoid taxpayers trying to evade taxes.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 28 October 2015, the European Union and Liechtenstein signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, aimed at improving cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. From 2016, the EU and Liechtenstein will then automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents, in order to increase efforts to combat fraud, avoidance and tax evasion, which see Liechtenstein as one of the most sensitive countries in these respects. The agreement certainly contains improvements compared with the current situation, but it is also true that a more complete and in-depth agreement could and should have been seeking, as this still leaves a number of regulatory gaps that can be easily circumvented. This is the second of a package of 5 agreements, which concern Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Andorra and Monaco: although they make improvements, they are all far from solving in practice a good number of problems that will remain present with all these countries. It is for these regions that I abstained.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Agreement could represent significant progress in the efforts being made to combat tax fraud and tax evasion and updates the 2004 agreement which ensured that the Principality of Liechtenstein would apply measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. In this way, the EU and the Principality of Liechtenstein will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of residents of the other Party from 2017. The aim is to prevent situations where a taxpayer tries to hide capital corresponding to income or assets for which no tax has been paid. It is important to monitor compliance with this agreement, avoiding the use of the usual trapdoors of these agreements which often serve only to elude public opinion. We abstained.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Liechtenstein on measures, equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments (COM(2015)0395 – C8-0320/2015 – 2015/0175(NLE)) as I believe it will further strengthen efforts and cooperation between the EU and Liechtenstein to combat tax fraud and tax evasion.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say on this report that I supported it, because I consider the conclusions set out here to be correct. However, I wanted to comment on one specific vote concerning the special protection of the rights of minors and the rights of LGBT people. I want to say that I did not support this not because I do not want to support minor children or LGBT minority people, but I consider it very exploitable to claim that I am an LGBT minority migrant and therefore do not have to be returned to my country of origin. The motion for a resolution contained no flaps, no restraint mechanisms to prevent a clear abuse of the fact that a migrant declares himself an LGBT person and then hopes to favour this provision. I had a slight embarrassment at this particular vote, but otherwise I supported the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the setting up of a complaints mechanism as we feel such a mechanism would be ineffective, open to malicious false claims and potentially demotivate border staff. Furthermore, we feel that a far better way to protect borders is to have sovereign states decide their own immigration policies, rather than to set up complaint mechanisms in an already broken and unworkable system.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Agency for the Security of the Union's External Borders (Frontex) since 2004 has been committed to fostering cooperation between Member States in the management of these areas, so that the work carried out by the competent authorities is in harmony with respect for the fundamental rights enshrined in the EU. The report is aimed at ensuring full and conscious information on the process of revising the Agency's regulation. I voted in favour of the European Ombudsman's special report because I believe it is essential to take action to ensure an increase in the levels of protection provided to migrants.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the measures recommended therein will help improve transparency in Frontex's activities and provide greater protection in terms of respect for fundamental rights. In addition, the report deals in particular with the most vulnerable groups and contains specific provisions for pregnant women and unaccompanied minors as well as in relation to the LGBT collective.  Other positive aspects of the report include the establishment of a patterned and clear mechanism for complaints to ensure that possible human rights violations in the context of Frontex operations are not unpunished and detailed in the Agency's annual report. Anonymous complaints by third parties in good faith are also offered for cases where victims may be under pressure or persecution.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I did not vote in favour of this report because I believe that Frontex's own activity, its militarisation and border defence work, inherently entails the permanent violation of fundamental rights. That is why, from my political group, we have tabled amendments to the report calling for the dismantling of Frontex, understanding that it would be the only effective way to end systematic human rights violations at EU borders and thus making clear the frontal rejection of the United Left to Frontex.  In addition, the approved mechanism, which seeks to give the possibility of bringing complaints for violations of fundamental rights in the context of the operations of this European agency, suffers from a serious shortcoming, for which we also tabled amendments which were equally rejected: its lack of independence, since the Agency itself is responsible for the management of complaints committed by its agents.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Whilst GUE/NGL amendments were adopted at committee level the proposals presented did go far enough to ensure an adequate standard of accountability for Frontex operations. The proposed complaints mechanism does not go far enough.  I abstained on this report as currently there is no complaint procedure and the report in no way extends or enhances the remit or powers of Frontex.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The Civil Liberties Committee and the Committee on Petitions voted on a resolution on Frontex that gives immigrants more opportunities to file complaints against border guards. This vote took place on November 23, 10 days after the Paris attacks... It is also staggering to vote on a text that gives legal rights to individuals whose presence in one of the Member States is illegal! Worse, this resolution gives the heavily subsidized NGOs the opportunity to file complaints on behalf of illegal immigrants. But that's not all! The text provides for an extensive information campaign to encourage immigrants to make use of their new "rights". Unlike other French MEPs who are showing their firmness on border control, National Front MEPs in the European Parliament voted against this aberrant text.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to evaluate the Special Report on frontex's own-initiative inquiry by the European Ombudsman. Frontex is making efforts to strengthen respect for fundamental rights by taking measures such as the establishment of a contingency reporting system, the development of codes of conduct, the establishment of a consultative forum on fundamental rights and the establishment of a Fundamental Rights Office. I agree that, in view of the ever-increasing humanitarian and legal challenges at the EU's external borders and the strengthening of Frontex operations, a mechanism is needed to deal with individual complaints about fundamental rights suspected of being violated in frontex operations.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 1 December 2009, with the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights made Frontex a legally binding force, supporting, coordinating and developing the management of the EU's external borders as a specialised EU agency. In the light of this new legal framework and in view of the interest shown by civil society in the management of the Union's external borders, including its fundamental rights acre, the Ombudsman considered that it would be useful to clarify how Frontex implements the abovementioned provisions through an own-initiative investigation. In the current immigration crisis, the adoption of the Ombudsman's proposals would further weaken Europe's border protection capabilities. One can agree with the statement contained in the alternative proposal of the ENF: "At the moment, Member States have more important things to do, such as ensuring the safety and freedom of their own citizens." The complaint mechanism proposed would have the opposite effect as desired in preventing illegal immigrants from entering the Schengen area and would prevent illegal immigrants from returning to their country of origin. On the basis of these arguments, I did not reject the report by my vote.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This report, which I have endorsed, acknowledges Frontex's ongoing efforts to ensure respect for fundamental rights, including the establishment of an incident reporting system, the design of codes of conduct, the creation of an advisory forum on fundamental rights and the appointment of a human rights officer. It also supports the European Ombudsman's recommendation that Frontex should deal with individual complaints of human rights violations during the course of its operations and should provide sufficient administrative support for this purpose. It therefore calls on Frontex to set up an appropriate complaints mechanism, including within the framework of its working agreements with the relevant authorities in third countries.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote on the European Ombudsman's Special Report on his own-initiative investigation into Frontex as, on the one hand, we are against frontex's role and we believe that this Agency should be rethinked and eventually dismantled. On the other hand, we did not vote against the report because it does not include any aspect which could strengthen Frontex's operations, but it does reflect the Conclusions of the European Ombudsman as regards the Agency's human rights obligations, including aspects which we consider fundamental, if not sufficient. Aspects of the report include individual complaint and reporting mechanisms for cases of human rights violations, fundamental rights, as they were not accepted to date. At the same time, measures are called for to improve guarantees and safeguards for human rights in the Agency's operations and the obligation of gender training is recommended before joining a Frontex operation, in particular to raise awareness of gender-based violence and the vulnerability of migrant women.

name: Joëlle Bergeron (EFDD)
text: In writing. This is yet another report that is full of good intentions but which risks having perverse effects if it were to be applied too rigorously. That is why I voted against this report. Of course, we must ensure that the fundamental rights of the Union are respected. No one will say otherwise. But I am convinced that we can have full confidence in the leaders of Frontex that these rights are effectively respected. Until now, there has been no slippage and the suspicion that this report poses to people who are doing everything possible to protect our external borders, often under very difficult conditions, has no reason to be.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteurs of this report, which I supported. I welcome the European Ombudsman's Special Report in the context of the own-initiative investigation into Frontex. It is a very important report, expressing concern about the legal vacuum surrounding the deployment of third-country agents during joint return operations, as well as the impunity that could exist in the event of human rights violations involving third-country actors.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Not content with opening Europe's doors wide to massive flows of refugees at the expense of the European peoples, the EPP rapporteurs - that is, the Republicans in the European Parliament - and the Greens of this text want to facilitate the procedures of migrants' complaints against Frontex, the European border management agency. We are therefore walking on our heads with this possibility offered to people present illegally on our territory to attack the border guards - with the help of heavily subsidised NGOs - and this, with the total complicity, even encouragement, of the Socialist and "Republican" MEPs who seek to make almost zero the number of expulsions already at the lowest. In France, the Socialist Prime Minister has offered public opinion tough stances on security and immigration, while the Republicans, for their part, are pretending to be alarmed against mass immigration, a real danger to the well-being of The peoples of Europe. In short, once again, it is in Brussels that the masks fall and only patriotic Members have had the audacity and constancy of their convictions in opposing this scandalous resolution.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal to vote is only a further bureaucratic burden for Frontex, which would further slow down its already deficient operation. Furthermore, the report is heavily unbalanced towards supporting a myopic political line, which does not want to openly address the real emergency from mass immigration and which persists in talking about rights but not about the binding obligations that migrants should respect but which they systematically break. For these reasons, I did not intend to support the text with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have abstained from the vote.  The fact that Frontex has so far not had a mechanism for individual complaints so far is remarkable, especially in view of the regular reports of human rights violations from both Amnesty and the UN refugee agency. Such a mechanism must be independent of Frontex and that the plaintiff has the right to remain anonymous and may be represented by a third party, such as the IOM, Amnesty or the UN refugee agency. Results are very questionable. An internal mechanism within Frontex is not enough. However, we found that the plaintiff could be represented by a third party. It is a small step in the right direction, but is not enough to be a system to be called legal certainty.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the measures recommended therein will help improve transparency in Frontex's activities and provide greater protection in terms of respect for fundamental rights. In addition, the report deals in particular with the most vulnerable groups and contains specific provisions for pregnant women and unaccompanied minors as well as in relation to the LGBT collective.  Other positive aspects of the report include the establishment of a patterned and clear mechanism for complaints to ensure that possible human rights violations in the context of Frontex operations are not unpunished and detailed in the Agency's annual report. Anonymous complaints by third parties in good faith are also offered for cases where victims may be under pressure or persecution.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament welcomes the Special Report of the European Ombudsman's own-initiative inquiry on Frontex. Parliament acknowledges frontex's current efforts to strengthen respect for fundamental rights through measures such as the establishment of a reporting system for unforeseen events, the development of codes of conduct, the establishment of a consultative forum on fundamental rights and the establishment of a Fundamental Rights Office. On the other hand, however, the European Parliament is deeply concerned about the legal vacuum in relation to third-country deployed officers in return operations, as stated in the European Ombudsman's report, as well as the lack of accountability that would be faced in the event of human rights violations by officials deployed by third countries. Parliament therefore considers that the introduction of a mechanism for dealing with individual complaints would enable individuals to exercise their right to an effective remedy in the event of a breach of their fundamental rights. In addition, such a complaint mechanism would ensure greater transparency and greater respect for human rights, including in the scope of Frontex's labour agreements, as frontex and the EU institutions would be better informed of possible violations of fundamental rights that might otherwise remain unnoticed, would not be reported and problems would not be resolved.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the European Ombudsman's special report on the own-initiative inquiry concerning Frontex, as it recommends, first and foremost, the establishment of a mechanism for individual complaints. This would give individuals the opportunity to exercise their right to an effective remedy in the event of a breach of their fundamental rights, which has so far proved to be a legal vacuum within the regime. There are also some other improvements in the regulation. Frontex is getting more and more tasks in today's migrant crisis, so it is positive that all the ambiguities regarding its functioning are also treated.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution adopted today comes on the eve of the revision of the Frontex Regulation and fully endorses the Ombudsman's recommendation made following the 2012 inquiry into compliance with the agency's human rights obligations. At a time when the refugee crisis is an increasingly pressing issue in need of solutions at European level, Frontex's role must be strengthened and its activities made more transparent, in full guarantee of fundamental human rights. In this regard, I welcome the report's proposal to establish a mechanism for handling individual complaints within Frontex. This mechanism, by providing for a central role for the fundamental rights officer within the agency in the preliminary assessment of complaints and their referral to the competent authorities, would allow individuals to exercise the right to effective redress in the event of a violation of their rights, while increasing their credibility in Frontex's action.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Following the adoption on 23 November of a resolution making it easier for migrants to file complaints against border guards, Roberta Metsola of the EPP and Ska Keller of the Greens are submitting a new resolution in favour of illegal immigrants to the European Parliament. It calls on Frontex to facilitate the filing of complaints in favour of illegal migrants, who are present illegally in the European Union, in the event of a violation of their rights. It also provides that third parties such as NGOs or other communitarian associations, which are heavily subsidized at taxpayers' expense, can file complaints on behalf of illegal migrants. Finally, the report recommends a communication campaign around the procedures they can initiate in the event of a violation of their fundamental rights.  The sole objective of this proposal is to significantly reduce the number of deportations in order to meet the labour needs of multinationals—cheap labour estimated by the Commission to be 3 million illegal migrants by 2017. We are absolutely opposed to this outrageous text. So I voted against it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to regulate the procedure for complaints against Frontex border guards by migrants. The mechanism to be set up should analyse complaints about violations of the human rights of migrants and asylum seekers. Meps call on the Commission to include this provision in the amendment of the Frontex Regulation, which will be voted on in the coming months. This report is blatantly unbalanced in favour of the good-natured policy that we are contesting. There is always only talk of the rights of migrants without insisting on the binding obligations that they too should respect. This proposal would be a further bureaucratic burden for Frontex and would further slow down the agency's work. I am voting against.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the measures recommended therein will help improve transparency in Frontex's activities and provide greater protection in terms of respect for fundamental rights. In addition, the report deals in particular with the most vulnerable groups and contains specific provisions for pregnant women and unaccompanied minors as well as in relation to the LGBT collective.  Other positive aspects of the report include the establishment of a patterned and clear mechanism for complaints to ensure that possible human rights violations in the context of Frontex operations are not unpunished and detailed in the Agency's annual report. Anonymous complaints by third parties in good faith are also offered for cases where victims may be under pressure or persecution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Ombudsman's special report on the own-initiative inquiry OI/5/2012/BEH-MHZ on Frontex. Dealing with immigration and, in particular, with issues related to illegal entry, presents the EU with major challenges from both a legal and humanitarian point of view. A balance must therefore be struck between the interest in controlling immigration and the humanitarian requirement to provide a safe place for people entering illegally, pending the completion of the legal process for asylum applications. The report therefore indicated that Frontex should address individual complaints of violations of fundamental rights committed in the course of its operations and provide adequate administrative support for this purpose through the establishment of an appropriate complaints mechanism, including in the framework of working agreements concluded with the competent authorities of third countries. In view of these factors, I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report was concerned with the Frontex complaint mechanism and the aim is to have an internal complaint mechanism within Frontex. However, an internal mechanism instead of an independent body is inadequate. Therefore, while the intention behind the report was positive, it did not contain enough procedural safeguards, so on this basis I abstained on the final vote.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the setting up of a complaints mechanism as we feel such a mechanism would be ineffective, open to malicious false claims and potentially demotivate border staff. Furthermore, we feel that a far better way to protect borders is to have sovereign states decide their own immigration policies, rather than to set up complaint mechanisms in an already broken and unworkable system.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because Frontex needs its own complaints mechanism to prevent any breaches of human rights. This will strengthen the Agency but at the same time will not affect the powers of Member States, in line with the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report concerns the European Ombudsman's inquiry into the Frontex agency (responsible for the security of the Union's external borders) and is intended to inform about the process of revising the Agency's regulation, which the Commission will formally present in mid-December. The text is good and the main innovation concerns the request by the agency for an internal mechanism for dealing with complaints about violations of fundamental rights committed by Frontex officials against migrants. I voted strongly in favour.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament rightly endorsed the European Ombudsman’s call for a stronger complaints mechanism allowing refugees to raise complaints on foot of breaches of fundamental rights. Closer cooperation between Frontex and the Ombudsman would be invaluable to address concerns that fundamental rights violations are not being effectively followed up. Furthermore, there is a great need for special protection of unaccompanied minors, women who are victims of gender-based persecution, LGBTI persons and other vulnerable groups. In order to do so, measures such as gender-based training on gender-based violence and vulnerability of migrant women is necessary. In order for the complaints mechanism to be effective, it is vital that information is available to the complainants and that this information can be distributed in the official EU languages and in languages that the complainants can understand. Lastly, a significant step towards improving Frontex’s transparency, accountability and effectiveness will come from allowing the thorough investigation of individual complaints, the use of funds by Frontex to be made public and details regularly reported to Parliament.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. Our 'yes' to the report should be read as a support for respect for human rights and the principle of an individual right of appeal. Not as an unconditional support for Frontex to set up an individual complaint mechanism. We recognise that some Member States are not good enough to respect human rights when controlling their external borders, and the European Union should take action on this. However, setting up an individual grievance is not necessarily the best or the right solution.  If, at some point, the Commission puts forward a proposal for Frontex to set up such a redress mechanism, we will assess the specific proposal, including the economic, legal and sovereignty implications that such a proposal would have, and then take a position.   Control of the EU's external borders is a national matter, which is why we also believe that such an individual complaint mechanism should operate in the Member States, not as part of Frontex.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The Report recommended that Frontex and the European Ombudsman work closely together to improve the protection of individuals from possible maladministration in the context of Frontex's activities, including where the Agency conducts an operation beyond the EU's external borders through cooperation arrangements. Member States and partner countries that have concluded cooperation arrangements with Frontex are invited to cooperate effectively with the Agency in order to ensure the smooth functioning of the complaints mechanism. Frontex is requested to provide publicly accessible information on the complaint mechanism in its annual general report; It is stressed that this information will help Frontex identify potential shortcomings and improve its working methods. In addition, it is proposed that provisions on the individual complaints mechanism should be included in the forthcoming revision of the Frontex Regulation. With this in view of this, we support the report positively.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Ombudsman's special report on the own-initiative investigation into FRONTEX concerns an issue of particular importance. The prospect of creating an appeal mechanism for rights violations by FRONTEX actions is crucial, especially in this politically and socially turbulent period. If we take into account the fact that FRONTEX's actions have so far not produced the expected results, we realise that the establishment of such a mechanism could only improve the existing structure, enabling asylum seekers and migrants to report possible violations against them. So while this proposal may not resolve all existing issues by setting up a non-independent mechanism for individual appeals, the rationale for improving FRONTEX is positive, which is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. With this report, the European Parliament welcomes the European Ombudsman's special report on the own-initiative inquiry into Frontex, supports the Ombudsman's recommendation that Frontex should address individual complaints of fundamental rights violations committed in the course of its operations; considers that the establishment of a mechanism for individual complaints can give people an opportunity to exercise the right to effective redress in the event of a breach of their fundamental rights and supports the need for a central official structure within Frontex for the handling of individual complaints. In addition, the EP recommends that Frontex and the European Ombudsman establish close cooperation with each other in order to improve the protection of persons from maladministration and calls on the Member States and partner countries to cooperate efficiently with the Agency to ensure the smooth functioning of the complaints mechanism. Finally, it calls on Frontex to provide publicly accessible information on the complaint mechanism in its annual general report.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report, as I believe that a firm point of the European Union is the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms of the Council of Europe. Furthermore, I am convinced that Frontex, like any other EU institution, body or body, must respect the Charter of Fundamental Rights in carrying out its activities, because the members of the responsible teams carrying out control and surveillance tasks at the external borders are obliged to comply with Community legislation and the national legislation of the host Member State. Finally, I fully agree with the rapporteur on the establishment of a mechanism for individual complaints, as I believe that it would give people an opportunity to exercise their right to effective redress in the event of a breach of their fundamental rights.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In 2013, the European Ombudsman (EO) issued a special report following an own-initiative inquiry because Frontex did not implement its recommendation to create an individual complaint mechanism through which it could deal with individual incidents of fundamental rights breaches to have supposedly occurred in the course of its operations. In view of the ever growing humanitarian and legal challenges at the EU’s external borders, the PETI/LIBE Committee draft INI report supports the EO’s recommendation that Frontex should deal with complaints regarding infringements of fundamental rights in the course of its operations and should set up such a mechanism based on Article 26(a) of the Frontex 2011 Regulation.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the setting up of a complaints mechanism as we feel such a mechanism would be ineffective, open to malicious false claims and potentially demotivate border staff. Furthermore, we feel that a far better way to protect borders is to have sovereign states decide their own immigration policies, rather than to set up complaint mechanisms in an already broken and unworkable system.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the setting up of a complaints mechanism as we feel such a mechanism would be ineffective, open to malicious false claims and potentially demotivate border staff. Furthermore, we feel that a far better way to protect borders is to have sovereign states decide their own immigration policies, rather than to set up complaint mechanisms in an already broken and unworkable system.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the establishment of a mechanism for individual complaints in the event of violations of fundamental rights. This opportunity will allow people to exercise individually or through a third party the right to effective redress, especially in the case of violations committed against vulnerable persons, pregnant women or children. Furthermore, as recommended by the European Parliament, Frontex must ensure that everyone has easy access to information on the procedures for introducing a complaint, as well as actively cooperating with the European Ombudsman and each Member State in order to ensure the proper functioning of the mechanism and the protection of individuals in the event of maladministration.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In view of the humanitarian and legal challenges of migration and the situation at the EU’s external borders, Parliament supports the recommendations of the European Ombudsman, so that Frontex deals with complaints regarding infringements of fundamental rights in the course of its operations. These new competences will lead to changes in the Frontex Fundamental Rights Strategy. Although setting up the new fundamental rights protection mechanism and structure comes under the competence of Frontex, necessary legal safeguards needed to be introduced in this report so as to ensure that only relevant complaints on infringements of fundamental rights are submitted to Frontex.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As the S&D shadow rapporteur on this report I am glad that this report is a solid achievement for the S&D Group, as Parliament has adopted the S&D calls for stronger fundamental rights safeguards for all. These include: the establishment of a system where third parties can make complaints on behalf of migrants who prefer to remain anonymous out of fear; a call which obligates Frontex to report on Fundamental Rights complaints in the Frontex annual report; better cooperation with third countries; and strong assurances that such a mechanism will not hinder life-saving operations or return decisions. Our message was clear: Now more than ever is it time that the EU ups its game in the field of security and external borders, but these must go hand in hand with, and be complemented by, human and fundamental rights safeguards.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ A number of the recommendations in this report do not take account of the special nature of Frontex Agency and its relationship with Member States. I am also extremely concerned that making the details available of a number of the complaints of potential breaches of human rights by Frontex during the course of its work could prove counter-productive in minimising the amount of false complaints, and in deterring individuals with genuine cases. I also feel that the calls for additional resources are not realistic or responsible in light of the budgetary constraints in this area. For these reasons I cannot support this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to support the recommendation made by the European Ombudsman that Frontex should set up a mechanism for dealing with individual complaints about human rights violations during the course of its operations. It recommends that persons who feel they have been harmed by border guards wearing frontex badges should have the right to file a complaint. Considering that this report is in line with the objectives of the EPP Group, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With this vote, the European Parliament wished to support the recommendation made by the European Ombudsman that the Frontex agency should set up a mechanism for dealing with allegations of human rights violations during the course of its operations. I support the establishment of such a mechanism. However, it is necessary not to place a disproportionate burden on the Frontex agency, which is responsible for managing operational cooperation at the external borders of the Member States of the European Union.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposed to facilitate the legal action of illegal migrants against the agency supposed to protect Europe's borders: FRONTEX. Thus, migrants will be able to oppose deportation orders that are already rarely issued and even less enforced, citing disrespect for their rights as asylum seekers. While France has already paid the price for the inconsistency of the European Union's unseated immigration policy, it is making the wound even worse. Opposed to uncontrolled immigration and the reckless granting of all kinds of rights to illegal immigrants, because I am committed to the safety of my fellow citizens, I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support the report on the European Ombudsman's special report on an own-initiative inquiry OI/5/2012/BEH-MHZ of Frontex, as I consider Frontex to be an agency that is by its very nature different from other EU agencies and institutions.  The current situation is not the point at which we need to impose an additional administrative burden on the agency.  Hundreds of thousands of migrants enter the EU every day and instead of criticising Frontex, we need to strengthen its capacity so that we can adequately respond to the crisis capable of destroying the EU.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 FRONTEX is a service that, on the basis of its composition and operational capabilities, is unable to cope with migration flows. Here entire Member States are building fences and restoring cross-border controls to contain the waves of migrants. Imagine if, of the 2 million migrants expected, 10,000 make a complaint, true or false. The system will collapse. We will fall into a series of investigations, legal details, language difficulties, rather than dealing with registration and assistance, FRONTEX's main task. Illegal immigrants, in particular, will invent violations to hinder the work of the authorities, to require their entry into the Schengen area and to hinder their repatriation operations.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 FRONTEX is one of our best agencies, its employees have a high degree of integrity. The assistance that FRONTEX provides to Member States in coordinating the flow of migrants at the EU's external borders in the current crisis situation deserves special mention and thanks. I would like to welcome the agency's proactive approach and action on the complaints mechanism. However, it should be clarified that FRONTEX is still not entitled to take action against national law enforcement officers involved in its operations, and these procedures fall solely within the competence of the national authorities. The Agency can only act against its own staff, since FRONTEX has only a coordinating role. In order for this EU agency to function properly and professionally and to fulfil its important mandate, the Commission and the Member States must provide the necessary financial resources to operate.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. This own-initiative report supports the Ombudsman's request to Frontex to establish an individual mechanism for complaints concerning incidents in which fundamental rights are undermined in the course of its operations. In this regard, the concluding observations of the United Nations Committee for monitoring the implementation of the CRPD in the EU made particular mention of the protection of vulnerable groups included in recent refugee movements. It is therefore a question of ensuring that there are sufficient safeguards to prevent the violation of the fundamental rights of the different groups within the framework of Frontex's operations and, consequently, this report proposes to introduce the legal safeguards necessary to ensure those rights as well as the proper functioning of the institution.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Agency responsible for the management of external borders (Frontex) should set up a mechanism capable of dealing with individual complaints of alleged violations of fundamental rights that occurred during its operations or in joint operations with third countries. The EU Regulation on Frontex requires the agency to ensure full respect for the fundamental rights and rights of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers. I also agree with the various recommendations on the structure of the complaints mechanism, the submission and admissibility of complaints, as well as the handling of complaints concerning the conduct of invited agents who are under the authority of a Member State but which have the frontex insignia.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it gives migrants unacceptable rights in the face of the safety of the peoples of Europe.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report follows the Special Report of the European Ombudsman, following the inquiry into the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (Frontex). In view of what has become a clamorous failure, it is intended to create a system of incident reporting and the development of codes of conduct, as well as the establishment of an Advisory Forum on fundamental rights and an agent for fundamental rights. It also establishes a mechanism for filing complaints (which did not exist) concerning the disregard for fundamental rights, including the rights of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers. There is, first of all, a first point of note that it is the unequivocal recognition of the disrespect of human rights by frontex's action. This agency has increasingly become a supranational police force that is acting against the territorial sovereignty of the Member States and acts as a repressive force against defenceless citizens, in the case of particular refugees and asylum seekers from North Africa and the Middle East, who arrive in Europe every day and suffer their repulsive action of xenophobic contours. The complaints follow. This now proposed mechanism does not respond, nowhere near or far, to what would be necessary.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained as the report is incomplete.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 FRONTEX is a service which, judging by its composition and operational capabilities, is unable to cope with migration flows. Here entire Member States are building fences and restoring cross-border controls to contain the waves of migrants. Imagine if, of the 2 million migrants expected, 10,000 make a complaint, true or false. The system will collapse. We will fall into a range of investigations, legal details, language difficulties, rather than dealing with the registration and assistance that constitutes FRONTEX's main mission. Illegal immigrants, in particular, will be suspected of violations in order to hinder the work of the authorities, to require their entry into the Schengen area and to hinder their repatriation operations. For all the above reasons, I am voting against the European Ombudsman's special report following an own-initiative investigation into Frontex.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe that it should be made easier for migrants to complain when it comes to alleged breaches of fundamental rights. Frontex should deal with complaints regarding infringements of fundamental rights in the course of its operations, should provide adequate administrative support for that purpose, and should set up an independent complaints mechanism. The mentioned mechanism must involve the fundamental rights officer. There is a clear need of such a mechanism in light of the growing migratory flows and expanding capacity of Frontex, in particular with regard to the agency’s participation in Migration Management Support Teams working in ‘hotspot’ areas. I therefore support the setting up an independent complaints mechanism within Frontex on alleged breaches of fundamental rights, call for more involvement of the Fundamental Rights Agency and EASO, and call for the speeding up the process of complaints to the benefit of the complainant. Follow-up measures by Member States must also be made public.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 FRONTEX is one of our best agencies, its employees have a high degree of integrity. The assistance that FRONTEX provides to Member States in coordinating the flow of migrants at the EU's external borders in the current crisis situation deserves special mention and thanks. I would like to welcome the agency's proactive approach and action on the complaints mechanism. However, it should be clarified that FRONTEX is still not entitled to take action against national law enforcement officers involved in its operations, and these procedures fall solely within the competence of the national authorities. The Agency can only act against its own staff, since FRONTEX has only a coordinating role. In order for this EU agency to function properly and professionally and to fulfil its important mandate, the Commission and the Member States must provide the necessary financial resources to operate.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Under Regulation (EU) No 1168/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2011 amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004 setting up a European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the external borders of the Member States of the European Union, the Agency must ensure full respect for fundamental rights and the rights of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers. Furthermore, the European Union wishes to join the Council of Europe Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms. In line with the rapporteur, I welcome the special report issued by the European Ombudsman in the context of his own-initiative inquiry into Frontex. While acknowledging Frontex's current efforts to strengthen respect for fundamental rights, which include, inter alia, the establishment of a notification system, the development of codes of conduct, the establishment of the Advisory Forum on Fundamental Rights and the Office of the Fundamental Rights Officer, I support the European Ombudsman's recommendation that Frontex act on individual complaints of fundamental rights violations in its operations and provide adequate administrative support for this purpose.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Ombudsman's report as Frontex is working to take into account twelve of the European Ombudsman's thirteen recommendations. We must always ensure that the EU, and the agencies that depend on it, respect human rights and fundamental freedoms, but always taking into account that Frontex does not have unlimited resources. Similarly, we must continue to work to end the legal loopholes faced by Frontex.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the measures recommended therein will help improve transparency in Frontex's activities and provide greater protection in terms of respect for fundamental rights. In addition, the report deals in particular with the most vulnerable groups and contains specific provisions for pregnant women and unaccompanied minors as well as in relation to the LGBT collective.  Other positive aspects of the report include the establishment of a patterned and clear mechanism for complaints to ensure that possible human rights violations in the context of Frontex operations are not unpunished and detailed in the Agency's annual report. Anonymous complaints by third parties in good faith are also offered for cases where victims may be under pressure or persecution.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the measures recommended therein will help improve transparency in Frontex's activities and provide greater protection in terms of respect for fundamental rights. In addition, the report deals in particular with the most vulnerable groups and contains specific provisions for pregnant women and unaccompanied minors as well as in relation to the LGBT collective.  Other positive aspects of the report include the establishment of a patterned and clear mechanism for complaints to ensure that possible human rights violations in the context of Frontex operations are not unpunished and detailed in the Agency's annual report. Anonymous complaints by third parties in good faith are also offered for cases where victims may be under pressure or persecution.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the European Ombudsman's special report on the own-initiative inquiry into Frontex, because I believe it is right and proper that migrants should be treated humanely and with dignity and should have a mechanism to protect and denounce violations of fundamental rights. The increasing flow of migrants and the enhanced presence of the Frontex agency to protect the EU's borders raise serious concerns about respect for human rights.  I therefore believe that the European Parliament must make its voice heard in the face of the scenes we have witnessed, and continue to witness, in some Member States. I therefore welcome the initiative launched by the European Ombudsman and the idea that the agency itself must be able to deal with individual complaints of infringement of rights, whether committed by Frontex staff or seconded staff in the Member States. Finally, I agree with the European Parliament's request to set up an internal complaints mechanism in Frontex, which can be activated by the victim in the event of a breach of rights, which involves the frontex responsible for fundamental rights and which is transparent, accessible, translated into languages understandable by migrants and which guarantees the protection of the complainant.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today against the report by Mr Keller and Mr Metsola on the European Ombudsman's special report on the own-initiative inquiry OI/5/2012/BEH-MHZ on Frontex for two reasons: firstly, I think it is purely parliamentary self-staging if we devote time to including non-legislative reports on the agenda. On the other hand, we in Europe currently have other challenges to overcome than the establishment of a complicated complaints system for refugees at the external borders. It is important to help people – not to create new bureaucracy.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In 2012, the European Ombudsman opened an inquiry into frontex's implementation of its fundamental rights obligations. The draft recommendations provide for m.in mechanism for the submission and handling of individual complaints. As of today, it can be assessed that Frontex has largely complied with the Ombudsman's recommendations. Its actions have resulted in mechanisms to ensure respect for fundamental rights, such as the introduction of an event reporting system, the development of codes of conduct, the establishment of a fundamental rights consultative forum and the establishment of a fundamental rights office. Frontex has also introduced a detailed procedure for dealing with internal reports of serious violations of fundamental rights by its staff and invited officers. Furthermore, in view of the growing humanitarian and legal challenges, Frontex needs a mechanism to deal with individual complaints of allegations of violations of fundamental rights. Such a mechanism should be both effective and cost-effective. Frontex and the Member States share responsibility for the actions of the officers involved in Frontex's activities and are therefore invited to cooperate with each other in order to ensure the effective functioning of the complaints mechanism.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Frontex is an important element in the protection of Europe's external borders. By establishing a mechanism for individual complaints, we can further optimise Frontex's work. However, this is only possible with additional funding. After all, the real work, the protection of borders, is a top priority.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given that the EU has a moral and legal imperative to ensure that its border agency carries out its tasks in full respect of human rights. That is why it is important that a complaints mechanism is set up to provide individuals with an opportunity to exercise their right to an effective remedy in case of violation of their fundamental rights in the context of actions carried out by Frontex.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Frontex has faced many challenges in the last year. The worsening migration crisis has weighed heavily on the agency and has often questioned its different aspects, from role to budget. I voted in favour of this report, which perhaps deals with the most important aspect. The more tasks and challenges the agency faces, the greater its responsibility. Frontex acts in contexts of exceptional delicacy, where situations of danger and emergency collide with the fragility of the people who are saved and at the same time the need to proceed with effective controls. The Ombudsman is putting to us the need to make Frontex a complete agency, which is responsible for the work of its agents, and thus to create a mechanism that guarantees transparency and, above all, the right to complain to those who see their rights not respected. I believe that it is precisely in this direction that Frontex must grow, while ensuring that this does not hinder or slow down the agency's other activities.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this scandalous report which provides that Frontex, the European border management agency, facilitates complaints from migrants about possible violations of their rights, even though they themselves are present in our territory illegally.  The procedure implemented opens up the possibility for third parties, such as heavily subsidised NGOs, to file complaints on behalf of migrants. In addition, information campaigns will be organised with migrants to ensure that they will use this recourse and the various documents relating to the procedure will be available in their languages. All this, of course, tends towards one goal: to further reduce the number of evictions, which are already almost zero. A few days after the Paris attacks, this report shows that the speeches made by the Socialists and the Republicans, who have recently shown their firmness on immigration and security, are nothing but a shad.  National Front MPs and their allies, true to their commitments, voted against the text and tabled an alternative resolution to effectively oppose mass immigration. This proposal was rejected by French and European immigrationist MEPs... The masks have fallen off!

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote on the European Ombudsman's Special Report on his own-initiative investigation into Frontex as, on the one hand, we are against frontex's role and we believe that this Agency should be rethinked and eventually dismantled. On the other hand, we did not vote against the report because it does not include any aspect which could strengthen Frontex's operations, but it does reflect the Conclusions of the European Ombudsman as regards the Agency's human rights obligations, including aspects which we consider fundamental, if not sufficient. Aspects of the report include individual complaint and reporting mechanisms for cases of human rights violations, fundamental rights, as they were not accepted to date. At the same time, measures are called for to improve guarantees and safeguards for human rights in the Agency's operations and the obligation of gender training is recommended before joining a Frontex operation, in particular to raise awareness of gender-based violence and the vulnerability of migrant women.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the measures recommended therein will help improve transparency in Frontex's activities and provide greater protection in terms of respect for fundamental rights. In addition, the report deals in particular with the most vulnerable groups and contains specific provisions for pregnant women and unaccompanied minors as well as in relation to the LGBT collective.  Other positive aspects of the report include the establishment of a patterned and clear mechanism for complaints to ensure that possible human rights violations in the context of Frontex operations are not unpunished and detailed in the Agency's annual report. Anonymous complaints by third parties in good faith are also offered for cases where victims may be under pressure or persecution.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote on the special report of the European Ombudsman in the own-initiative inquiry concerning Frontex was decided by the fact that, in view of the ever-growing humanitarian and legal challenges at the EU’s external borders and the strengthening of Frontex operations, there is a need for a mechanism that is capable of processing individual complaints about alleged breaches of fundamental rights occurring in the course of Frontex operations or cooperation with third countries, thus becoming a first-instance body for complaints.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the measures recommended therein will help improve transparency in Frontex's activities and provide greater protection in terms of respect for fundamental rights. In addition, the report deals in particular with the most vulnerable groups and contains specific provisions for pregnant women and unaccompanied minors as well as in relation to the LGBT collective.  Other positive aspects of the report include the establishment of a patterned and clear mechanism for complaints to ensure that possible human rights violations in the context of Frontex operations are not unpunished and detailed in the Agency's annual report. Anonymous complaints by third parties in good faith are also offered for cases where victims may be under pressure or persecution.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the current crisis situation, the border protection assistance that FRONTEX provides to Member States at the EU's external borders in coordinating the flow of migrants deserves special mention and thanks. I welcome the agency's proactive approach and actions with regard to the complaints mechanism. At the same time, it should be clarified that FRONTEX is still not entitled to take action against national law enforcement officers, and that operational procedures are solely a matter of national competence. The Agency may only act against its own staff, since FRONTEX is only entitled to a coordinating role. In order to ensure that this Union agency can continue to operate in an appropriate and professional manner and fulfil its important mandate, the Commission and the Member States should provide the necessary financial resources to operate.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report due to the fact that an individual complaints mechanism should be both efficient and transparent. Additionally, the fundamental rights office must be adequately equipped and staffed to handle the complaints received and must have the necessary additional resources for this purpose. Ensuring the efficient implementation of the common rules on standards and procedures for the control and surveillance of the external borders with respect to fundamental rights, by means of closer coordination of operational cooperation between Member States, is fundamental in the current migration climate.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the setting up of a complaints mechanism as we feel such a mechanism would be ineffective, open to malicious false claims and potentially demotivate border staff. Furthermore, we feel that a far better way to protect borders is to have sovereign states decide their own immigration policies, rather than to set up complaint mechanisms in an already broken and unworkable system.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the Report by Metsola & Keller on the European Ombudsman's proposal on Frontex. This report deals with the requirements for a complaint procedure following possible assaults by Frontex employees. The proposed procedure has been largely adopted from the procedural directives of other EU institutions, such as the ECB, which have very different and hardly transferable requirements to Frontex. In the past, it has been shown that a large proportion of complaints against Frontex were insubstantial and that most of the accusations of alleged human rights violations were baseless. A particularly critical attitude towards Frontex, as in some of the amendments to this report, is therefore not appropriate. As Frontex is to be expanded and is expected to receive a wider mandate, the complaints procedure should also be included in the negotiations on the new mandate and adapted to the very specific needs of Frontex. This is the only way to ensure that Frontex has an appropriate complaints procedure that works permanently and does not restrict Frontex's important activities. Incidentally, I believe that the euro is causing strife and discord in Europe and must therefore be abolished!

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 FRONTEX is one of our best agencies and its employees have a high level of expertise. The assistance that FRONTEX provides to Member States in coordinating the flow of migrants at the EU's external borders in the current crisis situation deserves special mention and thanks. I would like to welcome the agency's proactive approach and action on the complaints mechanism. At the same time, it should be clarified that FRONTEX is still not entitled to take action against national law enforcement officers involved in its operations. These procedures shall be subject to national competence only. The Agency can only act against its own staff, since FRONTEX has only a coordinating role. In order for this EU agency to function properly and professionally and to fulfil its important mandate, the Commission and the Member States must provide the necessary financial resources to operate.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the setting up of a complaints mechanism as we feel such a mechanism would be ineffective, open to malicious false claims and potentially demotivate border staff. Furthermore, we feel that a far better way to protect borders is to have sovereign states decide their own immigration policies, rather than to set up complaint mechanisms in an already broken and unworkable system.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. Parliament supported the European Ombudsman's approach to ensuring the possibility of making individual and non-anonymous complaints to the head of the FRONTEX agency's fundamental rights officer when there is an allegation of human rights violations during an operation. The difficulty today is that FRONTEX is made up of agents attached to their Member State. Until now, it has been impossible for an abuser to file a complaint against a border guard acting on behalf of FRONTEX and for the agency to take disciplinary action against the officer concerned.  From now on, it will be possible for Frontex to register complaints provided they are filed in person and not by a third party and to pass them on to the authorities of the Member States on which the investigating officer depends.  It is really a question of restoring legality where it did not yet exist. I would like to see this mechanism as closely as possible to avoid the system being hijacked by ill-intentioned persons whose objective would be to disrupt the missions of the FRONTEX agents, whose dedication and work I do under extremely difficult conditions.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It is important to mention that this report supports the recommendation by the European Ombudsman that Frontex should deal with complaints regarding infringements of fundamental rights in the course of its operations. Moreover, Frontex should provide adequate administrative support for that purpose and should set up an independent complaints mechanism.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Ombudsman's Special Report on The Investigation on my own initiative, OI/5/2012/BEH-MHZ relating to Frontex, as I believe that this agency should establish a mechanism for lodging individual complaints about fundamental human rights violations during its operations and provide adequate administrative support, not only within the EU but also in cooperation with third countries. We are witnessing a growing humanitarian crisis and legal challenges at the EU's external borders on a daily basis, so this mechanism would become the primary complaint handling body that would certainly contribute to greater transparency and awareness of fundamental human rights violations.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks that plunged Paris into a bloodbath, the Civil Liberties and Petitions Committees, meeting as part of an expedited procedure, passed a resolution on Frontex to facilitate migrant complaints against border guards. This resolution provides that Frontex facilitates complaints from migrants about possible violations of their rights, even though they themselves are present in our territory illegally. The procedure also provides that third parties, such as heavily subsidised NGOs, can file complaints on behalf of migrants.  The European MPs (notably Socialists and Republicans) are also planning an information campaign with migrants to make sure that they will use this recourse... All this, of course, tends towards one goal: to further reduce the number of evictions, which are already almost zero. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I and my fellow UKIP colleagues voted against the setting up of a complaints mechanism as we feel such a mechanism would be ineffective, open to malicious false claims and potentially demotivate border staff. Furthermore, we feel that a far better way to protect borders is to have sovereign states decide their own immigration policies, rather than to set up complaint mechanisms in an already broken and unworkable system.
