name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues Roberta Metsola and Ska Keller on the European Ombudsman's report on Frontex. The text supports the establishment of a mechanism for handling complaints made by individuals for human rights violations during Frontex's operations. The report was voted on by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I do not agree with the report. It leads to a massive increase in the burden on Frontex. Many aspects of the report also lead to a bureaucracy, which hinders Frontex in the fulfilment of its actual competences and tasks, as well as in the pursuit of its essential tasks.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the Report by Metsola & Keller on the European Ombudsman's proposal on Frontex. This report deals with the requirements for a complaint procedure following possible assaults by Frontex employees. The proposed procedure has been largely adopted from the procedural directives of other EU institutions, such as the ECB, which have very different and hardly transferable requirements to Frontex. In the past, it has been shown that a large proportion of complaints against Frontex were insubstantial and that most of the accusations of alleged human rights violations were baseless. A particularly critical attitude towards Frontex, as in some of the amendments to this report, is therefore not appropriate. As Frontex is to be expanded and is expected to receive a wider mandate, the complaints procedure should also be included in the negotiations on the new mandate and adapted to the very specific needs of Frontex. This is the only way to ensure that Frontex receives an appropriate complaint procedure which works permanently and does not restrict Frontex's important activities.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 FRONTEX is one of our best agencies, its employees have a high degree of integrity. The assistance that FRONTEX provides to Member States in coordinating the flow of migrants at the EU's external borders in the current crisis situation deserves special mention and thanks. I would like to welcome the agency's proactive approach and action on the complaints mechanism. However, it should be clarified that FRONTEX is still not entitled to take action against national law enforcement officers involved in its operations, and these procedures fall solely within the competence of the national authorities. The Agency can only act against its own staff, since FRONTEX has only a coordinating role. In order for this EU agency to function properly and professionally and to fulfil its important mandate, the Commission and the Member States must provide the necessary financial resources to operate.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with setting up an individual complaint mechanism for Frontex’s operations in case of breaches of fundamental rights. This was initiated by a Special Report of the European Ombudsman. I stress the need for the implementation of a mechanism which will provide an effective remedy in case of violation of fundamental rights in this context. I support this report, since it underlines the need for close cooperation between Frontex and the Member States and it will be an improvement regarding the efficient implementation of this procedure, and acknowledging that legal and administrative safeguards are needed to ensure a proper follow-up of complaints. Therefore, I voted in favour.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it aims to facilitate migrants' appeals against Frontex agents. Advised by NGOs, migrants will file systematic appeals to save time and stay in Europe. This is a new aspiring immigration pump that is being implemented.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the measures recommended therein will help improve transparency in Frontex's activities and provide greater protection in terms of respect for fundamental rights. text: in writing. In addition, the report deals in particular with the most vulnerable groups and contains specific provisions for pregnant women and unaccompanied minors as well as in relation to the LGBT collective. name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I did not vote in favour of this report because I believe that Frontex's own activity, its militarisation and border defence work, is a permanent violation of fundamental rights. That is why, from my political group, we have tabled amendments to the report calling for the dismantling of Frontex, understanding that it would be the only effective way to end systematic human rights violations at EU borders, and thus making clear our frontal rejection of Frontex. In addition, the approved mechanism, which seeks to give the possibility of bringing complaints for violations of fundamental rights in the context of the operations of this European Agency, suffers from a serious shortcoming, in respect of which we also tabled amendments which were also rejected: their lack of independence, since the Agency itself is responsible for the management of complaints committed by its agents.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the Report by Metsola & Keller on the European Ombudsman's proposal on Frontex. This report deals with the requirements for a complaint procedure following possible assaults by Frontex employees. The proposed procedure has been largely adopted from the procedural directives of other EU institutions, such as the ECB, which have very different and hardly transferable requirements to Frontex. In the past, it has been shown that a large proportion of complaints against Frontex were insubstantial and that most of the accusations of alleged human rights violations were baseless. A particularly critical attitude towards Frontex, as in some of the amendments to this report, is therefore not appropriate. As Frontex is to be extended and is expected to receive a wider mandate, the complaints procedure should also be included in the negotiations on the new mandate and adapted to the very specific needs of Frontex. This is the only way to ensure that Frontex has an appropriate complaints procedure that works permanently and does not restrict Frontex's important activities.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Frontex's task is to effectively implement common rules on controlling and controlling external borders and coordination and cooperation between Member States. However, Frontex's role in these moments is more than border control since saving lives is an integral part of their missions. Frontex has an impact on human rights, in particular when intercepting illegal migrants, asylum seekers and refugees at land and sea borders. The human rights of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers must be respected without discrimination, regardless of their administrative status and circumstances.  I supported the report by MEPs Roberta Metsola and Ska Keller because human rights, democracy and the rule of law are at the heart of the Lisbon Treaty and the objective of a common foreign and security policy. A human rights-based approach to migration policy is key to achieving this goal, while addressing the causes of migration, such as poverty, war and serious human rights violations in countries of origin and transit, should be a priority.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from voting on the European Ombudsman's special report following an own-initiative OI/5/2012/BEH-MHZ investigation into Frontex, because it is not complete and substantiated, as I mentioned in my written proposal on this subject.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This outlier resolution wishes to facilitate complaints by migrants about violations of their rights, even as they arrive in our territories in an irregular situation! Worse, the resolution provides that third parties, such as heavily subsidised NGOs, can file these complaints for migrants, all of which, of course, are accompanied by information campaigns with migrants. The obvious aim of this action is to reduce again and again the number of evictions, already almost zero. Just a few days after the deadly attacks in Paris that demonstrated the dangers of this immigration, we can only strongly oppose such a measure.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report concerning an own-initiative inquiry carried out by the European Ombudsman in relation to Frontex and, in principle, proposes the establishment of a mechanism to deal with individual human rights violations allegedly taking place in the context of Frontex's work. It is clear that addressing immigration issues, and in particular those related to illegal entry, poses significant legal and humanitarian challenges for the EU. There must almost necessarily be tension between a legitimate interest in controlling immigration and asylum seekers. I agree that we need to put in place a functional mechanism to deal with individual complaints of human rights violations by Frontex staff. However, I consider the proposed concept, which does not adequately address how to proceed, e.g. when calling a complaint unacceptable or the right of appeal, unclear and incomplete. That is why I abstained.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. Members of this Parliament believe that Frontex should establish a mechanism to prosecute complaints from citizens or organisations who believe that the fundamental rights of migrants and asylum seekers have been violated. That is why we voted in favour of this Resolution, which I support after learning of the Ombudsman's recommendations, because I believe it is important to regulate this process in order to protect all parties involved and prevent abuse.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report leads to further bureaucracy. The report will add to the burden on Frontex, which will make it even more difficult for Frontex to carry out its actual tasks in the future. I therefore reject this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Ombudsman conducted an investigation into the European external border control agency, Frontex, to enforce human rights. In particular, it proposed to set up an internal redress mechanism to collect all complaints from migrants who could be addressed to the agency, and to the Member State, according to the staff present at the border. Frontex refused, considering that it is not within its mandate, but the competence of Member States to receive complaints about their staff. The problem is that, by the way, it refuses to improve its complaints information system for its own community staff. Parliament's report defends this internal mechanism at Frontex and thereby legitimizes its brutal role. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. A resolution on Frontex, passed a few days after the Paris attacks, makes it easier for migrants to complain about border guards in the event of possible violations of their rights, even though they themselves are present in our territories illegally. The procedure also provides for third parties, such as NGOs, to file complaints on behalf of migrants. To top it all off, some European MEPs are calling for a wide-ranging information campaign for migrants to make them aware of this new right, in order to further reduce, of course, the number of expulsions. I am therefore opposed to this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome first ly the Special Report of the European Ombudsman following the own-initiative investigation into Frontex. The European Ombudsman made the recommendation to Frontex that a mechanism should be established to deal with complaints about fundamental rights violations in all joint operations with the Frontex seal. The mechanism should receive complaints from persons claiming to have been personally affected or who wish to lodge a complaint for reasons of public interest. This function could be assigned to the fundamental rights officer, who would be endowed with the necessary resources for its exercise.  The EU Regulation on Frontex requires the agency to ensure full respect for the fundamental rights and rights of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers, so Frontex should set up an appropriate complaints mechanism. I share the rapporteur's position that the mechanism for handling individual complaints should be efficient and transparent. I have presented my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As co-rapporteur of this report I felt that a very balanced report was negotiated. This report calls for the setting up of an individual complaints mechanism by Frontex which will provide an avenue for people to exercise their right to a more effective remedy. It means that Frontex and the EU institutions and bodies are more aware of any possible violations of fundamental rights that could otherwise remain undetected, unreported or unresolved and so I chose to support this report.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Following an investigation by the European Ombudsman in 2012 into Frontex's human rights obligations, the European Parliament called for the creation of a system within the agency to deal with complaints of violations of the human rights of migrants and asylum seekers in the agency's operations. I welcome the inclusion in the text of provisions highlighting the need to protect vulnerable migrant groups such as women, unaccompanied minors and LGBTI people. I am also pleased that Commissioner D. Avramopoulos has already stressed that he will take this proposal into account in the revision of the Frontex regulation.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The European Ombudsman's report assesses Frontex's fulfilment of its fundamental rights obligations. In order to consolidate fundamental rights, the Ombudsman proposes the creation of a mechanism for making individual complaints about infringements. I support the proposal establishing the right of appeal, as this would increase transparency, which is always a guarantee of better public affairs. Given the current serious and difficult situation at the EU's external borders, where security and order must be ensured in the first place, the proposed mechanism must be designed in such a way that it is not abused and does not cause obstruction in ensuring proper control and protection in the interests of EU citizens.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report supporting the recommendation by the European Ombudsman that Frontex should deal with complaints regarding infringements of fundamental rights in the course of its operations and should provide adequate administrative support for that purpose. The report also calls on Frontex to set up an independent complaints mechanism. In light of the growing migratory flows and expanding capacity of Frontex, I am in favour of the creation of such a complaint mechanism which will help migrants to complain when it comes to alleged breaches of their fundamental rights.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 7 November 2013, the European Ombudsman submitted a special report on frontex's own-initiative inquiry OI/5/2012/BEH-MHZ. In its joint report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Petitions welcome the Ombudsman's special report and support the Ombudsman's recommendation that Frontex act on individual complaints about violations of fundamental rights in its operations and, to that end, establish an individual complaints mechanism. I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Civil Liberties and Petitions Committees met on 23 November as part of an expedited procedure to vote on a resolution on Frontex (the European Border Management Agency) which was absolutely outrageous by 62 votes in and 11 against. This resolution facilitates the ability of migrants, who are illegally present on our territory, to file a complaint against border guards in the event of possible violations of their rights! In addition, the resolution provides that third parties, such as publicly funded NGOs, can file complaints on behalf of migrants and that an information campaign be carried out with them to inform them of this appeal. This resolution, which we strongly oppose, is based on the suicidal logic of our leaders to want to bring millions of migrants into our territories and give them as many rights as possible. And it is interesting to note that despite the recent attacks, reality has failed to shake the so-called humanist madness of the Republicans and Socialists.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union must ensure full respect for the fundamental rights and rights of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers. It should be noted that Frontex's mission is to ensure the effective implementation of the common rules on the control and surveillance of external borders with regard to fundamental rights and that these actions therefore have implications for human rights.  I support the European Ombudsman's recommendation that Frontex should deal with each individual complaint concerning violations of fundamental rights in the course of its operations and should provide appropriate administrative support for this purpose. This individual complaints mechanism will give people an opportunity to exercise their right to an effective remedy in the event of a breach of fundamental rights, and will have as a corollary the increase in transparency and respect for them. The enforcement of this right should be carried out by an information campaign, disseminated in the official languages of the EU and in languages which asylum seekers and migrants understand or it is reasonable to assume that they understand.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report, which approves the establishment within Frontex of a mechanism for dealing with individual complaints relating to allegations of human rights violations during the course of its operations. Article 26 bis of the agency's regulation provides for the implementation of a fundamental rights strategy, the creation of an advisory forum and the appointment of a human rights officer. This report recommends that this officer be in charge of handling individual complaints. The aim is to put an end to the situation of legal uncertainty in the cooperation operations between the Frontex agency and the competent authorities of the partner countries in the context of the management of the migration crisis.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this report, which supports the European Ombudsman's recommendation that Frontex deal with complaints about violations of fundamental rights in the course of its operations, provide adequate administrative support for this and provide an independent redress mechanism. The report was necessary as a result of the growing phenomenon of migratory flows. The appeal mechanism requested is therefore very important in the light of frontex's increased capacity, in particular as regards participation in the management of migrants in so-called "hotspot" areas. It also requires that the appeal mechanism be supported by human rights actors. In addition, it stresses the need to have a system in which appeals are first checked and filtered, in order to assess their admissibility, that the eligibility criteria are clearly defined, and that the forms for appeals are translated into languages that recurrent citizens are able to understand. Finally, it is crucial that we exclude from all Frontex activities those officials who have acted in violation of fundamental rights.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report on the basis of the European Ombudsman's proposal, whose primary objective is to establish a complaints mechanism for frontex's work that can serve as an effective tool for the protection of fundamental human rights without jeoparding the agency's work. Frontex's role in the coming months and years will be more significant than ever. It should ensure that key tasks such as the protection of the external borders and the implementation of the Recovery Directive are carried out. Therefore, we must not create unnecessary administrative burdens or allow for abuse of the complaints mechanism. For this reason, I do not consider it appropriate to involve third parties in these matters. The exceptions are unaccompanied minors and persons with disabilities, for whom we need to establish a simple and reasonable system for representing them. The complaints mechanism is intended to guarantee the responsibility of Frontex representatives, and this should not have any impact on the enforcement of member states' rights in the EU, such as the withdrawal of any financial benefits.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that calls for the setting up of a Frontex individual complaints mechanism, laying down the structure, lodging and admissibility of complaints.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Frontex report because I agree that Frontex should also be subject to a human rights review. If any complaints are made in relation to its activities, they should be investigated. Refugees should also be entitled to proper and lawful treatment and the possibility to lodge complaints against illegal interference by Agency staff in the performance of their activities. However, there should be mechanisms to prevent possible abuse of the complaints institute, which is why I have not supported the efforts of some of my colleagues on the left-wing spectrum to allow complaints to be lodged anonymously.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because this special report seeks to respond to unjustified demands from migrants, which I do not believe should be supported under any circumstances. We need to secure our borders, this is a priority, not the transgender craze. For example, this report will only have the result that border guards will face a flood of unfounded complaints.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which aims to support the European Ombudsman in its process of modifying the functioning of the FRONTEX agency in order to include in its regulation the possibility for its teams to file a complaint for human rights violations. The report also reveals a number of anomalies concerning the functioning of the agency, notably regarding a certain legal vacuum around the status of staff or the low transparency of the use of European funds allocated to Frontex. These anomalies need to be corrected in view of the agency's major role in managing the refugee crisis.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Frontex has an important role to play in saving lives and must ensure that people's fundamental rights are respected. The Special Report foresees, inter alia, the establishment of an individual complaints mechanism for Frontex.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report.  In view of the activities carried out by Frontex and its growing role under EU law, as well as the recommendations made by the Ombudsman, I consider it appropriate that a mechanism be established for the handling of individual complaints within this agency. The Agency would become a complaint handling body at first instance. It needs to be noted that the rights of a person must not be formally, but effectively and effectively protected against both private individuals and illegal acts by officials. It is therefore essential to ensure that the new mechanism ensures that complaints about fundamental rights potentially violated in frontex operations are properly dealt with. In addition, the complaints mechanism must comply with EU law and the principle of good administration would also contribute to the effective implementation of the Agency's fundamental rights strategy. This would enable victims to properly exercise their right to an effective, cost-effective and expeditious defence of their violated rights.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the setting up of a complaints mechanism as we feel such a mechanism would be ineffective, open to malicious false claims and potentially demotivate border staff. Furthermore, we feel that a far better way to protect borders is to have sovereign states decide their own immigration policies, rather than to set up complaint mechanisms in an already broken and unworkable system.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to take this opportunity to express my confidence and esteem in the work and role of the European Ombudsman, a fundamental body for the realisation of democracy in Europe. I would also like to thank my colleagues in the LIBE Committee for their efforts in the analysis of the Ombudsman's report, which they discussed constructively at this month's meetings. I agree with them that the possibility of a complaint mechanism against Frontex agents (and national agents made available to Frontex during its missions) in the event of human rights violations is of fundamental importance, in order to ensure fair treatment for all. I strongly urge my fellow Members to vote in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I support the European Ombudsman’s position that Frontex set up a complaints mechanism on fundamental rights infringements occurring in the course of its operations. Fundamental rights of migrants and asylum seekers should not be undermined in any way and it is the right of every person to be able to file a complaint when he or she believes his rights are being violated.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Frontex has to be given the necessary space to set up its own mechanism with its own structure and legal safeguards. I believe that in the current situation, Frontex is a key player to safeguard EU external borders and any obstacles that would make its operations difficult should be removed.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 As one of the key agencies of the European Union in carrying out border control and protection tasks, which are experiencing conceptual and practical redefiniency in the face of new challenges, it is necessary to stress that FRONTEX must not be exempted from the European Union's human rights practices under the Charter of Fundamental Rights in its work.  Since FRONTEX action most often involves working with vulnerable and vulnerable groups such as women, minors, displaced persons, refugees, we must be aware that the framework defining their operational segment must indeed be a reflection of what the European Union is. The establishment of a mechanism of individual complaints is a step forward in terms of institutionalising the protection of rights and ensuring equal treatment. Such a control model is a fuse of the quality implementation of FRONTEX missions, but also a way of external and internal evaluation of the work of the body itself. Since the quality of work so far is not disturbed in this way, the introduction of a mechanism of individual complaints and its implementation reflects the willingness to deal with internal organizational shortcomings, mostly expressed in the level and manner of conduct, individual responsibility and inability to systematicly monitor the work of officials. The introduction of a model of individual complaints should not be considered an attack on current work, but as a guarantee that the future work of the agency will be even better.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report by Rapporteurs Roberta Metsole and Ska Keller on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, and the Committee on Petitions on the European Ombudsman's Special Report on The Investigation on Its Own Initiative concerning Frontex, which insists on the implementation of the individual complaints mechanism.  The Regulation of Parliament and the Council requires Frontex to guarantee respect for fundamental human rights and the rights of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers, as well as any other right. As the Frontex Regulation does not have legal barriers to the introduction of an individual complaint mechanism, and given the growing humanitarian and legal challenges at the EU's external borders, and the strengthening of Frontex operations, a mechanism is needed to deal with individual complaints about alleged violations of fundamental rights that occur during Frontex operations. Such a mechanism is primarily necessary to increase transparency and respect for fundamental rights.  In my view, the further development of Frontex is important as there is no other joint body to manage and coordinate actions on a multi-country level, and Member States cannot achieve equal success by taking independent measures without coordination with other Member States.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am glad that Parliament voted positively on this report. It shows that Frontex sees room for improvement and it is taking the initiative to do it. With the current and ongoing migration crisis it is critical that the EU’s external borders should be strong and secure, but this does not mean that human rights go by the wayside. Implementing the complaint system is a step forward in this regard. For this to work, I encourage the Member States to cooperate with Frontex to ensure that the new process runs as smoothly as possible, and to ensure the mechanism’s effectiveness. Finally, for a complaint process to work, it must be efficient and transparent, and I trust that the proper agencies will ensure that this is the case.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is balanced and relevant, thanks in particular to the work of the EPP. We have succeeded in removing unnecessary references that some political groups want. On FRONTEX, the message is clear.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the own-initiative inquiry on the European Management Agency for Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the Union (Frontex), the European Ombudsman published a Special Report in which a mechanism for individual complaints was insisted on. The Ombudsman advocates the establishment of a system for reporting incidents and drawing up codes of conduct, as well as the establishment of an Advisory Forum on fundamental rights and an agent for fundamental rights.  These mechanisms are so much more relevant in the framework of FRONTEX's operational cooperation with the competent authorities of partner countries, carried out through non-legally binding operational agreements and without insertion under international law. Whereas FRONTEX, like any EU body or body, must observe, in the exercise of its activities, the Charter of Fundamental Rights, and whereas this obligation is enshrined in the TFEU, and also considering that the implementation of the mechanism proposed by the Ombudsman is the indispensable guarantor of frontex's fulfilment of the fundamental rights obligations, I voted in favour of the report under this.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the setting up of a complaints mechanism as we feel such a mechanism would be ineffective, open to malicious false claims and potentially demotivate border staff. Furthermore, we feel that a far better way to protect borders is to have sovereign states decide their own immigration policies, rather than to set up complaint mechanisms in an already broken and unworkable system.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. At a time when Member States are focusing on external border control, it is all the more important to have the resources to strengthen the rights of migrants and asylum seekers. The Socialists and Democrats fully support the content of this report and the recommendations of the European Ombudsman. It is essential that Frontex has an individual mechanism for dealing with human rights complaints. This mechanism should also apply to the agency's signed labour agreements with certain third countries, which allow, among other things, the organisation of joint return operations. These texts are not subject to international law. They therefore do not impose on both sides respect for the fundamental rights of migrants and asylum seekers. Moreover, Parliament does not know how they are implemented on a day-to-day basis.  The complaints mechanism will ensure greater transparency in the face of possible violations of fundamental rights that would otherwise not be detected, reported or resolved. This will be a first step in ensuring that the fundamental rights of migrants and asylum seekers are respected by Frontex at the EU's borders, but also beyond.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Union must regain control of its borders. This is a fact that is necessary as the lack of preparation and good management of the unrelenting flow of migrants fleeing war in the Middle East is a no-brainer. The President of the Eurogroup, Jeroen Dijsselbloem, expressed this in very clear words recently: "If the Union does not better protect its external borders, then a small group of countries will do so". This means the importance of strengthening Frontex, the European border management agency, in parallel with the establishment of a European border guard and coastguard. More powers and more rights for Frontex agents, but also duties as demanded today by MEPs by voting on a resolution. In practice, Parliament wants a mechanism to deal with individual complaints about alleged violations of the fundamental rights of migrants and asylum seekers. This request follows the Ombudsman's 2012 investigation into Frontex's fundamental rights obligations. The ball is in the European Commission's court to include this complaints mechanism in the frontex regulatory review, scheduled for December.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. In this report, which I voted on, we reiterate the importance of ensuring that Frontex respects the fundamental rights and rights of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers. The agency has already made efforts to do so. However, areas of shadow remain. Effective handling of individual complaints should be encouraged when allegations of human rights violations committed by frontex-wearing border guards are identified during the course of its operations. The Office of the Rights Officer must play a leading role in this mechanism.  With regard to guest officers, for whom Frontex cannot take disciplinary action, we recommend that the Office of the Fundamental Rights Officer report complaints through a referral system to the national competent authority. In addition, the Human Rights Officer must have the necessary resources to deal with complaints in the best possible conditions. Finally, I would like to point out that this House has relied on the recommendations of the European Ombudsman to determine its position.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the measures recommended therein will help improve transparency in Frontex's activities and provide greater protection in terms of respect for fundamental rights. In addition, the report deals in particular with the most vulnerable groups and contains specific provisions for pregnant women and unaccompanied minors as well as in relation to the LGBT collective.  Other positive aspects of the report include the establishment of a patterned and clear mechanism for complaints to ensure that possible human rights violations in the context of Frontex operations are not unpunished and detailed in the Agency's annual report. Anonymous complaints by third parties in good faith are also offered for cases where victims may be under pressure or persecution.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which believes in particular that, given the ever-increasing humanitarian and legal challenges at the External Borders of the European Union, and the strengthening of Frontex's operations, it is necessary to have a mechanism capable of dealing with individual complaints of alleged violations of fundamental rights during the conduct of Frontex operations or cooperation with third countries and thus for Frontex to become a first-degree forum for handling of complaints, in line with the conclusions of the European Ombudsman's report, which insisted on the implementation of such a mechanism.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following a report by the European Ombudsman published in 2013, which follows the inquiry into the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (Frontex), a set of 13 recommendations is proposed on the need to promote greater respect for fundamental rights, in particular through the establishment of an incident reporting mechanism , the development of codes of conduct, the establishment of an Advisory Forum and an Agent for the Guarantee of Fundamental Rights. Overall, I support the report by Mr Metsola and Mr Keller, stressing the need for the Agency to adopt mechanisms to ensure the effective implementation of fundamental rights, thereby promoting greater transparency of Frontex's work agreements with third countries, over which Parliament exercises no democratic control. These are positive measures that respond to the current pressure and the humanitarian and legal challenges currently existing at the EU's external borders, and a set of proposals that I consider necessary for Frontex's Fundamental Rights Strategy, so to that extent I think they should be included in the next revision of its Regulation.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which supports the Recommendation of the European Ombudsman for the European Union's External Border Management Agency, Frontex, to establish a mechanism for dealing with individual complaints to deal with allegations of human rights violations during the course of its operations. In view of the refugee crisis and the growing number of humanitarian and legal challenges facing Frontex, it is necessary, as the European Ombudsman calls for, to set up this mechanism. This report makes a series of proposals to make such a mechanism viable and possible.  The European Union must ensure control of its external borders and strengthen cooperation between Member States.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote on the European Ombudsman's Special Report on his own-initiative investigation into Frontex as, on the one hand, we are against frontex's role and we believe that this Agency should be rethinked and eventually dismantled. On the other hand, we did not vote against the report because it does not include any aspect which could strengthen Frontex's operations, but it does reflect the Conclusions of the European Ombudsman as regards the Agency's human rights obligations, including aspects which we consider fundamental, if not sufficient. Aspects of the report include individual complaint and reporting mechanisms for cases of human rights violations, fundamental rights, as they were not accepted to date. At the same time, measures are called for to improve guarantees and safeguards for human rights in the Agency's operations and the obligation of gender training is recommended before joining a Frontex operation, in particular to raise awareness of gender-based violence and the vulnerability of migrant women.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I did not vote in favour of this report because I believe that Frontex's own activity, its militarisation and border defence work, inherently entails the permanent violation of fundamental rights. That is why, from my political group, we have tabled amendments to the report calling for the dismantling of Frontex, understanding that it would be the only effective way to end the systematic violations of human rights at EU borders, and thus making clear the frontal rejection of Alternative Galega de Esquerda in Europe to Frontex.  In addition, the approved mechanism, which seeks to give the possibility of bringing complaints for violations of fundamental rights in the context of the operations of this European Agency, suffers from a serious shortcoming, for which we also tabled amendments which were also rejected: its lack of independence, since the Agency itself is responsible for the management of complaints committed by its agents.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ At committee level, my colleagues in the Socialist and Democrats Group supported the report from its beginning. They managed to include some vital amendments which I am pleased to see. In my view all people should have the ability to seek redress for breaches of their fundamental rights, and in this time of turmoil for people escaping war and economic stagnation in other countries, who are making the dangerous trip across, into Europe, it is more important than ever that migrants have easier access to legal redress when it comes to alleged breaches of their fundamental rights. Something which the EU has long championed.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the European Ombudsman's special report on own-initiative inquiries in relation to Frontex.  The Ombudsman acknowledges Frontex's current efforts to improve respect for fundamental rights and in the form of the establishment of an event reporting system as well as the development of codes of conduct. Frontex should address individual complaints about fundamental rights violations occurring during its operations and provide adequate administrative support to this end. In view of the growing humanitarian and legal problems at the EU's external borders and the intensification of Frontex operations, there is a need for a mechanism within which individual complaints can be processed against alleged fundamental rights violations occurring in the course of Frontex operations or cooperation with third countries.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Ombudsman and the European Parliament are right in calling for an effective mechanism to monitor respect for fundamental rights in all the activities of Frontex, as it is also the case of other EU institutions, bodies and agencies. The setting—up of an individual complaint mechanism is especially important in the light of the highly sensitive nature of Frontex’s activity, and also if we consider the long-term plans to extend the current legal remit of Frontex and to transform it into an independent border guard service. Nevertheless, I believe that any new legal obligation concerning an individual complaint mechanism should be matched with adequate financial and human resources and, on the other hand, should contain appropriate safeguards preventing the misuse of a complaint mechanism in a way to ensure that Frontex is still able to effectively perform its tasks.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome this report, which was worked on by ppe colleague Robert Metsol. The report is very balanced. It responds well to the European Ombudsman's 2013 call for Frontex to establish a mechanism for individual complaints about human rights violations that could occur in the Agency's operations. The European Parliament also expresses its support for this matter from Frontex itself and in cooperation with it. It is about guaranteeing human rights, but at the same time ensuring that the Agency is not crippled by unnecessary complaints, especially anonymous ones. Frontex is a key external border control authority whose capacity must not be disrupted. On the contrary, it should be strengthened. I also consider it positive for the role of the European Ombudsman to draw the European Parliament's attention to the real problems in the exercise of eu competences. It is a good safeguard for the protection of fundamental rights, which should not interfere with the activities of the responsible authorities. Similarly, the Ombudsman's Institute has proved itself to us in the Czech Republic.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. -u2012 Frontex's task is to ensure the effective implementation of common rules on standards and procedures for external border control and control by closer coordination of operational cooperation between Member States. Frontex is carrying out various operations in the Member States where it is most needed. These are mainly involving visiting officials sent by other Member States in support. They may carry out their duties and exercise their powers in accordance with the instructions and in the presence of border guards of the host Member State. As regards Frontex's implementation of its fundamental rights obligations, in 2012 the European Ombudsman launched an own-initiative inquiry. It states in its report the need to introduce a mechanism for individual complaints. I agree that, in view of the growing humanitarian and legal challenges at the EU's external borders, Frontex should establish an appeal mechanism. This would allow individuals' complaints about alleged breaches of fundamental rights during operations to be hinged. Persons who are alleged to have been harmed by border guards with the Frontex emblem and third parties acting in the interests of those persons would have the right to lodge a complaint. By the entry into force of this complaint mechanism, individuals would gain the opportunity to exercise their right to an effective remedy, which is why I voted in plenary.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the Report by Metsola & Keller on the European Ombudsman's proposal on Frontex. This report deals with the requirements for a complaint procedure following possible assaults by Frontex employees. The proposed procedure has been largely adopted from the procedural directives of other EU institutions, such as the ECB, which have very different and hardly transferable requirements to Frontex. In the past, it has been shown that a large proportion of complaints against Frontex were insubstantial and that most of the accusations of alleged human rights violations were baseless. A particularly critical attitude towards Frontex, as in some of the amendments to this report, is therefore not appropriate. As Frontex is to be extended and is expected to receive a wider mandate, the complaints procedure should also be included in the negotiations on the new mandate and adapted to the very specific needs of Frontex. This is the only way to ensure that Frontex has an appropriate complaints procedure that works permanently and does not restrict Frontex's important activities.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I was very happy to support the European Parliament's report on the European Ombudsman's special report in the context of the own-initiative inquiry on Frontex. The report recommends the use of a mechanism within Frontex to allow individuals to lodge complaints. Where Frontex or its staff interfere with the rights of individuals through their activities, they should have the means of defence common in the rule of law. I am therefore very glad that the Commission has undertaken to take this recommendation into account in the forthcoming revision of the Regulation on the Agency concerned. I am also pleased that a reasonable compromise has been found on the identification of complainants. In my opinion, it is necessary to find a solution that ensures the protection of fundamental rights while effectively preventing their abuse. I am glad that anonymous complaints remain inadmissible in the text. Otherwise, frontex's activities would be weakened, if not crippled. On the other hand, However, I supported the possibility of lodging a complaint through third parties acting in good faith in the interest of a complainant who does not wish to reveal his identity. I consider this to be a sensible step which, in well-founded cases, will allow the identity of the complainant to be protected without the risk of abuse.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. 'The N-VA delegation in the European Parliament believes that anyone whose fundamental rights are harmed has the right to lodge a complaint and to receive a response. Nevertheless, we are voting against this report on the grounds that the proposed complaints procedure is completely inappropriate. This procedure is based on the complaints mechanism used within the framework of the European Central Bank (ECB). As such, it does not take into account frontex's own structure, which, as an EU agency, brings together and coordinates resources and staff from different EU Member States.  The ideas set out in this report should have been better developed so as not to place an administrative burden on an agency that is now putting all hands on deck to deal with the problems at our external borders. Problems of uncontrolled mass migration towards the European continent combined with a substantial security threat through infiltration of foreign jihadists.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this report because I believe that further clarifying frontex's role and further regulating their attitude towards work will lead to further and as good adherence to human rights and the aforementioned rules. I think it would be useful to introduce a mechanism through which people can submit their proposals, demands and criticism. This mechanism will allow us further transparency and the opportunity to know the reaction of citizens who have been in contact with frontex's activities, and this will enable further improvement of Frontex's action to better the citizens of the European Union, the agency itself and the people who come into contact with the work of the agency itself.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Frontex was set up to ensure, in cooperation with Member States, the effective implementation of rules in the control of external border crossing points of the European Union. However, in this report by the EU Public Ombudsman, the human rights problem within Frontex is seen as not clearly defined. Since safeguards are necessary in preventing abuse of appeal procedures, it is recommended not to take anonymous reports, unless a third party submits the same in order to protect another person.  Also, in this report it is recommended to create a single form, which would contain all the relevant data necessary for the efficient processing of the application. The form should be written in languages that asylum seekers will be able to understand, and contain all legal measures at their disposal. It should be possible to submit an application on frontex's website and via the mobile application. I accept the proposals for this report because I consider that the determination of clear measures in the acceptance of appeal procedures, and the facilitation of the submission through a single form, further ensures human rights for all asylum seekers.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Ombudsman's special report in the context of the own-initiative inquiry on Frontex, as the fundamental rights to which the EU has subscribed, such as those set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights, must also be exercised in situations in which Frontex operates. This is not about reducing frontex's effectiveness. On the contrary, this situation shows the importance of reforming Frontex so that it has the competence to carry out effectively the tasks that we believe it should carry out in the future. The unclear position of the workers seconded by each Member State only illustrates the current inadequate arrangements.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The JOINT LIBE-PETI report deals with the European Ombudsman's proposal to set up a mechanism for individual actions/complaints in relation to Frontex's violation of fundamental rights. Unfortunately few of the amendments tabled by the Group of the European United Left concerning the independence of the mechanism from Frontex, the possibility of anonymous complaints, and the need to promote specific measures for vulnerable groups [women victims of violence, stateless people, LGBT people] have been adopted. The important proposals of our group to recognise the violation of fundamental rights by Frontex operations were also not accepted. Our position is clear. Although an individual appeal mechanism is needed, it is clear that the proposed mechanism is inadequate and is not based on the recognition of the reality surrounding Frontex's action. Our main position is the dismantling of Frontex and its immediate replacement by mechanisms and humanitarian operations to search and rescue refugees. For these reasons we did not vote in favour of the report but abstained in order to continue the debate on improving the mechanisms for saving refugees.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 FRONTEX is a service which, judging by its composition and operational capabilities, is unable to cope with migration flows. Here entire Member States are building fences and restoring cross-border controls to contain the waves of migrants. Imagine if, of the 2 million migrants expected, 10,000 make a complaint, true or false. The system will collapse. We will fall into a range of investigations, legal details, language difficulties, rather than dealing with the registration and assistance that constitutes FRONTEX's main mission. Illegal immigrants, in particular, will be suspected of violations in order to hinder the work of the authorities, to require their entry into the Schengen area and to hinder their repatriation operations.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 FRONTEX is one of our best agencies, its employees have a high degree of integrity. The assistance that FRONTEX provides to Member States in coordinating the flow of migrants at the EU's external borders is particularly important in the current crisis situation. However, it should be clarified that FRONTEX is still not entitled to take action against national law enforcement officers involved in its operations, and these procedures fall solely within the competence of the national authorities. The Agency can only act against its own staff, since FRONTEX has only a coordinating role. In order for this EU agency to function properly and professionally and to fulfil its important mandate, the Commission and the Member States must provide the necessary financial resources to operate.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report because I consider the European Ombudsman's proposals to be important and particularly timely. I agree with the approach that joint European management of the refugee crisis naturally raises the question of strengthening Frontex's powers, finances and organisation, but in doing so we must not lose sight of the fact that our officers in charge of guarding EU borders here are not facing a mass of vulnerable people fleeing real dangers, not hostile ones.  The new challenge demands both efficiency and a flexible, humane approach from Frontex staff. To this end, the Ombudsman's report provides appropriate legal and humane evidence, in particular by introducing a new transparent complaint mechanism to protect the rights and persons of whistleblowers while minimising the possibility of abuse, bearing in mind the letter and spirit of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. I also consider it appropriate to prioritise humane aspects and the human rights of refugees in relation to frontex's activities, because it is a fact that within the Union, even at the level of some Member State governments and heads of government, there is a political uprootation against refugees, anti-foreigner incitement, migration and the conscious washed-up of the challenges of international terrorism. In this political situation, the Ombudsman's report, as well as a warning and a concrete package of proposals aimed at protecting common European values, can only be welcomed.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Frontex has been operating for more than a decade, but many people are unaware of its existence. Furthermore, due to poor transparency and leadership, Frontex has been criticised by numerous institutions and NGOs, most recently the European Ombudsman. As indicated in the Ombudsman's report, there are strong grounds for being called incompatible with human rights by Frontex, and the current migration crisis has further highlighted this problem. Among other things, many people trying to enter Europe were sent back, even though they had to be granted the right to asylum. It is therefore so important to take action to increase the transparency of the agency, m.in. through universal access to information on the complaints mechanism in the context of frontex's annual general report, or to increase the powers of a fundamental rights officer. The Agency must also ensure a better ethnic, national and gender balance within its activities. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the EP report and I believe that Frontex will start the process of making changes as soon as possible in order to increase not only its effectiveness, but also the degree of respect for the EU's fundamental rights.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The intensification of migration to EU Member States in recent months requires changes to certain regulations on European instruments for managing the flow of migrants. One such instrument is Frontex, which contributes to the defence of the Union's external borders. Ensuring the security of the Member States is an essential condition for the viability of European construction. However, in the context of the intensification of the terrorist phenomenon, there is a tendency to attribute to all immigrants coming from conflict zones near the borders of the Union that they do not have and to manage this problem by limiting their legitimate rights. In the event of such infringements, immigrants must have the right to submit individual petitions to Frontex structures, personally or through representatives. The referral to the European Ombudsman concerns this very issue, which is not currently provided for by any European regulation. If Frontex staff were responsible for the violation of the fundamental rights of immigrants, then they would be significantly reduced and there would be no danger of inhumane treatment of those groups. Of course, that mechanism must also act as a filter on the admissibility of those petitions on a case-by-case basis. Adoption of the current document is necessary to avoid potential abuses.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. I am also of the view that Frontex should deal with individual complaints of human rights violations during the course of its operations and should provide sufficient administrative support for this purpose. We call on Frontex to set up an appropriate complaints mechanism, including as part of its working agreements with the relevant authorities in third countries.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ A few months ago, the European Ombudsman put forward a number of proposals for the Frontex common border agency, so that it ensures more respect for the fundamental rights of persons subject to their agent.  Following these proposals Parliament prepared a report that was voted on 2 December 2015 and that I supported (despite a number of provisions where I would have doubts concerning the feasibility or the coherence in a crisis situation) the report promotes common rules on constraint and compels Member States to improve their complaints procedures. If the report is not the one I would expect, it brings nevertheless a few interesting elements for reflection that can be used for the future in order to improve respect for fundamental rights.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The rapporteur, Ska Keller, is addressing a very important issue aimed at bringing together the two most important problems for today's Europeans: ensuring the safety of citizens while respecting human rights. Frontex, like any other institution or Agency of the European Union, must comply with the Charter of Fundamental Rights. In view of the increasing number of humanitarian and legal challenges at the EU's external borders, it is necessary to establish a mechanism to analyse individual complaints relating to allegations of fundamental rights violations that may arise from frontex activities or in cooperation with third countries. In democratic states, such legal instruments must be guaranteed, which is why I supported the report in question.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ In 2011 FRONTEX was given the specific task of acting in accordance with the Charter of Fundamental Human Rights in carrying out its activities – administrative arrangements should be created in its work that will not only promote but also monitor the coherence of actions in border areas with the Charter. In 2012. On its own initiative, the Ombudsman launched an investigation into FRONTEX's activities in respect of fundamental human rights and submitted the report to the European Parliament. While the report notes that FRONTEX has made reasonable progress in commitments made within the Charter, the Ombudsman found that it does not have a mechanism at the same time to address individual violations of fundamental human rights. On these grounds, Parliament has developed a model under which individual complaints can be treated and dealt with more effectively in the future; similar model they apply in other European agencies and bodies. This approach today, when external borders are under unbearable pressure, which again puts respect for human rights in the foreground instead of the security dimension, is unacceptable. Advocating for an increase in Frontex staff to handle complaints of human rights violations received instead of using these human resources for more necessary purposes today is a completely missed policy of sticking its head in the sand, which has already backfired on Europe.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the European Ombudsman's special report on the own-initiative inquiry OI/5/2012/BEH-MHZ in relation to Frontex because I believe that Frontex needs to strengthen and expand its powers, as it is a very important link in relation to illegal immigration and is a major player in the return of immigrants back to their home countries. Furthermore, I believe that Frontex needs to be made more efficient, thus more secureing the European Union's external borders.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It has been two years since the European Ombudsman published the special report on Frontex, and it is time that the Agency took that report seriously and followed its advice. Especially now, with the large influx of refugees, it is crucial that human rights are safeguarded. So far, Frontex has been avoiding its responsibilities for human rights violations during coordinated operations. Through the individual complaints mechanism this gap will be addressed effectively.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote on the European Ombudsman's Special Report on his own-initiative investigation into Frontex as, on the one hand, we are against frontex's role and we believe that this Agency should be rethinked and eventually dismantled. On the other hand, we did not vote against the report because it does not include any aspect which could strengthen Frontex's operations, but it does reflect the Conclusions of the European Ombudsman as regards the Agency's human rights obligations, including aspects which we consider fundamental, if not sufficient. Aspects of the report include individual complaint and reporting mechanisms for cases of human rights violations, fundamental rights, as they were not accepted to date. At the same time, measures are called for to improve guarantees and safeguards for human rights in the Agency's operations and the obligation of gender training is recommended before joining a Frontex operation, in particular to raise awareness of gender-based violence and the vulnerability of migrant women.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. I rejected the Report by Metsola & Keller on the European Ombudsman's proposal on Frontex. This report deals with the requirements for a complaint procedure following possible assaults by Frontex employees. The proposed procedure has been largely adopted from the procedural directives of other EU institutions, such as the ECB, which have very different and hardly transferable requirements to Frontex. In the past, it has been shown that a large proportion of the complaints against Frontex were insubstantial and that accusations of alleged human rights violations were baseless. A particularly critical attitude towards Frontex, as in some of the amendments to this report, is therefore not appropriate. As Frontex is to be extended and is expected to receive a wider mandate, the complaints procedure should also be included in the negotiations on the new mandate and adapted to the very specific needs of Frontex. This is the only way to ensure that Frontex has an appropriate complaints procedure which works permanently and does not restrict Frontex's important activities.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. A few days after the attacks in Paris on 23 November, the Civil Liberties Committee and the Committee on Petitions, convened as part of an expedited procedure, passed a resolution on Frontex to facilitate migrant complaints against border guards. This resolution provides that Frontex, the European border management agency, facilitates complaints from migrants about possible violations of their rights, even though they themselves are present in our territory illegally. The procedure also provides that third parties, such as heavily subsidised NGOs, can file complaints on behalf of migrants. To make matters worse, European MEPs are calling for an information campaign with migrants to make sure they will use this recourse... All this, of course, tends towards one goal: to further reduce the number of evictions, which are already almost zero. It seems important to monitor the votes of socialists and Republicans who have recently shown their firmness on immigration and security.  I therefore logically oppose the adoption of this text.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2012, the European Ombudsman opened an own-initiative investigation into Frontex's implementation of its fundamental rights obligations. In view of the growing humanitarian and legal challenges facing the EU at its external borders and the intensification of frontex's operations, a mechanism is needed to process individual complaints about alleged violations of fundamental rights occurring during the Agency's operations or cooperation with third countries, thus becoming a first instance body for lodging complaints. A mechanism for individual complaints can only be effective if both potential complainants and agents taking part in Frontex operations are informed of the right of individuals to submit complaints, through effective and gender-sensitive information, in the official languages of the EU, as well as in languages that asylum seekers and migrants understand. Establishing a transparent and effective mechanism for individual complaints would give citizens the opportunity to exercise their right to an effective remedy when their fundamental rights are jeopardised. The report concerns these issues, so I voted in favour of it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Frontex is responsible for ensuring the effective implementation of common rules on requirements and procedures for the control and detention of external borders, while respecting fundamental rights, through closer coordination of operational cooperation between Member States. As an integral part of its mandate, Frontex should also establish operational cooperation with non-EU countries in key areas such as information exchange, risk analysis, training, research and development, joint operations (including joint return operations) and pilot projects. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive, since I believe it ensures that human rights violations will not go unresolved. This is a strong message to Frontex that they have to follow the Fundamental Rights Charter.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree that the EU’s Frontex border agency should set up a system to handle complaints about alleged breaches of the fundamental rights of migrants and asylum seekers. With this I also supported the European Ombudsman’s recommendation. The mechanism should become ‘a first-instance body for complaints’, and I agree with the recommendation that any individuals who consider that their rights have been breached by border guards wearing the Frontex emblem should have the right to lodge a complaint. I also support the call on the Member States and the partner countries which have concluded working arrangements with Frontex to cooperate efficiently with the Agency in order to ensure the smooth running of the complaints mechanism, and a call for additional resources to ensure that the Frontex Fundamental Rights Office is adequately equipped and staffed to handle complaints.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The report supports the Ombudsman's recommendation that Frontex handle complaints concerning the violation of fundamental rights in the course of its operations. To this end, it suggests the development of a mechanism based on Article 26(a) of the Frontex Regulation. We are therefore talking about a topical issue, taking into account the current humanitarian crisis arising from the conflict in Syria, so I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of the report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I did not vote in favour of this report because I believe that Frontex's own activity, its militarisation and border defence work, inherently entails the permanent violation of fundamental rights. That is why, from my political group, we have tabled amendments to the report calling for the dismantling of Frontex, understanding that it would be the only effective way to end the systematic violations of human rights at EU borders, and thus making clear the frontal rejection of the United Left to Frontex. In addition, the approved mechanism, which seeks to give the possibility of bringing complaints for violations of fundamental rights in the context of the operations of this European Agency, suffers from a serious shortcoming, for which we also tabled amendments which were equally rejected: its lack of independence, since the Agency itself is responsible for the management of complaints committed by its agents.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With the current humanitarian crisis surrounding the movement of refugees into the European Union, the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (Frontex) is more vital than ever in order to ensure that EU borders are monitored and protected in line with the EU Fundamental Rights Charter. I support the European Ombudsman’s recommendation that Frontex should provide individuals with a transparent and accessible individual complaints procedure so that they can exercise their right to an effective remedy if their rights have been violated. This report establishes a framework for this complaints procedure and I was therefore happy to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'Our European Union urgently needs to improve its external borders. In order to do this, I believe it is necessary to give more opportunities and more powers to Frontex. Together with these powers, there will of course be more duties for this organisation. For example, we in the European Parliament want an individual complaints mechanism to be implemented. This individual complaints procedure should make it possible for refugees to address any human rights violations that have occurred during Frontex operations or in cooperation with third countries. After all, it is crucial that human rights are protected. That is why I voted in favour of this special report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims at establishing an incident reporting system and developing codes of conduct, as well as establishing an Advisory Forum on fundamental rights and an agent for fundamental rights. It also establishes a mechanism for submitting complaints about non-compliance with fundamental rights, including the rights of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers. There is, first of all, a first point to be pointed out in this document that it is the unequivocal recognition of the disrespect of human rights by frontex's action. This agency has increasingly become a supranational police force that is wary of the territorial sovereignty of the Member States and acts as a repressive force against citizens, in particular in the case of refugees and asylum seekers from North Africa and the Middle East, who arrive in Europe every day and suffer their repulsive action of xenophobic contours.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report leads to further bureaucracy. The report will add to the burden on Frontex, which will make it even more difficult for Frontex to carry out its actual tasks in the future. I therefore reject this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Ombudsman's recommendations on Frontex. I am convinced that it is necessary to facilitate the lodging of complaints by asylum seekers at a time when they suspect a violation of their fundamental rights. The Ombudsman's proposal is fully acceptable: Frontex must deal with complaints about alleged violations of fundamental rights in the course of its operations, the number of which has increased dramatically in recent months. In addition, Frontex must establish an independent mechanism for verifying these complaints, establish clear criteria for their admissibility and take appropriate measures against officials guilty of violations.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the European Ombudsman's Special Report on the frontex's own-initiative investigation. The report welcomes the European Ombudsman's own-initiative investigation into Frontex, as well as Frontex's ongoing efforts to respect fundamental rights more strictly. Among the proposals included in the report is the one establishing a mechanism capable of processing individual complaints concerning alleged violations of fundamental rights occurring during Frontex operations or cooperation with third countries, which will become a body of first instance for lodging complaints.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which supports the European Ombudsman's recommendation to set up a mechanism for Frontex to investigate complaints of fundamental rights violations during the Agency's operations. Parliament rightly points out in its resolution concrete measures for the proper functioning of the mechanism.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. The initiative report by Mrs Metsola and Mrs Keller demonstrates the House's commitment to human rights. The Ombudsman is right to express the need for a clear commitment to human rights and avenues of appeal in the event of non-compliance. But I also believe it is necessary to ensure the good work and good development of Frontex's operations and not to raise its administrative burden to unsustainable levels. It is also important to remember that Frontex is intrinsically linked to full respect and protection of fundamental human rights in fulfilling the task entrusted.  It is positive that human rights are guaranteed and there is a right of "complaint" in cases where abuses of some kind occur, provided that they are properly tested and justified. Frontex currently has its own mechanisms for ensuring respect for human rights at both Community and national levels.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament resolution on the recommendations made by the European Ombudsman in a special report on Frontex's obligations to respect fundamental rights. I believe that the European agency responsible for managing the Union's external borders should set up a mechanism for receiving complaints about violations of the fundamental rights of migrants and refugees. This is particularly important today, in view of the growing humanitarian and legal challenges at the EU's external borders.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I did not support the motion for a resolution on the European Ombudsman's special report on own-initiative inquiries in relation to Frontex. It goes without saying that fundamental rights must be protected, whether they are EU citizens or asylum seekers. At the same time, however, we must ask ourselves whether the proposed mechanism for the protection of fundamental rights is sufficiently thought out, adapted to the situation in question and whether the preconditions are to be effective. In this case, in my opinion, the proposal does not meet the various points. On the one hand, it is too detailed for some, in my opinion irrelevant, aspects of complaints, but on the other hand it does not address important issues such as the suspensive effect of lodging a complaint. The fact that the recommended mechanism works in the European Investment Bank, from which Frontex is proposed, does not guarantee that it will be equally suitable for Frontex, which has a completely different structure and scope and which is facing increasing pressure as a result of the migration crisis. Taking into account the role currently played by the Agency, I am of the opinion that it does not need to be burdened with unthinking mechanisms and requirements.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report follows the Special Report of the European Ombudsman following the OI/5/2012/BEH MHZ inquiry into the Frontex Agency, which aims to establish a system for reporting incidents and drawing up codes of conduct and also establishes a mechanism for submitting complaints concerning failure to comply with fundamental rights, including the rights of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers.  There is, first of all, a first point to be pointed out in this document that it is the unequivocal recognition of the disrespect of human rights by frontex's action.
