This agency has increasingly become a supranational police force that is wary of the territorial sovereignty of the Member States and acts as a repressive force against citizens, in particular in the case of refugees and asylum seekers from North Africa and the Middle East, who arrive in Europe every day and take repulsive action from xenophobic contours. What we are advocating is the abolition of the Frontex Agency and the entire EU-set up repressive system for the control of external borders. However, in the current situation it will be important, at least, to have a mechanism for filing complaints about attacks on fundamental rights. We abstained.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 European Parliament resolution on the European Ombudsman's special report on the own-initiative inquiry OI/5/2012/BEH-MHZ in relation to Frontex (2014/2215(INI)) whereas I agree that the provisions on the individual complaint mechanism should be included in the forthcoming review of the Frontex Regulation, which will allow individual complaints concerning alleged violations of fundamental rights to be hinged during Frontex operations. Above all, I also consider it justified to call for safeguards to be put in place at the same time to prevent abuse of the complaint mechanism, such as, inter alia, clear criteria for the admissibility of complaints (only complaints of infringements of fundamental rights as protected by EU law), the prohibition of anonymous complaints and the introduction of a standard complaint form where detailed information on the alleged infringement of fundamental rights must be provided.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I could not support this report for several reasons. This concerns cycling or the promotion of alternative modes of transport in suburban mobility, because, in my opinion, it is already, to some extent, beyond what can be regarded as a sensible European arrangement which does not contradict the principles of subsidiarity. In my opinion, it would be much more beused if these issues were entrusted to national arrangements. Not that I am an opponent of cycling or alternative modes of transport in the city, on the contrary, I consider them very appropriate, but I do not think it is necessary for this issue to be regulate by EU law or european parliament resolutions, but rather to be dealt with by nation states according to their own specific conditions.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Environmental protection has always been a costly and objective theme of European policies, which is why changing urban mobility patterns is all the more necessary and indispensable, given the current climatic conditions and the urgent need for action in this regard. The high proportion of gas emissions, the damage to citizens' health and the problems of road congestion are just a few examples of the catastrophic effects of excessive use of private cars powered by traditional fuels. New forms of environmentally sustainable transport, incentives for public transport, as well as the adoption of electric mobility projects could certainly reduce the impact of the above-mentioned problems, improving the well-being of society and citizens. For these reasons, I voted in favour

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. This Resolution is the answer to the support that this Commission wants to give to all common policies with an impact on cities, where most Europeans live. In the face of those who think that the Union's action does not fit in the urban environment, the Socialists are defending its relevance, and proof of this is that we get the Connecting Europe Facility or funds such as the EIES to finance urban nodes. We support this Resolution because we share many of the proposals for safer and more sustainable urban transport, accessible to all, and in which public transport plays a predominant role. However, we would have liked to nuance the reference to urban tolls. We understand that such actions have to be accompanied by measures of favorable discrimination for those who have been expelled from the center, as well as to prevent it from ending up being the exclusive ally of the affluent classes. Nor do we think it is right to support any form of mobility in the sharing economy, such as Uber, which puts sectors such as cooperatives and taxi self-employed people who do comply with social and labour legislation and provide a safe and quality public service against the ropes.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The improvement of urban mobility is an essential step in reducing global emissions, as well as improving air quality and traffic safety in European cities. Although the report's final proposal is unjust and contains contradictory elements, such as the absence of criticism of implicit deregulation in the "collaborative" economy or some voluntarism in addressing the energy transition, we believe that support for transport planning, intermodal integration and improved efficiency justify voting in favour.

name: Martina Anderson and Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report from Parliament’s Committee on Transport and Tourism. It is a positive and progressive report that proposes further development of sustainable transport, particularly public transport, to aid urban mobility in the EU. It discusses the need for, and ways to reduce conventional car use, carbon emissions and air pollution in European cities by promoting public transport. It does so without imposing solutions on Member States.  There were a small number of paragraphs that I voted against, including promotion of the ‘sharing economy’ (e.g. Uber) without any recognition of the problems that abound in this sector. I also voted against endorsing the ‘polluter pays’ principle in individual car use (Sinn Féin supports this principle for major polluters but not in the form of consumer taxes, for example the Irish carbon tax), and against endorsing road toll booth charges. Despite these small disagreements with elements of the text, the report was overwhelmingly positive and will result in mobility-related and environmental benefits for citizens in Ireland and the EU, so I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposes to combat pollution and noise in cities. No one is against it. However, it is surprising that this kind of problem can be dealt with by the European institutions with the help of urban mobility observatories, Commission action agendas or 'European mobility weeks', or concepts such as the 'shareable city'. And that's not to mention the myriad of expensive programs and "green growth" strategies! All this is wind and a lot of waste. This report, of course, aims to pave the way for supranational governance to regulate the behaviour of individuals and to punish "ecologically deviant behaviour". Measures such as "polluter pays" or the obligation to introduce speed limits of less than 30km/h in the city are thus promoted by this text. So I logically voted against it.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to refocus urban mobility on sustainable modes of transport in order to meet the challenges of our age: climate, health and environmental protection, the well-being and security of all. By 2050, almost 82% of all EU citizens are projected to live in urban areas. About 50% of EU citizens use private cars every day, only 16% use public transport and only 12% ride bicycles. EU citizens believe that lower public transport prices (59%), better quality of public transport services (56%) and better infrastructure for cyclists (33%) are the most effective tools for improving urban mobility. I agree that the main priorities for improving urban mobility should be: the return of space and infrastructure to all citizens and the improvement of accessibility, improvement of the environment, quality of life and health, energy saving and climate protection, innovation, more sustainable and safer urban mobility, reduction of external costs and ensuring higher quality investment, etc.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The primary objective of the Report on Sustainable Urban Mobility is to provide some solution to traffic congestion in the EU's major cities and the resulting GHG gas emissions. The report takes into account the opportunities available in greening. However, there are objectionable elements to the report. Ignoring the EU's geographical, development and cultural differences, it is thinking about urban development concepts, dictated and coordinated by the Commission, based on EU rules and regulations, moving beyond urban mobility. In this way, it limits the authority of governments to develop and apply development policies in their territory.  There is also a risk that local development policy coordinated by the Commission could adversely affect cities in central and eastern European countries. The application of the Transport 2050 strategy and the realisation of its objectives is a vain fantasy. It is not possible at EU level to halv the total use of conventionally driven vehicles by 2030 and to displace them completely from mobility by 2050. On the one hand, this is also a violation of citizens' personal freedom, and it would also mean limiting their right to free movement if, for financial reasons, they were unable to replace their old conventionally driven vehicles with electric ones.  Despite these objections, the report is overall positive and I therefore supported its adoption.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this report, which underlines the positive aspect of the work taken so far at European level in the organisation of sustainable urban mobility. In this regard, it highlights the importance of land use planning for the creation of well-organized, efficient and sustainable transport networks, as well as information and the association of all stakeholders (citizens, traders, transporters, etc.) to ensure transparency and efficiency in urban mobility projects.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Delli report, after a long process of conciliation between the different groups, has been acceptable to all in proposing a number of measures to address, inter extensions, the problem of pollution resulting from fossil fuel-propelled transport. While it has lost some definition in quantifying objectives related to the use of public or alternative means, it proposes numerous measures, integrated and coordinated at different administrative levels, aimed at protecting climate, health and the environment, as well as promoting well-being and safety. The goal is to promote smart and sustainable cities. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work done by the rapporteur on this report on sustainable urban mobility which we have discussed a great part of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. The work that has been done at European level and in many cities has been very positive and must be continued, and I therefore welcome the Commission's communication.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text where, once again, MEPs use good pretexts to create bad policies at the expense of the peoples and Member States. Thus, the Delli report on sustainable urban mobility, behind the laudable intention to combat urban pollution, lays the foundations for an urban policy led by the European Commission at the expense of municipalities managing the needs of their city and their inhabitants more to the facts. Urban mobility plans will have to be subject to the European Commission's timetables and objectives. In addition to this disregard for the principle of subsidiarity, the objectives set by the report, if carried by good intentions, will be achieved at the expense of the most modest households, who do not always have the means to invest in a vehicle with the latest standards in force or to buy a home near their workplace. Little by little, we are witnessing the victory of the "polluter pays" principle, which ignores social and economic realities. Finally, all the new measures proposed represent an inordinate cost that will not solve the concrete problems facing municipalities.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 While we can support positions, I find that some of the proposed solutions are poorly balanced and become possible sources of problems and critical issues in the near future. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This Resolution is the answer to the support that this Commission wants to give to all common policies with an impact on cities, where most Europeans live. In the face of those who think that the Union's action does not fit in the urban environment, the Socialists are defending its relevance, and proof of this is that we get the Connecting Europe Facility or funds such as the EIES to finance urban nodes. We support this Resolution because we share many of the proposals for safer and more sustainable urban transport, accessible to all, and in which public transport plays a predominant role. However, we would have liked to nuance the reference to urban tolls. We understand that such actions have to be accompanied by measures of favorable discrimination for those who have been expelled from the center, as well as to prevent it from ending up being the exclusive ally of the affluent classes. Nor do we think it is right to support any form of mobility in the sharing economy, such as Uber, which puts sectors such as cooperatives and taxi self-employed people who do comply with social and labour legislation and provide a safe and quality public service against the ropes.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with urban movements, i.e. traffic congestion, traffic regulation, safety of people on the streets and on the roads, environmental and health impacts, etc. Mobility is not an end in itself, but it should become the right of all citizens. 80% of Europeans will live in cities quickly, so mobility should enable everyone, including persons with reduced mobility, to learn, work, participate in cultural activities, have leisure time and access to healthcare. However, urban mobility is often seen as a constraint, the reason for which lies in the excessive use of private cars fuelled with conventional fuels. As a result, the transition to more sustainable modes of transport is very slow: the car remains the main means of our mobility, which travels 43% of the world and three quarters of journeys in Europe. Dependence on the car and its consequences are congestion on roads, with costs of EUR 80 billion in all European cities. 2015 by turning urban cities into prisoners of forced mobility (which cannot be chosen). The aim of this report is therefore to refocus urban mobility on sustainable modes of transport in order to meet the challenges of our age: climate, health and environmental protection, the well-being and security of all. Current and future urban mobility must focus on eco-mobility and cooperation networks. New urban driving practices, such as car sharing, are being developed and it is essential that such practices be included in the intermodal mobility chain alongside cycling, walking and collective transport.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution on the sustainability of urban mobility, which we also supported in the EPP Group, welcomes the European Commission's report on urban mobility, as significant progress has been seen in this area in recent years. With a focus on the importance of spatial planning and continued active work on reducing emissions by transport, innovation in sustainable transport, both freight and passenger transport, is also improving. Highly developed, efficient, affordable, safe and accessible public transport is a very important component of sustainable urban development. In Slovenia, too, we have problems with the efficiency of urban and long-distance public transport, and I am sure that many places can make significant improvements. I support the resolution and, at the same time, I hope that its recommendations will also be taken into account by the competent authorities in Slovenia.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on sustainable urban mobility, a document that combines a holistic approach to real and concrete objectives. Urban mobility is becoming increasingly important in Europe, where 80% of the population lives in urban centres. The report has the merit of fully focusing on the various aspects that touch on this issue, including the sustainability of urban transport planning, improving the quality of life of citizens, innovation and development. It is important to provide the necessary support to urban centres committed to providing safe services, the efficiency of which in terms of emissions contributes to achieving the Union's CO2 emission reduction target, as well as paying due attention to improving the quality of life of citizens, both in terms of the usability of services and in terms of health protection. It is good that it is emphasised that mobility and sustainable urban planning represent a particularly favourable environment for the development of new investment and growth opportunities.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that we need to look at ways to reduce conventional car use in order to bring down our carbon emissions and air pollution. This report promotes public transport which is the only way that we can effectively encourage people to move away from car use. In Ireland, only 8% of the population uses public transport at least once a day; this makes us one of the lowest users of public transport in the EU, second only to Cyprus. A recent survey showed that 50% of respondents cited cost as the main reason for their reluctance to use public transport. Given that the Irish public transport system is the least subsidised public transport system in the whole EU, is it any wonder that fares are so high as to be a barrier to use. It beggars belief that the United States subsidises its private transport system more than Ireland subsidises its public transport. Sustainable urban mobility will never be achieved if we refuse to invest in public transport.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposes to tackle air and noise pollution in city centres. On this principle, no one can object to it. On the other hand, the means put forward in this report to achieve this objective raise great substantive differences with our proposals.  Unlike the rapporteur, we do not consider that the European institutions are in the best position to reduce the level of pollution in urban areas. Supranational ecological governance would be bureaucratic and therefore counterproductive. The Commission uses such reports to grant itself additional prerogatives in order to impose scandalous measures on Member States and local authorities such as the obligation to drive at less than 30km/h in the city or the principle of alternating traffic.  We believe that this responsibility lies solely with national authorities and local authorities in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. That is why I voted against it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. Here's why: "We are facing a climate emergency" – False. CO2 emissions are deliberately used to pollute the debate and policies on polluting emissions from the transport sector.  "We are facing an emergency for the lives of road users!" – True, 38% of road accident deaths occur in urban areas. But that is not a good reason to ban vehicles from driving. "Another mobility is possible" – Some proposed recipes: elimination of diesel and petrol cars in urban centers by 2020 and petrol by 2050; total electrification of means of transport (translated: more expensive and inefficient means; owning one will once again be a vezzo from high aristocracy); planning a sharing economy (see voting list in § 20); "EU Sundays on foot"; general speed limit at 30 km/h; binding targets for the use of bicycles and public transport; double public transport networks (under austerity!); "ecological" tolls; generalize ecological urban logistics, combining it in particular with an increasing use of cargo bicycles, cargo barges, electric vans, freight and bus trams; the Commission's planning role in urban mobility plans developed by local authorities.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. This Resolution is the answer to the support that this Commission wants to give to all common policies with an impact on cities, where most Europeans live. In the face of those who think that the Union's action does not fit in the urban environment, the Socialists are defending its relevance, and proof of this is that we get the Connecting Europe Facility or funds such as the EIES to finance urban nodes. We support this Resolution because we share many of the proposals for safer and more sustainable urban transport, accessible to all, and in which public transport plays a predominant role. However, we would have liked to nuance the reference to urban tolls. We understand that such actions have to be accompanied by measures of favorable discrimination for those who have been expelled from the center, as well as to prevent it from ending up being the exclusive ally of the affluent classes. Nor do we think it is right to support any form of mobility in the sharing economy, such as Uber, which puts sectors such as cooperatives and taxi self-employed people who do comply with social and labour legislation and provide a safe and quality public service against the ropes.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report on sustainable urban mobility, as I am convinced of the need for an urgent definition of an ambitious regulatory framework on sustainable urban mobility, because global needs are ambitious, in terms of quality of life, health and climate protection.  I must point out, however, that, without regard to the opportunity for the European Union to be the protagonist at COP21 in Paris of the necessary political commitment on this issue, the systematic manipulation of legislation by European manufacturers and the ability of the car industry to delay the Union's climate and energy objectives and to improve energy efficiency are highlighted in many quarters. I therefore agree with the report, given that priority is given to its attention to energy saving and climate protection, to the need to restore space and infrastructure to all citizens and to improve accessibility, while respecting technological neutrality.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This was a positive report which contained a number of progressive provisions. It discusses the need for, and ways to reduce conventional car use, carbon emissions and air pollution in European cities by promoting public transport without imposing solutions on Member States.  There were some provisions contained within which I was concerned with. For example, I voted against point 48 which endorsed road toll booth charges. I also voted against point 47 which endorsed the ‘polluter pays’ principle in individual car use. Sinn Fein policy supports the ‘polluter pays’ principle for major polluters but not in consumer taxes, for example the Irish carbon tax.  However, as this was a progressive report with an important intention, I voted in favour of this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK has been working on projects for sustainable urban mobility for years. For example London introduced the ‘Boris Bike’ in 2010 and Manchester has continuously expanded its metro system and is delivering completion ahead of schedule and within budget. This report is the EU adopting an approach of ‘teaching your grandmother to suck eggs’. The call for the ban of all cars by 2050 is ludicrous and would lead to chaos. It is not for the EU to tell the subjects of the UK when and where they can use their cars.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it outlines measures which will help us achieve our resource efficiency and sustainable development objectives. Today most of our mobility is still based on cars despite all the steps that have already been taken to reduce this. We need to keep working on making our transport systems more intelligent and efficient.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to define a new model of urban mobility based on environmental, economic and social sustainability. At present, the use of private cars with traditional fuels is still predominant in urban mobility and urban transport is responsible for a quarter of greenhouse gas emissions. The text therefore emphasises the importance of prioritising clean forms of transport – such as trams, cable cars, bicycles, car sharing/pooling – by encouraging the adoption of plans for electric mobility and by promoting intermodality that combines walking and public transport. It also calls for energy efficiency to be placed at the heart of urban mobility policies in conjunction with COP21 and, alongside this, for a legislative package on 'transport and climate' to be drawn up. My vote was certainly in favour.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. – Adequate, sustainable urban mobility solutions hold a lot of potential in our efforts to address growing sources of inequality and achieve the EU climate change targets. We aim to halve the use of ‘conventionally fuelled’ cars in urban transport by 2030, and to eliminate their use by 2050. We also want to make carbon-free movement of goods a reality in major urban areas by 2050.  In order for this to happen, policymakers must promote mobility improvements that are efficient, sustainable and less dependent on the use of private, conventionally fuelled cars. Furthermore, the way the EU finances urban mobility projects cannot be focused solely on infrastructure. It must also encompass IT services and an increased focus on inter-regional projects. Funding application processes can often be tricky and burdensome, and there is room to make them more accessible and manageable by local authorities.  Urban mobility is not just about transport systems and emissions, people are the driving force of the economy. Transport workers and those in related sectors in cities are often overlooked. Their vital role in ensuring the quality and safety of public transport must be born in mind to ensure the sustainability of these essential services.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sustainable mobility is becoming one of the main themes of environmental policy for the impact on air quality and the inevitable impact on citizens' health. Making our cities more livable is a challenge that Europe has been facing for some time now and presents considerable difficulties, since it is a question of reconciling, on the one hand, the economic development of cities and the accessibility of their territory and, on the other, the quality of life and environmental protection. There have been a number of European regulations put in place; above all, we should mention initiatives such as the Covenant of Mayors or CIVITAS 2020 or programmes dedicated to the subject, such as URBAN or URBACT, to try to find solutions and define models capable of designing future mobility policies. Transport and climate are now an indivisible combination and I hope that during the work of COP 21, which is currently taking place in Paris, the issue of urban mobility, which is one of the greatest challenges of the coming years, will also be addresses. I voted in favour of this report because it identifies all the problems related to the subject and offers the European Commission important ideas for the development of future actions.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We agree with the report and support the position that mobility is not an end in it own right, but must be a right of all citizens. According to data, soon 80% of Europeans will be living in cities. Mobility should promote access for everyone including people with reduced mobility - to school, work, culture, entertainment and health. It is also important that urban mobility of the present and the future must and can be largely based on ecological mobility and cooperation networks.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on sustainable urban mobility addresses an issue that concerns the vast majority of European states, and is being discussed at a time when discussions on a new binding climate agreement have been formalised. The uncomfortable reality, which includes evidence of a continuous rise in gas emissions from 1990 to the present day and correlates around 400 thousand deaths a year with pollution issues, is at the same time inextricably linked to transport problems and malfunctions in the urban environment. In view of these elements, it is obvious that any proposal for mobilisation to improve conditions can and should be accepted in a positive mood. As I therefore believe that this proposal brings to the fore issues such as the protection of the environment and the health of citizens, especially urban areas, I have decided to support it.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I chose to support the measure. The report aims to redirect urban mobility towards sustainable modes of transport, with the aim of addressing the challenges of our century: the protection of the climate, health and the environment. Mobility is not an objective in itself, but it must be a right of all citizens. Car dependency costs are estimated at EUR 80 billion for all European cities. On the eve of the COP21 summit, the European Union, as well as the Member States and local authorities, must put energy efficiency at the heart of urban mobility policies. To this end, the rapporteur proposes that the European Commission start drawing up as soon as possible a legislative package on 'transport and climate' involving all stakeholders and, in particular, cities, so as to set binding targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the transport sector. The rapporteur also calls on the European Commission to make the granting of funding for urban mobility conditional on local authorities implementing sustainable urban mobility plans. Finally, it calls on the Commission to reserve 20% of European funds for sustainable urban mobility projects.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because the possibility of sustainable urban mobility is an issue to which I am particularly attached. Given that mobility is not an objective in itself, but must be a right of all citizens, I note that it is often seen as a burden, the cause of which is the excessive use of the private car powered by traditional fuels that reduce the possibility of environmentally friendly transport. I support this report because it aims to redirect urban mobility towards sustainable modes of transport, with the aim of addressing the objectives of our century that I want to help pursue: the protection of the climate, health and the environment. I feel called upon to contribute to the achievement of the objectives just listed, given that we are facing a climate emergency; Now that the fight against global warming is a global challenge and the organisation of our car-centred movements is preventing the European Union from participating fully in it, I feel that I am going against this trend. It is therefore necessary, through new development practices, to ensure that the mobility of today and tomorrow can be based mainly on ecomobility.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Sustainable urban mobility requires high-quality investment that will serve the general interest. This means that it can help achieve the EU’s resource-efficiency objectives, in particular those linked to the circular economy with its job-creating potential. Many European countries currently have to cope with dilapidated and costly infrastructure. In order to develop and maintain urban transport infrastructure, the main idea is to dedicate a part of EU funds such as the ERDF, CEF and Cohesion Funds to sustainable urban mobility projects. The Commission’s support is also needed for research and innovation projects linked to urban transport, through its research framework programmes (Horizon 2020) and the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI).

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK has been working on projects for sustainable urban mobility for years. For example London introduced the ‘Boris Bike’ in 2010 and Manchester has continuously expanded its metro system and is delivering completion ahead of schedule and within budget. This report is the EU adopting an approach of ‘teaching your grandmother to suck eggs’. The call for the ban of all cars by 2050 is ludicrous and would lead to chaos. It is not for the EU to tell the subjects of the UK when and where they can use their cars.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The concept of urban mobility is, nowadays, of great importance and timeliness. Soon, 80% of European citizens will live in cities, which changes the whole paradigm in the accessibility and mobility plans of European citizens, putting urban centres facing social, quality of life and sustainable development challenges. I believe that it is urgent to establish sustainable urban mobility plans, including all citizens, especially people with reduced mobility, and which is on the one hand of reducing car dependency in cities responsible for serious health, ecological and congestion problems and, on the other hand, in redrawing the way we travel in cities (both in the transport of people and goods). I share the concerns addressed in the Delli report and the solution suggestions put forward by the Committee on Transport and Tourism.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the initiative to help cities and municipalities achieve better sustainability in transport and improve network infrastructures across Europe. We need sustainable urban mobility with access to schools, jobs, cultural, leisure and health facilities. However, this access must indeed be possible. I therefore welcome the fact that some overly far-sighted demands – banning conventional cars in all inner cities and introducing car-free Sundays – have been removed.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK has been working on projects for sustainable urban mobility for years. For example London introduced the ‘Boris Bike’ in 2010 and Manchester has continuously expanded its metro system and is delivering completion ahead of schedule and within budget. This report is the EU adopting an approach of ‘teaching your grandmother to suck eggs’. The call for the ban of all cars by 2050 is ludicrous and would lead to chaos. It is not for the EU to tell the subjects of the UK when and where they can use their cars.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Urban mobility is a priority for the citizen nowadays, since we all have to move on a daily basis for a variety of reasons and unfortunately the vehicle we use the most is often the car, which does offer the advantage of comfort but which in turn has a considerable impact on the environment. Because of the excessive use of the car, we are facing a climate emergency: since 1990, in fact, there has been a 30% increase in greenhouse gas emissions, a component that is highly harmful not only to the climate itself but also to human health. In addition, in the field of road safety, 38% of accident deaths occur in urban areas. I firmly believe that funding must be given to local authorities in order to facilitate and encourage the implementation of sustainable local mobility plans, both in terms of people's movements and in terms of freight transport. That is why I voted in favour of this report, which aims to redirect urban mobility towards sustainable modes of transport, with the aim of addressing the challenges of our century: the protection of the climate, health and the environment, as well as the well-being and safety of all.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Many European countries have to cope with ineffective and costly urban transport infrastructure. In order to develop and maintain sustainable urban mobility, we need to dedicate a part of EU funds and Cohesion Funds to this. This plays an important role to achieve the EU’s resource-efficiency objectives, in particular those linked to the circular economy. The sustainable urban mobility concept does not represent a one-size-fits-all approach to urban transport planning. We need effective support from the Commission for urban transport research and innovation projects mentioned in the report, through research framework programmes like Horizon 2020 and the European Fund for Strategic Investment.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is the follow-up of the Commission communication on Urban mobility which encourages best practice exchanges and guidance for tackling urban mobility challenges. The report calls for supporting and promoting walking and cycling, sustainable urban mobility for workers who live far away from their workplace, reducing carbon emissions from transport in urban areas, and enhancing  road safety in urban areas.  Over the last months I have made it clear that I stand by our citizens’ aspiration for a healthier environment and lifestyle. Governments, city administrations and all other authorities involved need to up their game in helping our citizens towards such aspiration and a better quality of life, hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I applaud many of the aims of this report, it deals with a lot of issues that are best dealt with at local level, rather than a European one, and I cannot support it. The report goes far beyond the sharing of best practice in European cities, which I agree with, and instead makes a detailed and prescriptive list of recommendations. Some of these are merely impractical, whilst others, such as the banning of cars in all European cities by 2050, are completely unrealistic and restrictive on citizens’ everyday lives. I also fundamentally disagree with this report prescribing how Member States should use the revenue gained from road tolls. That is a national competence and should remain so.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to promote a new mode of urban mobility by mobilising the Union's financial instruments to develop and conserve urban transport infrastructure. The main idea is to set aside part of the European funds such as the ERDF, the Cohesion Fund, or Horizon 2020 and its European Strategic Investment Fund (EFSI), for sustainable urban mobility projects. However, in support of this objective, we have mobilised with my colleagues in the EPP Group to rebalance the rapporteur's approach, whose initial proposals were considered unrealistic, particularly with regard to the use of the car. I objected to several paragraphs in the vote on "Car-Free Sundays", drastic reductions in traditional fuel vehicles in cities or the use of part of toll revenue to improve urban mobility. Such decisions depend on the competence of Member States or local authorities, but should not be taken at European level, in accord with the principle of subsidiarity.  Nevertheless, considering that improving urban mobility through more varied and environmentally friendly modes of transport is a key challenge for our cities, I have spoken in favour of this text.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK has been working on projects for sustainable urban mobility for years. For example London introduced the ‘Boris Bike’ in 2010 and Manchester has continuously expanded its metro system and is delivering completion ahead of schedule and within budget. This report is the EU adopting an approach of ‘teaching your grandmother to suck eggs’. The call for the ban of all cars by 2050 is ludicrous and would lead to chaos. It is not for the EU to tell the subjects of the UK when and where they can use their cars.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this initiative report on sustainable urban mobility as part of the fight against global warming. A more sustainable and smarter management of the mobility of people and goods in Europe is indeed essential to improving the quality of life of European citizens.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The pursuit of sustainability and resource efficiency is essential in the long-term development of urban transport. Working together in Europe, efforts should be made to ensure the sustainability, preservation and development of the development of urban mobility, which in turn requires a high level of investment. These measures will have a positive impact not only on transport, but also on the economy and the labour market. Of course, there are many other positive effects that this development can have, such as a reduction in CO2 emissions, improvements in quality of life and health, the development of infrastructure and the promotion of innovation. It is necessary to set ambitious targets, which our regions and cities must work together to achieve.  Due to the excessive green nature of the original approach, the report needed to be redesigned several times. However, thanks to the amendments, a draft, which is also suitable and feasible for the majority, was achieved, which I personally supported with my vote.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. In a context of the intensification of metropolises on the one hand and, on the other, the need to link all territories together, I voted in favour of this resolution, which promotes soft urban mobility based on the development of reliable, intelligent, greenhouse gas-efficient and easily accessible public transport. As a former regional president, I have long advocated an integrated approach to mobility that limits the use of private transport solutions and reduces air, noise, accidents, traffic jams, etc. Intermodality must therefore be organized. The development of cities must accompany and anticipate new shared uses. Rates must be incentive and take into account the different time constraints of the day (race, school pick-up, etc.).  As President of the "public service" intergroup, I draw attention to the need to include all populations in this dynamic, those on the periphery of cities, but also those of the countryside, which often have no choice but to take their personal vehicle or, for lack of having it, to be assigned to house arrest and deprived of mobility which is known to be one of the factors of engagement.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report was to promote the reduction of noise, pollution and traffic jams in cities. While the objective is, of course, laudable, the proposed methods of remedying it are far from convincing. In particular, the report proposes 'European Mobility Weeks' or 'shareable cities'. Apart from the totally utopian and vague aspect of these proposals, the report seeks above all to promote supranational ecological governance. While the peoples of Europe all aspire more clearly every day to a newfound sovereignty, Europe is blithely flouting the principle of subsidiarity. The re-emergence of healthy, healthy city centres with limited traffic jams requires the development of a small local business and short circuits. However, this report proposes even more of the European Union without finding that it is very ineffective in the areas concerned. So I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 It takes an average of one and a half hours per day for each citizen to travel to and from work. In monetary terms, every hour on the road is 80% of that employee's hourly pay. On the other hand, the main pollutants in urban areas are private cars. That is why we must strive both to reduce harmful gases and reduce people's journey times to and from their workplaces. So far, no other way to reduce harmful gases has been found other than to switch from conventional fuels to biofues or electricity.  Of course, these measures will not be effective unless new ways of managing traffic are introduced. The introduction of ITS is a step towards this governance. We must, of course, also focus on protecting the health of both pedestrians and other road users. I support this report and hope to lay the foundation with it in creating a sustainable urban mobility that leads to less pollution, smaller travel intervals and, of course, fewer road deaths.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report as it proposes ways of doing things that will benefit both the environment and European citizens and improve public health and the standard of living, as well as the emergence of cities.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The pursuit of sustainability and resource efficiency is essential in the long-term development of urban transport. Working together in Europe, efforts should be made to ensure the sustainability, preservation and development of the development of urban mobility, which in turn requires a high level of investment. These measures will have a positive impact not only on transport, but also on the economy and the labour market. Of course, there are many other positive effects that this development can have, such as a reduction in CO2 emissions, improvements in quality of life and health, the development of infrastructure and the promotion of innovation. It is necessary to set ambitious targets, which our regions and cities must work together to achieve.  Due to the excessive green nature of the original approach, the report needed to be redesigned several times. However, thanks to the amendments, a draft, which is also suitable and feasible for the majority, was achieved, which I personally supported with my vote.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Soon, 80% of European citizens will live in cities. Mobility should therefore promote access for all, including people with reduced mobility, to school, work, culture, recreational activities and health care. Dependence on the car and its corollary, road congestion, which costs all European cities an estimated €80 billion, makes the inhabitants of cities prisoners of supported rather than chosen mobility.  While certain sectors, such as agriculture and industry, have reduced their greenhouse gas emissions, the transport sector has seen a 30% increase since 1990. While major cities in the European Union are experiencing the pace of pollution peaks, around 400 000 premature deaths are caused annually by particles emitted by the European car park. It should also be reported that 38% of deaths in road accidents occur in urban areas.  To this end, the European Union must set ambitious targets so that Member States and regional and local authorities can, together, implement this new sustainable urban mobility model by giving priority to electricity mobility plans, clean modes of transport: trams, cable cars, bicycles and car sharing.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it goes in the direction of supranational ecological governance.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report stresses the importance of defining sustainable urban mobility policies in order not to inhibit the development of cities, regions and countries, while ensuring the reduction of environmental impacts in the transport sector, better urban planning, improving health indices and social inclusion. Relevant objectives. The impact of transport on societies (especially urban ones, which by 2050 will concentrate on 85% of the EU population) is significant. The organisation of urban mobility is predominantly attributable to the car – 50% of eu citizens use their own cars on a daily basis, while only 16% use public transport and 12% use bicycles. The transport sector is therefore the only one that has not reduced greenhouse gas emissions. The report emphasises the promotion of quality and affordable public transport (including as a means of boosting urban economies and helping to combat poverty and social exclusion), the need to promote mobility plans, the use of alternative fuels, the improvement of pollution situations and their impact on human health (emission of air pollutants and noise pollution) and the reduction of accidents. A bottom-up approach is advocated, as opposed to the imposition of guidelines by the European institutions. Despite some shortcomings, we voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as the proposal makes sense to the general public.

name: Jacqueline Foster (ECR)
text: in writing. – Whilst well intentioned, this report presents a number of serious subsidiarity-based concerns for the UK delegation. In particular, the report deals with issues that are best dealt with at local level, and goes beyond the sharing of best practice in European cities in favour of a detailed and prescriptive list of recommendations, some of which are impractical, whilst others, such as the banning of cars in all European cities by 2050, are simply utopian. In particular, the report seeks to prescribe how Member States should use the revenue gained from road tolls and strays into issues such as the pricing of parking and asking local authorities to include environmental performance requirements as part of all their public procurement procedures.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on sustainable urban mobility. The report proposes ways of doing things that will benefit both the environment and European citizens and improve public health and the standard of living, as well as the image of cities.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Sustainable urban mobility has to be one of our main priorities and a key to boost the social and economic conditions in cities whilst preventing growing inequalities and fighting against climate change. Cities are the drivers of growth and economic activity, generating over 80% of EU GDP, but they are also often unequal places, with extreme divisions and with inadequate attention given to the needs of disabled people, the elderly, and others who are vulnerable. Supporting and promoting walking and cycling in particular should be a high priority. I support the Sustainable urban mobility plans as an important tool for providing adequate and safe mobility solutions for all citizens (including also persons with reduced mobility), improving quality of life in cities by fostering modal shift towards sustainable modes of transport, and promoting efficient, affordable, safe and accessible public transport as an integral part of sustainable urban development.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The pursuit of sustainability and resource efficiency is essential in the long-term development of urban transport. Working together in Europe, efforts should be made to ensure the sustainability, preservation and development of the development of urban mobility, which in turn requires a high level of investment. These measures will have a positive impact not only on transport, but also on the economy and the labour market. Thanks to the amendments, a draft, which is also suitable and feasible for the majority, was achieved, which I personally supported with my vote.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, mobility is not an objective in itself, but should be a right for all citizens. Soon, 80% of Europeans will live in the city, so we need to address this issue even more prominently.  Public transport is used by many people and it is vital for many that they operate and are accessible. This also applies to people with reduced mobility.  Therefore, priority should be given to clean modes of transport in electric mobility plans: trams, cable cars, bicycles and shared cars.  It is extremely important to note that not all Member States and local authorities yet have sustainable urban mobility plans. I support the rapporteur's call on the European Commission to tie the financing of urban mobility to the condition that local authorities develop a sustainable urban mobility plan by eliminating this shortcoming.  The rapporteur calls on Member States to ensure that sustainable urban mobility plans are developed and implemented in their urban areas and integrated into a broader, sustainable urban and territorial development strategy.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour considering that it is necessary and essential to support the transition to more sustainable modes of transport. Car dependence and traffic congestion make citizens captives of increasingly complicated mobility. It is time to bet on the protection of the climate, health and the environment, the well-being and safety of all European citizens.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. This Resolution is the answer to the support that this Commission wants to give to all common policies with an impact on cities, where most Europeans live. In the face of those who think that the Union's action does not fit in the urban environment, the Socialists are defending its relevance, and proof of this is that we get the Connecting Europe Facility or funds such as the EIES to finance urban nodes. We support this Resolution because we share many of the proposals for safer and more sustainable urban transport, accessible to all, and in which public transport plays a predominant role. However, we would have liked to nuance the reference to urban tolls. We understand that such actions have to be accompanied by measures of favorable discrimination for those who have been expelled from the center, as well as to prevent it from ending up being the exclusive ally of the affluent classes. Nor do we think it is right to support any form of mobility in the sharing economy, such as Uber, which puts sectors such as cooperatives and taxi self-employed people who do comply with social and labour legislation and provide a safe and quality public service against the ropes.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. This Resolution is the answer to the support that this Commission wants to give to all common policies with an impact on cities, where most Europeans live. In the face of those who think that the Union's action does not fit in the urban environment, the Socialists are defending its relevance, and proof of this is that we get the Connecting Europe Facility or funds such as the EIES to finance urban nodes. We support this Resolution because we share many of the proposals for safer and more sustainable urban transport, accessible to all, and in which public transport plays a predominant role. However, we would have liked to nuance the reference to urban tolls. We understand that such actions have to be accompanied by measures of favorable discrimination for those who have been expelled from the center, as well as to prevent it from ending up being the exclusive ally of the affluent classes. Nor do we think it is right to support any form of mobility in the sharing economy, such as Uber, which puts sectors such as cooperatives and taxi self-employed people who do comply with social and labour legislation and provide a safe and quality public service against the ropes.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Delli's report on sustainable urban mobility because I believe that it is today one of the greatest social and environmental challenges of our time. The increase in the urban population presents a series of commitments that relate not only to the quality of life, but also to the sustainable development of the territory, and it is therefore necessary to provide for responsible and effective urban planning in good time. At the opening of COP21, the Heads of State or Government of most countries of the world reaffirmed the importance of taking action to save our planet from environmental disasters. In this context, cities can also play a leading role, hoping for greater responsibility on the part of citizens and local administrators in the review of territorial environmental policies aimed at reducing pollution, promoting alternative fuels and building an ecological culture. It is therefore essential to rethink the models of land development, starting first and foremost from sustainable public transport which, on the one hand, reduces smog, noise pollution and road accidents and, on the other, undoubtedly improves the quality of life of citizens, especially those living in the most disadvantaged areas.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on sustainable urban mobility in Europe today because I believe that the orientation and focus of the paper is insufficient and partly wrong. Urban mobility is indeed a major challenge. Much more than has happened here, however, it must take into account the social aspect: how mobile are senior citizens? How much does mobility cost our families? Do our cities also make people with disabilities mobile? How does the interlocking of urban and rural areas and urban metropolises work? The report leaves many of these questions unanswered.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Sustainable transport is particularly important in urban transport. They can make a decisive contribution to achieving the EU's climate targets. However, this requires practical and, above all, feasible solution concepts. A blanket approach to the use of passenger cars is not a solution.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on sustainable urban mobility which covers the transport issues faced by people across the EU living in different urban communities. Good public transport has important social and economic benefits, as well as environmental ones, helping people gain access to jobs and get out of poverty.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the congestion in our cities has a profound impact on the quality of life of our citizens. The expansion of journey times, air quality and accident rates are some of the negative effects of a short-sighted mobility policy focused exclusively on personal car transport. Cohesion policy plays a key role in defining local government's mobility choices. The PON and POR absolutely must respond to the need for efficient and sustainable mobility of cities. When it came to smart cities, mobility is one of the sectors that promises radical change. The alternatives are different, the keywords must be public services and sharing.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Delli report, after a long process of conciliation between the different groups, has been acceptable to all in proposing a number of measures to address, inter extensions, the problem of pollution resulting from fossil fuel-propelled transport. While it has lost some definition in quantifying objectives related to the use of public or alternative means, it proposes numerous measures, integrated and coordinated at different administrative levels, aimed at protecting climate, health and the environment, as well as promoting well-being and safety. The goal is to promote smart and sustainable cities. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the report on sustainable urban transport because it contains numerous inaccuracies and shortcomings in discussing issues important for the introduction of sustainable transport in eu Member States. Promoting sustainable transport is important, in particular for urban agglomerations. The development of sustainable mobility can significantly improve the environment, quality of life and health of residents of European Union cities, or contribute to climate protection. Such initiatives are worthy of attention and support, but their development should pay particular attention to the innovation disparities in the economies of the EU Member States.  For this particular report, many key issues have been left unanswered or explicitly omitted. As a Member of the European Parliament, I could not therefore support an incomplete report from the vote, the legal, social and economic impact of which has not been fully analysed in relation to the Member States.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I understand the importance of urban mobility, which is why I voted for the overall report. Sustainable strategies that require investment are needed. It needs to move to the digitisation of transport and it needs to be decarbonised, but through investment and not by banning a certain type of fuel. That is why I did not vote on the amendment calling for an end to the subsidy of fossil fuel. The amendment didn't pass. I believe that we need to set targets that each Member State can meet through investment. For this reason, I did not vote for Amendment 32 Part 3. Reducing emissions is necessary to improve life, but we need to gradually set targets that can be sustained by investment without harming jobs.

name: Karoline Graswander-Hainz (S&D)
text: Writing. The SPÖ delegation voted against Amendment No 1 in the vote on the own-initiative report on sustainable urban mobility, as we believe that diesel can serve as an important bridge fuel until there is a real alternative to fossil fuels. The tax advantage of diesel over petrol is therefore quite justified, in part because diesel produces less CO2 emissions. At the same time, however, we are, of course, very concerned about the promotion of alternative fuels. In the long term, our aim must be to completely replace fossil fuels with alternative fuels.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. This Resolution is the answer to the support that this Commission wants to give to all common policies with an impact on cities, where most Europeans live. In the face of those who think that the Union's action does not fit in the urban environment, the Socialists are defending its relevance, and proof of this is that we get the Connecting Europe Facility or funds such as the EIES to finance urban nodes. We support this Resolution because we share many of the proposals for safer and more sustainable urban transport, accessible to all, and in which public transport plays a predominant role. However, we would have liked to nuance the reference to urban tolls. We understand that such actions have to be accompanied by measures of favorable discrimination for those who have been expelled from the center, as well as to prevent it from ending up being the exclusive ally of the affluent classes. Nor do we think it is right to support any form of mobility in the sharing economy, such as Uber, which puts sectors such as cooperatives and taxi self-employed people who do comply with social and labour legislation and provide a safe and quality public service against the ropes.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was decided by the fact that mobility can provide a vital boost for our economy and if we are to deliver economic growth. With this in mind, we want to promote inter-modality and co-modality in a way that can deliver more sustainable and efficient urban transport modes. We should also encourage cooperation, sharing of best practices and integration of innovation and digitalisation into forthcoming mobility planning.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The pursuit of sustainability and resource efficiency is essential in the long-term development of urban transport. The investment needs for urban mobility development through joint European work are extremely high. Therefore, these measures will have a positive impact not only on transport, but also on the economy and the labour market. Of course, these improvements can also have a number of other positive effects, such as a reduction in CO2 emissions, improvements in quality of life, the development of infrastructure and the promotion of innovation. It is necessary to set ambitious targets, which our regions and cities must work together to achieve. Due to the overly 'green' approach of the original approach, the report needed to be redesigned several times. However, thanks to the amendments, a draft that is acceptable and feasible to the majority has been achieved.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because mobility should be a right for all citizens. Mobility will assist in making access to school, work, culture and health easier for all. The transformation to more sustainable modes of transport is very important looking into the future. The majority of our mobility is based on cars which bring negative consequences such as road traffic congestion at a very high cost for European citizens, roughly EUR 80 billion. This report will aim to redirect urban mobility towards more sustainable modes of transport with the goal of facing up to the challenges of our century, mainly protecting the climate, health and environment as well as the well-being and security of citizens.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK has been working on projects for sustainable urban mobility for years. For example London introduced the ‘Boris Bike’ in 2010 and Manchester has continuously expanded its metro system and is delivering completion ahead of schedule and within budget. This report is the EU adopting an approach of ‘teaching your grandmother to suck eggs’. The call for the ban of all cars by 2050 is ludicrous and would lead to chaos. It is not for the EU to tell the subjects of the UK when and where they can use their cars.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report focused on promoting new sustainable transport modes in cities, with a focus on environmental aspects, a prioritisation of cyclists and pedestrians, and a better use of European funds and sustainable urban mobility plans. The key issue of the draft report for the ECR was a set of paragraphs undermining the subsidiarity principle of Member States. Furthermore our shadow rapporteur was keen to reduce any excessive promotion of electric vehicles by respecting a technology neutral approach. A strong opposition block was formed by the PPE, the ECR and ALDE during the negotiations. We decided to abstain. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished, because it leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The pursuit of sustainability and resource efficiency is essential in the long-term development of urban transport. Working together in Europe, efforts should be made to ensure the sustainability, preservation and development of urban mobility. This requires a high level of investment. This will have a positive impact not only on transport, but also on the economy and the labour market. In addition, development can have a number of other positive effects, such as a reduction in CO2 emissions, improvements in quality of life and health, the development of infrastructure and the promotion of innovation.  It is necessary to set ambitious targets, which our regions and cities must work together to achieve. In view of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK has been working on projects for sustainable urban mobility for years. For example London introduced the ‘Boris Bike’ in 2010 and Manchester has continuously expanded its metro system and is delivering completion ahead of schedule and within budget. This report is the EU adopting an approach of ‘teaching your grandmother to suck eggs’. The call for the ban of all cars by 2050 is ludicrous and would lead to chaos. It is not for the EU to tell the subjects of the UK when and where they can use their cars.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully agree with the view that land planning is crucial to creating long-term, efficient and safe transportation networks that will have a strong impact on traffic volumes. Safety is essential to the development of any sustainable urban projects. Furthermore, all stakeholders, especially EU citizens, must be consulted and informed in order to ensure transparent planning, development and decision-making of urban development strategies. Thus, I would like to call upon the Member States to construct sustainable urban mobility plans.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Sustainable Urban Mobility Report, as I believe that the EU actions taken so far have been very successful and positive in this regard, so they should continue. Large cities and urban centres face daily societal challenges, quality of life and sustainable development challenges, including urban mobility and transport playing a significant role. This report aims to improve environmental protection, quality of life and health, and also focuses on many interesting innovations that smartly approach urban mobility.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text starts with good intentions (fighting urban pollution). However, it is questionable whether the European institutions are in the best position to remedy the problems set out. The principle of subsidiarity is the case: anything that is not the exclusive competence of the Union can only be returned to it if its institutions are better placed to know about a file. However, it is the municipalities that are in a greater able to address these issues. The un avowed aim of this kind of text is to pave the way for supranational ecological governance. The Commission wants to increase its prerogatives and impose inconsistent measures that will weigh on low-income households who cannot afford, among other things, a vehicle to the latest standards in force. In addition, there is the requirement for municipalities to introduce speed limits of 30 km/h in the city, as well as alternating traffic. My colleagues from the National Front called in committee for the principle of subsidiarity to be fully respected and recalled that improving traffic flow requires the rescue of small shops in the city centre and the return to short circuits. I voted against the resolution.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The UK has been working on projects for sustainable urban mobility for years. For example London introduced the ‘Boris Bike’ in 2010 and Manchester has continuously expanded its metro system and is delivering completion ahead of schedule and within budget. This report is the EU adopting an approach of ‘teaching your grandmother to suck eggs’. The call for the ban of all cars by 2050 is ludicrous and would lead to chaos. It is not for the EU to tell the subjects of the UK when and where they can use their cars.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Communication presented by the European Commission and this report focus on environmental and safety issues. These are undoubtedly important problems, which is why I voted in favour of the report. In my opinion, however, these documents do not refer to the impact that sustainable and well-organised public transport has on improving the labour market. We must not forget that, for many people, public transport is the only means of communication to reach the workplace. Therefore, the effectiveness of measures taken to combat poverty and social exclusion is determined by the development of public transport in urban centres and suburban areas.  Very often it turns out that the barrier to getting out of unemployment is the cost of getting to the workplace or the time that needs to be spent on it. The problem is that these dependencies are often not recognised, both at local and EU level. If we want to achieve the Europe 2020 targets for increasing employment and reducing social exclusion, we need to focus more on the development of efficient and sustainable public transport. This is all the more important because forecasts show that in the near future more than 80% of Europeans will live in urban areas and, consequently, the problems that already exist today will increase over time.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Karima Delli's report on sustainable urban mobility. I believe that a balance must be struck between the social, environmental and economic impacts of transport and between meeting the needs of current and future generations. While the rapporteur's initial approach was not acceptable because of sometimes unrealistic and demagogic proposals, the EPP negotiators managed to reach balanced compromises. This text was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D)
text: Writing. The SPÖ delegation voted against Amendment No 1 in the vote on the own-initiative report on sustainable urban mobility, as we believe that diesel can serve as an important bridge fuel until there is a real alternative to fossil fuels. The tax advantage of diesel over petrol is therefore quite justified, notably because diesel produces less CO2 emissions. At the same time, however, we are, of course, very concerned about the promotion of alternative fuels. In the long term, our aim must be to completely replace fossil fuels with alternative fuels.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining from this report. While the report contains positive aspects in its desire to introduce a new transport concept for major European cities, which should also promote the development of public transport and the use of alternative car propulsion systems, the report also contains proposals which are to be classified as unrealistic or which would disproportionately discriminate against motorists.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The pursuit of sustainability and resource efficiency is essential in the long-term development of urban transport. Working together in Europe, efforts should be made to ensure the sustainability, preservation and development of the development of urban mobility, which in turn requires a high level of investment. These measures will have a positive impact not only on transport, but also on the economy and the labour market. Of course, there are many other positive effects that this development can have, such as a reduction in CO2 emissions, improvements in quality of life and health, the development of infrastructure and the promotion of innovation. It is necessary to set ambitious targets, which our regions and cities must work together to achieve.  Due to the excessive green nature of the original approach, the report needed to be redesigned several times. However, thanks to the amendments, a draft, which is also suitable and feasible for the majority, was achieved, which I personally supported with my vote.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the goal of facing up to the current environmental challenges by reducing urban mobility towards more sustainable modes of transport. The climate, health conditions, the road user’s life and social cohesion demand urgent action. Even if there are considerable improvements in this matter, urban mobility is still experienced as a constraint arising from over-reliance on private cars powered by traditional fuels. By rethinking the way in which we conceive urban mobility and by shifting to more sustainable modes of transport, we can deal more effectively with these challenges. This is the reason why I voted in favour.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. This report aims to redirect urban mobility towards sustainable modes of transport in order to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Of course, I can only agree with that objective. We are, in fact, on the eve of COP21 and it is imperative to give a strong signal, demonstrating that Europe is doing, and will do in the future, everything possible to promote the well-being and safety of its citizens. We need, now more than ever, to change our habits, and the gradual design of greener modes of transport is another step in the right direction.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I believe that improving the flow of urban traffic should continue to be the responsibility of municipalities and public institutions of inter-communal cooperation. The Union really meddles in everything, the principle of subsidiarity no longer has any reality!

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This Resolution is the answer to the support that this Commission wants to give to all common policies with an impact on cities, where most Europeans live. In the face of those who think that the Union's action does not fit in the urban environment, the Socialists are defending its relevance, and proof of this is that we get the Connecting Europe Facility or funds such as the EIES to finance urban nodes. We support this Resolution because we share many of the proposals for safer and more sustainable urban transport, accessible to all, and in which public transport plays a predominant role. However, we would have liked to nuance the reference to urban tolls. We understand that such actions have to be accompanied by measures of favorable discrimination for those who have been expelled from the center, as well as to prevent it from ending up being the exclusive ally of the affluent classes. Nor do we think it is right to support any form of mobility in the shared economy that puts sectors such as cooperatives and self-employed people in other sectors that comply with social and labour legislation and provide a safe and quality public service against the ropes.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The improvement of urban mobility is an essential step in reducing global emissions, as well as improving air quality and traffic safety in European cities. Although the report's final proposal is unjust and contains contradictory elements, such as the absence of criticism of implicit deregulation in the "collaborative" economy or some voluntarism in addressing the energy transition, we believe that support for transport planning, intermodal integration and improved efficiency justify voting in favour.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the proposals put forward in The Report by Advocate Karime Delli. Sustainable urban transport requires investments in infrastructure that will serve the general interest, which means that it can help achieve the efficiency targets of EU resources. This Report aims to redirect urban mobility towards sustainable modes of transport to meet the challenges of today.
