I also support the Commission's call for 20% of the European Union's funding for urban mobility projects. Member States are currently coping with dilapidated and expensive infrastructure. The rapporteur proposes that 50 per cent of Eurovignette's revenues should be invested to improve urban mobility and that 75 per cent of urban tolls be used to develop and maintain urban transport infrastructure.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today, the European Parliament adopted a resolution calling on the Member States and the Commission to promote sustainable urban mobility. The approach aims at moving to resource-efficient transport systems, as well as significantly reducing pollution and congestion in cities. The trend towards an increase in the urban population will not change in the near future. This necessitas the need for specific policies for urban mobility and work at the same time to provide sufficient parking spaces and accessible, fast and environmentally friendly public transport. Urban mobility projects are usually large and expensive endeavors. European Union co-financing is therefore key.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The proportion of the population living in cities is growing. There is therefore a need to urgently address urban mobility issues. The deteriorating environment and the natural requirement of safety require a focus on promoting public, clean transport, with an emphasis on electric mobility. Addressing these problems requires thorough, forward-looking urban spatial and transport planning and increasing support for integrated transport.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on sustainable urban mobility, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 2/12/2015, and because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This text is totally contrary to the principle of subsidiarity and intolerably increases the prerogatives of the European Commission. However, in Brussels, the EU is not in the best position to combat pollution and noise in the city centres. Worse, the inappropriate measures she suggests will affect low-income households who do not have the resources to afford a car that meets the latest standards, or to buy a home near their workplace. As is often the case, the Union works outside its competence, tackling the wrong people, with the wrong methods.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report on sustainable urban mobility. Urban transport is the source of up to 25% of all CO2 emissions and is a sector in which greenhouse gas emissions continue to increase. It should also be noted that, according to the 2013 Special Eurobarometer 406, only 16% of European citizens use public transport, while 50% of them use a car daily. The environment in cities is thus constantly deteriorating, which has a negative impact on human health, and I have not yet mentioned the number of road accidents affecting, in particular, unprotected road users and the noise that is also related to transport. The report supports the construction of cycle paths as well as increased support for rail transport and calls for the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Proper coordination of mobility and spatial planning must go hand in hand with this. I supported the report in the final vote.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I very much welcome the adoption by this Plenary of the proposal for a Resolution on Sustainable Urban Mobility, one of the main objectives of which is to restore space and infrastructure to all citizens and improve accessibility. I also welcome the commission's adoption of the European Accessibility Act in time. We must improve the environment and the quality of life and health in our cities and take steps to protect the climate, as is being discussed in Paris, as well as to save energy. And we must finally achieve more sustainable, secure and secure urban mobility.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Urban mobility has increased rapidly in recent years and unfortunately this rate is projected to continue, reaching 82% of the population living in urban centres by 2050. This creates huge problems on the roads because of the use of a private car by the majority of citizens. The problem is particularly evident in Cyprus where public transport is used by a very small number of citizens, mainly foreigners, while the vast majority use private cars creating serious car congestion and air pollution. Fully aware of the impact of excessive use of private cars on health, safety and environmental protection, I am voting in favour of the report on sustainable urban mobility in the hope of taking measures to tackle this social and economic problem. Some of these measures, as the report itself rightly states, are the use of alternative energy sources avoiding the use of fossil fuels, but also the incentive to citizens to use public transport such as buses, in order to deal with the negative consequences mentioned above. Reducing transport costs is a good example in this direction.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, the report contains a number of points which are to be welcomed. A new (sustainable) transport concept for major European cities is urgently needed. The rapporteur makes some good proposals on this (promoting local public transport, promoting alternative propulsion for vehicles, etc.); however, the report also contains a number of points which discriminate against motorists or are simply unrealistic. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Almost 82% of EU citizens will live in urban areas by 2050. Urban transport accounts for 25% of total CO2 emissions, and is the only sector where greenhouse gas emissions have been steadily increasing since 1990.  The report aims to reverse this trend. To do this, he proposes to rely on "land use planning" but without questioning urban sprawl. He cites the "low-emission" modes of transport to be developed - electric traction or alternative fuels - but without setting a target. Then comes a list of anecdotal measures to "promote the provision of digital services in public transport and in stations" while "also taking into account the linguistic needs of tourists". All this without condemning the use of fossil fuels, which are directly implicated in the 400,000 premature deaths linked to fine particulate matter.  In short, it is a vague text, certainly full of good intentions, but totally inoperative in this matter. I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The objectives of combating pollution, noise in city centres or reducing congestion are laudable, but the means proposed by this report ("action agendas", "Urban Mobility Observatory", concept of "shareable city", "green growth strategies") appear inadequate. Moreover, the European institutions do not seem to be the most capable at the appropriate to respond to these concrete problems facing municipalities. Thus, in view of the inappropriate measures supported by the Commission and the non-compliance with the principle of subsidiarity, I am voting against this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have presented my vote in favour of the proposal on sustainable urban mobility. Mobility is a right of all citizens. If we think that around 80% of European citizens will live in cities in the near future, it is extremely important that there is a reorientation of urban mobility, especially with regard to more sustainable modes of transport. Protecting the climate, health, the environment, well-being and safety are 21st century challenges that the EU must ensure. Climate warming requires a reversal of behaviors. It is up to the EU to give a clear signal that combating this phenomenon is not pure rhetoric. Emissions targets by 2030 must be met.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it suggests strategies for sustainable urban development in terms of transport infrastructure.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Due to increasing urbanisation, 82% of EU citizens will soon be living in an urban environment. Together, these inhabitants guarantee almost 85% of Europe's GDP. Cities are important engines of innovation and economic growth and in the city we still find the best opportunities for work, education, cultural activities and hospitality. But the increasing mobility pressure and the finding that urban transport is responsible for 25% of CO2 emissions threatens to affect the vitality of the city. In order to maintain and support the dynamism of cities, new and sustainable models of urban mobility are needed.  New transport plans for the city will therefore primarily use low-carbon transport modes that connect to an urban grid of smart transport hubs that allow the quick and easy transition from one mode of transport to another. In drawing up sustainable transport plans, a good balance must always be sought between the ecological and social consequences of a mobility plan and the needs of the inhabitants and visitors of the city, all without sputtering the economic engine of the city.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ The trend of urbanisation and the need to increase mobility in cities where up to 70% of the European population lives and which account for around 85% of GDP is irreversible and requires increased attention from the professional and lay public. The aim of the report is to find new ways of simplifying and accelerating urban mobility and moving towards less polluting and more sustainable modes of transport, in particular in order to protect human health, the environment and the climate, while striking a rational balance between social, environmental and economic aspects. I believe that it is in our interest and in the interests of the future of our children to set ambitious targets and allocate adequate European funds to sustainable urban mobility projects.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Sustainable urban mobility is a key to boost the social and economic conditions in cities whilst preventing growing inequalities and to fight against climate change. Cities are the drivers of growth and economic activity, generating over 80% of EU GDP, but they are also often unequal places, with extreme divisions and with inadequate attention given to the needs of disabled people, the elderly and others who are vulnerable. Therefore, I fully support the report which in my opinion provides valuable recommendations for the improvement of future sustainable urban areas.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Transport and Tourism has proposed a resolution to the European Parliament on sustainable urban mobility. In its report, the Committee points out that 80% of Europeans will soon live in cities.  While mobility should be a right for all citizens, the excessive use of conventional fuel cars and the associated road congestion limit this right. For 43% of the kilometres travelled in the world and three quarters of european journeys, the main means of mobility are cars; the overall annual additional cost of road congestion in European cities is estimated at around EUR 80 billion.  At the same time, 50% of journeys within the urban zone do not exceed 5 kilometres, i.e. they could easily be made on foot, by bicycle or by public transport. The aim of the report is therefore to steer urban mobility towards sustainable modes of transport. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report presents ways to combat pollution and noise in city centres, as well as solutions to reduce congestion. We agree that solving these problems is a priority in the development of urban areas. However, we believe that the European institutions do not have the competence to respond to these problems, firstly out of respect for the principle of subsidiarity, and above all because the obvious objective of this text is supranational ecological governance. The Commission would be given new powers and could thus impose technocratic measures which, once again, would only impact the middle classes, already suffering from the crisis and austerity. Our position to smooth the flow of the city centres is first of all to preserve small shops and to recreate short circuits in line with cultural and local specificities.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on sustainable urban mobility. This text recommends that the European Union contribute, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, to develop an integrated and long-term approach to urban mobility aimed at reducing pollution, congestion and road accidents in cities. The aim is to put in place better coordination between the European Union, in charge of the common urban policy, and the local and regional authorities, which are responsible for the management of urban transport. The report points out that an estimated 82% of EU citizens will live in urban areas by 2050. This strong urban growth means ensuring that efficient transport is planned to improve the quality of life of European citizens.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that 75% of Europeans live in urban centres and that the phenomenon is on the increase, I welcome the proposal to improve the quality of city life. The optimisation of urban transport networks, with a particular focus on sustainable mobility, would have a positive impact on the social and environmental problems facing European centres. Accessibility of transport, especially for the most vulnerable groups such as the disabled, the elderly and low-income families, is a fundamental means of social inclusion. In fact, urban centres, responsible for 80% of Europe's GDP, are all too often characterised by high levels of inequality and lack of social integration. The weakest sections of the world are also the most exposed to the risks of air pollution, which, every year, kills more than four hundred thousand people. Urban mobility, characterized by a preponderance of diesel vehicles and burdened by the massive use of private cars, is responsible for 25% of total emissions and 70% of those emitted in cities. The report is therefore consistent with the European Union's position on the international stage and, in particular, strengthens its role at the Paris Conference. In addition, I strongly support the call for the European Commission to take note of and catalyse the reality of collaborative consumption.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report by Mr Beazley on be it is a good one. Delli proposes that the Commission start drawing up a transport and climate legislative package as soon as possible, involving all stakeholders, with a view to setting binding targets for reducing gas emissions in the transport sector. Some of the objectives in the text concern the diesel ban in 2020, the gradual reduction of petrol cars in 2030 and their elimination from 2050. I believe that the European Union must set itself ambitious targets so that Member States and regional and local authorities can jointly commit themselves to reducing pollution and implementing a new model of sustainable urban mobility. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report, as I am sure that environmentally friendly forms of transport need even more support than at present. Greenhouse gas emissions in the transport sector have increased by 30% in the last 25 years, a growing trend that we need to tackle at EU level. We must promote the widest possible use of environmentally friendly forms of public transport, while encouraging people in our cities to make the most of public transport. We must also make sure that technologies based on non-internal combustion engines gain as much ground as possible in the propulsion of urban road transport vehicles. In addition to positive environmental impacts, these environmentally friendly solutions can make a major contribution to the reduction of the EU's external energy dependency in the long term.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Urban mobility is often experienced as a constraint arising from over-reliance on private cars powered by traditional fuels. I voted for this report that calls for a faster shift to more sustainable modes of transport taking into consideration that today the mobility of EU citizens is still essentially based on cars.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on urban mobility, inter alia, because, in my opinion, it is necessary to look for ways towards sustainable modes of transport and to create conditions for higher use of alternative means of transport and less polluting vehicles, taking into account their actual carbon footprint. I am also in support of the development of non-motorised transport in cities, the creation of better conditions for pedestrians and cyclists, and initiatives such as the European Mobility Week. Urban air pollution poses significant health risks to their inhabitants and ultimately reduces the quality of life in cities.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report. The rapporteur calls for the number of conventional lyronations (petrol or diesel) vehicles used in public transport to be halved by 2030 and for they to be phased out from cities by 2050. Cities are severely curtailed in their sovereignty, and no alternatives are mentioned. However, the report also contains very good approaches, such as the promotion of public staff transport or the promotion of alternative propulsion in vehicles.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the establishment of a European roadmap for the energy transition of urban public transport. Given that 80% of Europeans will be urban dwellers by 2050, alternatives to the 'all-road' need to be developed, ensuring that these solutions are sustainable and environmentally friendly. To this end, the rapporteur proposes a series of objectives, including the promotion of sustainable initiatives such as carpooling, the modal deferral of the road to river or rail routes for the transport of goods or the abolition of diesel subsidies.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In a situation where almost half of urban transport is carried out by cars, congestion is a daily phenomenon that in turn pollutes the environment, restricts movement and people off, and therefore proposals are being made to redirect urban mobility to sustainable modes of transport in order to protect the climate, health and the environment.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. Transport ensures our mobility. Urban mobility is an important part of transport policy making. The changing urban transport system must ensure the mobility needs of each population and the accessibility of urban areas at the shortest distance and at the lowest cost of time, protecting the environment and improving quality of life.  The development of sustainable and environmentally friendly urban transport strategies and sustainable mobility plans must therefore be encouraged. It should be noted that the development of sustainable mobility plans is an important element in the financing of EU projects in the field of urban transport. It is essential that efsi is systematically used for the development and implementation of comprehensive and integrated sustainable urban mobility plans.  Urban mobility should contribute to the EU's resource efficiency targets, to reducing air pollution, noise, greenhouse gas emissions and energy consumption. However, I do not believe that the high consumption of diesel in the European Union has been caused by favourable tax rules, and I do not support the proposal, which calls for immediate action to phase out subsidies for fossil fuels.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The UK has been working on projects for sustainable urban mobility for years. For example London introduced the ‘Boris Bike’ in 2010 and Manchester has continuously expanded its metro system and is delivering completion ahead of schedule and within budget. This report is the EU adopting an approach of ‘teaching your grandmother to suck eggs’. The call for the ban of all cars by 2050 is ludicrous and would lead to chaos. It is not for the EU to tell the subjects of the UK when and where they can use their cars.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am glad that just today, while COP21 has been started a few days ago, we have the opportunity in this House to debate and vote on this document: greater sustainability of urban mobility improves not only many aspects of the daily lives of our citizens, but also makes it possible to use our efforts for a healthier environment, which pollutes less and which contributes to the achievement of the objectives that the world's great leaders have set themselves for the climate. , and that we ourselves hope that they can be achieved. I am pleased to be able to contribute with my vote to an issue that is very close to my heart, I would vote in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Sustainable urban mobility is an important element of improving citizens’ quality of life, strengthening the economy and, thus, achieving a more sustainable development on a regional and European level. In Bulgaria, concrete steps are being taken towards the implementation of the green city philosophy but much work is left to be done. That is why I am in favour of the report and the dedication of part of EU funds for sustainable urban mobility projects.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agreed with the report, though I consider more ambition is needed on urban mobility – as cities concentrate most of the population and generate most of the air pollution as well.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. I supported this report because I think that the personal contribution of each of us, the citizens of Europe, but also the whole world is equally important no matter where we live. Our personal contribution to reducing pollutant emissions into the environment, as well as reducing greenhouse gas emissions may seem insignificant from the point of view of personal consumption and personal contribution in relation to the world scale, but if we view this contribution cumulatively as the aggregated contribution of each individual inhabitant of Europe, and we all drive over 220 million passenger vehicles together (often because of our personal commotion), then we must ask ourselves if we are acting responsibly towards the community and the future of our children.  Well-regulated public transport, accessible to most people can bring change. Each city area is unique, the conditions and possibilities are different, but there are also numerous similarities. I welcome the development of a platform that will enable the exchange of experience and best practices between cities. I call on all decision-makers at local and regional level to take advantage of this opportunity to share their good and bad experiences and identify strategies that will make transport in cities more sustainable than it is today.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support Mp Della's report on sustainable urban mobility. Greenhouse gas pollution, high noise levels and unsustainable daily traffic congestion are an extremely difficult problem for large urban areas in the EU. Likewise, each city has specific characteristics and needs and therefore must be viewed separately. For this reason, there is no universal solution, but each member must create its own package of measures to reduce pollution caused by urban transport. Urban transport is responsible for 70% of CO2 emissions in urban areas and is the only sector in the European Union whose greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise.  According to a survey by the European Environment Agency, 125 million EU residents are exposed to excessive noise due to urban transport. This proposal will take a big step in improving environmental protection, quality of life and health. On the financial side, negative externalities will, and therefore costs, decrease in the long run. Energy efficiency, the use of renewable energy sources, sustainable development and technology neutrality are concepts mentioned in the proposal, which are crucial in order to achieve the objectives of the European Union.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased by the result of the vote on sustainable urban mobility. I agree that long-term sustainable urban mobility planning is essential for cities to continue to provide safe and efficient service for their citizens. It is also beneficial in order to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, as well as noise pollution, air pollution, and accident reduction. I encourage Member States to carry out sustainable mobility plans in order to achieve these goals in their respective cities. Furthermore, planning should also keep in mind and give priority to low-emission transport models, including electric traction and alternative fuels. We should always strive to provide the best for our citizens. They deserve to have safe, clean and efficient cities where they can learn, work and play.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved this report to send a clear message to our fellow citizens. On the other hand, I object to the ideological use that has been made throughout the negotiations. The Greens Group is characterised by an unpro constructive attitude and very marked by the idealization of a green society. Also, I object to this idea of wanting to remove diesel from our cars, or simply the cars of our cities... It makes no sense until we find the silver bullet for urban transport. I studied the subject well when I was in charge of the reports on CARS2020. Moreover, this myth of public transport is a decoy: some people cannot do without the car as a means of transport (carriers, inhabitants of residential areas, VRP, etc.). Finally, our industry is the world leader in diesel technology, and France is at the forefront. On the other hand, I would like to point out that I am for tests in real condition, as I said in CARS2020.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I understand that the significant increase in the urban population requires global planning measures.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK has been working on projects for sustainable urban mobility for years. For example London introduced the ‘Boris Bike’ in 2010 and Manchester has continuously expanded its metro system and is delivering completion ahead of schedule and within budget. This report is the EU adopting an approach of ‘teaching your grandmother to suck eggs’. The call for the ban of all cars by 2050 is ludicrous and would lead to chaos. It is not for the EU to tell the subjects of the UK when and where they can use their cars.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Congestion and pollution in major cities are painful realities of our daily lives that need to be urgently improved for good health and a better environment. This is what the European Parliament reiterated this evening when it adopted the Delli report on sustainable urban mobility. Some of the tracks are known to reduce the presence of cars in cities: better networking of public transport, facilitated train-metro-bus connections, the development of carpooling or telework. However, I did not support Amendment 1 to remove any subsidies for fossil fuels. The idea is relevant and is in part in line with the OECD's conclusions in its September report, which identified no less than 800 measures to support fossil fuels worldwide. However, it seems impractical in reality, since many subsidies for polluting energy directly benefit the most vulnerable people. The priority is therefore to reverse current practice and to direct public aid towards renewable energy. One idea to dig up, put forward by OECD experts, would be to directly subsidize household incomes through a cheque, leaving them the freedom to spend it as they see fit.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. On the occasion of COP 21, which brings together (very) the world's leaders in (very) pomp and pomp, I reiterate the urgent need to reduce the impact of transport on emissions of both greenhouse gases and fine particulate matter. I voted in favour of the report on sustainable urban mobility, which promotes a wide range of solutions combining competitiveness and sobriety to achieve these goals. With regard to urban nodes, the text encourages the use of the Mechanism for Interconnection in Europe and the European Fund for Strategic Investments (the financial arm of the Juncker Plan) for the financing of the necessary transport infrastructure. The aim is to make traffic safer, more fluid and more environmentally friendly in congested areas, when the vast majority of citizens now live in cities. In general, I support any initiative to promote and develop the emergence of the sharing economy in urban mobility, such as car-sharing and carpooling, which have great potential for reducing pollution as well as reducing urban nuisances caused by traffic.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. By 2050, more than 80% of EU citizens will live in urban areas. In this context, action for sustainable urban mobility is necessary, especially since benefits in the areas of environment, health, energy, security, urban planning, infrastructure, quality of life or innovation can result. Intelligent mobility involves supporting research into new technologies, including the development of low-emission means of transport, as well as new economic models, based in particular on the sharing economy. All levels of public action and actors will have to find the means to meet the needs of our cities and the citizens who live there. The Union must contribute to this, not least through its programmes and funding, but also through other measures presented in this text which I believe are right. That is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. This Resolution is the answer to the support that this Commission wants to give to all common policies with an impact on cities, where most Europeans live. In the face of those who think that the Union's action does not fit in the urban environment, the Socialists are defending its relevance, and proof of this is that we get the Connecting Europe Facility or funds such as the EIES to finance urban nodes. We support this Resolution because we share many of the proposals for safer and more sustainable urban transport, accessible to all, and in which public transport plays a predominant role. However, we would have liked to nuance the reference to urban tolls. We understand that such actions have to be accompanied by measures of favorable discrimination for those who have been expelled from the center, as well as to prevent it from ending up being the exclusive ally of the affluent classes. Nor do we think it is right to support any form of mobility in the sharing economy, such as Uber, which puts sectors such as cooperatives and taxi self-employed people who do comply with social and labour legislation and provide a safe and quality public service against the ropes.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which in particular encourages Member States to review their strategies so as to promote non-motorised transport in order to serve the converging interests of improving mobility and the urban environment. The adopted text also encourages Member States to promote the use of bicycles, including setting ambitious targets for cycling rates by 2030 and improving conditions for walking and cycling.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The importance of sustainable mobility - in particular urban mobility - is increasingly a topic on the table and is currently being widely debated worldwide, as is also european. According to statistical data, it is estimated that by 2050 about 82% of citizens will live in urban areas, thus posing new social and urban planning challenges, sustainable development and the level of their own quality of life in cities. Thus, in order to achieve the goal of creating a new model of sustainable urban development it is necessary to invest in solid projects of urban mobility, of high quality, which serve the general interest. To that extent, from this own-initiative report, which I voted in favour of, I highlight the importance of creating long-term sustainable urban mobility plans that incorporate information technologies, create appropriate and secure mobility solutions for all citizens and take into account the special needs of people with reduced mobility. I also support the position adopted by the rapporteur on the position that the EU should take by ensuring that Member States, local and regional authorities work together to achieve such a desideratum, creating the conditions for positive effects on spatial, socio-economic and environmental preservation.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on sustainable urban mobility. The congestion of Europe's urban and peri-urban spaces necessities the promotion of a new form of mobility. It is a question of meeting an ever-increasing demand for mobility while assessing the environmental, social and economic impacts. The report calls on Member States and local authorities to continue and intensify their efforts in implementing a new model of urban mobility. I have supported this text, which makes proposals for the efficient use of the various European funds in order to make the necessary quality investments. The aim is to ensure the development and conservation of urban transport infrastructure. To this end, the report suggests that part of the ERDF, the Cohesion Fund, the European Strategic Investment Fund (EFSI) or Horizon 2020 programmes should be set aside for funding for sustainable urban mobility projects. The Union must continue its commitment to sustainable urban mobility in order to achieve its objectives, particularly those related to the circular economy that will create jobs.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on sustainable urban mobility. Virkkunen, shadow rapporteur for the GROUP of the European People's Party, for his work. I agree to increase the efficiency of sustainable modes of travel and to strengthen the transport logistics network in urban areas. Member States and local authorities must work to implement sustainable urban mobility plans and ensure accessible, efficient and safe public transport for European citizens.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Delli report, after a long process of conciliation between the different groups, has been acceptable to all in proposing a number of measures to address, inter extensions, the problem of pollution resulting from fossil fuel-propelled transport. While it has lost some definition in quantifying objectives related to the use of public or alternative means, it proposes numerous measures, integrated and coordinated at different administrative levels, aimed at protecting climate, health and the environment, as well as promoting well-being and safety. The goal is to promote smart and sustainable cities. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Over 80 percent of Europe’s populations live in urban centres. They are plagued by traffic congestion, long commuting times, environmental pollution and inefficient public transport. Worthy efforts continue to overcome the growing problems. Many fail.  Given the present context, where privatisation, public-private partnerships and market-based solutions are considered essential elements in a ‘holistic’ solution, problems will surely multiply not decrease. The emphasis should be on public, not private solutions.  Still, state investment in urban public transport systems has not kept pace with needs. Moreover, modernising public transport has been confused with privatising, when the real need was to modernise the public management of transport systems. Generally, there is little impetus in favour of a long-term plan. Through major public investments, it would create new infrastructures for mass urban transport. Its control and strategic direction would be retained by public authorities, operating not for profit but to serve a public purpose. As a general rule, public transport systems run as if they were private entities cannot solve satisfactorily the large scale problems of urban mobility. At national level, free market ideological dogma obscures this reality. Perhaps it can be countered at a European level, but I doubt it.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The improvement of urban mobility is an essential step in reducing global emissions, as well as improving air quality and traffic safety in European cities. Although the report's final proposal is unjust and contains contradictory elements, such as the absence of criticism of implicit deregulation in the "collaborative" economy or some voluntarism in addressing the energy transition, we believe that support for transport planning, intermodal integration and improved efficiency justify voting in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Sustainable urban mobility is a priority for both me and the Socialists in this chamber. It is key to boosting the social and economic conditions of those living in cities and prevents the growing inequalities that we are seeing more and more in recent years. Importantly, and this vote comes at an appropriate time, the ‘sustainability’ dimension to mobility in urban areas will contribute to our fight against climate change.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ in the case of a legislative resolution on sustainable urban mobility, I voted against the proposal tabled. It is important that we invest in the development of our cities. However, this development cannot be conditioned by a system of exaggerated requirements for uniform modes of operation of transport in all cities. The infrastructure of our cities is now too diverse to demand the same modes of transport or the same approach to ambitious emission ceilings. It is necessary to accept the diversity of our cities, their natural transport possibilities and to leave the Member States their competence in this area.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ in most European countries, including Slovakia, where I come from, increasing transport is considered the main source of impaired air quality. Personally, I myself am convinced on a daily basis that the vehicle remains the main means of our urban mobility, and therefore there is nothing special about the fact that the entrances to our cities are overwhelmed by cars. Unfortunately, individual car transport continues to dominate at the expense of sustainable modes of transport, not only in most Slovak cities, but also in many European cities. I regret that, in many cases, the current state of mobility also signs the uneasy of competent persons in municipalities to solve mobility problems and to look for new, innovative approaches and solutions. I supported the resolution because I believe that it is essential to reorient urban mobility towards sustainable modes of transport, and the present report comes up with possible solutions. I also believe that sustainable urban mobility will require much more quality investment in favour of the general interest. Although there are many different approaches to urban mobility planning in Europe, I expect the Union, in cooperation with the Member States and regional and local authorities, to be able to develop a new model of sustainable urban mobility.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Urban mobility is mainly based on the use of conventional vehicles. As a result, 96% of the EU's energy transport needs depend on oil and petroleum products, equivalent to about a third of total energy. Urban transport is a source of approximately 25% of carbon dioxide emissions and about 70% of all emissions in urban areas. The fact that around 50% of journeys in urban areas are less than 5 kilometres is also important. Aware of the impact of carbon dioxide emissions on climate change and the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, I would like to see an urgent need for a different direction of transport policies in the cities of THE EU Member States. The report encourages authorities in the Member States to draw up sustainable urban mobility plans, prioritising low-emission modes of transport, including electric propulsion and alternative fuel vehicles. I agree that, in accordance with the precautionary principle and the principle of proportionality, preventive measures must be taken in order to improve urban air quality and that an integrated approach is needed. As sustainable urban mobility plans are essential to meet the EU's targets for carbon dioxide emissions, noise, air pollution and road accident reduction, I voted in plenary to adopt the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The use of conventionally powered vehicles is still one of the popular ways of transport. With an increasing urban population, our priority must be to focus on the long-term vision and clear formulation of urban mobility objectives. Effective spatial planning, but also raising awareness of alternative modes of transport among our citizens, are steps towards sustainable mobility.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this proposal because I believe that overcrowding in cities and the use of a large number of cars leads to a critical point of air pollution. Such a situation is an environmental problem. Therefore, I believe that work needs to be done to improve public transport to enable anyone to take quality transport to work, school or any other necessary place. I also believe that the right to mobility is one of the basic human rights, and I believe that people should be given as many options as possible that will lead to a reduction in the use of passenger cars and thus reduce the rate of environmental pollution. Improving public transport will reduce emissions of harmful gases within cities and prevent further pollution.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Nowadays, a large concentration of inhabitants is located in an urban area, so it is estimated that by 2050 82% of EUROPEAN Union citizens will live in urban areas. As urban centres face societal and sustainable development challenges with a projected significant increase in urban populations, comprehensive urban planning measures will need to be put in place. By increasing the city's population, urban mobility is also increasing. City mobility still relies in large part on the use of cars on conventional fuels. Consequently, 96% of transport's energy needs in the EU depend on oil and its derivatives, which corresponds to a third of total energy consumption. I support the Council's position because I believe that spatial planning is the most important stage for creating smooth, safe and durable transport networks that have a real impact on overall life, transport and its distribution, and I emphasise that safety must always be seen as a key element of sustainable urban planning. Low-emission means of transport, including those powered by electric and alternative fuels and fitted with intelligent transport systems, should also be prioritised.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on sustainable urban mobility because it emphasises and promotes sustainable urban mobility at European level. It points out the importance of developing sustainable urban mobility plans, which is further supported by information and communication technologies, in order to create an efficient and secure transport network while reducing CO2 emissions, noise and making urban transport efficient with the least negative impact on the environment. The measures targeted in the report are to increase car-sharing, carpooling and car occupancy services. This report also supports the development of intelligent technologies, including ITS and infomobile systems, and the optimisation of freight logistics in cities. The report also recalls that intelligent transport and intermodal systems make mobility more efficient and environmentally friendly. In the future, new digital technologies in the field of connection search and communicating vehicles will also contribute to shortening urban travel.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report proposes ways of doing things that will benefit both the environment and European citizens and improve public health and the standard of living, as well as the image of cities.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The pursuit of sustainability and resource efficiency is essential in the long-term development of urban transport. Working together in Europe, efforts should be made to ensure the sustainability, preservation and development of the development of urban mobility, which in turn requires a high level of investment. These measures will have a positive impact not only on transport, but also on the economy and the labour market. Of course, there are many other positive effects that this development can have, such as a reduction in CO2 emissions, improvements in quality of life and health, the development of infrastructure and the promotion of innovation.  It is necessary to set ambitious targets, which our regions and cities must work together to achieve.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on sustainable, energy-efficient urban mobility, as I share the view that this right is a right for all citizens, including persons with reduced mobility. More and more people are living in cities, which is why it is important to formulate principles that make it sustainable for people to move. This should be done in such a way as to reduce the environmental and health pressures of transport, and therefore, for example, the tax relief on urban means of transport powered by diesel should be reduced.  Urban transport alone is responsible for a quarter of greenhouse gas emissions, which must be reduced in order to achieve the 2030 targets set by the European Union.  As has been said in a previous report, air pollution in major cities in the European Union results in around 400 000 premature deaths each year. The tiny particles that are largely emitted by diesel engines, which make up 55% of the European fleet, are often responsible for this. In my opinion, this trend has not only environmental, health and economic effects, as the member states' energy dependency and bills are increasing. I therefore agree that immediate action is needed and that today's and future urban mobility must be largely based on green mobility and cooperation networks.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Currently, more than four-five Europeans live in urban areas, and this percentage is likely to increase in the coming years, creating new social calls related to quality of life or sustainable development. Unfortunately, urban mobility continues to rely heavily on the use of conventionally powered vehicles, which account for around 25% of CO2 emissions in the EU.  In order to change this trend, both the European Union and the Member States should take action to ensure that city dwellers use public transport, shared travel or bicycles more often. This is a great undertaking not only infrastructure, but also social. Transport prices need to decrease and the number of cycle paths to increase. The Commission should therefore work towards the coordination and consolidation of EU mobility initiatives, and Member States should encourage their cities to take greener but also economically fair action.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the initiative of my colleague Karima Delli.  Mobility is not a goal in itself, but should be a right for all citizens. 80% of Europeans will soon be living in cities; mobility should therefore promote access to school, work, culture, recreation and health for all, including people with reduced mobility. However, urban mobility is often experienced as a constraint, which has its origin in the excessive use of the individual car operating with traditional fuels. In fact, the transition to more sustainable modes of transport is very slow: the car remains the essential mode of our mobility, accounting for 43% of the kilometres travelled in the world and three quarters of journeys in Europe.  Car dependence and its corollary, traffic congestion, which is estimated to cost 80 billion euros for all European cities, makes city dwellers prisoners of mobility suffered, if not chosen.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which, in the context of an ever-growing urban population, aims at drawing up the framework for a sustainable urban mobility which would reduce pollutant emissions while strengthening mobility in itself. The report welcomes the existing EU tools and objectives (sustainable urban mobility plans, ITS, white paper, CEF, EU projects) and encourages Member States and the Commission to make better use of them and allocate more funds to their development. Modernisation and digitalisation of the transport sector are addressed in a forward-looking perspective, asking for passengers’ behavioural change as regards public transportation to be better taken into account. I opposed the amendment which asked to phase out subsidies on fossil fuels as I believe this issue must be addressed with a much more comprehensives approach than the one of taxation.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. 80% of Europeans will live in cities and mobility should therefore promote access for all, including people with reduced mobility, to schools, work, culture and health facilities. Meanwhile, urban mobility is often mistakenly considered an inconvenience. The aim of this report is to guide urban mobility towards more sustainable means of transport in order to confront the challenges of our age, such as health and environmental protection or safety. In order to achieve this objective, the European Union must set itself ambitious targets so that Member States, regional and local authorities are able to implement this new model of sustainable urban mobility together. For this reason, it is worth supporting this report.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ While I think it is extremely important to promote new, sustainable modes of transport in cities and focus attention on environmental aspects and focus priorities on cyclists and pedestrians, many of the proposals for this report diminish the principle of subsidiarity of Member States. While I support in principle the position and idea that better use of EU funds is needed to promote more sustainable and secure urban mobility plans, the role of Member States must not be diminished in achieving this goal. In addition, the way the report encourages the use of electric vehicles is excessive and does not respect a technologically neutral approach at all.  In my view, it is inappropriate and excesive to suggest that the principle of 'income use' related to tolling be used to improve sustainable urban mobility, and as an additional disadvantage of this report, I consider not including a strong recommendation for the use of diesel engines, in particular with a focus on the ongoing controversial Volkswagen case.  For these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on sustainable urban mobility because I believe that there is still room for improvement in this area. It is important to move forward to implement radical changes and innovations in urban transport in cities. Public transport needs to be upgraded to make it more attractive, more accessible and more efficient for residents. In addition, the use of bicycles, following the example of the northern states, should also be encouraged, as this ultimately also indirectly contributes to better human health.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Delli report, after a long process of conciliation between the different groups, has been acceptable to all in proposing a number of measures to address, inter extensions, the problem of pollution resulting from fossil fuel-propelled transport. While it has lost some definition in quantifying objectives related to the use of public or alternative means, it proposes numerous measures, integrated and coordinated at different administrative levels, aimed at protecting climate, health and the environment, as well as promoting well-being and safety. The goal is to promote smart and sustainable cities. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this text is to pave the way for supranational ecological governance. Karima Delli never hid from it when she explained in an interview: "The first step is that before the end of 2016, each Member State must make what is called a national plan for sustainable urban mobility." Gradually, the Commission will therefore see its prerogatives increase and may impose outliers affecting low-income households who cannot afford a vehicle to the latest standards in force or to buy a home near their workplace. Thus, the idea of the "polluter pays" is making its way. Also prepares for the requirement for municipalities to introduce speed limits of 30 km/h in the city, as well as alternating traffic. It is therefore appropriate to oppose a text which deliberately denies the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are many harmful effects of the current transport model on the fundamental elements of the natural environment, including air, water, soil and various ecosystems. As there is no universal solution for urban areas, with cities in the European Union having specific situations and needs, conditional on geographical location, climate or demographic structure, safety must always be considered a key element of all sustainable urban transport plans. Estimates show that 82% of EU citizens will live in urban areas by 2050. New practices, such as the sharing of cars, alongside bicycles, walking and public transport, are in development. Energy efficiency and the use of renewable energy, which involve low carbon emissions, are essential for achieving sustainable urban mobility. I believe that support for urban mobility is possible and necessary for an integral approach, with sustainable urban transport helping to reduce energy consumption, air and noise pollution, the number of accidents, traffic congestion, land use and soil waterproofing, while being one of the key factors of sustainable economic growth.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. Mobility is not an end in itself, but should be a right for all citizens. Soon, 80% of Europeans will live in cities; mobility should therefore make it easier for everyone, including persons with reduced mobility, to reach school, work and access to culture, leisure and health care. This report undertakes to steer urban mobility towards sustainable modes of transport in order to face the challenge of our century, the protection of the climate, our health and environment, our well-being and our safety. I voted in favour.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive and I believe Parliament voted in favour of reorienting transport policy in our cities and ensuring it can respond to major challenges facing the sector today. We need to ensure the transport sector shifts towards renewable and truly sustainable energy sources and, ultimately, this means shifting away from car-dominated systems and fossil fuels like diesel and petrol.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on sustainable urban mobility because I agree with the principle that mobility should be a right for all citizens. It is very important to address topics such as urban mobility by making it more sustainable, safe and secure, giving space and infrastructure back to all citizens and improving accessibility, improving the environment, quality of life and health, saving energy and protecting the climate, making innovation the core of research policy aimed at smart mobility approaches, supporting innovations in the area of sustainable freight transport, minimising external costs and making better-quality investment, and integrating networks of efficient mobility systems and fostering cooperation. In the context of the crisis that has hit the European Union, too many citizens are devoting a significant share of their time and income to transport, to which some citizens have no possibility of access whatsoever. In order to foster improvements in this regard, Member States need to take active steps to bring about a modal shift from road to inland waterway and rail as a matter of urgency, attaching particular importance to inter-modality, bringing together walking, cycling and public transport.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. As I rightly expressed in the opinion for this report of which I was rapporteur in the Committee on Regional Development, it is necessary to continue to contribute to our cities fostering alternative and environmentally friendly means of transport in order to have more decongested, less dependent on fossil energy, more environmentally friendly and more competitive cities in this way. The European authorities must contribute to this not only through the use of funds, but also by promoting multi-level governance. Sustainable urban mobility is therefore an essential element in making better cities in the future. Given that this report reflects these ideas, I considered it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The improvement of urban mobility is an essential step in reducing global emissions, as well as improving air quality and traffic safety in European cities. Although the report's final proposal is unjust and contains contradictory elements, such as the absence of criticism of implicit deregulation in the "collaborative" economy or some voluntarism in addressing the energy transition, we believe that support for transport planning, intermodal integration and improved efficiency justify voting in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'A sharp increase in mobility pressure and the associated pollution in our cities are an increasing problem for our society. There is no way we need to look for new CO2-neutral transport options that improve urban mobility in a sustainable way. However, we will always have to take into account economic, social and environmental factors and strike a healthy balance between these three aspects. I therefore voted in favour of this report because better and more sustainable mobility can also be a major boost to our economy.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Land use planning is crucial for the creation of efficient, accessible transport networks and is essential for environmentally sustainable urban planning. Long-term sustainable urban mobility (SMP), supported by ICT technologies, are important tools for providing adequate and secure mobility solutions for all citizens. We insist on the idea of the need for public policies that can rely on instruments that can leverage these development strategies at the service of the citizen. In this sense, we converge globally with the objectives of the report, while marking our differences in the face, among other things, of the White Paper on European Transport Policy which aims to impose a mercantile vision on this sector.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, the report contains a number of points which are to be welcomed. A new (sustainable) transport concept for major European cities is urgently needed. The rapporteur makes some good proposals on this (promoting local public transport, promoting alternative propulsion for vehicles, etc.); however, the report also contains a number of points which discriminate against motorists or are simply unrealistic. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on sustainable urban mobility because it is a priority for the Group of The Party of European Socialists and Democrats. It is, in fact, a fundamental element in promoting better economic and social conditions in cities, especially for the most disadvantaged sections of the population, without forgetting the positive effects that good management of urban mobility can have on the fight against climate change. I would also like to highlight a point that is particularly close to my heart: the text we have adopted explicitly talks about new forms of mobility based on the sharing economy model, recognising the role of peer-to-peer mobility solutions as a benefit to citizens.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the amended report on sustainable urban mobility. Sustainable urban mobility is very likely to positively influence the EU’s resource-efficiency objectives, especially the ones which are linked to the circular economy. Moreover establishing a mobility strategy will offer our citizens easier access to work, school, culture, leisure and health services.  The ways of achieving that are included in the report. Firstly, the necessity for the European Union to set targets which will help to make this sustainable urban development real for the Member States. And therefore, they will ensure the regional and local cooperation between them.  Secondly, there is an idea to offer a part of EU funds such as Cohesion Funds and the ERDF to boost the projects at the domestic and the EU level.  This report and the possible result coming from its implementation are going to be beneficial for both our economy and our citizens.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the own-initiative report on sustainable urban mobility. The report notes that the transition to more sustainable modes of transport is very slow. In this regard, the rapporteur proposes to the European Commission to ask all Member States and local authorities to have a sustainable urban mobility plan. Such plans are absolutely necessary in view of the fact that, according to forecasts, in the near future 80% of Europeans will live in cities. Urban mobility needs to be refocused on sustainable modes of transport in order to meet the major challenges of this century: protecting the climate, health and the environment.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report of the Committee on Transport and Tourism on sustainable urban mobility. Given congestion in urban areas, different urban mobility is more than necessary. The aim is to rethink the way we move within cities to transport people and goods. The resolution puts forward concrete proposals in this direction.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. In 2012 Coinciding with COP 21 in Paris these days, this report seems to me to be more than adequate. As has already been stated at the Summit, we are facing a climate emergency. All countries must react and make commitments to curb climate change; it's everyone's challenge. We, from the European Union, must promote initiatives that pursue the sustainability and durability of the planet. Given that 80% of Europeans live in cities, the challenge of achieving sustainable urban mobility is a small step in the efforts we must make to reduce emissions.  In recent years we have experienced a reduction in emissions from industry and agriculture. However, the transport sector has only increased. We must propose more efficient and inclusive urban transport systems for all, which give access to all people with reduced mobility. The European Union must provide itself with financial mechanisms and instruments to achieve a new model of urban mobility adapted to the needs of our times.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report, the aim of which is to redefine a new model of urban mobility based on environmental, economic and social sustainability. Urban transport is responsible for a quarter of greenhouse gas emissions, which have seen a 30% increase in greenhouse gas emissions over the past 25 years. The result is serious damage in terms of air pollution and damage to health, road congestion and safety for citizens. This report therefore proposes giving priority to new forms of clean transport such as trams, cable cars, bicycles, car sharing/pooling, encouraging the adoption of plans for electric mobility and promoting intermodality that combines walking and public transport. It also calls for energy efficiency to be placed at the heart of urban mobility policies and for a legislative package on 'transport and climate' to be developed.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Transport, especially in cities, greatly affects the quality of our lives both positively and negatively. I support this report because it is necessary to look at how people and goods are transported, so that both are balanced. In my opinion, in these considerations, it is necessary to look not only at the current situation, but also into the future. Furthermore, Member States need to be induced to cooperate with local authorities and to effectively target financial support for sustainable projects.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I abstained in the vote on the report on sustainable urban mobility. In most cases, the report was able to maintain a balance between the principle of subsidiarity and the support of Member States in plans and initiatives relating to sustainable urban mobility, and also rightly noted that positive changes should come mainly from below, i.e. from regional and local authorities. On the other hand, however, it has made all too much appeal to the use of electric propulsion in vehicles, which, in my opinion, undermines the technological neutrality of the resolution and some other requirements, such as the replacement of public transport fleets as environmentally friendly, or the complete elimination of the propulsion of oil-based vehicles and its derivatives, which I find disproportionately burdensome, and I fear that small and medium-sized enterprises in particular would be negatively affected.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report stresses the importance of defining sustainable urban mobility policies in order not to inhibit the development of cities, regions and countries, while ensuring the reduction of environmental impacts in the transport sector, better urban planning, improving health indices and social inclusion.  The report emphasises the promotion of quality and affordable public transport (including as a means of boosting urban economies and helping to combat poverty and social exclusion), the need to promote mobility plans, the use of alternative fuels, the improvement of pollution situations and their impact on human health (emission of air pollutants and noise pollution) and the reduction of accidents. A bottom-up approach is advocated, as opposed to the imposition of guidelines by the EU institutions. We voted in favour.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that a gradual abandonment of the fossil is the only way to redefine a new model of urban mobility in order to improve the environmental impact. Car transport in cities is responsible for a quarter of greenhouse gas emissions, with the latter increasing by 30% over the past 25 years. In fact, it is estimated that total road congestion costs amount to EUR 80 billion for European cities alone, not to mention the serious damage in terms of air pollution and health for citizens. The document voted on incorporated the M5S proposals such as reducing pollution through alternative methods such as teleworking or the use of green public transport, in order to optimise travel to the workplace and travel in general. I have always been convinced of the need to promote new forms of clean transport such as trams, cable cars, bicycles, car sharing/pooling, with an incentive to adopt plans for electric mobility and by making public transport accessible, many of which could enjoy free rates.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on sustainable urban mobility (2014/2242(INI)) because I believe that long-term plans for sustainable urban mobility are an important means of providing adequate and secure mobility solutions for all citizens. Investment in sustainable public transport not only solves urban mobility problems, but also has other positive effects on reducing CO2 emissions, noise, air pollution and road accidents.

name: Presidente. –
text: Explanations of vote are closed.
